This patient is at high risk for this disease based on Wells criteria, so imaging instead of D-dimer testing would be more appropriate once his respiratory status is stabilized.  
❌ Order low molecular weight heparin:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are concerning for a right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. This patient's respiratory distress should be addressed before initiating therapeutics.  
❌ Order venous ultrasound of the right leg:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are concerning for a right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. While venous ultrasound may be an appropriate diagnostic tool for evaluating for deep vein thrombosis in this patient, addressing the patient’s respiratory distress takes precedence.  
✅ Provide supplemental oxygen:
Correct: See main explanation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of epigastric burning and regurgitation presents to the primary care clinic for follow-up evaluation. The patient just finished an eight-week trial of standard-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI), which has been unsuccessful at alleviating symptoms. There is no associated chest pain, difficulty swallowing, vomiting, melena, hematemesis, or unintentional weight loss. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. After withholding PPI for 14 days, an EGD with biopsies is performed and is non-diagnostic. Histopathology shows no evidence of erosive esophagitis, esophageal stricture, Barrett esophagus, malignancy, or other complications. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation and management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform a 24-hour esophageal impedance study with pH monitoring
Increase the dose of PPI and reevaluate in four weeks
Repeat EGD with biopsy in eight weeks
Start a different PPI and reevaluate in four weeks

questions.solution:
This patient may have non-erosive reflux disease, a variant of GERD that lacks endoscopic evidence of esophagitis. This patient should have a 24-hour esophageal impedance study with pH monitoring to confirm a diagnosis of non-erosive reflux disease before altering management. Normal findings include 40 or fewer reflux events with a pH of 4 or greater, while abnormal findings include more than 40 reflux events with an acidic pH of less than 4.

Patients with typical GERD symptoms should be managed with lifestyle modifications and empiric PPI for eight weeks. Response to treatment is often clinically diagnostic of GERD. If patients fail to improve, then EGD with biopsy should be performed after stopping PPI for 7-14 days. 24-hour esophageal impedance study with pH monitoring is indicated if there is high suspicion of GERD but a non-diagnostic EGD. If GERD is confirmed, PPI therapy can be restarted, and a surveillance EGD should be performed in one year to screen for Barrett esophagus and determine long term treatment.

Patients with atypical GERD symptoms should be evaluated for an alternative diagnosis if typical GERD symptoms are not present. Patients with alarm signs and symptoms (e.g. severe chest pain, dysphagia, odynophagia, GI bleed, persistent severe heartburn, frequent vomiting, and unintentional weight loss) should undergo early EGD with biopsies and CBC with iron studies to assess for GERD complications and malignancy. EGD may show findings of complications of GERD like evidence of Barrett esophagus with areas suspicious for metaplasia or dysplasia, esophageal strictures, or it can show a mass consistent with malignancy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform a 24-hour esophageal impedance study with pH monitoring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increase the dose of PPI and reevaluate in four weeks:
Incorrect: Since this patient’s symptoms of heartburn and regurgitation have persisted despite an eight-week trial of empiric standard-dose PPI and the EGD did not yield a diagnosis, it would be inappropriate to treat this patient’s symptoms without first confirming the diagnosis of GERD with a 24-hour esophageal impedance study with pH monitoring.  
❌ Repeat EGD with biopsy in eight weeks:
Incorrect: Given this patient's initial non-diagnostic EGD, repeating the EGD with biopsy is not indicated, as it is unlikely to provide new information.  
❌ Perform esophageal manometry:
Incorrect: Esophageal manometry can be used to assess the function of the esophagus and the lower esophageal sphincter. It is used in the diagnosis of esophageal motility disorders. However, it is not used in the diagnosis of GERD in the absence of dysphagia.  
❌ Start a different PPI and reevaluate in four weeks:
Incorrect: Since this patient’s symptoms of heartburn and regurgitation persisted despite an eight-week trial of empiric standard-dose PPI and the EGD did not yield a diagnosis, it would be inappropriate to restart a PPI without first confirming the diagnosis of GERD with a 24-hour esophageal impedance study with pH monitoring.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of lethargy. Paramedics report that the patient is currently bed bound in a nursing facility following a left-sided MCA stroke several weeks ago. Additional past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. The patient appears ill and is moaning. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and a large unstageable sacral wound with foul-smelling discharge. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lethargy and multiple medical comorbidities and a likely infected sacral pressure ulcer. She has greater than 2 SIRS criteria which is concerning for underlying sepsis. Patients with sepsis should have a blood lactate measurement as part of their initial assessment.

Sepsis refers to an exaggerated immune response to infection associated with end organ dysfunction and shock (often due to capillary endothelial dysfunction). The infection can be bacterial, viral, or fungal and may originate from any tissue, initiating a complex interplay between infectious virulence factors and host defense mechanisms.

Patients with sepsis typically present with tachycardia and fever as well as associated symptoms secondary to the source of underlying infection. For example, patients with pneumonia may present with respiratory distress or a cough. Patients may also present with nonspecific symptoms, including fatigue, dizziness, altered mental status, or syncope. This patient is presenting with lethargy and moaning likely from pain from an infected pressure ulcer. When sepsis is suspected, patients should be screened using the SIRS criteria as outlined in the table below. Patients with 2 or more of these abnormal values should undergo further sepsis evaluation with measurement of blood lactate and blood culture analysis as well as administration of broad spectrum antibiotics and IV hydration.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Measure lactic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Place a central venous catheter:
Incorrect: Central venous catheter placement should be considered in patients without appropriate hemodynamic response to intravenous crystalloid administration who likely need vasopressors.  
❌ Place an arterial line:
Incorrect: An arterial line is a useful tool for continuous hemodynamic measurement. It should be considered in patients with sepsis who do not respond appropriately to intravenous crystalloid administration or in those patients who have evidence of septic shock.  
❌ Administer norepinephrine:
Incorrect: Administration of vasoactive agents, such as norepinephrine, should be considered for patients with sepsis who do not respond appropriately to intravenous crystalloid administration.  
❌ Measure mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2):
Incorrect: SvO2 reflects the amount of oxygen left in the bloodstream following tissue circulation and is typically measured using a pulmonary artery catheter. While this could provide information regarding the tissue extraction of oxygen, it is not generally indicated for the treatment of sepsis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an episode of syncope at home. The patient is unable to provide a history due to altered mental status. The patient’s wife states that he had been in his usual state of health. This morning the patient stood up from a chair, went into the bathroom, and suddenly collapsed. The patient has not seen a physician in several years and takes no medications. The patient smokes 2 packs of cigarettes per day and does not drink alcohol. Temperature is 36.0 °C (96.8 °F), blood pressure is 88/50 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air.  The patient is ill-appearing and pale, and has cool clammy extremities. A midline abdominal mass is palpated. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Blood glucose is within normal limits. The patient is started on intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Results from initial blood work are detailed below. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after an episode of syncope, for which there is a broad differential diagnosis. This patient with a significant smoking history has bloodwork showing anemia, and an abdominal mass on physical exam. In addition, the patient has evidence of hypovolemic shock on examination. Together these findings are concerning for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm which is best diagnosed via abdominal ultrasound.

Hypovolemic shock refers to a life-threatening condition defined by organ hypoperfusion secondary to decreased intravascular volume. Hypovolemic shock can be defined as hemorrhagic or non-hemorrhagic. Hemorrhagic shock is associated with blood loss which can be seen in traumatic conditions – such as a ruptured spleen – or non-traumatic conditions like variceal bleeding or abdominal aortic rupture, as is likely in this case. Non-hemorrhagic shock is associated with fluid loss, most commonly from volume depletion as occurs after prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, as well as with severe widespread burns.

Initial diagnostic workup for patients with suspected hypovolemic shock includes obtaining blood work including CBC, lactate, CMP, PT, PTT, INR. When the presentation is unclear (e.g. no evidence of trauma on examination) several biomarkers can assist with differentiating between hemorrhagic and non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock. In general, patients with hemorrhagic shock will have new or worsening anemia and will have derangements in coagulation studies if coagulopathy is present. Patients with non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock will often have an elevated hemoglobin consistent with hemoconcentration. Both hemorrhagic and non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock can present with acute kidney injury, lactic acidosis, and elevated transaminases.

Option Analysis

✅ Order an abdominal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consult gastroenterology for upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient presentation is not consistent with acute upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage which typically presents with melena or hematemesis. Additionally, this patient lacks risk factors for an upper GI bleed like liver disease or NSAID use. This patient’s presentation is concerning for an intra-cavity (e.g. intraperitoneal) source of bleeding likely a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  
❌ Consult gastroenterology for a colonoscopy:
Incorrect:  This patient presentation is not consistent with a lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage which typically presents with bright red blood per rectum.  
❌ Order chest radiograph:
Incorrect: Obtaining a chest radiograph is unlikely to provide significant diagnostic information for determining the etiology of the suspected internal hemorrhage.  
❌ Administer norepinephrine:
Incorrect: Administration of vasoactive agents should be reserved for patients presenting with hypotension who fail to respond to fluid resuscitation, and in cases of hemorrhagic shock, blood products as well. This patient has a suspected underlying hemorrhage and should receive packed red blood cells and IV fluids for resuscitation prior to using vasoactive agents.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for dark tarry stools. The patient first noticed dark stools 2 to 3 days prior, along with lightheadedness, dizziness and mild epigastric pain.  The patient drinks 6 to 7 beers daily and takes naproxen daily for osteoarthritis pain. He has no other medical history. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 87/53 mmHg, pulse is 118/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears pale. There is tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region. Digital rectal examination shows melena. The patient is started on intravenous fluids and bloodwork is obtained. The initial results are detailed below. Which of the following should be ordered next?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with new onset melena, concerning for an upper gastrointestinal bleed, and clinical findings of hemorrhagic shock.  Given these concerns, upper endoscopy is the best next step in management.

On evaluation of patients with hemorrhagic shock, they will typically have evidence of new or worsening anemia and/or evidence of obvious bleeding on examination. If patients have evidence of obvious bleeding, they should receive blood product resuscitation which may include packed RBCs, platelets, and fresh frozen plasma. These patients should also receive intravenous fluids as needed, and prompt surgical or gastroenterology consultation depending on the bleeding source. In patients with evidence of hemorrhagic shock but without an obvious source of bleeding or trauma, further history may reveal the underlying cause. For example, evidence of melena or hematochezia suggests a gastrointestinal source of bleeding. Patients with a suspected upper gastrointestinal bleed should have an upper endoscopy (EGD), and those with a suspected lower gastrointestinal bleed should have a colonoscopy. Certain patients may be considered for interventional radiology consultation for possible arterial embolization depending on the source of bleeding. In some cases, the source of bleeding is unclear based on history or examination and patients need imaging to evaluate for an internal source of bleeding using CT of the abdomen and pelvis or abdominal ultrasound.

Patients with non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock typically have evidence of hemoconcentration on CBC without any evidence of anemia and a history consistent with fluid loss. They should have crystalloid fluid resuscitation while assessing organ systems and determining the underlying cause.  

Option Analysis

✅ Upper endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation is not consistent with a lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage which typically presents with bright red blood per rectum. Colonoscopy is unlikely to have diagnostic utility for this patient.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: In patients with hypovolemic shock and evidence of blood loss but without a suspected source, abdominal imaging should be obtained to evaluate for an internal source of bleeding like ruptured aortic aneurysm. The presence of melena, possible alcohol use disorder, and frequent NSAID use suggest an upper GI source of bleeding.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: In patients presenting with hypovolemic shock from blood loss but without a suspected source, abdominal imaging should be obtained to evaluate for an internal source of bleeding. The presence of melena, possible alcohol use disorder, and frequent NSAID use suggest a GI source of bleeding.  
❌ Ketorolac for pain control:
Incorrect:  Administration of ketorolac is contraindicated given this patient's anemia and impaired renal function. Administration of NSAIDs may ultimately worsen this patient’s bleeding, particularly if it is from the upper gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever reaching 39.1°C (102.4°F), and right upper quadrant pain. The patient reports unintentional weight loss of 10 kg, jaundice, and dark urine over the past 3 months. Past medical history is significant for chronic pancreatitis. BMI is 21 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), blood pressure is 103/69 mmHg, pulse is 124/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96%. On physical examination, the patient appears ill, cachectic, and has right upper quadrant tenderness to palpation. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis with left shift, elevated total and conjugated bilirubin, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis reveals an ill-defined mass in the head of the pancreas, dilation of both the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct. IV access is established, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. Which of the following is the best next step in the management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute cholangitis secondary to pancreatic cancer. This is confirmed with a CT of the abdomen showing a poorly defined mass in the head of the pancreas and dilation of both the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct. The best next step in management is to relieve the obstruction and obtain tissue for diagnosis with an emergency ERCP with biliary stenting.

A multidisciplinary approach is used in the treatment of pancreatic cancer consisting of a team of a medical oncologist, radiation oncologist, gastroenterologist, and surgeon. The management is complex and depends on the presence of signs of biliary obstruction and the extent of disease.

Patients with findings of biliary obstruction such as fever, severe jaundice, pruritus, altered mental status, or sepsis should be managed with stabilizing treatment, IV antibiotics, and emergency ERCP with biliary stenting or with percutaneous cholecystostomy tube placement to relieve the obstruction.

Management of confirmed pancreatic cancer depends on the TNM staging of the disease and determination of whether or not the tumor is surgically resectable, borderline resectable, or unresectable. Patients with resectable tumors can be treated with a Whipple procedure (or modified version) for resection followed by possible adjuvant chemoradiation therapy depending on the extent of the disease on histopathology. Patients with borderline resectable pancreatic cancer should undergo neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by reassessment with CT or MRI imaging. Patients with positive response to neoadjuvant chemoradiation are treated as surgically resectable. However, patients with minimal or no response to chemoradiation are managed as surgically unresectable. Patients who are found to have surgically unresectable pancreatic cancer have a very poor prognosis and are managed with chemoradiation therapy, supportive care, possible palliative care with pain medications, antiemetics, and ERCP with biliary stenting if obstruction occurs.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emergency ERCP with biliary stenting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endoscopic-US guided biopsy:
Incorrect: Endoscopic-US guided biopsy may be used to provide a tissue diagnosis for pancreatic cancer. This patient has a fever, right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and leukocytosis suggestive of acute cholangitis secondary to a mass in the head of the pancreas. Urgent ERCP with biliary stenting can be used to relieve the obstruction and confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Surgical excision of the mass:
Incorrect: Surgical excision of the mass is indicated for the management of patients with confirmed pancreatic cancer on histology without evidence of distant metastases or encasement/occlusion of major vessels. It is not indicated for the management of acute cholangitis in the setting of suspected pancreatic cancer.  
❌ Neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy:
Incorrect: Neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy is indicated for the management of patients with confirmed pancreatic cancer that is considered borderline resectable (local growth into nearby tissues without distant metastases). It is not indicated for the management of acute cholangitis in the setting of suspected pancreatic cancer.  
❌ CA-19-9 level measurement:
Incorrect: CA-19-9 levels are used to monitor treatment response and assess for future recurrences of pancreatic cancer and should be drawn in the case of suspected pancreatic cancer. However, they are not used to screen for pancreatic cancer or to make a definitive diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is evaluated in the pulmonology clinic for a follow-up visit for asthma that was diagnosed one month ago after spirometry showed an FEV<sub>1</sub>/FVC ratio of 0.6 and an increase in FEV<sub>1</sub> of 15% after albuterol administration. The patient was started on a daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS)-long-acting beta-agonists(LABA) inhaler and has noticed an improvement in his symptoms. The patient wakes up short of breath several times weekly and needs to use a short-acting albuterol inhaler several times a day. Physical exam reveals diffuse bilateral wheezing. Serum IgE is 10 IU/mL, and eosinophils are 50 cells/µL. High-resolution CT of the chest is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Change the ICS-LABA inhaler to a medium dose
Add a long-acting muscarinic antagonist inhaler
Make no changes and reevaluate the patient in one week

questions.solution:
Asthma is an obstructive lung disease characterized by episodic inflammation and hyperresponsiveness of bronchial smooth muscles leading to shortness of breath and wheezing. Treatment is directed at reducing inflammation (steroids) and relaxing bronchial smooth muscle (beta-agonists and muscarinic antagonists). Inhaled medications include short-acting beta-agonists (SABA), long-acting beta-agonists (LABA), inhaled corticosteroids (ICS), and long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMA).

Patients with mild symptoms should be started on an as-needed low-dose ICS-LABA. If more control is needed, this regimen can be changed to a daily low-dose ICS with or without an as-needed SABA for rescue therapy. If a patient’s asthma continues to be partially controlled, they should switch to a daily low-dose ICS-LABA, again adding a SABA for rescue therapy. If patients are still poorly managed, the next step is changing to a daily medium-dose ICS-LABA and, eventually, a daily high-dose ICS-LABA. If asthma is still poorly controlled, other medications should be considered, such as an inhaled LAMA or biological agents (e.g., mepolizumab, omalizumab).

For acute asthma exacerbations, including those in status asthmaticus, patients should receive supplemental oxygen, inhaled bronchodilators including a short-acting muscarinic antagonist like ipratropium and a short-acting beta agonist or SABA like albuterol, and systemic corticosteroids. If a patient doesn’t respond to this treatment, then a single dose of IV magnesium may be administered. If they do not respond to these measures, patients should be considered for non-invasive ventilation (e.g. bi-level positive airway pressure) or endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. Mechanical ventilation should be considered for any patient with altered mental status, cyanosis, inability to maintain respiratory effort, and worsening hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Change the ICS-LABA inhaler to a medium dose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consider an alternative diagnosis:
Incorrect: This patient’s spirometry (PFT) findings suggest asthma. COPD and  vocal cord paralysis are in the differential diagnosis, but are not indicated by the findings in this vignette.  
❌ Add a long-acting muscarinic antagonist inhaler:
Incorrect: Patients with inadequately controlled asthma should have their ICS-LABA inhaler increased to a high dose before adding a LAMA (long-acting muscarinic antagonist) inhaler. This patient is only on a low-dose ICS-LABA inhaler.  
❌ Make no changes and reevaluate the patient in one week:
Incorrect: This patient’s asthma is poorly controlled, and making no changes to therapy is inappropriate.  
❌ Start omalizumab or mepolizumab:
Incorrect: These medications are monoclonal antibodies indicated for use in severe, uncontrolled asthma with specific lab abnormalities (IgE >30 IU/mL for omalizumab and eosinophils >150 cells/µL for mepolizumab).

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to new yellowing of the skin. This has been gradually worsening for the past week. The patient has never experienced this before. Past medical history is significant for HIV, hypertension, and active tuberculosis. Current medications include bictegravir-emtricitabine-tenofovir, losartan, rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient is noticeably jaundiced. Bloodwork is drawn in the office and the results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Serum Test
Result   
Haptoglobin
Increased
LDH
190 U/L (nml: 140-280 U/L)
Total Bilirubin
6.0 mg/dL
Direct Bilirubin
0.5 mg/dL
AST
19 U/L
ALT
15 U/L
questions.solution:
Unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia is typically caused by one of three factors: increased production (hemolysis), decreased hepatic uptake, or impaired hepatic conjugation. Hemolysis generally presents with anemia, reticulocytosis, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin. Peripheral smear can help differentiate between the causes of hemolysis. Decreased hepatic uptake can occur due to medications (e.g. rifampin) as seen in this case, portosystemic shunting (e.g. after TIPS procedure), cirrhosis, and congestive hepatopathy from right heart failure. Impaired bilirubin conjugation occurs in hereditary diseases, such as Crigler-Najjar and Gilbert syndrome.

This patient presenting with new unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia in the setting of treatment for active TB with rifampin likely has medication-induced (iatrogenic) hyperbilirubinemia. Several medications (such as probenecid, rifampin, and others) can impair the hepatic uptake of bilirubin. Unconjugated bilirubin then gets absorbed into the bloodstream without conjugation and leads to elevated serum unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. This patient’s LDH and haptoglobin point away from hemolysis, the history does not suggest Gilbert syndrome, and the normal transaminases (AST and ALT) point away from hepatic pathology. The next step in management would be to discontinue the rifampin and follow the bilirubin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Medication-induced hyperbilirubinemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gilbert syndrome:
Incorrect: This patient has never had any episodes of jaundice prior to this and is now 48 years old. This makes it unlikely to be Gilbert syndrome, which is a congenital disorder of impaired bilirubin conjugation. In addition, the current use of rifampin is a much more likely cause for his unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  
❌ Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Warm AIHA (usually IgG-mediated) can present with unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia. While we do not know this patient’s hemoglobin, a haptoglobin that is normal and not decreased and an LDH in the normal range rules out any significant hemolysis.  
❌ Cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Cold AIHA (usually IgM-mediated) can present with unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia. While we do not know this patient’s hemoglobin, a haptoglobin that is in the normal range and not decreased and a normal LDH rules out any significant hemolysis.  
❌ Hereditary spherocytosis:
Incorrect: A normal haptoglobin that is not decreased and a normal LDH that is not increased rules out significant hemolysis. This makes hereditary spherocytosis unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to lethargy and weakness. The symptoms started abruptly three days ago and have gotten slowly worse since then. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 36.8ºC (98.2ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 98/61 mmHg, respirations are 16/min and SpO2 is 99% on room air. On physical examination the patient is pale and lethargic. There are no abnormal findings on abdominal exam. There is no lower extremity edema. Bloodwork is obtained and results are shown below. Which of the following tests should be ordered next?
 
Serum Test
Result
Hemoglobin
6.8 g/dL
Haptoglobin
Decreased
Total Bilirubin
7.4 mg/dL
LDH
450 U/L (nml: 140-280 U/L)
questions.solution:
In patients with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, hemolytic anemia should be ruled out early because some causes can be life-threatening. Hemolytic anemia presents with anemia, reticulocytosis, elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin. Hemolytic anemia can be life-threatening in the case of autoimmune hemolytic anemia or thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. These disorders should always be considered and ruled out in cases of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The clinical vignette is highly suggestive of hemolytic anemia; so further testing should be performed, including peripheral smear and the direct antiglobulin Coombs test to look for autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

If hemolytic anemia is ruled out as the cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, then further testing should be directed at investigating the liver for things that may cause impaired hepatic uptake (such as congestive hepatopathy, cirrhosis, and portosystemic shunting). If there is no liver pathology, this may indicate hereditary (e.g. Crigler-Najjar, Gilbert syndrome) causes of impaired conjugation or medications as the cause of impaired hepatic uptake.  

Option Analysis

✅ Direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ G6PD assay:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood work indicates hemolytic anemia, which can be caused by G6PD deficiency. However, G6PD assays are unreliable during an active attack and should not be checked until the hemolysis is resolved.  
❌ Fractionated bilirubin:
Incorrect: In this patient, the severity of the anemia, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin are suggestive of hemolytic anemia. Fractionating the bilirubin would not provide additional useful information at this point.  
❌ GGT:
Incorrect: An elevated serum gamma glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) can indicate hepatobiliary pathology, especially when it is unclear whether an elevation in alkaline phosphatase is from bone or biliary pathology. This patient has hemolytic anemia, and this test is unlikely to provide additional useful information.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: While abdominal ultrasound is an appropriate test to order in patients with elevated bilirubin and/or hemolytic anemia, a Coombs test should be ordered first to determine if the cause is autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right upper abdominal pain, vomiting, and confusion for the past 2 days. Her temperature is 39.7 °C (103.6 °F), blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 104/min. The patient is alert but confused. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and right-upper-quadrant tenderness with guarding. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. Abdominal ultrasound demonstrates multiple stones in the gallbladder without gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. The diameter of the common bile duct (CBD) is 8 mm, with a small stone visualized. Blood cultures are obtained and empiric treatment with intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
Complete Blood Count (CBC)

Hemoglobin
13 g/dL
White blood cell count (WBC)
13,000/mm3
Liver Function Tests

Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
300 u/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
238 u/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
159 u/L
Total bilirubin
6 mg/dL
INR
1.3
Serum chemistry

Lipase
50 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with high grade fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, jaundice, and change in mental status has 4 of the 5 components of Reynolds pentad, which can be seen in patients with acute cholangitis. Liver function testing demonstrates a cholestatic pattern of liver injury and ultrasound shows an obstructing stone in the common bile duct. This patient should be treated with immediate antimicrobial therapy in combination with urgent decompression of the biliary tree with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).

In cases where ERCP fails or is unavailable, endoscopic ultrasound-guided biliary drainage can be performed. If endoscopic drainage is unavailable, percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography can be used to drain the infected biliary system and extract any obstructing stones. If these interventions are unsuccessful or unavailable, then a surgical approach is recommended. Definitive treatment with cholecystectomy should be performed during the initial hospitalization or within 2 weeks to reduce the risk of recurrence and complications.

Option Analysis

❌ Laparoscopic biliary drainage:
Incorrect: Laparoscopic biliary drainage with stone removal is invasive and is reserved for cases where ERCP has failed or is contraindicated.  
❌ Urgent cholecystectomy:
Incorrect: The most appropriate next step is to decompress the common bile duct via ERCP. Though cholecystectomy should be performed during the initial hospital stay to prevent recurrence, it is not the first step in management.  
✅ Urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan:
Incorrect: Cholescintigraphy using 99mTc-HIDA scan is indicated in patients with suspected cholecystitis not evident on ultrasound. It is not used to evaluate or treat patients with acute cholangitis.  
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP):
Incorrect: MRCP is typically obtained for nonurgent evaluation of suspected choledocholitihiasis that is not evident on ultrasound. It should not be performed in this patient with life-threatening acute cholangitis that has been confirmed with ultrasound.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man was brought to the emergency department for evaluation of vomiting and confusion for one day. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and chronic back pain following a motor vehicle accident several years ago. The patient has a history of drinking up to 2 pints of vodka per day. Current medications include oxycodone/acetaminophen 5-325 mg as needed every 2 hours. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. The patient appears lethargic and is only oriented to person. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and jaundice. There are no signs of chronic liver disease. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Laboratory value
Result
Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
100 u/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
1,549 u/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
1,845 u/L
Total bilirubin
3 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin
1 mg/dL
INR
1.3
White blood cell (WBC) count
10,000/mm3
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)300 u/L
questions.solution:
This patient with vomiting, lethargy, altered mental status, and supratherapeutic use of acetaminophen in the setting of heavy alcohol use most likely has had an acetaminophen overdose resulting in drug-induced liver injury.

Patients with chronic alcohol use disorder appear to be at increased risk for hepatotoxicity following ingestion of repeated, supratherapeutic (or even therapeutic) doses of acetaminophen. Alcohol induces CYP2E1 which results in accelerated metabolism of acetaminophen and enhanced generation of N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI), the primary hepatotoxic metabolite.

Acute acetaminophen overdose presents with nausea, vomiting, lethargy, and jaundice, with a hepatocellular pattern of injury. Aminotransferases are typically >1000 u/L. Elevations of INR and total bilirubin, oliguria, and renal function abnormalities can also be seen. Treatment is guided by serum acetaminophen concentrations using the modified Rumack-Matthew treatment nomogram. If indicated, N-acetylcysteine therapy is recommended.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute autoimmune hepatitis:
Incorrect: Acute autoimmune hepatitis is typically seen in women with a history of autoimmune disease. Clinically, it presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, anorexia, and weight loss. This patient’s use of acetaminophen in the setting of alcohol use makes drug-induced liver injury more likely.  
❌ Acute viral hepatitis:
Incorrect: Acute viral hepatitis usually presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and myalgias. This patient’s use of acetaminophen in the setting of alcohol use makes drug-induced liver injury more likely.  
✅ Drug-induced liver injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ischemic hepatitis:
Incorrect: Ischemic hepatitis is typically seen in patients with significant hemodynamic instability (e.g. patients with septic shock). LDH is significantly elevated in these patients.  
❌ Alcohol induced hepatitis:
Incorrect: Patients with alcohol-induced hepatitis typically have moderate elevations in aminotransferases (rarely higher than 500 u/L) with AST: ALT 2:1. They typically have moderate neutrophilic leukocytosis. This patient’s AST and ALT levels are significantly elevated in the setting of supratherapeutic acetaminophen use, making drug-induced liver injury more likely.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of 3 days of yellowing skin, lethargy, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. Medical history is significant for insulin-dependent type 1 diabetes. She is not on any other medications. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears lethargic but is alert and oriented. She has evidence of jaundice and scleral icterus without signs of cirrhosis. Abdominal exam is significant for right upper quadrant pain. Initial laboratory evaluation is shown below. Which of the following tests should be ordered next?
 
Laboratory value
Result
Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
205 u/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
1134 u/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
1231 u/L
Total bilirubin
24 mg/dL
INR
3.0
Serum iron
100 mcg/dL
Serum transferrin
250 mg/dL

choices.text: Serum anti nuclear (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle (ASMA) antibodies

questions.solution:
Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) typically presents as a chronic inflammatory liver disease; however, some patients can have an acute presentation that may progress to autoimmune acute liver failure as seen in this patient. Since patients with autoimmune hepatitis can respond dramatically to corticosteroids, it is important to consider autoimmune hepatitis in patients presenting with acute liver failure. Given this patient’s age, gender, and history of autoimmune disease (type 1 diabetes mellitus), and the fact that she has no prior history of liver disease, she should be tested for autoimmune hepatitis. She should be evaluated with serum anti-nuclear (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle (ASMA) antibody testing.

Other causes of acute liver failure should be ruled out with appropriate testing. These include acetaminophen toxicity, viral hepatitis, ischemic hepatic injury, Wilson disease, alcoholic hepatitis, and HELLP syndrome in pregnant patients.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serum anti nuclear (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle (ASMA) antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum antimitochondrial antibodies:
Incorrect: Serum antimitochondrial antibodies are positive in patients with primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC), which typically presents with a cholestatic pattern on bloodwork. Patients usually are asymptomatic or have associated pruritus.  
❌ HFE gene testing:
Incorrect: HFE gene testing is used to diagnose hemochromatosis. Clinical presentation varies from asymptomatic to nonspecific symptoms of fatigue to signs of iron overload in multiple organs (arthropathy, skin hyperpigmentation, abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, etc.). Patients exhibit iron overload on laboratory evaluation. This patient’s iron and transferrin levels are within normal limits.  
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP):
Incorrect: MRCP is used in patients with a cholestatic pattern of liver injury when ultrasound does not reveal extrahepatic obstruction (e.g. in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis). This patient’s liver function testing shows a hepatocellular pattern of injury.  
❌ ERCP:
Incorrect: ERCP is the initial test for patients presenting with acute cholangitis since it can be used for both diagnosis and treatment with biliary decompression. This patient’s blood work shows a hepatic pattern of injury and not the cholestatic pattern that would be seen with acute cholangitis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner with a one-day history of altered mental status, fever, and chills. The patient was recently diagnosed with small-cell lung cancer and received the first cycle of chemotherapy last week. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The patient has a 30 pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 126/min, blood pressure is 89/64 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. On physical examination, the patient appears ill and is oriented to place but not to person or time. The patient moves all limbs and has normal reflexes bilaterally. There is no neck stiffness. There is a right chest wall central line in place with marked erythema, tenderness, and purulence at the insertion site. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis with left shift and an elevated lactate. Peripheral IV access is established; IV fluids are administered and two sets of blood cultures are obtained from different sites. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate empiric IV antibiotics and remove the central venous catheter
Order MRI of the brain with gadolinium contrast
Remove the central venous catheter and admit to the intensive care unit for observation
Initiate empiric IV antibiotics and admit to the intensive care unit for observation

questions.solution:
This patient with fever, altered mental status, hypotension, and elevated leukocytes and lactic acid most likely has septic shock. The presence of a central venous catheter with local signs of infection at the insertion site and the absence of signs and symptoms indicating another source of infection are consistent with the diagnosis of a complicated central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). Complicated CLABSI is defined as CLABSI with septic shock, septic thrombophlebitis, or metastatic infection.

CLABSI is a primary bloodstream infection often associated with septic shock; septic thrombophlebitis; and metastatic infection to the joints, heart valves, and lungs. The initial management of a hemodynamically unstable patient with a suspected CLABSI consists of initiating IV fluids and vasoactive agents if necessary. For all patients with suspected CLABSI; obtain blood cultures from two distinct sites, administer empiric antibiotics covering both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, and remove the central venous catheter to eliminate the source of infection and bacteremia. In hemodynamically stable patients, consider antibiotic lock therapy or line exchange if the central line absolutely has to stay in place.

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate empiric IV antibiotics and remove the central venous catheter:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Although lumbar puncture may be indicated in patients presenting with altered mental status and fever to assess for meningoencephalitis; the lack of neck stiffness and the presence of central venous catheter with findings of erythema, tenderness, and purulence at the insertion site makes the diagnosis of CLABSI more likely.  
❌ Order MRI of the brain with gadolinium contrast:
Incorrect: This patient presents with fever and altered mental status in the presence of a central venous catheter with signs of infection and the absence of neck stiffness. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of CLABSI; therefore, MRI with gadolinium contrast is not the next best step in management.  
❌ Remove the central venous catheter and admit to the intensive care unit for observation:
Incorrect: Although removal of the central venous catheter is indicated in this case, empiric antibiotics are essential for the management of suspected CLABSI.  
❌ Initiate empiric IV antibiotics and admit to the intensive care unit for observation:
Incorrect: Empiric IV antibiotics are indicated in this case as this patient is presenting with sepsis from a CLABSI. The catheter must be removed to eliminate the ongoing bacteremia and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 54-year-old-woman is brought to the emergency department due to fever and altered mental status, which started a few hours ago. The patient has breast cancer that was treated with surgical resection, and is currently receiving chemotherapy via an internal jugular venous catheter. The patient’s last chemotherapy was given two weeks ago, and the catheter was removed yesterday. Review of systems is otherwise negative. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 120/min, blood pressure is 87/57 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. There is no neck stiffness and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable other than the presence of confusion. Laboratory evaluation shows leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein and lactic acid. Which of the following is necessary to establish the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Blood cultures from two different sites

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, altered mental status, and hypotension within 24 hours after removal of a central venous catheter. These findings, in conjunction with elevated white blood cells, C-reactive protein, and lactic acid, are most consistent with a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) complicated by septic shock. Hemodynamically unstable patients (i.e. septic shock) are more likely to have lactic acidosis and symptoms such as altered mental status. The most appropriate test to establish the diagnosis of CLABSI and to guide antibiotic management is blood culture. Other possible sources of infection should also be ruled out.

Ideally, blood cultures should be collected from two different peripheral sites prior to initiation of antibiotics; if that is not possible, they should be drawn from a peripheral and a central site or from a peripheral site on two separate occasions. Diagnosis is made if at least one of the following criteria is met:

  • Growth of a bacterial (e.g. S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, enterococci) or fungal (e.g. Candida sp.) pathogen that is considered a true pathogen from one or more blood cultures.

  • Growth of a common commensal bacterial organism (e.g. coagulase-negative staphylococci) from two different blood cultures in the setting of systemic signs of infection and in the absence of other sites of infection. 
 


Option Analysis

✅ Blood cultures from two different sites:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT scan of the chest:
Incorrect: This patient presents with fever, altered mental status, and hemodynamic instability in the setting of recent internal jugular venous catheter removal. These findings strongly suggest complicated CLABSI. CT scan of the chest would be appropriate if a pulmonary source of infection were suspected.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture is indicated for the evaluation for suspected CNS infections, which can present with a fever and altered mental status. The recent internal jugular venous catheter removal and the absence of neck stiffness make the diagnosis of CLABSI more likely.  
❌ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Transesophageal echocardiogram is frequently performed in patients diagnosed with CLABSI to rule out endocarditis. It cannot make the diagnosis of suspected CLABSI.  
❌ Procalcitonin level:
Incorrect: Procalcitonin level may be helpful in assessing bacterial pneumonia or guiding antibiotic management in patients with CLABSI. However, it is not specific and cannot establish the diagnosis of CLABSI.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 3-day history of dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and urgency. She does not have a fever, chills, flank pain, or vaginal discharge. Her medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. The patient has been sexually active with multiple partners with inconsistent use of condoms. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals mild suprapubic tenderness without costovertebral angle tenderness. Pregnancy test is negative. Urinalysis shows positive nitrites, positive leukocyte esterase, 15-20 WBCs, and 1-2 RBCs. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and physical exam findings of suprapubic tenderness in the absence of fever, chills, and flank pain. These findings, along with the presence of pyuria, positive leukocyte esterase, and nitrites on urinalysis, are suggestive of uncomplicated acute cystitis. The most common pathogen associated with uncomplicated UTIs is Escherichia coli accounting for approximately 75% to 95% of cases. Other causative organisms include Klebsiella pneumoniae, Proteus mirabilis, and Staphylococcus saprophyticus.

Risk factors for lower UTIs include female sex, recent sexual activity, use of spermicidal agents, urinary tract abnormalities, urinary catheterization, and other comorbidities such as diabetes mellitus. Urinary tract infections have a higher incidence in women due to their shorter urethra and the close proximity of the urethral opening to the anus, which facilitates the colonization and migration of bacteria, especially E. coli, from the gastrointestinal tract into the urinary tract.

The clinical presentation of lower UTIs typically involves dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic tenderness. Patients may also report nocturia and painful hematuria. In contrast, upper UTIs are often accompanied by fever, chills, and costovertebral angle tenderness.

In cases of acute cystitis caused by E. coli, urinalysis findings typically include positive nitrites, positive leukocyte esterase, an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count, and possible bacteriuria and possible hematuria.  

Option Analysis

✅ Escherichia coli:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Staphylococcus saprophyticus:
Incorrect: Although S. saprophyticus is a common cause of uncomplicated UTIs, especially in young, sexually active females, E. coli remains the most common cause of uncomplicated cystitis accounting for approximately 75% to 95% of cases.  
❌ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Incorrect: Trachomatis is a common sexually transmitted infection that typically presents with vaginal discharge and cervicitis in females. The absence of vaginal discharge and the presence of  positive nitrite test on urinalysis (indicating infection with Enterobacteriaceae), makes E. coli the likely pathogen.  
❌ Candida albicans:
Incorrect: Candida albicans may cause fungal UTIs, particularly in patients with predisposing factors such as diabetes mellitus, immunosuppression, or recent antibiotic use. However, this patient does not present with any of these risk factors, making it less likely.  
❌ Proteus mirabilis:
Incorrect: Although P. mirabilis is a common cause of uncomplicated UTIs, E. coli remains the most common cause of uncomplicated acute cystitis accounting for approximately 75% to 95% of cases.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to three days of right leg swelling. Four days ago, the patient developed pain and swelling in the posterior right knee and distal thigh. The patient had an episode of cellulitis of the right leg four years ago after a cat scratch. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and generalized moderate osteoarthritis. Current medications include celecoxib and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is decreased range of motion of the right knee with prominent swelling at the posterior right knee. The right posterior leg is erythematous and slightly warm to touch and is mildly edematous down to the ankle. Skin of the right leg and right foot interdigital spaces is intact. Ultrasound is performed which confirms the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a ruptured Baker cyst, given the history of osteoarthritis and significant pain and swelling of the posterior knee. Baker cyst can be diagnosed with physical examination, but it is often confirmed with ultrasound or MRI of the knee. Treatment includes arthrocentesis of the knee with intra-articular injection of glucocorticoids (e.g. 40 mg triamcinolone acetonide).

Lower extremity (LE) edema, unilateral or bilateral, is a common presentation and is a feature of many different pathologies. Patients with bilateral LE swelling should be asked about other symptoms or signs of volume overload such as dyspnea or abdominal fullness. The patient should be asked about new medications (e.g. calcium channel blockers). Physical examination should focus on looking for systemic findings such as cardiac (e.g. extra heart sound or murmur), abdominal (e.g., ascites, hepatosplenomegaly), or renal abnormalities.

For unilateral LE swelling, assessment should be performed looking for local trauma to the area such as burns or skin breaks. Patients with DVTs may have a personal or family history of blood clots, recent prolonged immobility (e.g., surgery, intercontinental flight), or coagulopathy. Patients with cellulitis often have a fever and a known injury to the skin. Severe pain, paresthesias, or pallor may suggest compartment syndrome. For chronic unilateral LE edema, ask about history of local lymph node resection or radiation, varicose veins, or severe prolonged pain. Physical examination should pay special attention to the skin to look for breaks, erythema, and warmth.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intra-articular corticosteroids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous furosemide:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics are effective at reducing lower extremity (LE) edema. They are used for treating bilateral LE edema in patients with a systemic disease (e.g., cirrhosis, congestive heart failure) and are rarely indicated for unilateral edema. Treatment should focus on the underlying cause of the unilateral edema rather than the edema itself.  
❌ Oral cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cellulitis can present with unilateral leg swelling, erythema, and warmth. Cephalexin can be used in patients without risk factors for MRSA infection. The time course, symptoms, intact lower extremity skin, posterior knee pain, and history of osteoarthritis makes a ruptured Baker cyst more likely than cellulitis.  
❌ Oral doxycycline:
Incorrect: Cellulitis can present with unilateral leg swelling, erythema, and warmth. Doxycycline can be used in patients with risk factors for MRSA infection. The time course, symptoms, intact lower extremity skin, posterior knee pain, and history of osteoarthritis makes a ruptured Baker cyst more likely than cellulitis.  
❌ Venous sclerotherapy:
Incorrect: This can be used to treat severe venous insufficiency, especially from varicose veins. This patient’s examination doesn’t demonstrate evidence of venous insufficiency (e.g. varicose veins).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with two days of fever, vomiting, and right flank pain. The pain is intermittent and has not responded to acetaminophen or ibuprofen. The patient also had burning urination that started around the same time, which he attributed to a new body soap. Temperature is 38.5 ºC (101.3 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 145/88 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has no periumbilical or suprapubic tenderness to palpation. The serum leukocyte count is 19,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase, moderate pyuria, and the presence of white blood cell casts. Which of the following physical exam maneuvers will most likely elicit pain in this patient?

choices.text: Palpation and percussion between the right 12th rib and spine
Palpation in the left lower quadrant and waiting for report of pain in the right lower quadrant
Flexion and internal rotation of the right hip while the patient is supine
Passive extension of the right hip while the patient lies on their left side
Elevation of the patient’s right foot and striking the right heel while the patient is supine

questions.solution:
This patient with fever, flank pain, dysuria, leukocytosis, and urinalysis positive for pyuria and white blood cell casts most likely has acute pyelonephritis. Pyelonephritis is a urinary tract infection involving the kidney. Laboratory evaluation of such a patient shows leukocytosis. When kidney function is deranged, creatinine may be elevated. Urinalysis reveals bacteriuria and pyuria and may show hematuria or white blood cell casts. Urine and blood cultures should be obtained.

Patients generally present with fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and flank pain. Some patients may have difficulty describing the pain and may describe it as back or abdominal pain. Some patients have dysuria or urinary urgency/frequency during or before the onset of flank pain. Tenderness to palpation or percussion at the costovertebral angle (CVA), which is the area between the 12th rib and the spine,, is highly suggestive of acute pyelonephritis in the right clinical scenario. This patient will likely have significant CVA tenderness to palpation and percussion.  

Option Analysis

✅ Palpation and percussion between the right 12th rib and spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Palpation in the left lower quadrant and waiting for report of pain in the right lower quadrant:
Incorrect: This is referred to as the Rovsing sign and, if positive, it suggests acute appendicitis. It is not associated with pyelonephritis.  
❌ Flexion and internal rotation of the right hip while the patient is supine:
Incorrect: If this maneuver causes pain, it is considered a positive obturator sign and suggests acute appendicitis. It is not associated with pyelonephritis.  
❌ Passive extension of the right hip while the patient lies on their left side:
Incorrect: If this elicits pain then it is considered a positive psoas sign and suggests acute appendicitis. It is not associated with pyelonephritis.  
❌ Elevation of the patient’s right foot and striking the right heel while the patient is supine:
Incorrect: This is the heel tap/strike sign, if it elicits pain it suggests acute peritonitis (possibly localized from acute appendicitis), not pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is hospitalized for fever, nausea, vomiting, right flank pain, and dysuria. After an initial evaluation, acute pyelonephritis is diagnosed, and the patient is started on intravenous ceftriaxone. The initial serum leukocyte count is 23,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Urine culture grows >100,000 colony-forming units of E. coli, which are susceptible to ceftriaxone. On hospital day three, the patient develops a fever after being afebrile for 24 hours. Flank pain is still present. Current temperature is 38.5 ºC (101.3 ºF), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 138/81 mmHg. Serum leukocyte count is 21,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Significant tenderness to palpation is still present at the right costovertebral angle. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient with acute pyelonephritis is not improving on appropriate antibiotics. Lack of improvement within 48 to 72 hours of initiation of treatment suggests that the antibiotic choice is incorrect (empiric antibiotic does not cover the pathogen that grows out or there is bacterial resistance to an appropriate antibiotic) or that the source of the infection must be controlled (calculus or obstruction, renal or perinephric abscess that needs intervention). This patient’s infection is sensitive to the antibiotic being used. The issue is likely a lack of source control, which raises concern for complicated pyelonephritis (e.g., abscess) requiring further imaging and possible intervention. CT of the abdomen and pelvis is generally used to diagnose physiologic or anatomical features leading to complicated pyelonephritis. If CT is not available or the patient cannot undergo radiation (e.g. a pregnant woman), ultrasound can often be used.
 

Patients with mild to moderate acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis can be treated as outpatients if they can tolerate oral antibiotics (e.g. ciprofloxacin) and oral hydration. If the patient has medical comorbidities (especially diabetes) or is very ill with persistently high fevers, severe pain, or the inability to take medications or hydrate orally, they require hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone, piperacillin-tazobactam).

Complicated pyelonephritis is associated with urolithiasis (kidney or ureteral stone), anatomic or functional urinary tract abnormalities, renal or perinephric (perirenal) abscess, recent urological manipulations, underlying immunosuppression,  and male sex. These patients need hospitalization, IV antibiotics, and a urology consultation for possible cystoscopy and intervention.

If patients on outpatient treatment are not improving, they should be admitted and started on intravenous antibiotics and hydration. Hospitalized patients, like the patient in this case, should have abdominal imaging if they are not improving despite 48 to 72 hours of appropriate antimicrobial therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Change ceftriaxone to cefepime:
Incorrect: This patient’s urine culture grew bacteria susceptible to ceftriaxone. Cefepime can be used if infection with Pseudomonas spp. is suspected or if cultures show resistance to ceftriaxone, neither of which apply in this patient’s case.  
❌ Obtain abdominal MRI:
Incorrect: While abdominal MRI can show complications of pyelonephritis, CT imaging or ultrasound would be more appropriate choices due to availability and cost-effectiveness.  
❌ Obtain a repeat urine culture:
Incorrect: The patient is unlikely to have developed a new separate urinary tract infection with a different organism, making repeat urine culture necessary. If there is a concern for inadequate source control, the next step is to pursue abdominal imaging.  
❌ Obtain a serum lactate level:
Incorrect: Lactic acid (lactate) levels help evaluate patients with sepsis since elevated levels generally suggest more severe disease. High levels can be trended to assess response to treatment, but a one-time lactate level now will have little clinical utility, and this patient is not currently exhibiting signs of sepsis.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for abdominal pain. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and Crohn disease. While in the ambulance, the patient is given several medications by the paramedics. Upon arrival at the emergency department, the patient describes new diffuse itching and raised red fluid-filled spots on her arms, legs, and abdomen. Temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 78/48 mmHg, respirations are 20/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 97% on room air. On examination, the patient has labored breathing and wheezing on pulmonary auscultation and hives on her arms, legs, and abdomen. Skin is warm to touch. Digital rectal exam shows a small amount of bright red blood in the rectal vault. Serum tryptase was drawn at the start of the patient’s itching and is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer intramuscular epinephrine and repeat serum tryptase level in 1 hour

questions.solution:
This patient has likely developed anaphylactic shock, a type of distributive shock. Patients often present acutely after a known trigger. Symptoms may include pruritus, urticaria, diffuse flushing, and labored breathing. Physical examination will generally demonstrate skin findings as well as wheezing on pulmonary auscultation. Treatment involves intramuscular or subcutaneous epinephrine and avoiding or stopping the triggering agent. Serum trypsase may not peak for 1-1.5 hours after symptom onset, and therefore should be repeated in 1 hour to help make a diagnosis.

Blood cultures, urinalysis, and imaging can be used to diagnose septic shock. An elevated tryptase confirms anaphylactic shock; however, tryptase may not peak for 1-1.5 hours after symptom onset and may be falsely normal (such as in this patient). Serum tryptase levels ideally should be drawn 1-3 hours after the onset of anaphylaxis symptoms begin to confirm the diagnosis. Brain or spinal cord imaging can confirm CNS injury leading to neurogenic shock.

Laboratory findings in a hypovolemic shock include severe anemia in hemorrhagic shock or signs of volume depletion (e.g. elevated BUN and creatinine) and hemoconcentration (elevated hemoglobin) in non-hemorrhagic shock.

Elevated troponin and ischemic changes on electrocardiogram are used to diagnose myocardial infarction. BNP and transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) can help diagnose severe heart failure.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, but chest radiograph or ultrasound will confirm pneumothorax. Pulmonary embolism can be suggested by an elevated D-dimer and diagnosed via CT angiography of the chest or V/Q scan. Cardiac tamponade is also a clinical diagnosis, but TTE would show equalization of pressures, RA/RV collapse, and other findings.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer intramuscular epinephrine and repeat serum tryptase level in 1 hour:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform colonoscopy with biopsy:
Incorrect: This would be reasonable in a patient with new onset inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, in this patient, if IBD were causing severe GI bleeding and hypotension, it would lead to hemorrhagic shock. This patient has only mild hematochezia and the clinical picture suggests anaphylactic shock and not hypovolemic shock.  
❌ Start intravenous cefepime and vancomycin:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if septic shock were suspected. This patient is afebrile, and the clinical history better supports anaphylactic shock.  
❌ Place a pulmonary artery catheter:
Incorrect: A pulmonary artery catheter allows for invasive hemodynamic monitoring and is not generally recommended in most patients. It can be useful in patients with undifferentiated or mixed shock, especially when there is cardiogenic shock.  
❌ Perform a transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: This would be reasonable if cardiogenic shock were suspected. This patient’s clinical picture suggests anaphylactic shock.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by his significant other for evaluation of respiratory distress. The patient has a history of asthma and eczema. Symptoms began while the patient was eating lunch at a local park. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and a fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6°F), blood pulse is 112/min, pressure is 91/59 mmHg, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. The patient has stridorous breath sounds. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral wheezes. There is an urticarial rash seen on the bilateral upper extremities. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Which of the following questions would be most relevant at this time?

choices.text: “Do you have any allergies to foods or insects?”
“Have you been using your inhalers for your asthma?”
“Have you had a recent productive cough?”
“Have you used an electronic cigarette recently?”

questions.solution:
This young man presenting with shortness of breath, increased respiratory effort, and an urticarial rash after exposure to a likely unknown inciting agent has anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis refers to an acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs upon second exposure after sensitization to an antigen. IgE-mediated activation of basophils and mast cells leads to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine, prostaglandins, cytokines). These mediators cause an overwhelming systemic inflammatory reaction that can ultimately result in anaphylactic shock or even death.

If anaphylaxis is suspected, immediate intramuscular epinephrine (typically in the lateral thigh) should be administered, even before obtaining a history and physical examination, to resolve the anaphylaxis and prevent shock.

History often reveals definite or suspected recent allergen exposure, but in some cases, the trigger can remain unknown. Physical examination typically shows mucocutaneous, respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal findings. Common mucocutaneous findings include urticaria with intense pruritus and edema of the mucous membranes. In severe cases, laryngeal edema can develop and cause voice hoarseness and stridor. Respiratory findings include labored breathing and wheezing, while cardiovascular manifestations include hypotension and syncope. In addition, if the gastrointestinal system is affected, the patient might have crampy abdominal pain and vomiting. Laboratory studies will show an elevated tryptase level which can confirm the diagnosis if it is not already clear by the history and physical. However, tryptase levels do not peak until 1 to 1.5 hours after the onset of symptoms.  

Option Analysis

✅ “Do you have any allergies to foods or insects?”   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ “Have you been using your inhalers for your asthma?”   :
Incorrect: While an asthma exacerbation may present as acute respiratory distress with the presence of wheezes on physical examination, this patient’s rapid progression of symptoms and urticarial rash suggest an alternate diagnosis.   
❌ “Have you recently traveled?”   :
Incorrect: Travel to regions with endemic pathogens (e.g., Histoplasma, Coccidioides) can result in lung disease. These pathogens typically follow a more indolent disease course and would not present as acutely as this patient’s current symptoms.   
❌ “Have you had a recent productive cough?”   :
Incorrect: Pneumonia can result in respiratory failure, especially in patients with other comorbidities or with immunosuppression. This patient is a relatively healthy, young man and the rapidly developing symptoms and urticarial rash are best explained by anaphylaxis.   
❌ “Have you used an electronic cigarette recently?”   :
Incorrect: E-cigarette or vaping product use-associated lung injury (EVALI) is an acute or subacute respiratory illness. EVALI is a clinical diagnosis that requires the use of an e-cigarette in the 90 days preceding the appearance of initial symptoms; pulmonary infiltrates on chest imaging, and the absence of any more likely etiology. This patient’s rapidly developing symptoms and urticarial rash are best explained by anaphylaxis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of recurrent mid-epigastric abdominal pain. The patient reports that his symptoms worsen with eating and drinking alcohol. The patient has a past medical history of alcohol use disorder, hypertension, and arthritis for which he takes ibuprofen daily. The patient has no history of surgeries. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 123/66 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. Rectal examination is positive for hemoccult blood. Initial laboratory findings are detailed below. Based on the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the next best step in management?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Complete Blood Count (CBC)  

Hemoglobin
10.1 g/dL  
White blood cell count (WBC)  
8,000/mm3   
Liver Function Tests  

Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)  
166 u/L  
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)  
47 u/L  
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  
55 u/L  
Total bilirubin  
.7 mg/dL  
INR  
1.1  
Serum chemistry  

Lipase
50 u/L

choices.text: Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of alcohol use disorder and chronic NSAID use presents for evaluation of epigastric abdominal pain. The patient has a positive stool hemoccult test and evidence of anemia on his screening CBC, suggestive of a bleeding peptic ulcer. Gastroenterology should be consulted for upper endoscopy for diagnosis and potential treatment.

Classifying upper abdominal pain by location can help with making the differential diagnosis for upper abdominal pain. Right upper quadrant pain may be caused by biliary or hepatic processes including acute cholecystitis, biliary colic, choledocholithiasis, acute cholangitis, acute hepatitis, liver abscess, Budd-Chiari syndrome, and portal vein thrombosis. Epigastric pain can be caused by pancreatic or gastric pathology including pancreatitis, GERD, gastritis, and peptic ulcer disease. Myocardial infarction should always be ruled out in patients presenting with epigastric pain. Left upper quadrant pain typically suggests a gastric process or a splenic process including infarction, aneurysm, abscess, or a hematologic disease that can cause splenomegaly.

Workup for each of these anatomic regions begins with obtaining basic blood work followed by additional laboratory studies and imaging based on initial findings as well as historical and physical examination findings.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Consult gastroenterology for upper endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Place a nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a gastric process and should have an endoscopy performed. Insertion of a nasogastric tube is not necessary at this time.  
❌ Consult gastroenterology for ERCP:
Incorrect: ERCP is the initial test for patients presenting with acute cholangitis since it can be used for both diagnosis and treatment via biliary decompression. This patient's clinical presentation and history are more consistent with a gastric process.  
❌ Order hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan:
Incorrect: Cholescintigraphy using 99mTc-HIDA scan is indicated in patients with suspected cholecystitis not evident on ultrasound. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a gastric process.  
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis would help evaluate for pathology in the liver, biliary tree, pancreas and spleen which could all be causes of upper abdominal pain; however given this patient’s epigastric pain and history of alcohol abuse and NSAID use, upper endoscopy should be ordered to evaluate for gastric pathology.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe pain with defecation. She has also noticed bright red blood in her stool. The pain lasts for a few hours after she has a bowel movement. Prior to the onset of the pain and blood in the stool, she had experienced increased straining to pass bowel movements and noticed that her stools were hard. She does not have abdominal pain or fever. She has no significant medical history. Temperature is 99.0°F; pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg. Peri-anal examination reveals a painful lesion that can be seen below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

 Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with painful hematochezia. On physical examination, she has tenderness to palpation and there is a tear in the posterior anal midline, suggesting an anal fissure. Anal fissures are one of the most common causes of anal pain and bleeding. Anal fissures are superficial tears in the anoderm distal to the dentate line and are usually located in the posterior midline. The majority of anal fissures are caused by local trauma such as constipation or diarrhea, vaginal delivery, or anal sex. On physical examination, they appear as superficial lacerations with or without bleeding. At times perianal skin tags may also be present which indicate prior episodes of inflammation or hemorrhoids.

When examining a patient with an anal fissure, the patient should be in the most comfortable position. Anal fissures are very tender to palpation and can be excruciatingly painful for the patient. Therefore, physical manipulation of the anus or rectum should be kept to a minimum, and instrumentation with anoscopy should be avoided if possible.

A thorough history and physical examination is important for developing the differential diagnoses for a patient presenting with hematochezia. One key historical element is the absence or presence of rectal pain. Causes of painless hematochezia include diverticular bleeding, Dieulafoy lesions, angiodysplasia, and colorectal cancer. Causes of painful hematochezia can include anorectal disorders (such as anal fissures, external hemorrhoids, thrombosed internal hemorrhoids, anorectal abscesses, and anal cancer), inflammatory colitis (IBD), and radiation telangiectasia or proctitis. The physical examination helps to distinguish between the various causes.

Option Analysis

✅ Anal fissure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemorrhoids:
Incorrect: A thrombosed internal hemorrhoid or an external hemorrhoid can cause pain and bleeding similar to an anal fissure. A careful and thorough physical examination will help to distinguish between hemorrhoids and fissures. Anoscopy may be required to diagnose internal hemorrhoids. Thrombosed hemorrhoids will appear as dark, bluish lumps.  
❌ Anal cancer:
Incorrect: Rectal bleeding is the most common initial presentation of anal cancer and some patients may also present with anal pain. On a physical exam, typically a lump or mass can be seen at the anal opening.  
❌ Perianal abscess:
Incorrect: Perianal abscess can also present with rectal bleeding and pain. However, the pain would more likely be constant and not specifically associated with bowel movements. On examination, there would be an area of fluctuance or a patch of erythematous and indurated skin.  
❌ Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome:
