Incorrect: Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome is a rare rectal disorder that presents with bleeding, passage of mucus, straining during defecation and a feeling of incomplete bowel evacuation. Pain may also be present. The physical exam findings may vary, but can include the presence of single or multiple ulcerations, polypoid and mass lesions, or just erythema.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the office because of anal itching for the past 4 months. She reports straining every time she goes to the bathroom and feels as if there is a bulging mass in the rectum. She notices bright red blood when wiping. She does not have abdominal pain or rectal pain. She has no medical history and has no family history of colon or rectal cancer. Vital signs are normal. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. On digital rectal examination, there is no visible blood or tenderness to palpation, and there are no palpable masses. Anoscopy is performed with findings of a purple-blue mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with intermittent episodes of painless hematochezia secondary to internal hemorrhoids. The finding of the purple-blue mass on anoscopy confirms the diagnosis. Internal hemorrhoids may not be palpable and are usually painless. They can be a cause of intermittent, limited rectal bleeding.

Lower GI bleeds can be categorized based on the severity of the bleeding as massive, moderate, and occult bleeds. Massive lower GI bleeds usually occur in older patients with multiple medical problems and present as hematochezia (bright red blood per rectum). Patients may be hemodynamically unstable with ongoing bleeding at the time of presentation. Bright red blood would be visible on rectal examination.

Moderate GI bleeds can occur at any age and can present as hematochezia or as melena (black, tar-like stool) if the source is an upper GI bleed. Patients usually are hemodynamically stable. Some disease processes that can cause moderate GI bleeding include neoplastic disease, anorectal diseases, and inflammatory diseases. Patients may not have active bleeding at the time of presentation.

Occult GI bleeds can occur at any age. Patients usually are hemodynamically stable. They may present with symptoms of blood loss or anemia such as lightheadedness, syncope, or dyspnea. Lab evaluation would be notable for microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Occult GI bleeds can be from inflammatory, neoplastic, and congenital causes.

All patients presenting with active, ongoing bleeding should have blood tests obtained to evaluate their hemoglobin and assess the need for transfusion. Blood tests may also help differentiate an active lower GI bleed from an active brisk ongoing upper GI bleed. Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)-to-creatinine ratio can help differentiate between the two. Blood gets absorbed as it travels through the small bowel leading to an increased BUN, and patients may have decreased renal perfusion with an ongoing bleed. This will lead to an elevated creatinine BUN-to-creatinine ratio in patients with an upper GI bleed. In a lower GI bleed, the BUN-to-creatinine ratio would be normal.

An upper GI endoscopy should be performed when an upper GI bleed is suspected. Endoscopy may not be possible if a patient is having active bleeding. However, other diagnostic studies should be obtained to identify the site of bleeding. These may include bedside NG tube lavage, CT angiography, and tagged red cell scan to identify the site of the bleeding. Catheter angiography is both a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that can be done in patients with active, ongoing bleeding.  

Option Analysis

✅ Internal hemorrhoid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prolapsed internal hemorrhoid:
Incorrect: Prolapsed internal hemorrhoids appear as pink, glistening masses at the anal margin that may be tender.  
❌ Thrombosed internal hemorrhoid:
Incorrect: A thrombosed internal hemorrhoid is typically painful and would appear as a dark, bluish lump visible without the aid of anoscopy.  
❌ Anal fissure:
Incorrect: An anal fissure can be diagnosed without the use of anoscopy. Physical exam would reveal a superficial tear in the anoderm that is tender to palpation.  
❌ Anal fistula:
Incorrect:  The external opening of a fistula would be visualized without the use of anoscopy. The skin might appear indurated or erythematous with pustular drainage appreciated.

questions.text: A 56 year old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after being found unresponsive at home. His wife states that he had been having flu-like upper respiratory symptoms for 5 days prior. He also has been drinking more water and using the restroom frequently. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. His medications include metformin, insulin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. He has not been taking his medications consistently over the past 5 days due to feeling unwell. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 110/minute, blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg, respiratory rate is 26/minute, and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is unresponsive to commands and moans intermittently. He has rapid, shallow breathing. He opens his eyes to pain and withdraws all extremities to pain. His mucous membranes are dry and there is poor skin turgor. Cardiac examination is significant for tachycardia. There are diminished breath sounds on auscultation of the lungs. There is no withdrawal to pain with palpation of the abdomen. Which of the following would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with altered mental status in the setting of a recent illness and a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus with inconsistent use of medications including insulin likely has hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome (HHS) or diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). All patients should first be assessed for stability. If unstable, the airway, breathing and circulation should be stabilized. This patient has an altered mental status and is in respiratory distress, he should have immediate stabilization of his airway and breathing with endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. In patients with HHS, intubation is recommended when the Glasgow coma score is less than 8.

Once the airway has been secured, the next step would be to obtain IV access, start IV fluid hydration and continuous vital sign monitoring. HHS and DKA may present similarly, so after stabilization of the patient, additional history should be obtained as well as laboratory testing. Both conditions occur in the setting of precipitating events which can include new-onset diabetes, infections or other acute illnesses, medication side effects, or inadequate treatment of already-diagnosed diabetes mellitus. HHS is more commonly seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Testing includes random blood glucose, serum osmolarity, BMP, urinalysis, hemoglobin A1C and arterial blood gas or venous blood gas.

Both conditions will have elevated blood glucose, though it is significantly more elevated in HHS (>600 mg/dL), electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia, hypokalemia) and elevated hemoglobin A1C. In HHS, the serum osmolarity is usually elevated (>320 mOsm/L) while it will likely be normal in DKA. The anion gap will be elevated in DKA and venous gas will confirm acidosis with low serum pH.

Key aspects of management for HHS or DKA include IV fluid resuscitation to correct dehydration and hyperosmolarity, electrolyte repletion and insulin for hyperglycemia. Patients should be aggressively rehydrated with isotonic fluid with electrolyte replacement. Potassium repletion should be started once the serum potassium is <5.3 mEq/L. Insulin drip should not be started until serum potassium is >3.3 mEq/L to avoid worsening the hypokalemia by driving potassium into the cells. Care should be taken when starting the insulin drip as a rapid drop in serum glucose could lead to cerebral edema. Lastly it is very important to treat the underlying or precipitating factor for HHS or DKA.  

Option Analysis

✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ IV fluid bolus:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs of dehydration with dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, tachycardia, and hypotension. He should receive fluids for volume resuscitation; however the priority would be to stabilize their airway and breathing first.  
❌ Continuous insulin drip:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and has not been taking his medications. He is presenting with an acute complication of diabetes mellitus and likely has elevated blood sugars. However, the most important next step would be to stabilize his airway and breathing.  
❌ Broad spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient has fever, tachycardia and hypotension on evaluation which suggests an infectious process as the precipitating event of his presentation. He should first be stabilized before starting other treatments.  
❌ CT of the head:
Incorrect: This patient presents with decreased responsiveness. On exam, he is not responding to commands and only withdraws extremities to pain. While a CT of the head would be reasonable to obtain to evaluate for an intracranial process, he first needs to be stabilized before any imaging or procedures are performed.

questions.text: A 52 year old woman presents to the office to follow up on management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. She was diagnosed 9 months ago with an hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C) of 8.0%. At that time she was having recurrent vaginal yeast infections. She started metformin 1000 mg twice a day along with atorvastatin 40 mg daily and lisinopril 5 mg daily. She has been taking all medications consistently. She has modified her diet and started walking 6 days a week and has lost 5 pounds. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/minute; blood pressure is 138/85 mmHg, BMI is 32. Her A1C today is 7.6%, and urine albumin to creatinine ratio is 50 mg/g creatinine. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has diabetes mellitus type 2 that is not yet under control. She has a hemoglobin A1C that remains above the goal of 7% despite initial pharmacological therapy and lifestyle changes. Lifestyle modifications and metformin are the initial therapy for most patients presenting with type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, in patients that present with hemoglobin A1C greater than 10%, insulin should be started at a basal rate, along with a GLP1-RA.

This patient would benefit from additional therapy for management of her blood sugars, with consideration given to therapies that have additional benefits. This patient would benefit from medications like a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist that produces cardiovascular risk reduction and weight loss.

In patients that present with hemoglobin A1C between 6.5-10%, metformin is often initiated, along with lifestyle modifications. Patients should be monitored every 3 months for response to treatment. Adequate response is considered a hemoglobin A1C < 7%. Patients should be counseled to engage in regular physical activity consisting of 150 minutes or more of moderate to vigorous intensity aerobic activity per week. Patients can be referred to dieticians for specific dietary recommendations one of which is a low carbohydrate and low saturated fat diet.

If there is inadequate response, patients can have glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists (GLP1-RA) or sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) added to metformin.  Along with their hypoglycemic benefits, both medications have been shown to reduce the risk of significant cardiovascular events and mortality, and therefore they should be considered in patients with cardiovascular disease. GLP1-RA and SGLT2i also reduce body weight and albuminuria which would benefit this patient. In this patient, GLP1-RA would be the preferred agent as SGLT2i can increase the risk of yeast infections and UTI.  

An important note: Although metformin has long been considered the first-line agent for type 2 diabetes, patients with contraindications or significant side effects to the drug, as well as those with strong clinical indications such as cardiovascular disease, diabetic kidney disease, or obesity, may benefit from a GLP1-RA or SGLT2i as initial therapy.

Option Analysis

✅ Add glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Add sulfonylurea:
Incorrect: The patient has an inadequate response to her current treatment, with A1C persisting over 7%. Adding a second agent for better control is indicated, and the specific medication should be determined based on comorbidities and other factors. Sulfonylureas are associated with weight gain. This patient would benefit from an agent that helps with weight loss.  
❌ Add insulin:
Incorrect: The patient’s hemoglobin A1C is not within goal and she would benefit from additional pharmacologic therapy. However, since her A1C is less than 10% and she is currently only on one oral agent, adding a non-insulin agent such as a GLP1-RA or SGLT2 would be more appropriate.  
❌ Add angiotensin receptor blocker:
Incorrect: The patient does have an indication for treatment with an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) given her history of elevated blood pressure and elevated urine albumin to creatinine ratio. However, she is already on an ACEI, so adding an ARB would not be appropriate. Her ACEI dosage should first be increased and a second agent for glucose control should be added.  
❌ Continue current therapy:
Incorrect: This patient has diabetes mellitus, type 2 with an A1C that is above the goal of 7.0% despite being on pharmacologic treatment and initiating lifestyle modifications. Additional pharmacologic therapy should be initiated to reach the goal A1C.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is hospitalized for respiratory failure and septic shock that resulted from community-acquired pneumonia. He is intubated and is receiving IV fluid resuscitation, antibiotics, and vasopressor therapy. Vasopressors are titrated off over the next few days, and his ventilator settings are weaned in preparation for eventual extubation. On hospital day 5, a significant amount of blood is aspirated from his orogastric tube. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 82/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on the ventilator. His morning laboratory studies are listed below. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient has likely developed a bleeding stress ulcer. He has multiple risk factors for stress ulcers, most notably the need for mechanical ventilation >48 hours. Additionally, the bleeding is causing hemodynamic instability, as evidenced by hypotension and tachycardia.

Stress ulcers are erosions of the upper GI mucosa that result from stressors, such as shock, trauma, hypovolemia, and excessive stimulation of parietal cells by gastrin. Bleeding from these erosions can result in the clinical manifestations of anemia, hematemesis, melena, tachycardia, and hypotension.

The first step in evaluating patients with a potential bleeding stress ulcer is to assess ABCDE’s. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, prompt stabilization measures should be enacted. This may include IV fluid resuscitation, blood transfusions, and intubation (if the patient is unable to protect their airway). Additional measures may include obtaining IV access, providing supplemental oxygen, monitoring vitals closely, and placing an NG tube for gastric lavage.

Once these measures are in place, a more thorough evaluation can take place, as well as gastroenterology consultation for upper endoscopy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transfusion of packed red blood cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is warranted in this patient for the evaluation and management of a significant upper GI bleed. However, addressing the patient’s hemodynamic instability takes precedence.  
❌ Bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: Bronchoscopy may be warranted in a case of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. However, with a diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, blood would be aspirated from the endotracheal tube, not the orogastric tube.  
❌ Administration of IV vitamin K:
Incorrect: Vitamin K can be given to reverse the anticoagulant effect of warfarin. This patient’s INR is normal, so vitamin K would not be of benefit.  
❌ Administration of IV corticosteroids:
Incorrect: IV corticosteroids are used in the management of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. However, with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, blood would be aspirated from the endotracheal tube, not the orogastric tube.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents to the primary care clinic with an 8-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath, chronic productive cough, and wheezing. His past medical history is significant for hypertension. Temperature is 36.6°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 109/72 mmHg, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. On physical examination, he has diminished breath sounds and bilateral expiratory wheezing. Laboratory findings are unremarkable. Pulmonary function tests reveal an FEV<sub>1</sub>/FVC ratio of 0.55 with minimal reversibility after bronchodilator administration. Which of the following is most likely to decrease mortality in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with an 8-month history of worsening dyspnea, cough, wheezing, hypoxia, and bilateral expiratory wheezing. These findings along with an FEV1/FVC ratio < 0.7 with minimal reversibility after bronchodilator administration are mostly consistent with the diagnosis of COPD.

Smoking cessation has shown to be the most effective intervention for reducing the risk of developing COPD, slowing its progression, and decreasing morbidity and mortality associated with the disease. Other interventions that have been shown to decrease mortality in COPD patients include lung reduction surgery, pulmonary rehabilitation, triple combination therapy (LAMA + LABA + ICS) in patients with a history of severe and/or frequent exacerbations, long-term oxygen therapy for patients with hypoxemia (resting PaO2 ≤ 55 mmHg or < 60 mmHg with cor pulmonale or secondary polycythemia), and NIPPV for patients with hypercapnia.

In addition to recommending smoking cessation, a stepwise comprehensive management plan should be initiated for patients with COPD which should include pharmacotherapy to control symptoms and reduce the frequency of exacerbations, influenza and pneumococcal vaccinations, and other lifestyle modifications (e.g. increase in physical activity).

Treatment is typically based on the GOLD classification. For patients with less severe symptoms and low exacerbation risk (Group A), single-agent long-acting bronchodilator therapy is recommended. For patients with more severe symptoms and low exacerbation risk (Group B), dual long-acting bronchodilator therapy is recommended. For patients with high exacerbation risk, regardless of symptoms (Group E, replacing previous Groups C and D categories), dual long-acting bronchodilator therapy is recommended.  

Option Analysis

✅ Smoking cessation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) therapy:
Incorrect: LABAs used as monotherapy have not been shown to decrease mortality in patients with COPD.  
❌ Systemic glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Systemic glucocorticoids can be used to treat acute exacerbations of COPD. They help by shortening recovery time, improving lung function, and preventing early relapse. However, their long-term use has not been shown to decrease mortality in patients with COPD and is associated with significant side effects.  
❌ Long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA) therapy:
Incorrect: LAMAs used as monotherapy have not been shown to decrease mortality in patients with COPD.  
❌ Phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE-4) inhibitors:
Incorrect: PDE-4 inhibitors, such as roflumilast, can help reduce the frequency of exacerbations in patients with severe COPD and chronic bronchitis. However, they have not been shown to significantly decrease mortality in COPD patients.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to her primary care physician’s office for abdominal pain for the past few months. She describes the pain as crampy. It usually occurs about 30–40 minutes after eating a meal. The pain lasts about an hour. Due to this, she has been avoiding some meals and has lost about 10 lbs. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 132/78 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination there is mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. An epigastric bruit is heard. CT angiography is ordered. Which of the following findings would be expected on imaging?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of crampy, postprandial abdominal pain, food aversion, and weight loss are concerning for chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI). CMI occurs when there is decreased blood flow within the mesenteric vasculature, often due to narrowing of the blood vessels by atherosclerotic plaques.

Diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging (CT or MR angiography) showing stenosis of 2 or more major mesenteric vessels (e.g., celiac, superior mesenteric, or inferior mesenteric artery).  Duplex ultrasonography is typically used as a screening test, while CT angiography is the preferred definitive diagnostic test. Additionally, imaging can reveal the degree of stenosis, which will help guide management decisions.

Keep in mind, the symptoms of abdominal pain and weight loss often lead to esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy being performed as a way to rule out GI malignancies. In patients with these symptoms and a negative endoscopic evaluation, consider CMI in the differential diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Thrombosis of the portal vein:
Incorrect: Portal vein thrombosis typically occurs in the setting of cirrhosis or other prothrombotic diseases and can be asymptomatic or associated with acute abdominal pain. This patient’s history, symptoms, and physical exam findings are more suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia.  
❌ Renal infarct:
Incorrect: Renal infarction is typically associated with acute flank pain and nausea. This patient’s history, symptoms, and physical exam findings are more consistent with chronic mesenteric ischemia.  
❌ Splenic infarct:
Incorrect: Splenic infarction typically presents with acute left upper quadrant pain in the setting of hypercoagulable or embolic disease (e.g., atrial fibrillation). This patient’s symptoms, history, and physical exam findings are more consistent with chronic mesenteric ischemia.  
✅ Stenosis of the mesenteric arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal aortic aneurysm:
Incorrect: Most individuals with an abdominal aortic aneurysm are asymptomatic and the aneurysm is detected incidentally; though abdominal, flank, or back pain can occur. However, food aversion and weight loss are more concerning for chronic mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for acute alcohol-induced pancreatitis. A central venous catheter and urinary catheter are placed on admission. Past medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, depression, and aortic and mitral valve replacement. Current medications include bupropion, citalopram, and warfarin. On the fifth day of hospitalization, the patient develops a new fever and is more difficult to awaken than is usual. There is no associated cough, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or dysuria. Blood tests show leukocytosis. Urinalysis shows 0-3 white blood cells/hpf and is negative for leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and blood. Chest radiograph shows no acute abnormality. Blood cultures are obtained and 2 bottles grow out coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. Which of the following tests is needed to confirm the most likely cause of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who has been hospitalized for several days has developed leukocytosis and a new fever. Hospitalized patients who develop a new fever should be promptly evaluated for a nosocomial (healthcare-associated) infection. The main types of nosocomial infections are catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), surgical site infection (SSI), hospital- or ventilator-associated pneumonia (HAP or VAP), and healthcare-associated Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). Of note, elderly patients who develop nosocomial infections can often present only with fatigue or altered mental status and without fevers and leukocytosis.

This patient has been hospitalized for several days and has both a central venous catheter and a urinary catheter in place, increasing the risk of a nosocomial infection. Depending upon the suspected source, the workup for nosocomial infection may include obtaining blood and urine cultures; chest imaging; and stool testing. If 1 of 2 blood culture bottles is positive for a pathogenic organism (e.g. S. aureus), this is considered a true infection. If 1 of 2 bottles is positive for a commensal (normal flora) organism such as S. epidermidis, this may reflect contamination of the specimen, and another set of blood cultures should be drawn. If both bottles are positive for a commensal organism, this indicates a true infection.

This patient has two blood culture bottles positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (likely S. epidermidis). Therefore this should be treated as the cause of a true infection, and antibiotics should be started and the central venous catheter should be removed unless there is a major contraindication.  

Option Analysis

✅ No further testing is needed:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Repeat blood cultures:
Incorrect: Commensal (normal flora) organisms can sometimes contaminate blood cultures. If 1 of 2 blood culture bottles was positive for these organisms (e.g. coagulase-negative Staphylococcus), then blood cultures should be repeated to ensure that it was a contaminant. However, in this case, where both blood culture bottles are positive, true infection and bacteremia from coagulase-negative Staphylococcus is likely.  
❌ Urine culture:
Incorrect: This patient’s urinalysis lacked significant pyuria, leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and blood. She has no suprapubic pain or dysuria. Urinary tract infection is not likely.  
❌ CT of the chest:
Incorrect: CT of the chest can be performed when there is significant concern for pulmonary pathology despite an unrevealing chest radiograph. This patient has no pulmonary symptoms and has bacteremia with organisms that are not associated with pulmonary disease.  
❌ Stool C. difficile toxin assays:
Incorrect: This would be reasonable to perform and could confirm the diagnosis in a patient with suspected C. difficile infection. However, this patient has no watery diarrhea or abdominal pain or tenderness and has 2 blood culture bottles positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. Staphylococcus bacteremia is the likely cause of infection.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is seen in the primary care clinic due to persistent constipation. The patient has severe lumbar spinal stenosis and has taken oxycodone 10 mg every four hours for the past month. The dose has been titrated up over time, and the patient feels relief of pain at the current dose. The patient otherwise has no medical history and takes no other medications. The patient’s last bowel movement was six days ago and bowel movements have been very firm and difficult to pass. On physical examination, the patient has abdominal distension in both lower quadrants with minimal left lower quadrant tenderness to palpation. Counseling on fluid intake, increased physical activity, and a high-fiber diet is provided. The patient is started on a combination of senna and polyethylene glycol without resolution of symptoms. Which of the following medications should be given at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient has been using opioids (oxycodone) for the past month and has developed opioid-induced constipation (OIC). Lifestyle changes and a combination of stimulant and osmotic laxatives have not relieved this patient’s constipation. Therefore, a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist (PAMORA) – such as naloxegol or methylnaltrexone should be started.

Constipation refers to decreased stool frequency or significant difficulty passing stool. Medications are a common cause of constipation. Opioids are the most common medication to cause this, but several other medications such as calcium channel blockers (e.g. amlodipine), antidepressants and agents with anticholinergic properties (e.g., diphenhydramine, oxybutynin) may also be the cause. If feasible, the culprit medication should be discontinued and swapped out for something else (e.g. hydrocodone in this case), or the dose should be decreased if possible. Lifestyle modifications are very important and include adjusting stooling habits (e.g. defecating immediately upon getting an urge), increasing fluid and fiber intake, and increasing physical activity.
 

If OIC persists despite medication adjustments and lifestyle changes then medications can be added including osmotic laxatives (e.g. polyethylene glycol) and stimulant laxatives (e.g. sennosides). If constipation persists despite all these measures, then a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist – such as naloxegol or methylnaltrexone – should be added. These inhibit opioid effects in the intestines without causing significant reversal of opioid CNS effects.  

Option Analysis

✅ Methylnaltrexone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Naltrexone:
Incorrect: This medication reverses the CNS effects of opioids. This could cause significant withdrawal side effects and the return of pain in this patient without effectively treating the opioid-induced constipation.  
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: This medication reverses the CNS effects of opioids. This could cause significant opioid withdrawal side effects and the return of pain in this patient without effectively treating the opioid-induced constipation.  
❌ Docusate:
Incorrect: Docusate is a stool softener and is weakly effective for constipation. It is unlikely to provide significant benefit for severe constipation and other agents should be used instead.  
❌ Diphenoxylate-atropine:
Incorrect: This medication is an anti-diarrheal (like loperamide) and can worsen constipation. This medication is not appropriate for this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and heart failure presents to the emergency department after a short episode of chest pain, palpitations, and lightheadedness. During the evaluation, his symptoms return and he becomes unresponsive. There is no pulse. His cardiac telemetry strip is shown below. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is currently in cardiac arrest, and the cardiac telemetry shows a uniform, wide QRS complex tachycardia with a rate of around 150 beats per minute. This is consistent with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT).

VT originates from an abnormal ectopic ventricular pacemaker and is often associated with myocardial ischemia or structural heart disease. The first step in evaluating a patient with VT is performing an ABCDE assessment. In unstable patients, acute management to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation should be employed. This may include resuscitation efforts (e.g., chest compressions, defibrillation, intubation, oxygen), obtaining IV access, and placing the patient on cardiac and vital sign monitoring.

In pulseless VT, defibrillation should occur as soon as possible after initiating high-quality CPR. Antiarrhythmics, such as amiodarone or lidocaine, may be used for cases refractory to defibrillation. Additionally, reversible causes of cardiac arrest should be identified and treated. These can be remembered as the 5 H’sand T’s: Hypoxia, Hypothermia, Hypovolemia, Hydrogen ions (for acidosis), Hyper- or Hypokalemia, Toxins, cardiac Tamponade, Thrombosis (for myocardial infarction), Thrombosis again (for pulmonary embolism), and Tension pneumothorax.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Chest compressions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Synchronized cardioversion:
Incorrect: Synchronized cardioversion is used to convert tachyarrhythmias when a pulse is present. However, the patient does not have a pulse, so high-quality CPR and defibrillation would be necessary.  
❌ Defibrillation:
Incorrect: Defibrillation would be advised for pulseless ventricular tachycardia. However, chest compressions should be initiated first while the defibrillator pads are being placed.  
❌ Magnesium sulfate administration:
Incorrect: Intravenous magnesium sulfate is a first-line treatment for torsades de pointes, a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. However, this patient has pulseless monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.  
❌ Amiodarone administration:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication that is often used in the management of ventricular tachycardia. However, this patient is in cardiac arrest, and therefore high-quality CPR and defibrillation would take precedence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after suddenly losing consciousness in the grocery store and requiring CPR and defibrillation. A copy of the rhythm strip during resuscitation efforts is shown below. The patient’s sister reports that the patient has schizophrenia and was recently started on haloperidol. The patient had not complained of chest pain, shortness of breath, or fevers prior to the event. Which of the following ECG findings would be expected based on the history and presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with a sudden cardiac arrest due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). More specifically, the waxing and waning amplitude on the cardiac rhythm strip is indicative of torsades de pointes. Torsades de pointes classically occurs in patients with acquired or congenital QT prolongation.
 

There are many potential causes of acquired QT prolongation, such as electrolyte abnormalities and medications. This patient was recently started on haloperidol, which has a known risk of QT prolongation. The mnemonic “ABCDE” can be used to help remember some of the most common medication classes associated with QT prolongation, such as antiArrhythmics, antiBiotics, anti”C”ychotics, antiDepressants, and antiEmetics.

Intravenous magnesium is the first-line treatment for torsades de pointes, and defibrillation is also used when a pulse is not present. From there, identification and management of the underlying cause (electrolyte replacement, withdrawal of the offending medication) is paramount to help normalize the QT interval and prevent recurrence.  

Option Analysis

❌ Peaked T waves:
Incorrect: Peaked T waves can be seen in severe hyperkalemia, which is a potential cause of ventricular tachycardia. However, this patient’s history suggests that this episode is related to the recent initiation of haloperidol, which is associated with torsades de pointes and QT prolongation.  
✅ Prolonged QT interval:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse ST segment elevation:
Incorrect: Diffuse ST segment elevation can be seen in pericarditis. However, this patient’s lack of symptoms and history of recent haloperidol initiation does not fit with this diagnosis.  
❌ Delta waves:
Incorrect: Delta waves can be seen in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is associated with supraventricular tachycardia. However, this patient’s rhythm strip is consistent with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.  
❌ Diffuse ST segment depressions:
Incorrect: Diffuse ST segment depression may be seen in conditions such as myocardial ischemia (particularly with left main coronary artery disease) or hypothermia. However, the patient’s history does not support either of these diagnoses.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department for worsening malaise and diffuse abdominal pain. He states that he has been feeling nauseous over the past 24 hours with multiple episodes of vomiting, and he has not been able to keep any food or liquids down over this time period. His health insurance was recently discontinued, and he has been taking lower doses of his insulin and skipping doses to make it last longer. On physical examination, he is sleepy, but able to answer questions. He is noted to be taking deep, rapid breaths. Temperature is 37.6 °C (99.7 °F), blood pressure is 84/52 mmHg, pulse is 128/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.  His lips are dry and his breath has a fruity odor. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history (e.g., type 1 diabetes, taking less insulin than prescribed, fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting) and examination (e.g., dry mucous membranes, Kussmaul respirations, fruity odor to his breath, tachycardia, and hypotension) are consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). This is a life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus, resulting from a severe insulin deficiency and glucagon excess. Hyperglycemia from insulin deficiency results in osmotic diuresis, often presenting as polyuria. Large volumes of free water loss, sodium, and potassium occur, causing significant volume depletion and electrolyte abnormalities.

Patients presenting with DKA should undergo an ABCDE assessment to determine whether they are stable or unstable. All patients should be placed on continuous vital sign monitoring, and IV access should be obtained. Those with respiratory compromise should have their airway and breathing stabilized. For hemodynamic instability, a bolus of isotonic fluid (1L 0.9% normal saline) should be given as soon as possible.  

Option Analysis

❌ Initiate IV insulin infusion:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis. Insulin is essential in the management of DKA. However, an IV insulin bolus is typically given before initiation of a continuous infusion.  
❌ Intubate the patient:
Incorrect: This patient’s deep, rapid breaths are known as Kussmaul respirations, and are an attempt to exhale excess CO2 in the setting of severe metabolic acidosis. This will improve with correction of the patient’s diabetic ketoacidosis and is not an indication to intubate.  
❌ Administer 50% dextrose solution:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis. At this point, correction of the patient’s dehydration and insulin deficiency is paramount and dextrose is not warranted.  
❌ Initiate a norepinephrine infusion:
Incorrect: While the patient is hypotensive, this typically improves with isotonic fluid resuscitation. Vasopressor therapy, such as norepinephrine, would only be warranted if the patient’s blood pressure did not respond to adequate rehydration measures.  
✅ Bolus 1 L 0.9% normal saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with somnolence, fever, abdominal and right flank pain, and vomiting. Her symptoms started with dysuria and urinary frequency several days ago. This progressed to right flank pain and fever yesterday. She has been unable to eat or drink and has progressively become weak and tired.  Temperature is 39.2 °C (102.5 °F), blood pressure is 88/62 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On examination, she is arousable to touch. Her mucous membranes are dry and respirations are quick and deep. There is tenderness to palpation in the suprapubic region, as well as the right flank and costovertebral angle. Laboratory findings are listed below. Which of the following tests should be included in this patient’s evaluation?  

Laboratory study   
Result
Leukocyte count  
17,000/mm3   
Sodium
128 mEq/L  
Potassium
4.8 mEq/L  
Glucose
450 mg/dL  
Lactic acid  
4.1 mmol/L  
Beta-hydroxybutyrate  
3.9 mmol/L  
Venous pH  
7.15
questions.solution:
This patient’s history, examination, and laboratory studies are consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). DKA in this patient was likely precipitated by pyelonephritis, which is evidenced by her fever, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and dysuria. As such, an important part of the evaluation of this patient would be to obtain urinalysis and urine culture.

DKA is a life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus, resulting from a severe insulin deficiency and glucagon excess. Patients have type 1 diabetes mellitus and present with hyperglycemia, ketosis, volume depletion, and multiple electrolyte abnormalities including hyponatremia and hypokalemia. There are many potential precipitating factors, the most common of which are missed insulin doses or infection. Other factors to consider are myocardial infarction, stroke, acute pancreatitis, trauma, medications (e.g., glucocorticoids, thiazide diuretics, SGLT-2 inhibitors), and drug use (e.g., cocaine).

Identifying the cause of DKA is an essential aspect of the evaluation, as it affects management and prevention. This process starts with a thorough review of the patient’s history and medication list, assessing the patient’s understanding and compliance with their medications, and evaluation for acute illnesses. Studies are generally guided by the patient’s clinical presentation and may include cultures (e.g., blood, urine), urinalysis, imaging (e.g., chest X-ray, head CT), ECG, and specific laboratory studies (e.g., troponin, lipase).

Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) can mimic DKA as patients present with similar symptoms and hyperglycemia. However in HHS, there is marked elevation of blood glucose, hyperosmolality, and little or no ketosis; and it typically presents in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.  

Option Analysis

❌ Sputum culture:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis. Identifying the underlying cause is important, and a sputum culture may be sent if there is concern for pneumonia. However, the patient’s history and examination suggest pyelonephritis.  
✅ Urinalysis and urine culture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chest X-ray:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis. Identifying the underlying cause is important, and a chest X-ray may be ordered if pneumonia is suspected. However, the patient’s history and examination suggest pyelonephritis.  
❌ Liver function tests:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis and pyelonephritis. Liver function tests would not be necessary.  
❌ Lipase:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis. Identifying the underlying cause is important, and a lipase may be ordered if there is concern for acute pancreatitis. However, this patient’s history and examination are more suggestive of pyelonephritis as the underlying cause of DKA.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of one week of watery diarrhea without blood or mucus in it. The patient reports associated abdominal cramping and poor oral intake. The patient does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 138/91, pulse is 121/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Abdominal examination is significant for mild diffuse tenderness without rebound or guarding. There are no rashes or joint swelling. Rectal examination is negative for hemoccult blood. Intravenous fluids are administered and bloodwork is pending. Which of the following additional historical elements is most likely to be present upon further questioning?

choices.text: History of cholangitis or liver disease

questions.solution:
This patient presents with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain, suggestive of gastroenteritis, and she has evidence of moderate dehydration. Since this patient is young, otherwise healthy, and presents with evidence of watery diarrhea, an important historical question would be about recent travel history. This patient's symptoms and examination findings would be consistent with travelers’ diarrhea secondary to enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC).  


Patients with watery diarrhea should have a thorough history performed to evaluate for recent travel and other factors that may place them at risk for acquiring enteric pathogens (e.g. working in daycare establishments or schools). Bloody diarrhea suggests infection with pathogens such as Campylobacter jejuni, Shigella dysenteriae, Salmonella enterica, Yersinia enterocolitica, and enteroinvasive and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli, as well as Entamoeba histolytica. These patients should be questioned regarding risk factors for C. difficile (which causes watery diarrhea that can also be bloody), immunosuppression, and personal or family history of inflammatory bowel disease to rule out inflammatory bowel disease.

Watery diarrhea can be caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus, Enterovirus, Norovirus, Adenovirus, enterotoxigenic E. Coli (most common cause of travelers’ diarrhea), enteropathogenic E. Coli or EPEC, as well as Cryptosporidium and Giardia. Treatment of watery diarrhea, including travelers’ diarrhea, typically involves rehydration and symptomatic care with bismuth subsalicylate or antimotility agents such as loperamide.  

Option Analysis

✅ History of recent travel:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alcohol use disorder:
Incorrect: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan that can cause dysentery with diarrhea with visible blood and mucus in the stool of patients who have spent long periods in endemic areas and also have factors that place them at high risk for symptomatic infection like young age, pregnancy, corticosteroid use, malignancy, malnutrition, and alcohol use disorder. This patient more likely has travelers’ diarrhea which is characterized by watery diarrhea.  
❌ Family history of ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: Questions about family history of inflammatory bowel disease are an important part of the assessment of patients with bloody or mucoid diarrhea, but less so for those with watery diarrhea. Additionally, this patient has no extraintestinal signs or symptoms of IBD (e.g., uveitis, arthritis, rash).  
❌ Use of anticoagulant medications:
Incorrect: Any patient with a hemoccult that is positive for blood should be asked about the use of anticoagulants that may lead to a GI bleed. However, this patient has a hemoccult that is negative for blood, and she has signs of gastroenteritis including abdominal cramping and tenderness and diarrhea.  
❌ History of cholangitis or liver disease:
Incorrect: Primary sclerosing cholangitis, fatty liver, and autoimmune liver disease can be associated with inflammatory bowel disease. This patient does not have bloody diarrhea or extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of watery diarrhea for the past 4 days. The patient reports five watery unformed stools a day without blood in them. She reports associated vomiting, abdominal cramping, and poor oral intake due to nausea. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 100/61, pulse is 127/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient appears fatigued. Physical examination is notable for dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and delayed capillary refill. The abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation, soft, and nondistended. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and nausea suggestive of gastroenteritis. She also has evidence of moderate-to-severe dehydration; therefore, obtaining intravenous access and administering IV fluids is the most appropriate next step.  


Patients with watery diarrhea should receive treatment dependent on their degree of dehydration. Patients with evidence of moderate-to-severe dehydration should receive intravenous fluids, as well as additional supportive medications (e.g., bismuth subsalicylate, or antimotility agents such as loperamide). Of note, loperamide should be avoided in patients with bloody diarrhea and fever since it may prolong disease. Patients who are well-appearing, without signs of moderate-to-severe dehydration, should receive oral rehydration therapy.

Patients with evidence of severe illness (e.g. high fevers, severe dehydration, severe abdominal pain) or those with high-risk features (e.g. older age, comorbidities) should have an entericpathogen stool panel sent. Empiric antibiotics may be considered in patients with high-risk features or persistent diarrhea. Antibiotics should be tailored once the cultures and sensitivities are available.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of intravenous fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: For patients with watery diarrhea and high-risk features like age ≥70 years and severe dehydration empiric antibiotics can be considered. However, administration of piperacillin-tazobactam would be inappropriate. Recommended antibiotics include azithromycin or a fluoroquinolone.  
❌ Oral rehydration therapy:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration therapy is inappropriate for this patient who has evidence of moderate-to-severe dehydration and has poor oral intake due to nausea. This patient should have an IV placed and receive intravenous fluids.  
❌ Gastroenterology consult for colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy is indicated in the emergent/urgent setting of a suspected lower GI bleed. A colonoscopy is not part of the workup or treatment for new onset gastroenteritis with dehydration.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis can be performed in patients with gastroenteritis to rule out complications in patients with evidence of peritonitis (e.g. ). Given that this patient’s abdominal examination is benign without evidence of peritonitis (e.g., soft, nondistended), IV fluid administration should take precedence.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of polyuria and polydipsia. The patient also reports fatigue and unexplained weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lbs) over the past 2 months. Past medical history is significant for celiac disease. The patient is not taking any medications. Family history is significant for vitiligo in his mother. BMI is 21 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Amyloid deposition in the islets of Langerhans

questions.solution:
This patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, fatigue, and unexplained weight loss over 2 months. Given his young age, normal BMI, and personal and family history of autoimmune disease, the most likely diagnosis is diabetes mellitus type 1. Type 1 diabetes mellitus, unlike type 2 diabetes mellitus, is caused by autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β cells in the islet of Langerhans with subsequent insulin deficiency.

Diabetes mellitus type 1 often presents with signs and symptoms related to hyperglycemia and subsequent osmotic diuresis, such as polydipsia (increased thirst) and polyuria (increased urination). It can also lead to symptoms related to increased fat and muscle breakdown due to the lack of insulin, such as unintended weight loss, as well as symptoms related to inadequate glucose utilization, such as generalized fatigue. Past medical history or family history of autoimmune disease, as seen in this patient, may also be present. Physical examination may reveal signs of dehydration such as dry mucous membrane and decreased skin turgor, and oral thrush. Notably, some patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus may present with diabetic ketoacidosis, a severe complication characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and high-anion gap metabolic acidosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Insulin resistance:
Incorrect: This is typically associated with T2DM and metabolic syndrome. In this case, where the patient is young with a normal BMI and a personal and family history of autoimmune disease, T1DM is more likely.  
❌ Uncontrolled gluconeogenesis in the liver:
Incorrect: Uncontrolled gluconeogenesis does occur in uncontrolled DM as a consequence of insulin deficiency, however, It is not the primary underlying defect in type 1 diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Amyloid deposition in the islets of Langerhans:
Incorrect: This is a histopathologic feature of T2DM and not T1DM. It is caused by the accumulation of amylin (or islet amyloid polypeptide), a protein co-secreted with insulin by the β-cells, in the islets of Langerhans.  
❌ Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic α cells:
Incorrect: Pancreatic α cells produce glucagon, not insulin. Destruction of these cells would not cause hyperglycemia and is not a feature of T1DM.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine check-up. The patient is asymptomatic, has no significant past medical history, and takes no medications. His family history is notable for hypertension in his father and hypothyroidism in his mother. He has a 10-pack-year smoking history and consumes 2-3 alcoholic beverages per week. He reports a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity and a high-sodium diet. BMI is 33 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 149/92 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination reveals no retinal changes, carotid or abdominal bruits, cardiac murmurs, or peripheral edema. Pulmonary examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in the evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: 24-hour urine collection for renal function and proteinuria
TSH, Free T3, and Free T4 measurements

questions.solution:
This asymptomatic patient with a history of obesity and a family history of hypertension is found to have elevated blood pressure during a routine check-up. In the absence of findings suggestive of a secondary cause of hypertension, this presentation is suggestive of essential hypertension (systolic BP ≥130 mm/hg or diastolic BP ≥80 mm/hg). The best next step is to confirm the diagnosis with 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring. This is done to rule out “white coat hypertension”, a condition where patients develop elevated blood pressures in clinical settings only due to anxiety.

Important risk factors for essential hypertension include advanced age, obesity, high sodium intake, excessive alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, insufficient sleep, and a family history of hypertension. Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with non-specific symptoms such as headaches. They may also have risk factors and comorbidities such as coronary artery disease, heart failure, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease. Physical examination may reveal signs of end-organ damage (e.g., peripheral edema, crackles on lung auscultation, retinal hemorrhages).

In the absence of evidence of end-organ damage, the diagnosis of essential hypertension should be confirmed with multiple blood pressure readings. Measurement methods include 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure readings via an automated device worn continuously by the patient, home blood pressure monitoring over a week, or an average of 2 to 3 blood pressure measurements obtained in the office on 2 to 3 separate occasions at least one week apart.  

Option Analysis

✅ 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nephrology consultation:
Incorrect: A nephrology consultation may be necessary if secondary etiologies of hypertension are suspected in a patient with an elevated in-office blood pressure. This patient does not display signs or symptoms indicative of secondary hypertension, such as renal bruits or treatment-resistant hypertension.  
❌ Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor therapy:
Incorrect: This patient's elevated office blood pressure reading needs to be confirmed with ambulatory blood pressure monitoring to confirm the diagnosis of essential hypertension prior to treatment initiation.  
❌ 24-hour urine collection for renal function and proteinuria:
Incorrect: While this testing would be useful for evaluating kidney damage secondary to long-standing hypertension or assessing for secondary hypertension, the diagnosis of hypertension should first be confirmed with ambulatory blood pressure monitoring prior to further evaluation.  
❌ TSH, Free T3, and Free T4 measurements:
Incorrect: Although thyroid disease should be ruled out as a cause of secondary hypertension, this patient’s elevated office blood pressure reading needs to be assessed with ambulatory blood pressure monitoring to confirm the diagnosis of hypertension prior to further evaluation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling for 3 days.  The patient has been unable to perform her activities of daily living because of the pain. Past medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. Temperature is 38°C (102.4°F), blood pressure is 96/71 mmHg, pulse is 107/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, there is a palpable effusion, warmth, and marked swelling of the right wrist when compared to the left wrist. Passive range of motion of the right wrist results in significant reproducible pain. Range of motion is limited. An arthrocentesis is performed with synovial fluid analysis pending. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Needle-shaped, negatively-birefringent crystals on synovial fluid analysis
History of remote well-healed radial fracture without complications
Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals on synovial fluid analysis

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of immunosuppression from diabetes presents for evaluation of unilateral wrist swelling and pain. Given that this patient has evidence of sepsis, significant swelling, pain with range of motion, and limited range of motion of the right wrist, septic arthritis is likely. Arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis would be necessary to make the diagnosis. An overlying soft tissue infection, such as cellulitis where contiguous spread can lead to septic arthritis is a risk factor for the development of septic arthritis.
 

Patients with septic arthritis typically present with monoarticular joint pain and swelling with associated infectious symptoms including fever or malaise. Risk factors for septic arthritis include a history of recent joint surgery, presence of a prosthetic joint, immunosuppression (including diabetes), intravenous drug use, smoking, and an overlying skin infection, ulceration, or wound.  On physical examination, patients will typically appear ill and have a joint effusion, with erythema and warmth of the overlying skin. Patients typically also have significant pain with range of motion, limited range of motion of the affected joint, and inability to bear weight or use of the affected joint.  

Option Analysis

✅ Overlying skin infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Needle-shaped, negatively-birefringent crystals on synovial fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Needle-shaped, negatively-birefringent crystals are found in the synovial fluid of patients with gouty arthritis. Given that this patient has evidence of sepsis and immunosuppression from diabetes, a diagnosis of septic arthritis is more likely.  
❌ History of remote well-healed radial fracture without complications:
Incorrect: A fracture that is associated with complications may lead to osteoarthritis that could increase a patient’s risk for septic arthritis, but a well-healed remote fracture without complications would not place this patient at increased risk. Having a joint with pre-existing arthritis from conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, gout, pseudogout, or Charcot arthropathy does increase the risk of septic arthritis.  
❌ Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals on synovial fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals seen on synovial fluid analysis indicates the presence of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals which are seen in  calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals deposition (CPPD) disease.  
❌ Synovial fluid cell count <2000 cells/microL:
Incorrect: A cell count of <2000 cells/microL on synovial fluid analysis is considered non-inflammatory and would not be consistent with septic arthritis. Given that this patient has evidence of sepsis and immunosuppression, a diagnosis of septic arthritis is more likely.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right knee pain and swelling for the past 2 days.  The patient has been unable to ambulate secondary to the pain. Past medical history includes hypertension, gout, diabetes, osteoarthritis, and obesity. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 125/71 mmHg, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, there is a palpable effusion, warmth, and marked swelling of the right knee. The patient is unable to bear weight without significant pain. An arthrocentesis is performed. The synovial fluid analysis results from later that day are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Laboratory value   
Result
Color
Opaque
Culture/Gram stain  
Moderate polymorphonuclear cells on Gram stain
No growth on culture thus far  
Cell Count  
77,532 cells/microL, 95% polymononuclear leukocytes  
Crystal Analysis  
Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of unilateral knee swelling and pain. Given this patient's fever, joint effusion, limited range of motion, significant pain with range of motion, and inability to bear weight on the affected joint, septic arthritis is likely. Arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis shows opaque fluid with a white blood cell count of 77,532 cells/microL, with 95% polymononuclear leukocytes which is consistent with septic arthritis.
 

The diagnosis of septic arthritis is both clinical as well as dependent on results from synovial fluid analysis. Synovial fluid analysis can be used to differentiate between non-inflammatory causes of arthritis like osteoarthritis and inflammatory causes such as rheumatoid arthritis and septic arthritis. What separates septic arthritis is that there are typically >50,000 cells/microL with >90% of those cells being polymorphonuclear cells, and gram stain and culture will be positive.  

Option Analysis

✅ Septic arthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteoarthritis:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis from osteoarthritic joints typically have cell counts <2000 cells/microL. This patient's synovial fluid analysis and clinical presentation are more consistent with septic arthritis.  
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis is typically inflammatory, with a white blood cell count >2000 cells/microL, but generally the range is 5000-50,000 cells/microL. This patient's synovial fluid analysis and clinical presentation are more consistent with septic arthritis.  
❌ Gout:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis in patients with gout is typically inflammatory, with a white blood cell count >2000 cells/microL, but generally the range is 5000-50,000 cells/microL. Patients with gouty arthritis will also have evidence of negatively birefringent crystals. This patient's synovial fluid analysis and clinical presentation are more consistent with septic arthritis.  
❌ Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis in patients with calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (pseudogout) is typically inflammatory, with a white blood cell count >2000 cells/microL, but generally in the range of 5000-50,000 cells/microL. Patients will also have evidence of calcium pyrophosphate crystals. This patient's synovial fluid analysis and clinical presentation are more consistent with septic arthritis.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents for follow-up for right knee pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion that has been present for one year. He has been using over-the-counter topical analgesics to manage his pain. He has been referred to physical therapy previously with inconsistent follow-up. He is now noticing that he is not able to walk as far due to the pain. Medical history is significant for hypertension and peptic ulcer disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/minute, respiratory rate is 16/minute, and blood pressure is 138/75 mmHg. BMI is 29 kg/m2. Right knee examination is notable for mild swelling of the knee, tenderness to palpation along the medial joint line, limited range of motion, and crepitus. There is no erythema or warmth. Radiograph of the right knee is shown below. What is the best next step in management?
 

Image reproduced from MDPI open access
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a one-year history of knee pain that persists despite the use of over-the-counter topical analgesics for management of his pain and intermittent physical therapy. Non-pharmacologic management of osteoarthritis is effective and should be recommended to all patients as initial treatment. This includes exercise, weight loss, Tai Chi, and assistive devices. Weight loss is recommended for patients with BMI > 25 kg/m2 because it relieves stress on weight-bearing joints, leading to a reduction in pain and increased mobility. Exercise increases muscle strength and improves range of motion. Tai Chi is a traditional Chinese mind-body practice that improves strength and balance. Patients with knee or hip osteoarthritis with difficulty ambulating may benefit from the use of assistive devices such as braces, canes, or walkers.

If patients do not respond to non-pharmacologic treatment or if they want to add pharmacologic treatment to non-pharmacologic therapy, NSAIDs (either topical or oral) can be added if the patient does not have contraindications. Topical NSAIDs can be prescribed initially for pain management and do not carry the same risks as an oral NSAID. Oral NSAIDs are the recommended initial oral medication; however, there is an increased risk for adverse effects in patients with chronic kidney disease, cardiovascular disease, or risk factors for gastrointestinal bleeding. In patients with intolerance or contraindication to NSAIDs, duloxetine may be used as an alternate oral therapy.

If patients do not respond to first-line pharmacologic management with NSAIDs or duloxetine, second-line treatment with intra-articular injections (glucocorticosteroids or hyaluronic acid) can be offered. Intra-articular glucocorticosteroids reduce inflammation within the joint leading to a reduction in pain and improvement in joint function; however, they are associated with adverse risks to the joint. Intra-articular hyaluronic acid acts as a cushion to lubricate the joint.

Patients with knee osteoarthritis who do not respond to nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments may be referred for surgical consultation for joint replacement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Weight loss counseling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Total Knee Replacement:
Incorrect: Joint replacement is an option for management of severe arthritis, or for pain and limitation from arthritis that is not responsive to non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments. This patient has only tried over-the-counter topical analgesics and intermittent physical therapy; therefore, he should try weight loss, exercise, and prescription topical and oral medications first.  
❌ Intra-articular glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Intra-articular glucocorticoids can be used for patients who have not had relief with non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments, or if they have contraindications to these treatments. This patient has only tried over-the-counter topical analgesics and intermittent physical therapy; therefore, he should try weight loss, exercise, and prescription topical and oral medications first.  
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: Oral steroids are typically not used to treat osteoarthritis which is a non-inflammatory arthritis. This patient has only tried over-the-counter topical analgesics and intermittent physical therapy and should try weight loss, exercise, and prescription topical and oral pain medications.  
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of peptic ulcer disease and should avoid the use of NSAIDs which can increase his risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever of 38.9°C (102°F). The patient reports a history of unexplained weight loss of 7 kg (15.4 lbs) and progressive shortness of breath over the past 3 months. He was admitted to the hospital 1 month ago for a right lower lobe consolidation and was treated for bacterial pneumonia. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 135/78 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On physical examination, decreased breath sounds and crackles are noted over the right lung fields. Laboratory evaluation reveals leukocytosis with left shift and elevated CRP. Chest x-ray demonstrates a right lower lobe consolidation. Which of the following is most likely to reveal the underlying etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 3-day history of shortness of breath, hemoptysis, fever along with leukocytosis, elevated CRP, and a right lower lobe consolidation on chest imaging. Together, these findings are consistent with the diagnosis of pneumonia. Given this patient’s history of smoking, recurrent pneumonia (in the same anatomic location), weight loss, and progressive shortness of breath, the most likely underlying etiology is an obstructing lung malignancy. The most appropriate test to diagnose this is a CT scan of the chest with IV contrast. Patients presenting with signs and symptoms of airway obstruction should have a thorough history taken and targeted laboratory and imaging studies guided by the most likely cause.

The diagnostic evaluation of patients with suspected airway obstruction is guided by the most likely cause based on history and physical exam. Tracheal narrowing manifests with persistent cough, sputum retention, and recurrent respiratory infections. Diagnostic imaging, such as a chest x-ray and neck and chest CT scans aid in assessing the location, length, and severity of the narrowing, while bronchoscopy allows for direct visualization.

In cases of foreign body aspiration, patients may present with choking episodes, cough, and difficulty breathing. While a chest x-ray serves as a first-line investigation, it has limited utility for non-radiopaque objects, but may show indirect findings including hyperinflation of the affected side and mediastinal shift towards the unaffected side. Chest CT can provide a more detailed visualization of the obstructing object, which most commonly lodges in the right main bronchus.

Patients with mucus plugging may present with dyspnea, cough, and recurrent respiratory infections. Either a chest x-ray or chest CT scan can be used to make the diagnosis. An x-ray may demonstrate the classic 'finger-in-glove' sign, where opacities originate from the hilum and project towards the periphery. CT findings will often reveal filling defects within the bronchi, indicative of mucus plugging.

Malignancies can present with a chronic cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and smoking history. Chest x-ray and chest CT scans are used to locate and assess the extent of the tumor, and bronchoscopy and biopsy are employed for definitive diagnosis.

When considering deep neck infections, symptoms may include severe throat pain, pain or difficulty swallowing, neck swelling, and systemic signs of infection (fever, tachycardia, hypotension). Initial evaluation may consist of a neck x-ray, but a neck CT scan with IV contrast provides a more detailed view–revealing abscesses or cellulitis.

Patients with trauma as a cause of airway obstruction present with respiratory distress following direct neck/pulmonary injury. CT imaging is the preferred modality for detecting fractures, hematomas, or injury to the tracheobronchial tree resulting in airway obstruction.  

Option Analysis

✅ CT scan of the chest with IV contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tuberculin skin test:
Incorrect: Although tuberculosis (TB) can cause fevers, hemoptysis, and weight loss, the presence of a recurrent consolidation and significant smoking history make the diagnosis of lung cancer more likely.  
❌ Flexible bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: Flexible bronchoscopy is indicated for the evaluation and management of certain causes of airway obstruction such as foreign body aspiration and mucus plugging. While foreign body aspiration can cause hemoptysis, recurrent pneumonia, and unexplained weight loss, this patient’s age, smoking history, and presentation are consistent with lung cancer, which can be best identified with CT of the chest.  
❌ Pulmonary function testing:
Incorrect: Pulmonary function testing is indicated for the evaluation of COPD, asthma, and restrictive lung disease. While COPD may present with dyspnea and productive cough in a patient with a smoking history, the presence of unexplained weight loss and recurrent pneumonia at the same location (right lower lobe) is more suggestive of lung cancer.  
❌ Serum immunoglobulin (IG) levels:
Incorrect: Although IG-related immunodeficiencies may present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, specifically recurrent pneumonia, they typically affect different regions of the lung. The presence of recurrent pneumonia in the same location (right lower lobe) suggests an anatomic obstruction.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department with lightheadedness and fatigue. Electrocardiogram is performed and the patient is found to be in atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute. Thirty minutes later the patient becomes lightheaded and develops chest pressure. Repeat electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 156 beats per minute. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), blood pressure is 78/55 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. On examination, the patient appears confused and uncomfortable. Peripheral IV access is established. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an unstable tachyarrhythmia (atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response with chest pain and hypotension) and requires immediate synchronized cardioversion.

The first step in managing patients presenting with tachycardia is to evaluate for stability via an ABCDE assessment. Initial management includes establishing IV access and providing supplemental oxygen if needed. Advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocols should be followed.

Unstable tachycardia is defined as tachycardia with hypotension, altered mental status, ischemic chest pain, or acute heart failure. Heart rates are generally >150 bpm. Patients who are unstable from tachycardia and who have a pulse should immediately undergo synchronized cardioversion to try and break the unstable rhythm. With synchronized cardioversion, the shock is synced to the patient’s underlying rhythm and delivered in concordance with the QRS complex to avoid precipitating ventricular fibrillation. If this patient had tachycardia and no pulse, he would likely have ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia, requiring immediate defibrillation and CPR. In patients with ventricular fibrillation, the underlying rhythm is unorganized and erratic, so the patient instead receives an untimed shock referred to as defibrillation.

In patients with stable tachycardia, treatment is directed at managing symptoms and treating the underlying etiology. Patients with AV nodal-reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) should be given IV adenosine. Patients with atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response (pulse >110/min) who are stable can be given IV beta-blockers or IV calcium channel blockers (usually diltiazem) for rate control.  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform synchronized cardioversion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform vagal maneuver:
Incorrect: Vagal maneuvers increase parasympathetic tone and can slow AV nodal conduction in certain arrhythmias (e.g. AV nodal reentrant tachycardia). This patient has unstable tachycardia from atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response requiring electrical cardioversion.  
❌ Administer IV amiodarone:
Incorrect: IV amiodarone (usually given as a bolus followed by infusion) is frequently used for management of wide-complex tachycardias. This unstable patient has atrial fibrillation which is a narrow-complex tachycardia requiring immediate electrical cardioversion.  
❌ Administer IV metoprolol:
Incorrect: IV beta-blockers (e.g., esmolol, metoprolol) are frequently used to control heart rate in stable patients with narrow-complex tachyarrhythmias (e.g. atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response). This patient is unstable.  
❌ Administer sublingual nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest discomfort is likely secondary to symptomatic atrial fibrillation rather than acute coronary syndrome. Moreover, nitroglycerin should be avoided in this patient with hypotension.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status, and chest discomfort. The patient has not had fever, cough, diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. Temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), blood pressure 100/60 mmHg, pulse is palpable at 42/min, respiratory rate 22 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 94% on 4L nasal cannula. The patient is awake but disoriented to place, time, and person and appears pale and diaphoretic. IV access is obtained, and IV fluids are initiated. An ECG is performed and is shown below.
