A large pericardial effusion and tamponade physiology is identified on bedside ultrasonography, and an emergent pericardiocentesis is performed. The results of the fluid analysis are shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?  

Laboratory value
Result
Color
Pale yellow  
Predominant cells
Squamous cells with increased nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio  
AFB
Negative
Gram stain
Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of weight loss, fatigue, shortness of breath and is found to have a large pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Based on the results of the pericardial fluid analysis, he has a malignant pericardial effusion.

Cardiac tamponade can occur due to bleeding, which is known as hemopericardium and typically occurs as result of chest trauma, aortic dissection, left ventricular free wall rupture, or iatrogenically as a result of medical interventions. Cardiac tamponade can also occur due to effusive-constrictive pericarditis, often as a result of infection, uremia, or malignancy. Patients with this type of pericardial effusion will have variable characteristics based on the underlying cause. Fluid from pericardiocentesis should be analyzed to help identify the underlying cause of the pericardial effusion. Analysis may include biochemical testing, cytology, gram stain and culture, and immunologic testing. Patients with an infectious etiology will often have fluid that appears cloudy, or purulent with elevated leukocytes. Patients with uremic pericardial effusions tend to have elevated monocytes, and those with malignancy will have malignant cells in the fluid.  

Option Analysis

✅ Malignancy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Uremia:
Incorrect: Patients with end-stage renal disease are susceptible to uremic pericarditis and pericardial effusions. Fluid analysis would typically demonstrate mononuclear cells. This patient’s fluid analysis is suggestive of a malignant etiology.  
❌ Tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Tuberculosis is one of many organisms that can be an infectious cause of pericardial effusions. Patients will often have a history of antecedent infection and pericardial fluid that appears cloudy with increased white blood cells. This patient’s fluid analysis is suggestive of malignancy.  
❌ Coxsackievirus:
Incorrect: Coxsackievirus is one of many viruses that can result in pericarditis and subsequent pericardial effusion. Patients will often have a history of antecedent infection and pericardial fluid that appears cloudy with increased white blood cells. This patient’s fluid analysis is suggestive of malignancy.
❌ Ventricular free wall rupture:
Incorrect: Ventricular free wall rupture would result in hemopericardium and a bloody pericardial effusion. This patient’s fluid analysis is suggestive of malignancy

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office for a routine physical examination. The patient plans to travel to Ethiopia next month to visit family. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies. He does not take any medications. Family history is significant for hypertension in the patient’s father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. In addition to mosquito bite prevention, which of the following drugs is most suitable for prophylaxis against Plasmodium falciparum malaria?
questions.solution:
Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for patients at risk of malaria infection. This patient plans to travel to Ethiopia, a malaria-endemic region with chloroquine-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum.

The selection of chemoprophylaxis must be tailored to the individual’s itineraries and circumstances. These include:
 
  • Travelers to malaria-endemic areas with chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum: atovaquone-proguanil, mefloquine, doxycycline, and tafenoquine. 
 
  • Travelers to malaria endemic region with chloroquine-sensitive P. falciparum: chloroquine 
 
  • Travelers to malaria endemic regions with chloroquine and mefloquine-resistant P. falciparum (mainly Eastern and Southeastern Asia): atovaquone-proguanil, doxycycline, or tafenoquine. 

Option Analysis

❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone is used for chemoprophylaxis against Neisseria meningitidis infection. It is not effective in protecting against Plasmodium falciparum infection.  
✅ Doxycycline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oseltamivir:
Incorrect: Oseltamivir or zanamivir can be used for prophylaxis against the influenza virus in institutional settings (e.g., long-term care facilities, hospitals). However, oseltamivir is not effective in protecting against Plasmodium falciparum infection.  
❌ Isoniazid:
Incorrect: Isoniazid can be used as chemoprophylaxis against Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. However, it is not effective in protecting against Plasmodium falciparum infection.  
❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Plasmodium falciparum strains found in Ethiopia are resistant to chloroquine. The only regions where P. falciparum is generally sensitive to chloroquine are the Caribbean, Central America west of the Panama Canal, and some areas in the Middle East.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department following an episode of hemoptysis. The patient was at home watching television when he began coughing and produced moderate quantities of bright red blood. He has had episodes of hemoptysis in the past, but the volume of blood coughed up today was more than normal. He has experienced a persistent cough over the past three months, which failed to improve with over-the-counter antitussives. His medical history is notable for HIV, for which he takes lamivudine, lopinavir, and abacavir. He is a wildlife photographer and recently traveled to India. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 115/77 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. On physical examination, rhonchi are heard in the right lung. Chest imaging is shown below. The patient’s most recent CD4 count is 9,000/mm3 (9.0*109/L). Which of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
With recent travel to tuberculosis-endemic regions of the world, this patient presents with a persistent cough, hemoptysis, and a cavitary region in the right perihilar region. This patient most likely has active tuberculosis.    

In most individuals, treatment of active tuberculosis involves 2-months of rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE) therapy followed by 4-months of rifampin and isoniazid. However, this patient has concurrent HIV infection and is taking a protease inhibitor, which is metabolized by cytochrome P450 (CYP450). Unfortunately, rifampin can induce CYP450, thus increasing protease inhibitor metabolism and causing plasma protease inhibitor concentrations to fall below therapeutic levels.  

As a result, rifampin should be replaced by rifabutin, a less potent inducer of CYP450, in patients concurrently taking protease inhibitors.  



Option Analysis

❌ Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms and imaging findings consistent with active tuberculosis, typically treated with rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. However, this patient has HIV and is taking the protease inhibitor lopinavir. As a result, rifampin should be replaced with rifabutin since the former induces cytochrome P450, increases lopinavir metabolism, and may cause plasma lopinavir concentrations to fall below therapeutic levels.   
✅ Rifabutin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Isoniazid and rifapentine:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms and imaging findings consistent with active tuberculosis. In contrast, the combination of isoniazid and rifapentine is used to treat latent tuberculosis.  
❌ Rifabutin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Rifabutin monotherapy can be used to treat latent tuberculosis. However, this patient has symptoms of active disease (e.g., persistent cough, hemoptysis) and a cavitary lesion in the right perihilar region. Therefore, a more aggressive treatment regimen should be administered.  
❌ Isoniazid monotherapy:
Incorrect: Isoniazid monotherapy can be used to treat latent tuberculosis. However, this patient has symptoms of active disease (e.g., persistent cough, hemoptysis) and a cavitary lesion in the right perihilar region. Therefore, a more aggressive treatment regimen should be administered.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner after a medication overdose. The partner became concerned when the patient appeared confused and had slurred speech. She has had two episodes of non-bloody emesis. Several empty medication bottles were found in the bathroom. The patient recently lost her job as a phlebotomist and has been under significant stress. Medical history is notable for depression, asthma, and latent tuberculosis. She is taking an antidepressant, an albuterol inhaler, and an antimycobacterial drug. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg, and pulse is 130/min. An EKG is obtained and shown below. The patient is oriented only to self. Bilateral pupils are reactive to light. 2+ reflexes are present in the extremities. The patient develops a tonic-clonic seizure lasting 5 minutes that is refractory to lorazepam therapy during the physical examination. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with confusion, slurred speech, and vomiting. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia but no QRS interval prolongation. She later develops a tonic-clonic seizure that is refractory to benzodiazepine therapy. Based on these findings, the patient most likely overdosed on isoniazid.  

Isoniazid can be used as monotherapy for the treatment of latent tuberculosis. The medication inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, an essential component of the mycobacterial cell wall. It also inhibits mycobacterial peroxidase, which leads to hydrogen peroxide accumulation within mycobacteria and subsequent cellular damage.    
Patients with isoniazid toxicity will initially present with relatively nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, and confusion. Later on, patients can develop seizures, metabolic acidosis, and coma.    

Seizures develop since isoniazid causes vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency. Pyridoxine is normally converted to pyridoxal phosphate and used to synthesize the inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA). In the setting of pyridoxine deficiency, GABA levels are reduced, and the risk of seizures is elevated. Often, the seizures that occur are intractable and refractory to benzodiazepine therapy.     

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Many patients with fluoxetine overdose remain asymptomatic, whereas others may develop nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, agitation, or tachycardia. In rare cases, patients can develop serotonin syndrome, presenting with altered mental status, autonomic instability, and hyperreflexia. Although seizures have been reported in the setting of fluoxetine overdose, the incidence rate is extremely low.  
❌ Ethambutol:
Incorrect: This patient presents with confusion, slurred speech, and vomiting. She develops a tonic-clonic seizure that is refractory to benzodiazepine therapy. These symptoms are consistent with isoniazid overdose. In contrast, ethambutol toxicity is more likely to present with visual disturbances (e.g., blurry vision, color blindness).   
✅ Isoniazid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amitriptyline:
Incorrect: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant. This patient has a normal QRS interval and lacks anticholinergic symptoms. Overdose can lead to anticholinergic symptoms (e.g., mydriasis, flushed skin), altered mental status, seizures, and QRS interval prolongation.   
❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: This patient presents with confusion, slurred speech, vomiting, and a tonic-clonic seizure refractory to benzodiazepine therapy. These symptoms are consistent with isoniazid overdose. Although rifampin toxicity can also cause seizures, it will likely be preceded by orange discoloration of the skin and body fluids.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care provider due to worsening visual disturbances for the past two weeks. He has experienced blurry vision and difficulty differentiating between red and green lights at traffic intersections. Medical history is notable for active tuberculosis diagnosed seven weeks ago. He is currently taking multiple antituberculosis medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 123/78 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination reveals reduced central visual acuity in both eyes. An Ishihara color perception test is performed, and the patient is noted to have red-green color blindness. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
After initiating anti-tuberculosis therapy, this patient presents with blurred vision and red-green color blindness. The offending agent is most likely ethambutol.   

Ethambutol blocks the enzyme arabinosyltransferase and prevents the synthesis of arabinogalactan, which is an essential component of the mycobacterial cell wall. The medication is used to treat active tuberculosis infections.  

The main side effect of ethambutol is optic neuritis, which can manifest with decreased visual acuity and red-green color blindness. Due to these potential complications, regular vision checks are necessary while taking ethambutol. The associated color blindness typically resolves once the medication is discontinued. In addition, ethambutol can decrease renal excretion of uric acid, causing hyperuricemia and increasing the risk of developing gout.  



Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of bacterial topoisomerase enzymes:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones work by inhibiting bacterial topoisomerase. These medications can cause gastrointestinal irritation, tendonitis, rupture, and QT-interval prolongation. However, fluoroquinolones would not cause optic neuritis, which can manifest with blurred vision and color blindness.  
❌ Inhibition of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Rifampin is an antituberculosis medication that works by inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase. Although this medication can cause hepatitis and elevated liver enzymes, it would not typically cause blurred vision or red-green color blindness.  
✅ Blockade of arabinogalactan synthesis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blockade of bacterial ribosomal 30S subunit:
Incorrect: Aminoglycosides, such as streptomycin, act on the 30S subunit of mycobacterial ribosomes, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Side effects include rash, fever, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity. However, aminoglycosides would not cause the constellation of side effects described in the question stem.  
❌ Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis:
Incorrect: Isoniazid inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acid, which is a component of the mycobacterial cell wall. Although the medication can be hepatotoxic, it would not typically lead to visual disturbances.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman arrives at the primary care physician for evaluation of headaches and blurry vision, which began five months ago. The symptoms are worse in the morning and progressively improve over the course of the day. Past medical history is notable for acne vulgaris. The patient currently takes oral contraceptive pills and doxycycline. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 70/min, blood pressure is 118/65 mmHg, and body mass index is 30 kg/m2. The neurological examination is nonfocal and there is no nuchal rigidity. A Fundoscopy is performed and reveals findings similar to the ones shown below. MRI imaging is noncontributory. A lumbar puncture is performed and the opening pressure is 260 mmH2O. The patient is noted to have immediate relief of her headache following the procedure. Which of the following would be the next best step in the management of this patient’s condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient has headaches, blurry vision, papilledema, and an elevated opening pressure in the setting of oral contraceptive and tetracycline use (e.g. doxycycline). She most likely has idiopathic intracranial hypertension (also termed pseudotumor cerebri).    

The first-line medication for treating idiopathic intracranial hypertension is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (CAI). Examples from this medication class include acetazolamide and brinzolamide. CAIs inhibit the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which can be found in the choroid plexus of the brain, proximal convoluted tubules of the kidney, and ciliary bodies of the eye. As a result, CAIs can reduce the rate of cerebrospinal fluid production, thereby improving the symptoms of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.  

CAIs can also be used to treat glaucoma by reducing aqueous humor production, mountain sickness by inducing a metabolic acidosis, as well as pulmonary edema and ascites via increasing urine output.   

Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of methylprednisolone therapy:
Incorrect: In the short-term, corticosteroids can quickly reduce intracranial pressure in patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension. However, in the long-term, corticosteroids can cause weight gain, which would further exacerbate symptoms. As a result, corticosteroids are generally avoided in the management of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.  
❌ Placement of ventriculoperitoneal shunt:
Incorrect: A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt can help drain excess cerebrospinal fluid. It is effective in reducing headaches and less effective for correcting visual disturbances. However, medical interventions to treat the patient’s idiopathic intracranial hypertension should be attempted first before proceeding to surgery.  
❌ Administration of mannitol:
Incorrect: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It can treat cerebral edema and elevated intracranial pressure by decreasing brain volume and its overall water content. However, mannitol’s efficacy in treating idiopathic intracranial hypertension is not as well documented as that of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.   
❌ Perform optic nerve sheath fenestration:
Incorrect: An optic nerve sheath fenestration involves making slits in the optic nerve. This procedure decompresses the nerve and helps relieve vision-related symptoms arising secondary to idiopathic intracranial hypertension. However, medical interventions should be attempted first before proceeding to surgery.  
✅ Administration of acetazolamide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed seizure. The patient has a past medical history of alcohol use disorder, pancreatitis, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 178/90 mmHg, pulse is 116/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. The patient is awake, tremulous, confused, and unable to provide a clinical history. Tongue fasciculations, psychomotor agitation, and diaphoresis are observed on physical examination. Finger stick blood glucose is 135 mg/dL. IV access is established and the patient is given intravenous normal saline. Which of the following should be administered next?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of alcohol use disorder is presenting after a witnessed seizure and signs of sympathetic hyperactivity (e.g. sweating, tremor, agitation, altered mental status) that are consistent with severe alcohol withdrawal. The best next step in management is to administer an intravenous benzodiazepine, like diazepam, to prevent severe complications of alcohol withdrawal. All patients with seizures or delirium tremens should be treated with IV benzodiazepines.

Alcohol withdrawal refers to symptoms that develop when patients with a history of heavy alcohol use either significantly reduce or ceases alcohol intake. Alcohol has an inhibitory effect on the central nervous system. Therefore, if alcohol intake drops after prolonged use, the inhibitory effect is removed and patients experience excitation of the CNS—resulting in signs and symptoms of alcohol withdrawal. These may include psychomotor agitation; sweating; insomnia; vomiting; nausea; palpitations; anxiety; and signs of autonomic hyperactivity, including agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, and tremor.

The acute management of patients presenting with severe alcohol withdrawal includes an ABCDE assessment to evaluate and stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Unstable patients with alcohol withdrawal present with evidence of sympathetic hyperactivity, including tachycardia, and require continuous vital sign monitoring, administration of intravenous fluids, and immediate pharmacologic therapy. They may also require intubation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous diazepam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral gabapentin:
Incorrect: Oral gabapentin can be used for the management of very mild alcohol withdrawal in the outpatient setting. This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of severe alcohol withdrawal and is at risk for complications like recurrent seizures, delirium tremens, and death; he should be treated with intravenous benzodiazepines.  
❌ Intravenous dextrose:
Incorrect: Administration of dextrose is not indicated given that this patient's blood sugar is within normal limits.  
❌ Thiamine:
Incorrect: While all patients with alcohol withdrawal should receive thiamine supplementation, intravenous benzodiazepine should be started immediately to prevent recurrent seizures and other manifestations of severe alcohol withdrawal.  
❌ Pyridoxine:
Incorrect: Pyridoxine deficiency (vitamin B6) is an established cause of refractory seizures. It is most often seen in patients taking isoniazid. Thiamine and folate (vitamin B9) deficiencies (not vitamin B6 deficiency) can be seen in patients diagnosed with alcohol withdrawal and should be replenished.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a one-day history of severe left eye pain and blurred vision accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and headache. Three days ago, the patient visited his primary care physician and was prescribed a nasal decongestant for sinus congestion. Past medical history is significant for migraine, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and schizophrenia. Family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. Ophthalmologic examination shows decreased visual acuity. The left eye appears red, with a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and dilated fixed pupil. The left eye is stony-hard in texture. The rest of the neurological exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with sudden onset, unilateral eye pain and ipsilateral headache, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision, combined with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil, suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG), most likely precipitated by pseudoephedrine (a sympathomimetic drug). Pseudoephedrine is a selective alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonist, which can induce angle closure by mydriasis and diminished outflow of aqueous humor.

Anything causing pupillary dilatation can trigger an acute attack. Topical or systemic parasympatholytic agents (mydriatics, antihistamines), sympathomimetics (epinephrine, pseudoephedrine), dim illumination, and emotionally upsetting events have all been used been implicated as precipitating factors. Critically ill patients treated for respiratory failure with nebulized β-sympathomimetic and anticholinergic medications (e.g., albuterol and ipratropium) may develop AACG.

Management of ACCG involves medical control of elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) via timolol, apraclonidine, pilocarpine, or acetazolamide, followed by a reversal of angle-closure by laser peripheral iridotomy or other surgical treatments. The patient should be referred urgently to an ophthalmologist for care.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute migraine attack:
Incorrect: Acute migraine attack is characterized by a disabling headache associated with nausea and light and sound sensitivity. The cornea is clear, and pupillary size and response to light are normal. Visual acuity is unaffected. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
✅ Medication-induced mydriasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eye dehydration secondary to lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and is the first-line medication for hypertension. It is unlikely to cause eye dehydration and precipitate angle-closure glaucoma as seen in this patient.  
❌ Bacterial conjunctivitis:
Incorrect: Bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by mild ocular pain. The cornea is clear, and pupillary size and response to light are normal. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
❌ Optic neuritis:
Incorrect: Optic neuritis is characterized by a sudden loss of vision (partial or complete), sudden blurred or "foggy" vision, and pain on movement of the affected eye, and can be seen in certain demyelinating diseases (e.g. multiple sclerosis). A fixed, mid-dilated pupil is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute-onset, severe right foot pain. The patient woke up this morning with pain, swelling, and redness of the affected extremity. The patient denies a history of recent trauma. The patient has experienced three similar episodes in the past year, which were treated adequately with colchicine. Past medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals redness, warmth, and a small effusion around the right great toe. A sample of synovial fluid shows needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy. Once stabilized, which of the following medications would be most helpful in preventing future recurrences of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute-onset toe pain, erythema, and swelling. Microscopy reveals the presence of needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals in the synovial fluid. These findings are consistent with an acute gout flare. The patient should initially be treated with indomethacin to manage the acute symptoms. Afterwards, pharmacologic urate-lowering therapy with allopurinol or febuxostat should be administered to prevent future episodes of acute gouty attack.  

Allopurinol is a purine analog that works via competitive inhibition of xanthine oxidase (XO). Allopurinol is first converted by XO into its active metabolite oxypurinol, which is a non-competitive inhibitor of XO. Inhibition of XO decreases serum uric acid levels and increases levels of the upstream molecules hypoxanthine and xanthine; which are more soluble compounds and therefore easier to excrete. As a result, there is a smaller chance of crystals depositing in the joints and tissues.    

Allopurinol is also effective in preventing tumor lysis syndrome in individuals with lymphoma or leukemia, who are receiving anti-cancer therapy. Common side effects of allopurinol include gastrointestinal irritation and rash. In rare cases, the medication can cause Steven-Johnsons syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis.  



Febuxostat, on the other hand, is a non-purine inhibitor of XO. It is reserved for individuals who cannot tolerate allopurinol. Side effects include gastrointestinal disturbance, headache, and hepatotoxicity.  



Option Analysis

✅ Allopurinol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin should be avoided in patients with a history of gout since it competes with uric acid for excretion via the kidneys. As a result, aspirin can increase the risk of future gout attacks.  
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are associated with elevated serum uric acid levels. They increase urate reabsorption in the proximal renal tubules and may precipitate a gout attack.  
❌ Fenofibrate:
Incorrect: Fenofibrate is a lipid lowering drug. It is typically effective in the management of hypertriglyceridemia and can reduce the risk of developing acute pancreatitis.  
❌ Prophylactic antibiotics:
Incorrect: Gouty arthritis is caused by either reduced uric acid excretion or excess uric acid production. It is not caused by bacterial infection. Therefore, urate-lowering agents, instead of prophylactic antibiotics, are indicated to prevent recurrent episodes of gout.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to severe right ankle pain. The pain developed overnight and woke him up from his sleep. He has not traveled recently and has no history of recent trauma. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. Family history is significant for osteoarthritis in the patient’s mother. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a moderate-sized effusion of the right ankle with surrounding erythema and warmth. Serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. Microscopic examination of the synovial fluid aspirate is shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug indicated to treat this patient’s condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Blockade of transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan
Conversion of uric acid to allantoin
Inhibition of renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid

questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute-onset right ankle pain, erythema, and swelling. Light microscopy reveals needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals. These findings are consistent with an acute gout attack.    

First-line treatment includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as indomethacin. NSAIDs work via reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase. In contrast, aspirin and other salicylates should be avoided in gout because they are weak acids and therefore they can compete with uric acid for secretion in the proximal convoluted tubules.    

Glucocorticoids such as methylprednisolone and prednisone can also be used to treat acute gout by inhibiting phospholipase A2.  



Finally, colchicine can treat acute gout by binding tubulin and inhibiting microtubule polymerization, thereby inhibiting neutrophil migration into joints and reducing inflammation. It can also be used for gout prophylaxis and treatment of familial Mediterranean fever. Colchicine is contraindicated in individuals with kidney, liver, or gastrointestinal problems. Moreover, the medication should be used only when NSAIDs and corticosteroids are contraindicated or ineffective. This precaution exists because colchicine has numerous side effects including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, peripheral neuropathy, rhabdomyolysis, kidney damage, and bone marrow suppression.  



Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan:
Incorrect: Penicillins act by blocking the transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan. It is indicated in the management of septic arthritis but plays no role in gouty arthritis.  
❌ Xanthine oxidase inhibition:
Incorrect: Allopurinol and febuxostat decrease uric acid levels by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. These medications can prevent recurrent gout attacks and prevent tumor lysis syndrome in patients receiving anti-cancer therapy. They are not effective in treating acute gout attacks.  
❌ Conversion of uric acid to allantoin:
Incorrect: Uricase medications (e.g., rasburicase, pegloticase) catalyze the conversion of uric acid to allantoin, a more soluble and easily excreted product. These agents are not used for acute gout treatment but are typically reserved for severe gout cases that have failed other urate-lowering therapies or to prevent uric acid nephropathy in situations of increased uric acid production, such as tumor lysis syndrome.
✅ Reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid:
Incorrect: Uricosuric agents (e.g., probenecid, sulfinpyrazone) inhibit renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid, thereby increasing its excretion. These agents are typically reserved for patients who under-excrete uric acid relative to their plasma levels. Uricosuric agents are not effective in the management of acute gout attacks.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought by ambulance to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. She has a past medical history of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (EF 10%), type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. She has missed multiple days of furosemide. The patient’s daughter found her sitting in her armchair too out of breath to walk to the phone; her daughter called EMS. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 115 beats/min, respiratory rate is 28 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Physical examination reveals distended jugular veins. Skin is cool touch in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Rales are present at the lung bases bilaterally. There is 4+ pitting edema to the knees bilaterally. Labs reveal a serum creatinine of 4.5 mg/dL (baseline 1.3 mg/dL), a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 60 mg/dL, and a potassium of 6.5 mEq/L. Urinalysis is unremarkable, and her urine output is very low. An electrocardiogram shows peaked T waves. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with cardiogenic shock due to severe heart failure. She has developed prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) secondary to lack of perfusion from cardiogenic shock. Treatment involves volume removal to alleviate cardiac strain and improve renal blood flow along with rapid correction of hyperkalemia This can be best accomplished with emergent hemodialysis.

Treatment of prerenal acute kidney injury depends on the underlying cause. In cases  of hypovolemia and prerenal AKI, treatment should focus on intravascular volume resuscitation. In cases where septic shock or anaphylaxis leads to systemic vasodilation and prerenal AKI, patients should be given IV fluids and vasopressors as necessary. The underlying cause should be treated for example with empiric IV antibiotics for septic shock and epinephrine and steroids for anaphylaxis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administer oral furosemide:
Incorrect: Administration of oral diuretics would be appropriate in the setting of  a mild-to-moderate heart failure exacerbation. This patient presents with cardiogenic shock and end-organ damage from hypoperfusion (e.g. acute kidney injury) and requires hemodialysis for fluid removal and correction of hyperkalemia.  
❌ Administer intravenous isotonic saline:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with cardiogenic shock and acute kidney injury with hyperkalemia. She needs acute volume removal and correction of hyperkalemia.  
❌ Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics would be indicated in the setting of septic shock, which can also cause organ hypoperfusion. This patient presents with cardiogenic shock as evidenced by the patient’s volume-overloaded status.  
✅ Consult nephrology for hemodialysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Place a foley catheter:
Incorrect: Placement of a foley catheter would be indicated in patients suspected of having urinary outflow obstruction. This patient’s lack of urine production is likely secondary to poor renal perfusion as a result of cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of intermittent bleeding from gums and excessive bruising since childhood. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in the patient’s paternal grandmother, who required occasional blood transfusions. The patient does not take any medications or use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pinpoint bleeding from gums and multiple purpuras all over his body. A complete blood profile is unremarkable, and a peripheral blood smear shows normal morphology of platelets. Adding antibiotic ristocetin to the patient’s blood sample results in agglutination, but platelet aggregometry is abnormal. Genetic testing identifies a defect in the protein targeted by the drug, abciximab. Which of the following best describes the role of the protein inhibited by this drug in hemostasis?

choices.text: Binds fibrinogen and induce platelet aggregation
Binds platelets to von Willebrand factor on collagen
Facilitates the production of thromboxane A2 in platelets
Facilitates the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin

questions.solution:
This patient with mucocutaneous bleeding (bruising and gum bleeding), combined with an abnormal platelet aggregometry, is most likely suffering from Glanzmann thrombasthenia. This autosomal recessive disorder is characterized by defective or deficient glycoprotein IIb/IIIa on the platelet surface targeted by the drug abciximab.

Platelets play a significant role in primary hemostasis, defined by the formation of a platelet plug. It is divided into five steps:
  
  • Endothelial injury (step 1): It results in transient vasoconstriction via neural stimulation reflex and endothelin 
  • Exposure (step 2): von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to exposed collagen 
  • Adhesion (step 3): Platelets bind vWF via the GpIb receptor at the site of injury only and undergo a conformational change, thereby releasing ADP, calcium ions (Ca 2+), and thromboxane A2 (TXA2). 
  • Activation (step 4): Released ADPs bind to P2Y12 receptor on platelets and induce GpIIb/IIIa expression at its surface 
  • Aggregation (step 5): Fibrinogen binds GpIIb/IIIa receptors and links platelets 
Primary hemostasis can be inhibited by antiplatelet drugs at different steps as described below:
 

Option Analysis

✅ Binds fibrinogen and induce platelet aggregation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Binds platelets to von Willebrand factor on collagen:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptor on the surface of platelets binds to von Willebrand factor on the subendothelial collagen, facilitating platelet adhesion to the site of injury, where platelets undergo conformational changes. The deficiency of GpIb is seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome and results in an abnormal ristocetin test (unlike this patient), and it is not targeted by abciximab.  
❌ Binds platelets to subendothelial collagen:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein Ia is responsible for binding platelets directly to the subendothelial collagen at the injury site. It is not inhibited by abciximab and does not result in abnormal platelet aggregometry.  
❌ Facilitates the production of thromboxane A2 in platelets:
Incorrect: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is produced by the action of cyclooxygenase (COX) on arachidonic acid which facilitates platelet aggregation. TXA2 production is inhibited by aspirin which blocks the COX enzyme.  
❌ Facilitates the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin:
Incorrect: Plasminogen is converted to plasmin by tissue plasminogen activator. This conversion is inhibited by antifibrinolytic drugs (e.g., aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid), not by abciximab.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of chest pain, and a diagnosis of an anterior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction is made. Cardiac catheterization is performed, and a drug-eluting stent is placed in the left anterior descending coronary artery. In addition to aspirin, an antiplatelet agent that blocks the ADP (P2Y12) receptors is added to reduce the risk of stent thrombosis. Which of the following is an example of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient had an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction and was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention with a drug-eluting stent. Long-term dual-antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and platelet ADP (P2Y12) receptor blocker (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor (reversible), ticlopidine) is usually indicated, which significantly lowers the risk of stent thrombosis.

ADP is a platelet activator that binds to the P2Y12 receptor on platelets, induces gpIIb/IIIa expression at its surface, and facilitates platelet aggregation. Except for ticagrelor (reversible), ADP receptor inhibitors are metabolized by the liver and irreversibly bind and block ADP receptors to prevent platelet aggregation. A combination of aspirin and platelet ADP (P2Y12) receptor blocker is indicated in patients after percutaneous angioplasty, unstable angina, NSTEMI, and STEMI for secondary prophylaxis. Adverse effects include bleeding, dyspepsia, diarrhea, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and rarely neutropenia (ticlopidine).  

Option Analysis

❌ Cilostazol:
Incorrect: Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase three inhibitor that reverses the inhibition of platelet aggregation, vasodilation, and vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation. It is usually used to manage peripheral vascular disease (intermittent claudication). Although it can be used in patients with elective stent placement, it is contraindicated in this patient with a history of heart failure (due to increased risk of mortality).  
❌ Apixaban:
Incorrect: Apixaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor that acts as an anticoagulant and is used to treat and prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Although it can be used in patients with a coronary stent (not first-line), it is not an antiplatelet drug.  
✅ Ticagrelor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abciximab:
Incorrect: Abciximab is a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor that prevents platelet aggregation. It is not routinely used in patients with percutaneous coronary intervention as it increases the risk of bleeding.  
❌ Dabigatran:
Incorrect: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor that directly inhibits the activity of free and clot-associated thrombin. It is usually used to manage venous thromboembolism and atrial fibrillation. It does not affect the ADP receptor.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of epigastric and chest pain accompanied by sweating for the past hour. The patient’s symptoms improved with aspirin and sublingual nitroglycerin administered by the paramedics. An ECG is shown below. Troponin levels are normal. She is started on conventional therapy for unstable angina. Upon re-evaluation, the patient’s chest pain is not improved, and another drug is administered to reduce the risk of coronary thrombosis. At the same time, she is scheduled for percutaneous coronary intervention later today. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
 

Reproduced from Flickr

choices.text: Relaxation of venous vascular smooth muscle cells via cGMP
Irreversible binding to and inhibition of the H+/K+ ATPase in parietal cells
Inhibition of the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin
Blockade of β1 adrenergic receptors in the heart
Prevent platelet cross-linking by binding to the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chest and epigastric pain, in combination with ECG findings of horizontal ST-segment depression, leads V3 to V6 and normal troponins, are consistent with the acute coronary syndrome (ACS) secondary to unstable angina. In addition to conventional therapy (aspirin, P2Y12 inhibitor, heparin, statin), a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor (e.g., abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban) is indicated to reduce the risk of coronary artery thrombosis.

Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors work by binding directly to the IIb/IIIa receptor on the platelet surface and preventing fibrinogen from cross-linking platelets together. There are three types of GP IIb/IIIa receptor blockers:
 
  • Monoclonal antibodies (e.g. abciximab, which is the Fab fragment of chimeric human-mouse monoclonal antibodies) 
  • Synthetic peptide antagonists (eg, eptifibatide) 
  • Synthetic nonpeptide antagonists (eg, tirofiban) 
These drugs are usually indicated in patients with unstable angina undergoing percutaneous coronary angioplasty whose pain is not resolved with conventional therapy. Major adverse effects include bleeding and thrombocytopenia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Relaxation of venous vascular smooth muscle cells via cGMP:
Incorrect: Nitrates act by causing venous smooth muscle relaxation (via cGMP), leading to a decrease in cardiac preload, which, in turn, causes a decrease in myocardial oxygen demand. It plays no role in the prevention of coronary thrombosis.  
❌ Irreversible binding to and inhibition of the H+/K+ ATPase in parietal cells:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors (e.g. omeprazole) irreversibly bind to and inhibit H+/K+–ATPase in parietal cells and are usually used in the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease and peptic ulcer disease. It is not indicated in this patient.  
❌ Inhibition of the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin:
Incorrect: Fibrinolytic agents (e.g. alteplase) inhibit the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin and are usually indicated in patients with ACS due to ST-elevation myocardial infarction when percutaneous coronary intervention is unavailable. It is not indicated in this patient with ACS due to unstable angina or NSTEMI.  
❌ Blockade of β1 adrenergic receptors in the heart:
Incorrect: Cardioselective beta-blockers (e.g. metoprolol) block β1 adrenergic receptors on the cardiac, smooth muscles to reduce myocardial oxygen demand and risk of ventricular arrhythmias. It plays no role in the prevention of coronary thrombosis.  
✅ Prevent platelet cross-linking by binding to the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for left elbow pain and swelling. The patient is an air conditioning technician, which requires him to move through tight spaces while resting on his knees and elbows. He did not sustain any recent trauma. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Upper arm exam is noncontributory. The patient has swelling at the posterior aspect of the left elbow as shown below. He has full range of motion of the elbow. He reports improvement in pain with full elbow extension and worsening with flexion. The swollen area is mildly tender to touch but is not warm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with posterior elbow swelling and tenderness consistent with olecranon bursitis. The olecranon bursa is a superficial bursa that overlies the triceps tendon and olecranon. Normally, the olecranon bursa is flat, but it can swell when it is irritated or inflamed due to direct trauma, prolonged pressure, or friction (leaning on the elbow or as part of an occupation such as laying carpet). As the bursa does not directly involve the joint, flexion/extension does not typically cause pain. Although if significantly swelling or inflammation is present, patients may experience increased pain with stretching of the bursa with flexion at the elbow.  

In addition to direct trauma, friction, and pressure, olecranon bursitis can be caused by septic bursitis or by underlying inflammatory conditions of the joint space (e.g. gout or osteoarthritis). If these are a concern, a bursal aspiration and analysis should be performed.  

Option Analysis

❌ Triceps tendinopathy:
Incorrect: Triceps tendinopathy results from repetitive elbow extension against resistance. Patients typically report pain at the posterior elbow with resisted elbow extension and tenderness at the triceps insertion at the olecranon. Swelling at the elbow would not be consistent with triceps tendinopathy.   
❌ Distal biceps tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Distal biceps tendon rupture presents following forceful lifting with sudden pain deep in the antecubital fossa. Physical examination often reveals tenderness over the radial tubercle and pain aggravated with resisted flexion and supination of the forearm. There can be swelling at the anterior elbow and a bulge can be seen or palpated at the upper arm which is the recoiled biceps muscle. However, posterior elbow swelling is not seen and is suggestive of olecranon bursitis.  
❌ Medial epicondylitis:
Incorrect: Medial epicondylitis (i.e. golfer’s elbow) is caused by overuse of the wrist, hand flexors, and forearm pronators. Patients typically present with pain over the medial epicondyle with resisted finger and wrist flexion. Posterior elbow swelling would not be expected.  
❌ Lateral epicondylitis:
Incorrect: Lateral epicondylitis (i.e. tennis elbow) is characterized by overuse of wrist extensors. It presents tenderness over the lateral epicondyle and pain with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. It does not present with posterior elbow swelling.  
✅ Olecranon bursitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to his outpatient provider to evaluate fatigue and lymphadenopathy. He states the symptoms have been ongoing for two weeks. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and has been sexually active with multiple female partners. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination reveals enlargement of cervical, supraclavicular, and inguinal lymph nodes. The tonsils appear erythematous, but no exudate is present. Subsequent testing reveals the presence of p24 antigens and anti-HIV antibodies. The patient is started on several antiviral drugs, one of which may cause side effects, including fat redistribution, hyperlipidemia, and hyperglycemia. Which of the following viral proteins is most likely targeted by this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lymphadenopathy, fatigue, fever, and sore throat. Laboratory testing reveals the presence of HIV antigens and anti-HIV antibodies. The patient was likely started on a protease inhibitor as part of her treatment regimen.

Protease inhibitors (e.g., darunavir, indinavir, ritonavir) can be used to treat HIV infection. These medications bind and inhibit HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing the Gag-Pol polyproteins into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication. Protease inhibitors are rarely used alone since HIV quickly develops resistance via point mutations of the pol gene, which is the gene that encodes HIV-1 protease. Typically, protease inhibitors are used as a part of the highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) combined with other drugs.

The most common side effects of protease inhibitors include gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, nausea, vomiting) and metabolic disorders (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia). These metabolic disorders are often followed by lipodystrophy. Lipodystrophy is characterized by abnormal accumulation of fat tissue in the abdomen, breasts (in women), and over the cervical vertebrae and loss of fat in the extremities and face.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nonstructural protein 5A:
Incorrect: Nonstructural protein 5A (NS5A) is found in the hepatitis C virus (HCV) and assists with viral RNA replication. This protein is targeted by medications such as ledipasvir, elbasvir, and daclatasvir. In contrast, these medications would be ineffective in treating infection by HIV, which lacks the NS5A protein.  
✅ Protease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Integrase:
Incorrect: Integrase inhibitors (e.g., raltegravir, dolutegravir) prevent viral DNA from integrating with the host’s DNA, impairing viral replication. These medications can cause elevated creatinine kinase, myopathy, and insomnia as side effects. However, integrase inhibitors would not typically cause fat redistribution, hyperglycemia, or hyperlipidemia.  
❌ Glycoprotein 41:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide is a fusion inhibitor that binds viral glycoprotein 41 (gp41) and prevents the virus from fusing with CD4 T-cells. Enfuvirtide may lead to injection site reactions but would not cause fat redistribution, hyperglycemia, or hyperlipidemia.  
❌ DNA polymerase:
Incorrect: A wide variety of antivirals, such as cidofovir, foscarnet, and acyclovir, work by inhibiting viral DNA polymerase and preventing viral replication. However, HIV does not have a DNA polymerase. As a result, these medications would be ineffective in treating HIV infection.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after an episode of hematemesis. The patient was at home watching television when she suddenly felt nauseous and subsequently vomited bright red blood. Past medical history is notable for atrial fibrillation diagnosed two years ago. She has been taking metoprolol and warfarin. In addition, she was diagnosed with HIV four months ago, for which she has been prescribed ritonavir. She does not use alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drugs. She had been sexually active with multiple partners before her HIV diagnosis. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 115/63 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. Physical examination reveals dried blood in the oropharynx. Multiple bruises are present over the upper and lower extremities. Abdominal examination reveals no focal tenderness or hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing is compared with results from a prior visit four months earlier. The results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s current symptoms?  

Laboratory Value   
Results (today’s visit)   
Results (4 months ago)   
Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL (1.88 mmol/L)  
10.8 g/dL (1.63 mmol/L)  
Platelet Count
250,000/mm3 (250*109/L)
220,000/mm3 (220*109/L)
Prothrombin Time (PT)
48 seconds  
28 seconds  
International Normalized Ratio (INR)  
4.5  
2.3

choices.text: Rupture of dilated veins within the esophagus
Invasion of the esophageal wall by opportunistic pathogens
Poor compliance with prescribed medication regimen

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hematemesis, skin bruising, and a markedly elevated PT/INR following initiation of ritonavir therapy. Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor that can be used to treat HIV infection. The drug binds and inhibits HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing Gag-Pol polyproteins into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication.

One notable side effect of ritonavir is that it inhibits cytochrome P450. Cytochrome P450 is an enzyme found in the liver responsible for the metabolism of many medications, including warfarin, antiepileptics, statins, and oral contraceptives. As a result, ritonavir can lead to impaired clearance and increased serum concentration of the medications mentioned above. In the case of warfarin, elevated plasma levels can lead to elevated coagulation parameters and an increased risk for bleeding.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Rupture of dilated veins within the esophagus:
Incorrect: An esophageal variceal bleed can manifest with hematemesis. Esophageal varices typically develop in the setting of portal hypertension, which leads to the formation of collateral venous circulation and esophageal vein dilation. In contrast, this patient lacks findings suggestive of underlying portal hypertension or liver disease (e.g., jaundice, ascites, hepatosplenomegaly).  
✅ Impaired hepatic metabolism of medications:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Invasion of the esophageal wall by opportunistic pathogens:
Incorrect: Esophagitis caused by opportunistic pathogens (e.g., Candida albicans, cytomegalovirus) can cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and chest pain. In rare cases, these conditions can also cause hematemesis. However, esophagitis would not account for the elevation in PT/INR between the patient’s prior and current visit.  
❌ Poor compliance with prescribed medication regimen:
Incorrect: This patient’s INR was initially within the target range (2.0-3.0) but became markedly elevated after initiating ritonavir. Ritonavir can inhibit cytochrome P450 and impair warfarin metabolism. As a result, drug-drug interaction, as opposed to medication noncompliance, is the most likely cause of this patient’s elevated PT/INR and bleeding episode.  
❌ Reduced renal clearance of anticoagulants:
Incorrect: This patient’s INR was initially within the target range (2.0-3.0) but became markedly elevated after initiating ritonavir. Ritonavir can inhibit cytochrome P450 and impair warfarin metabolism. As a result, a decrease in hepatic metabolism, as opposed to a decrease in renal clearance, is most likely responsible for this patient’s elevated PT/INR and bleeding episode.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency room after being in close contact with an individual diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. The patient is a graduate student and lives in an apartment with several roommates. One of the roommates had recently fallen ill and was diagnosed with Neisseria meningitidis infection earlier today. The patient is currently asymptomatic but is worried he may have been exposed to the pathogen. His past medical history is notable for HIV infection, for which he currently takes lamivudine, lopinavir, and abacavir. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 119/72 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Physical examination is unremarkable, and no nuchal rigidity is present. The patient’s most recent CD4 cell count is 700/mm3. Which of the following medications should be administered for post-exposure prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
This patient requires post-exposure meningococcal prophylaxis. However, he is also taking several medications, including the protease inhibitor lopinavir, to treat HIV infection. While rifampin is often used for meningococcal prophylaxis, the medication can induce cytochrome P450 activity and cause the serum concentration of protease inhibitors (and other medications metabolized by cytochrome P450) to fall below therapeutic levels. As a result, patients with protease inhibitors should not be administered rifampin.

In the case of meningococcal prophylaxis, an alternative agent such as ceftriaxone or ciprofloxacin should be given since they are not known to induce cytochrome P450 activity. Furthermore, in the case of Mycobacterium tuberculosis treatment, rifabutin can be administered as an alternative to rifamycin.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: Rifampin can be used for post-exposure prophylaxis in close contact with individuals with meningococcal infection. However, rifampin induces cytochrome P450 and increases the metabolism of other medications. In this patient's case, rifampin may increase lopinavir (protease inhibitor) metabolism and cause serum concentrations to fall below therapeutic levels.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: This individual has been in close contact with someone diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis and requires post-exposure prophylaxis. Azithromycin is a second-line prophylaxis agent and is generally administered to patients who cannot tolerate first-line agents (e.g., rifampin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin).  
✅ Ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rifabutin:
Incorrect: Rifabutin is part of the rifamycin antibiotic group. It can treat tuberculosis and prevent and treat Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection. However, rifabutin is ineffective in providing prophylaxis against Neisseria meningitidis and would not address the patient’s primary concern.  
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) can provide prophylaxis against opportunistic pathogens like Pneumocystis jiroveci and Toxoplasma gondii. However, TMP-SMX is largely ineffective in providing prophylaxis against Neisseria meningitidis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to high blood pressure and the right upper extremity numbness. She has measured her blood pressure at home several times, with the highest recorded value at 194/92 mmHg. She does not have a prior history of hypertension. Medical history is notable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and 20-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 202/86 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Neurological examination is notable for a diminished sensation of the right upper extremity. Faint end-expiratory wheezing is heard on lung auscultation. She is given a medication that has both ɑ- and ꞵ-blocking effects. Which of the following medications was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe hypertension and a focal neurologic deficit, which is concerning for a hypertensive emergency. The patient is subsequently started on a rapid blood pressure reduction medication that has both ɑ- and ꞵ-blocking effects. Among the answer choices, labetalol exhibits these properties.

ꞵ-blocking agents have a variety of effects, including ꞵ-receptor selectivity versus non-selectivity, as well as ɑ-receptor selectivity. The ꞵ-blockers that fall into each of these categories are listed above.

Non-selective ɑ- and ꞵ-blockers (e.g., carvedilol, labetalol) have antagonistic effects at both ɑ- and ꞵ-receptors. The ɑ-blocking properties of these drugs make them potent vasodilators, whereas the ꞵ-blocking properties lead to decreased heart rate and contractility. This combination of effects makes non-selective ɑ- and ꞵ-blockers ideal drugs for the rapid treatment of hypertension.  

Option Analysis

✅ Labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem works by blocking calcium channels and inducing vasodilation. It does not have ɑ- or ꞵ-blocking effects.  
❌ Phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Pure ɑ-agonists, such as phenylephrine, will result in systemic vasoconstriction and increase the patient’s blood pressure.  
❌ Albuterol:
Incorrect: ꞵ-agonists such as albuterol will induce both increased heart rate and bronchodilation.  
❌ Esmolol:
Incorrect: Selective ꞵ-blockers such as acebutolol, atenolol, betaxolol, bisoprolol, esmolol, and  metoprolol preferentially affect ꞵ1-receptors, resulting in decreased heart rate and cardiac contractility. However, these agents do not exhibit ɑ-blocking effects.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic to evaluate shortness of breath and increased swelling of the lower extremities. He states, “I get so winded after only walking half a city block now that I think my heart failure is worsening.” Past medical history is notable for heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. The patient’s medications include atorvastatin, metformin, metoprolol, rivaroxaban, aspirin, and lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 64/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 174/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100%.  A beta-blockers examination is notable for bibasilar rales and 3+ pitting edema of the lower extremities.  The patient is subsequently administered a medication that decreases cardiac contractility and increases the release of nitric oxide in the vasculature. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings suggestive of worsening heart failure. He is started on a medication that decreases cardiac contractility and increases the release of nitric oxide in the vasculature. He was most likely prescribed nebivolol.

Third-generation β-blockers such as carvedilol, labetalol, and nebivolol carry more than their typical β-blocking effects (e.g., decreased heart rate, decreased cardiac contractility). For instance, nebivolol has β1-blocking properties, which results in decreased cardiac contractility, and β3-receptor agonism properties. The latter results in nitric oxide synthase activation in the vasculature and a subsequent decrease in systemic vascular resistance.

On the other hand, Carvedilol and labetalol have not only β-blocking effects and some α-blocking effects, which lead to vasodilation. This combination makes these drugs exceptionally useful in acute hypertension management and the treatment of heart failure or myocardial infarction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nebivolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Esmolol:
Incorrect: Selective β-blockers such as acebutolol, atenolol, betaxolol, bisoprolol, esmolol, and  metoprolol preferentially affect β1-receptors, resulting in decreased heart rate and cardiac contractility. However, since these medications do not stimulate β3-receptors, they would not induce nitric oxide release.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a non-selective β-antagonist. It does have agonistic effects on β3-receptors and would not induce nitric oxide release.  
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem causes vasodilation via calcium channel blockade, not nitric oxide release.  
❌ Epinephrine:
Incorrect: Epinephrine is a non-selective β-agonist, which results in increased cardiac contractility and peripheral vasoconstriction.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department with status epilepticus. Per paramedics, the patient was found seizing in a nearby park. His only belongings are a wallet and an identification card. The patient’s past medical history reveals polysubstance use, depression, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 196/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. During the physical examination, the patient is actively seizing. A white powder is noted in the patient’s bilateral nares. Subsequently, he is given 2 mg of intravenous lorazepam, which terminates the seizure activity. An electrocardiogram is obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in treating this patient’s clinical condition?
 

 Image reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents in status epilepticus with evidence of recent cocaine use. His electrocardiogram demonstrates inferolateral ST-depressions, which concern myocardial ischemia. In this clinical setting, the administration of β-blockers is contraindicated due to the potential for unopposed ɑ-adrenergic stimulation and further exacerbation of coronary vasospasm.

β-blockers, including medications such as metoprolol, carvedilol, atenolol, and esmolol, are frequently used to treat hypertensive emergencies, supraventricular tachycardias, and heart failure. However, β-blocker administration must be carefully considered when evidence of cardiac ischemia and associated cocaine use. This precaution is due to theoretical concerns of coronary artery vasoconstriction and systemic hypertension secondary to unopposed α-adrenergic stimulation.

Care must also be taken when administering β-blocking medications to patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) since β2-blockade on respiratory tract smooth muscles can lead to bronchoconstriction. Additional caution should be taken when administering these medications to patients with cardiovascular instability involving bradycardia or hypotension, as β-blockers can worsen these symptoms and potentially lead to heart block or heart failure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Metoprolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: This patient has markedly elevated blood pressures and an electrocardiogram demonstrating inferolateral ST-depressions, suggestive of myocardial ischemia. Nitroglycerin is a potent vasodilator that can manage hypertensive emergencies, acute coronary syndromes, and acute congestive heart failure.  
❌ Phentolamine:
Incorrect: Phentolamine is a pure α-antagonist. The medication is often used to treat demand ischemia and hypertensive emergency secondary to cocaine ingestion.  
❌ Diazepam:
Incorrect: Diazepam is an appropriate medication to administer to this patient given this patient’s recent seizure and concern for an adrenergic surge.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: This patient has markedly elevated blood pressures and an electrocardiogram demonstrating inferolateral ST-depressions, suggestive of myocardial ischemia. There are no factors in this patient’s history that would preclude aspirin administration.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a new rash on her left thigh. The rash developed three days ago and has been slowly enlarging since then. She recently went camping in the Appalachian Mountains and removed a tick from the area about five days ago. The patient has been experiencing fatigue, a mild fever, and myalgia on review of systems. She is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Physical examination is notable for a large bright red targetoid lesion on the left thigh. She is prescribed an oral antibiotic to take for three weeks. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the first-line antibiotic treatment for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Binding of D-ala D-ala in cell wall precursors
Inhibition of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome
Binding to phospholipids on the bacterial cell membrane

questions.solution:
After hiking in the Appalachian mountains, this patient presents with a targetoid rash and flu-like symptoms. This infection is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through the Ixodes scapularis tick. Infection occurs in the New England and mid-Atlantic regions of the United States.

Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic antibiotics. The first-line treatment for Lyme disease is doxycycline, a tetracycline antibiotic that inhibits the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, thereby preventing the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA. Other examples of tetracyclines include minocycline and tigecycline.

Apart from treating Lyme disease, tetracyclines are also used to treat infections caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Rickettsia rickettsii, Chlamydia species, and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

The most common adverse effects include gastrointestinal distress, photosensitivity, tinnitus, and hepatotoxicity. Tetracyclines can also accumulate in the teeth and bones, causing discoloration of the teeth and inhibition of bone growth. As a result, they are contraindicated in pregnancy, women who are breastfeeding, and children less than 8-years-old. Finally, they should not be taken with milk, antacids, or iron-containing preparations as they contain divalent cations (calcium, magnesium) that can inhibit the absorption of tetracyclines in the gut.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones. They are a class of bactericidal antibiotics that are most effective against Gram-negative bacteria in the genitourinary and gastrointestinal tracts, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and some Gram-positive bacteria. However, fluoroquinolones are not the first-line antibiotic for treating Lyme disease.  
❌ Formation of toxic free radicals:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of metronidazole. It is used to treat infections caused by Giardia lamblia, Entamoeba histolytica, Gardnerella vaginalis, Bacteroides species, and Clostridium difficile. However, fluoroquinolones are not used in the treatment of Lyme disease.  
❌ Binding of D-ala D-ala in cell wall precursors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Vancomycin is used to treat multidrug-resistant severe infections with Gram-positive bacteria, but not Lyme disease caused by Boreilla burdefori.  
✅ Inhibition of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Binding to phospholipids on the bacterial cell membrane:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of polymyxins. They disrupt cell membrane integrity, causing leakage of cellular components and cell death. They are used as salvage therapy in multidrug-resistant Gram-positive infections. They are not used in the treatment of Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department with discharge from an ulcer on the left foot. He has had the ulcer for nearly a year. However, the ulcer started giving off copious white discharge over the past few days. There has also been some pain and increasing redness around the area. Past medical history is significant for poorly-controlled type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and insulin. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 117/84 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Physical examination reveals a well-demarcated ulcer with a tender erythematous border and a sizeable purulent discharge on the left foot. Foot radiography does not show evidence of osteomyelitis. Wound cultures grow methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Blood cultures are negative. He is started on vancomycin and linezolid but fails to show improvement. He is subsequently started on tigecycline. What is the most likely adverse effect this patient will experience with tigecycline?
questions.solution:
Tigecycline antibiotics are tetracycline derivatives developed to overcome traditional tetracycline resistance. Tigecycline can treat multidrug-resistant bacteria such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. It binds to the 30S bacterial ribosomal subunit to inhibit protein synthesis.

Its side effects are similar to tetracycline antibiotics and include nausea and vomiting, headache, photosensitivity, and tooth discoloration. Moreover, there has been an increased risk of death associated with tigecycline use. As a result, it should only be used when there are no alternative treatments.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nausea and vomiting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral motor neuropathy:
Incorrect: This adverse effect can be seen with dapsone therapy. This antibiotic inhibits dihydropteroate synthase and is used to treat leprosy and Pneumocystis jiroveci prophylaxis.  
❌ Orange discoloration of urine:
Incorrect: This adverse effect can be seen with rifampin therapy. The drug inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase and is used for tuberculosis and leprosy treatment.  
❌ Vitamin B6 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B6 deficiency is a significant adverse effect caused by isoniazid. The drug inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acids and is used to treat tuberculosis. Isoniazid should be administered with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to prevent peripheral neuropathy and sideroblastic anemia.  
❌ Disulfiram-like reaction:
Incorrect: This side effect is most commonly seen with drugs such as metronidazole, griseofulvin, sulfonylureas, procarbazine, and certain cephalosporins are taken with alcohol. A disulfiram-like reaction can present with severe flushing, tachycardia, and hypotension.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the office for HIV testing. He recently learned that a previous sexual partner has tested positive for HIV infection. The patient is feeling well and has no acute symptoms. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies and asthma. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. An HIV screening test and confirmatory test are both positive, and the physician informs the patient that he should be started on a multidrug antiretroviral therapy that includes lamivudine. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of lamivudine?

choices.text: Prevents complementary DNA synthesis from RNA template
Inhibits cleavage of viral polyprotein precursors
Inhibits viral genome integration into host cell
Prevents entry of viral core into host cytoplasm
Inhibits attachment of the virus to target cell surface

questions.solution:
Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV infection. This class of medication is an essential component of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

NRTIs are prodrugs converted by host cell kinases to triphosphates. They inhibit nucleotide-binding from reversing transcriptase and terminating DNA chain elongation, given the NRTI molecules lack a 3′-OH group. NRTIs have no effect on completed proviral DNA already incorporated into CD4+ cells, and as a result, cells that are already infected remain infected. Therefore, NRTIs can only slow down the progression of the disease but not cure it. Examples of NRTIs include zidovudine, stavudine, lamivudine, didanosine, abacavir, and tenofovir.

Apart from being used in HAART, NRTIs can also be used in children born to mothers infected by HIV to reduce the risk of vertical transmission. Moreover, lamivudine can be used in the treatment of hepatitis B infection.

Side effects of NRTIs include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain), bone marrow suppression, central nervous system toxicity (e.g., insomnia, headache, and peripheral neuropathy), and metabolic effects (e.g. lactic acidosis). In addition, abacavir can sometimes lead to fatal hypersensitivity reactions, whereas didanosine can cause pancreatitis.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Prevents complementary DNA synthesis from RNA template:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits cleavage of viral polyprotein precursors:
Incorrect: Protease is an HIV enzyme that cleaves the polypeptide products of HIV mRNA into their functional parts. This enzyme is inhibited by protease inhibitors (e.g., ritonavir, indinavir).  
❌ Inhibits viral genome integration into host cell:
Incorrect: Integrase is an enzyme produced by HIV that incorporates the viral genome into host chromosomes. Integrase inhibitors (e.g. raltegravir) reversibly inhibit HIV integrase.  
❌ Prevents entry of viral core into host cytoplasm:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide is an antiviral fusion inhibitor that blocks viral attachment, penetration, and uncoating. It binds to the gp41 subunit of the HIV envelope glycoprotein, thereby preventing conformational changes and subsequent fusing of the virus with T-cells.  
❌ Inhibits attachment of the virus to target cell surface:
Incorrect: gp120 facilitates HIV attachment to the host cell by binding CD4 receptor and chemokine coreceptor CCR-5.  Maraviroc binds CCR-5 on the surface of T-cells/monocytes, thereby inhibiting interaction with gp120.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of severe diarrhea for the past three days. Diarrhea developed suddenly, is non-bloody, and has not been associated with abdominal pain.
