Incorrect: Transdermal nitroglycerin patches are used for long-term prevention (not acute treatment) of angina in patients with coronary artery disease.  
❌ Intravenous nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: Intravenous nitroglycerin is indicated in patients with angina pectoris who do not respond adequately to sublingual nitroglycerin. It is not the first line for the management of acute angina episodes.  
❌ Pentaerithrityl tetranitrate:
Incorrect: Pentaerithrityl tetranitrate is a long-acting nitrate used in patients with chronic stable angina mainly because it does not induce the development of nitrate tolerance. It, however, is not commonly recommended to treat an acute episode of angina.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chest pain that started an hour ago while shoveling the snow. He describes it as a crushing pain that radiates down his left arm and rates it as a seven on a -point scale. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily, drinks 5-6 beers on weekends, and does not use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.33°C (99.2°F), pulse is 115/minute, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/58 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and cardiac examination shows no murmurs. A 12-lead ECG is shown below. Which of the following medications, if administered, is most likely to result in severe complications in this patient?  


Reproduced fromWikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation with typical angina, hypotension, and the ECG findings of ST-elevation in lead II, III, and aVF suggest an inferior wall myocardial infarction usually involving the right ventricle. Since the functioning of the right ventricle is dependent on preload to maintain cardiac output, treatment includes maintenance of preload, reduction of afterload, inotropic support (if needed), and prompt reperfusion. Nitrates act by decreasing the cardiac preload by venodilation and a minor decrease in afterload by vasodilation of arterial beds. This is achieved by promoting the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), which causes smooth muscle relaxation via protein kinase G. Its use in patients with right ventricular infarction can result in severe hypotension, leading to decreased coronary artery perfusion and worsening ischemia and is therefore contraindicated. Moreover, this patient has a history of hypertension and may have a systolic blood pressure of ≥30 mmHg below his baseline, which is another contraindication to nitrates use.  

Other contraindications to nitrates include bradycardia, aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (due to increased outflow obstruction), and a combination with PDE inhibitors (potentiates the hypotension). Common side effects include flushing, headache, orthostatic hypotension, and reflex tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: The antiplatelet effects of aspirin are significant in patients with ACS. Chewable aspirin (325 mg) should be administered as part of initial management in all suspected myocardial infarction (MI) patients.  
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: Patients with ACS should receive dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel (or ticagrelor) before reperfusion therapy with either primary percutaneous intervention (PCI) or fibrinolytic therapy.  
❌ Enoxaparin:
Incorrect: Enoxaparin, low molecular weight heparin, is indicated in ACS to prevent intraluminal clot extension, formation, and re-infarction. It should be avoided in patients with contraindication to anticoagulants (history of cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, intracranial neoplasm, recent (within past six months) thromboembolic stroke).  
❌ Fentanyl:
Incorrect: Adequate analgesia is vital for managing pain and anxiety (with resultant tachycardia).  
✅ Nitroglycerin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up appointment. The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 7 years ago and follows a strict glucose control diet. He has no active complaints. Past medical history is otherwise noncontributory. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 148/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows decreased lower-extremity sensations during a monofilament test. Laboratory evaluation reveals increased urinary albumin and a serum creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. His most recent HbA1c was 7.1%. The patient is started on an antihypertensive agent. This new medication likely provides benefit by blocking the formation of what hormone?
questions.solution:
This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by neuropathy (decreased lower extremity sensations) and nephropathy (albuminuria). The progression of diabetic nephropathy can be reduced by glycemic and blood pressure control. Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors play an important role in slowing the progression.  

ACE is responsible for activating angiotensin I to angiotensin II and for inactivating bradykinin, a vasodilator normally present in very low concentrations. ACE inhibitors (ACEI) such as captopril, enalapril, or lisinopril, inhibit the action of ACE and prevent the formation of angiotensin II, thereby lessening systemic vasoconstriction. In addition, they lower aldosterone release (which subsequently results in natriuresis) and cause an increase in endogenous vasodilators of the kinin family (bradykinin).    

ACEI is  indicated in the management of hypertension, heart failure, and diabetic nephropathy (by reducing the glomerular filtration pressure). It should also be given right after an acute myocardial infarction to increase the perfusion of the heart to prevent further ischemic damage.    

Side effects include dry cough and angioedema (due to bradykinin accumulation), hypotension, and hyperkalemia (due to less circulating aldosterone). It is excreted renally so care should be taken in patients with renal impairment.  



Option Analysis

❌ Bradykinin:
Incorrect: Degradation of bradykinin is mediated by kininases. ACE, which plays a role in the degradation of bradykinin, can be inhibited by ACE inhibitors and would increase the serum levels of bradykinin.  
✅ Angiotensin II:
Correct: See Main Examination.
❌ Endothelin:
Incorrect: Endothelin-receptor antagonists (e.g., bosentan and ambrisentan) can help improve symptoms in patients with pulmonary hypertension.  
❌ Substance P:
Incorrect: Aprepitant is an oral antagonist at NK1 (substance P) receptors and is approved for use in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. It has no role in systemic hypertension.  
❌ Vasopressin:
Incorrect: The presser effects of vasopressin are mediated by V1a receptors, whereas V2 receptors are responsible for the antidiuretic action. Conivaptan, a V1a and V2 antagonist, is approved for use in hyponatremia. It has no role in systemic hypertension.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a dry, nagging cough. He does not have chest pain or shortness of breath. The rest of the review of systems is within normal limits. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, and hypertension. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/85 mmHg. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Laboratory results show a serum creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL and potassium of 4.9 mEq/L. Chest x-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
This patient’s dry nagging cough is most likely a side effect of lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.  

The cough usually begins within one to two weeks of instituting therapy, but it can be delayed by up to six months. It is thought to result from increased local concentrations of kinins, the substance P, and prostaglandins. Inhibition of bradykinin and substance P breakdown by ACEI results in their increased concentration, which may induce bronchial irritation and cough via enhanced production of prostaglandins. Moreover, ACE inhibition may also activate the arachidonic pathway, which leads to elevated levels of thromboxane, potentiating bronchoconstriction.    

Treatment includes replacing ACE inhibitors with angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), which does not affect bradykinin levels and does not cause cough.  

Option Analysis

❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can increase the excretion of potassium in the urine, leading to hypokalemia (in contrast to hyperkalemia in this patient). Moreover, it does not cause a dry cough.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: Metformin increases insulin sensitivity in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and does not cause cough or hyperkalemia.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can cause pulmonary fibrosis, which may present with cough. This patient’s chest x-ray is normal.  
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Although digoxin may cause hyperkalemia, it is unlikely to cause dry cough as a side effect.  
✅ Lisinopril:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services after being found on the ground. The patient was walking outside this morning without adequate clothing and did not remember anything until she woke up in an ambulance. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 85 ºF (29.4 ºC), pulse is 42/min, respiratory rate is 10/min, blood pressure is 98/53 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic but answers orientation questions appropriately when awoken. The patient is shivering, and the skin is cold. There are no abnormal heart or lung sounds on auscultation. Serum creatinine is 2.3 mg/dL (1.0 mg/dL two years ago). Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with moderate hypothermia (temperature between 82-90 ºF, or 28-32 ºC) with the expected signs of bradycardia, hypoventilation, and decreased mentation. Treatment for moderate hypothermia, as seen in this case, should include supportive care, external rewarming, and internal rewarming with warmed IV fluids.

Hypothermia is defined as a core temperature < 95 ºF (35 ºC). It can be caused by some medical conditions (e.g., myxedema coma, sepsis) but usually occurs due to prolonged exposure to cold. The most common risk factors include excessive alcohol use (inebriation and poor perception of temperature), older age (dysfunctional thermal regulation), homelessness, and psychiatric conditions. Patients will present with shivering, altered respiratory rates (hyper- or hypoventilation), and frequent alterations in mental status. Bradycardia is very common and can be related to sinus bradycardia, junctional arrhythmias, atrioventricular block, or other arrhythmias. Electrocardiographic abnormalities, such as J waves (prominent convex deflections at the J point) may also be present.

Hypothermia can be classified as mild (90-95 ºF, or 32-35 ºC), moderate (82-90 ºF, or 28-32 ºC), or severe (< 82 ºF, or < 28 ºC). Treatment centers around providing supportive care, warming the patient, and treating any complications. External rewarming (e.g. heating blankets) should be initiated immediately. Internal rewarming (e.g. warmed IV fluids) should be provided for moderate and severe hypothermia. Patients with severe and/or refractory hypothermia may need extracorporeal life support to provide more active rewarming.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer warmed IV fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer room temperature IV fluids:
Incorrect: This intervention would be appropriate for initial resuscitation for patients with mild hypothermia who respond well to external rewarming measures. This patient has moderate hypothermia and should undergo internal warming.  
❌ Initiate extracorporeal membrane oxygenation:
Incorrect: This intervention would be appropriate for severe hypothermia if there is hemodynamic instability or cardiac arrest. Warmed IV fluids are more appropriate at this time.  
❌ Initiate hemodialysis with warmed fluids:
Incorrect: This intervention would be appropriate for severe hypothermia unresponsive to other measures, especially if associated with severe acute kidney injury. This patient’s kidney injury is mild, and warmed IV fluids are more appropriate at this time.  
❌ Provide a warm blanket:
Incorrect: This intervention would be appropriate for initial management of patients with mild hypothermia. This patient has moderate hypothermia and should undergo internal warming, as well.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after his partner found him at home lethargic and confused. His partner states that over the last week, he has been easily agitated, forgetting simple tasks, and sleeping during the day.  He told his partner he was feeling nauseous. His partner states he has a substance use disorder and uses IV drugs. He has no significant medical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mmHg. On exam, he is somnolent but arousable to sound and is able to follow commands. Eye exam shows scleral icterus without papilledema and with a normal pupillary exam  Abdominal tenderness is present in the right upper quadrant. Flapping is noted when he extends his arms and cocks his hands back. Head CT is normal and toxicology screen is negative. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
AST
967 units/L
ALT
1,132 units/L
Total bilirubin
7.3 mg/dL
INR
1.9
Anti-HBc IgM
+
HBsAg
-
HBsAb
-
questions.solution:
This patient’s altered mental status and asterixis in conjunction with abnormal AST/ALT and liver function tests is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy, which is a life-threatening brain disorder caused by liver disease.  The laboratory and exam findings are consistent with acute hepatitis B infection (HBV) during the window period where Hepatitis B surface antibody and antigen are negative, but IgM antibodies to core antigen are positive.  When acute Hepatitis B infection has progressed to this severity, options for definitive treatment are limited, and surgical consultation for liver transplant should be obtained urgently as patients can rapidly deteriorate.

Hepatitis B infection is a blood-borne viral infection that can present during the acute stage on a continuum from asymptomatic disease to fulminant hepatic failure.  Early disease presents with generalized symptoms of fatigue, nausea, sleep disturbances, and behavioral changes, with or without right upper quadrant abdominal pain, pruritus, and jaundice.  Hallmarks of fulminant hepatic failure include altered mental status, asterixis, ascites, GI bleeding, and cerebral edema.  Laboratory results in severe disease typically include extreme elevations of liver transaminases, coagulopathy with an INR ≥ 1.5, and elevated bilirubin.

The first priority in treating patients with acute hepatitis B infection and fulminant liver failure is to stabilize the patient, obtain IV access, and arrange for close monitoring with frequent checks of vital signs.  Antiviral therapies will not eradicate the virus but may help reduce viral replication and reduce the likelihood of progression to chronic infection.  They are typically prescribed in cases of severe disease or protracted illness from acute hepatitis B infection. Most cases of acute HBV infection will resolve spontaneously with supportive measures only, but severe disease with fulminant liver failure has a high mortality rate without liver transplantation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical consultation for liver transplant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surgical consultation for VP shunt:
Incorrect:  Shunting fluid from the brain to the abdomen is a treatment for cerebral edema.  This patient has no papilledema and a normal head CT. Given his lab results, he likely has acute Hepatitis B infection with hepatic encephalopathy.  
❌ Administration of zidovudine:
Incorrect: Zidovudine is used to treat HIV, it is not used in the management of acute hepatitis B infection and fulminant liver failure and could contribute to liver damage.  
❌ Administration of interferon-⍺:
Incorrect: Pegylated interferon can be used to treat young patients with well-compensated liver disease from chronic Hepatitis B who do not want to be on long-term treatment. It is not a treatment for fulminant hepatic failure and hepatic encephalopathy.  
❌ Administration of naloxone:
Incorrect:  Naloxone reverses opiate overdoses, however, this patient does not have miotic pupils, is arousable and able to follow commands, and is breathing on his own.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain. His symptoms started four months ago. He has not seen any blood in his stool. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. He follows a balanced diet but has stopped consuming milk as it exacerbates the symptoms. He has not experienced any changes in weight or appetite. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following disease processes most likely explains this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Presence of unabsorbed solutes in the intestines
Secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen
Inflammation of the intestinal wall with granuloma formation
Bacterial invasion of the intestinal wall with inflammatory cell infiltration

questions.solution:
This patient presents with crampy abdominal pain and intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is exacerbated by consuming lactose containing foods. These findings are suggestive of lactose intolerance, which is a type of osmotic diarrhea. Affected patients lack the enzyme lactase. As a result, lactose cannot be broken down and remains in the intestinal lumen, where it is osmotically active and prevents water absorption by the intestines.

Osmotic diarrhea occurs due to the presence of unabsorbed solutes (e.g. lactose) in the intestinal lumen. These unabsorbed solutes exert an osmotic power, trapping water in the lumen as well as drawing water into the lumen. Osmotic diarrhea is watery, non-bloody, and typically resolves when the causative substance (e.g., food, medication) is discontinued.

Another type of diarrhea is secretory diarrhea, which can occur in certain infections (e.g. Vibrio cholera) and some gastrointestinal disorders (e.g. VIPoma). It results from excessive secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen, which exerts an osmotic effect and sucks fluid from the surrounding tissues into the intestinal lumen. Secretory diarrhea is also watery, and non-bloody, but unlike osmotic diarrhea, persists even with decreased oral intake.

Moreover, there is inflammatory (exudative) diarrhea. This type of diarrhea is typically seen in patients with certain autoimmune disorders (e.g. inflammatory bowel disease) or bacterial (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni) invasion of the intestinal wall. These conditions lead to an inflammatory process that damages the intestinal epithelium. The diarrhea is usually purulent, bloody, and persists during fasting. Systemic symptoms such as fever, tachycardia, and weight loss may also be seen.

Finally, diarrhea can occur due to increased gastrointestinal motility, which causes water and nutrients to reach the colon too fast without adequate time for proper digestion and absorption. Potential etiologies include irritable bowel syndrome and hyperthyroidism.  

Option Analysis

✅ Presence of unabsorbed solutes in the intestines:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen:
Incorrect: Secretory diarrhea is due to the secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen. Examples of secretory diarrhea include infections (e.g. Vibrio cholera) as well as other conditions such as VIPoma. In contrast, this patient has intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is associated with milk ingestion, which is more suggestive of lactose intolerance.  
❌ Inflammation of the intestinal wall with granuloma formation:
Incorrect: Crohn disease is characterized by intestinal wall inflammation and granuloma formation. It is associated with inflammatory diarrhea that is often purulent and bloody. In contrast, this patient has intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is associated with milk ingestion, which is more suggestive of lactose intolerance.  
❌ Bacterial invasion of the intestinal wall with inflammatory cell infiltration:
Incorrect: Certain bacteria (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, Shigella species) invade and destroy the epithelial lining of the intestinal wall and induce an inflammatory response. Bacterial infection typically presents acutely with bloody diarrhea and systemic manifestations (e.g. fever, chills). In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are suggestive of another underlying etiology.  
❌ Deficiency in pancreatic digestive enzymes:
Incorrect: Chronic pancreatitis and resulting pancreatic enzyme insufficiency leads to fat malabsorption and steatorrhea. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with lactose intolerance, which is due to a deficiency of the brush border enzyme lactase.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the doctor for evaluation of diarrhea and abdominal cramps. His symptoms started yesterday, after he returned from a one week trip to Haiti. In the last 24 hours, the patient has had 2 watery stools. He also experienced a decrease in appetite and has felt nauseous. Past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination is normal. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. The patient requests medication that will help reduce his diarrhea. He is prescribed a medication that has anti-secretory, anti-inflammatory, as well as antimicrobial effects and is also used in the treatment of acid reflux. Which of the following side effects is most likely associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is suggestive of traveler’s diarrhea, which usually occurs during or shortly after a trip to resource-limited regions. It presents with diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Most cases are treated conservatively with fluid replacement. In some causes, bismuth subsalicylate, an adsorbent antidiarrheal, can also be added to the treatment regimen.

Bismuth subsalicylate’s mechanism of action is not completely understood. However, it is thought to exert antimicrobial effects by preventing bacteria from binding and proliferating on gastrointestinal mucosal surfaces. Moreover, it has anti-secretory and anti-inflammatory effects.

Apart from treating travelers' diarrhea, bismuth subsalicylate can also be used to treat dyspepsia and as part of a combination therapy to treat Helicobacter pylori infection.

The medication can cause ototoxicity and hearing loss. It can also cause the patient’s tongue and stool to turn black. Bismuth subsalicylate should be avoided in children with viral infections (e.g., influenza) since the salicylate component of the medication can potentially cause Reye syndrome.

Other adsorbents include:

- Cholestyramine: It is a resin that binds bile acids and certain toxins in the gastrointestinal tract and excretes them via feces. It is used in bile salt diarrhea, where excessive bile salts in the gastrointestinal tract stimulate ion secretion. However, cholestyramine also interferes with bile acid function to absorb fat and fat-soluble vitamins. Therefore, it can lead to fat-soluble vitamin deficiency.

- Kaolin and pectin: These two indigestible compounds are often used together. They bind bacterial toxins in the gastrointestinal tract and prevent them from affecting the gut epithelium. However, they might interfere with the absorption of other drugs that are concurrently taken.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pill induced esophagitis:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely prescribed bismuth subsalicylate, which is not associated with pill-induced esophagitis. In contrast, tetracyclines, iron, and bisphosphonates are drugs known to cause pill-induced esophagitis.  
❌ Gastric ulcer:
Incorrect: Gastric ulcers can develop as a complication of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and aspirin. Bismuth subsalicylate, on the other hand, is sometimes used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. The drug coats peptic ulcers and protects them from gastric acid, allowing the ulcer to heal.  
❌ Fat soluble vitamins deficiency:
Incorrect: Cholestyramine, an adsorbent antidiarrheal drug, is associated with fat-soluble vitamin deficiency (e.g., vitamin A,D,E, and K). Cholestyramine is used mainly to treat bile salt diarrhea, not travelers diarrhea.  
✅ Ototoxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevation of liver enzymes:
Incorrect: Bismuth subsalicylate is not associated with elevations in liver enzymes. In contrast, some medications that cause elevated liver enzyme levels include statins, fibrates, and oral contraceptives.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath, chest pain, and blue discoloration of lips. The patient reports that symptoms started a few hours after she took double the dose of the drug prescribed to her by a dermatologist for intensely pruritic erythematous papules and vesicles on elbows and knees. Past medical history is significant for celiac disease managed by strictly following a gluten-free diet. Oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry is 85% on ambient air. A 100% oxygen by nasal cannula is administered but fails to improve pulse oximetry readings or the cyanosis. Physical examination shows bluish discoloration of lips and fingertips. Results of urgent laboratory investigation are shown below. Which of the following medications most likely contributed to this patient’s condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Arterial blood gas 
 pH  7.39 
 PaO2  142 mm Hg 
 PaCO2  34 
 Oxygen saturation  99%
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from methemoglobinemia, a complication that can occur after excessive exposure to an oxidizing agent like dapsone, which this patient was prescribed for the treatment of dermatitis herpetiformis secondary to celiac disease.    

Methemoglobin is the form of hemoglobin in which the iron molecule is in the oxidized ferric (Fe3+) state rather than in the ferrous state (Fe2+). As such, the molecule itself is unable to carry oxygen or carbon dioxide. It is commonly present with cyanosis, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain, and fatigue. This patient’s symptoms are most likely due to methemoglobinemia due to dapsone hydroxylamine’s generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS).   

Like sulfonamide, dapsone is an antimetabolite that inhibits the synthesis of dihydrofolic acid by competing with para-aminobenzoic acid for the active site of dihydropteroate synthetase (but is a structurally distinct agent). It also acts as an anti-inflammatory agent by inhibiting the migration of neutrophils to areas of inflammation. It is usually indicated in the management of leprosy (often in combination with rifampicin and clofazimine), toxoplasmosis, dermatitis herpetiformis (in combination with a gluten-free diet), and for prophylaxis against pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in immunocompromised patients and Plasmodium falciparum malaria.    

Dose-related hemolysis is the most common side effect which can lead to hemolytic anemia (especially in those with G6PD deficiency) and methemoglobinemia. Other adverse effects including toxic hepatitis, cholestatic jaundice, nausea, headache, fatigue, insomnia, psychosis, and peripheral neuropathy have also been reported.  

Option Analysis

❌ Topical permethrin:
Incorrect: Topical permethrin 5% is the treatment of choice for scabies. It is intensely pruritic and affects the flexor surfaces of the wrist, lateral surfaces of the fingers, and the finger webs with small, crusted, red papules and linear burrows. Moreover, permethrin is not associated with the development of methemoglobinemia.  
❌ Oral sulfasalazine:
Incorrect: Although sulfasalazine can be used for the treatment of dermatitis herpetiformis in patients who are intolerant to dapsone, it is not associated with the development of methemoglobinemia.  
❌ Topical corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Although topical corticosteroids are used for the treatment of pruritis in dermatitis herpetiformis,  it is not associated with the development of methemoglobinemia.  
✅ Oral dapsone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Oral terbinafine:
Incorrect: Oral terbinafine is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of tinea corporis, which presents with a scaly erythematous rash with central clearing. This patient's skin condition is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a high fever, chills, headache, myalgias, and a diffuse red rash. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.5 °F), blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, heart rate is 122/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Mucous membranes appear dry, and capillary refill time is delayed. Skin exam is significant for a diffuse macular erythematous rash. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. A retained tampon is found on pelvic exam with dried blood. Laboratory findings are listed below. Blood cultures are drawn, and the patient is started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. Blood pressure remains 78/42 after initial fluid resuscitation. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory test  
Result
White blood cell count
18,000 /µL  
Platelet count  
70,000 /µL  
Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL  
AST
80 U/L  
ALT
95 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome (fever, hypotension, tachycardia, diffuse macular erythroderma, multisystem dysfunction, retained tampon). Despite appropriate fluid resuscitation, her blood pressure remains low. In this case, a vasopressor such as norepinephrine should be initiated to maintain perfusion.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a serious multisystem disease where toxin production by bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes) causes an exaggerated inflammatory response. This results in shock and organ damage. TSS may develop from skin and soft tissue infections or contaminated foreign bodies.

When TSS is suspected, an ABCDE assessment is critical as these patients are most often hemodynamically unstable. IV access should be obtained promptly, and continuous vital sign monitoring should be initiated. Patients usually need aggressive IV fluid resuscitation and vasopressors. Patients with respiratory compromise may require intubation. In addition, laboratory studies and blood cultures should be obtained. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are typically initiated, including antibiotics targeting toxin production (e.g. clindamycin, linezolid).  

Option Analysis

✅ Start norepinephrine infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pursue endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically unstable due to toxic shock syndrome. However, she does not have evidence of respiratory compromise or failure. Thus, intubation and mechanical ventilation is not warranted.  
❌ Order IV methylprednisolone and diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Antihistamines and corticosteroids would be indicated for a severe allergic reaction. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with toxic shock syndrome from an infection.  
❌ Continue IV fluid hydration:
Incorrect: While continued IV fluids may be given, this patient’s hypotension has not improved with fluid resuscitation. Therefore, a vasopressor is warranted.  
❌ Order platelet transfusion:
Incorrect: While thrombocytopenia is present, there is no evidence of active bleeding that would necessitate a platelet transfusion.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a high fever, generalized body aches, nausea, and headache. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 80/42 mmHg, heart rate is 128/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. She appears acutely ill with warm, flushed skin and the presence of a diffuse macular erythematous rash that is similar to a sunburn that is covering most of her body, including the trunk, palms, and soles. There is no nuchal rigidity, and Nikolsky sign is negative. Which of the following additional factors is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Recent antibiotic use for a urinary tract infection
Current housing in a dormitory setting

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms and physical exam findings that are consistent with toxic shock syndrome (e.g. hemodynamic instability, diffuse erythroderma). Risk factors for the disease should be assessed, including recent use of high-absorbency tampons.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a serious multisystem disease where toxin production by bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes) causes an exaggerated inflammatory response. This results in shock and organ damage. TSS may develop from skin and soft tissue infections or contaminated foreign bodies. Risk factors should be assessed upon presentation, including recent procedures or surgeries (including childbirth), cuts or abrasions, nasal packing, and use of high-absorbency tampons.

Patients with TSS often present with nonspecific symptoms, such as fever, myalgias, and headache. Gastrointestinal symptoms may also be present, such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Physical examination findings include fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. Cutaneous manifestations, such as a macular erythroderma, can be seen. Macular erythroderma is a diffuse erythematous rash covering most of the body that may involve the palms and soles, and desquamation may occur later after initial onset.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recent use of high-absorbency tampons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recent antibiotic use for a urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Steven-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis secondary to medications can present similarly; however, the rash typically spares the palms and soles. Additionally, Nikolsky sign would be expected to be positive.  
❌ Current housing in a dormitory setting:
Incorrect: While meningococcal disease would be in the differential diagnosis, her lack of nuchal rigidity makes meningitis less likely.  
❌ Recent initiation of oral contraceptives:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Oral contraceptives are not associated with this condition.  
❌ Recent hiking trip to Missouri:
Incorrect: Tick-borne illnesses, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, can present with an erythematous rash. However, the rash of RMSF is typically described as a blanching, maculopapular or petechial rash that starts as small pink macules on the extremities that then can involve the trunk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting. He was in the emergency department a few days ago for a bloody nose. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 74/40 mmHg, heart rate is 130/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, he appears acutely ill with bilateral nasal packing still in place. His skin examination reveals a diffuse, erythematous macular rash. Which of the following laboratory findings would be consistent with the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms, examination, and history are consistent with toxic shock syndrome, likely as a result of nasal packing for epistaxis. Laboratory studies will generally demonstrate evidence of multiorgan dysfunction, such as an elevated creatinine level.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a serious multisystem disease where toxin production by bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes) causes an exaggerated inflammatory response. Most cases of TSS are due to methicillin-susceptible S. aureus (MSSA), though cases secondary to MRSA have been emerging. Streptococcal TSS occurs most frequently in the setting of infection due to group A Streptococcus. Isolation of group A streptococcus from blood or tissue culture is required for diagnosis of streptococcal TSS. Staph TSS does not require positive cultures for diagnosis as they are often negative.

Laboratory studies in TSS can show a multitude of findings. Leukocytosis with left shift, anemia, and/or thrombocytopenia may be seen on a complete blood cell count. Metabolic panels may show an elevated BUN and creatinine, elevated liver enzymes, low albumin, and creatine phosphokinase (if myositis or necrotizing fasciitis is present). Lactic acidosis, DIC, and electrolyte abnormalities may also be present. All of these are influenced by the underlying inflammation, hypoperfusion, and multiorgan dysfunction that results from the disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated serum creatinine level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated eosinophils:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Laboratory studies will generally demonstrate elevated neutrophils and bands, not eosinophils.  
❌ Normal lactic acid:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. This typically is associated with an elevated lactic acid due to decreased perfusion from shock.  
❌ Elevated serum calcium:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Hypocalcemia may be seen in this condition.  
❌ Elevated serum bicarbonate:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Metabolic acidosis, and thus a low serum bicarbonate level, would be expected in this condition.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department because he has been unable to void urine for the past 12 hours and has suprapubic pain. He returned home yesterday after outpatient laparoscopic shoulder surgery. The patient reports a history of recurrent urinary retention due to an enlarged prostate. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 177/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 101/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination the patient appears uncomfortable. Abdominal examination reveals suprapubic fullness and tenderness. Rectal exam is significant for an enlarged prostate and normal anal sphincter tone. Bladder scan reveals >1L.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy presents with acute urinary retention following an outpatient surgical procedure. The immediate treatment of acute urinary retention is foley catheter placement to decompress the bladder and relieve pain.

For patients who present with acute urinary retention, immediate decompression of the bladder with a foley catheter or suprapubic catheter should be performed to relieve pain. Then further evaluation should be undertaken to determine the underlying etiology and address it accordingly. Patients with evidence of an enlarged prostate can be treated with alpha blockers or PDE inhibitors to relieve symptoms. When urinary retention is caused by urinary infection, it should be treated with appropriate antibiotic therapy. If a causative medication is identified (e.g. diphenhydramine or other antimuscarinic agents) it should be discontinued. Patients with urinary retention secondary to cauda equina syndrome or spinal cord lesions require immediate surgical intervention.  

Option Analysis

✅ Insert a foley catheter:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer tamsulosin:
Incorrect: This patient should first have a foley catheter placed to immediately relieve his pain. Tamsulosin can relieve symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia within days.  
❌ Administer intravenous fluids:
Incorrect:  Administration of intravenous fluids is likely to worsen this patient's symptoms of urinary retention.  
❌ Administer morphine:
Incorrect: While analgesia can help relieve this patient's discomfort, a foley catheter should be placed to immediately address the urinary retention and relieve pain. Additionally opioids can induce urinary retention and should be avoided.  
❌ Insert a suprapubic catheter:
Incorrect:  A suprapubic catheter should only be placed for urinary retention if straight catheterization or foley catheter placement cannot be performed or are unsuccessful.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presents to the office for a routine follow-up. He is asymptomatic and feels well. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, simvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in the patient’s father. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals the findings shown below. Recent laboratory workup revealed an elevated triglyceride level and a normal liver function test. The patient is prescribed gemfibrozil for the management of hypertriglyceridemia. Which of the following is most helpful in monitoring for potential complications of statin and fibrate combination therapy?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with elevated serum triglyceride (TG) levels and xanthelasma around the eyes. He likely has familial hypertriglyceridemia. Fibrates should be added to his medication regimen to reduce the future risk of pancreatitis. Using fibrates with statins is associated with an increased risk of myopathy, which can be monitored by measuring serum creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels.

Fibrates act by activating PPARα, decreasing very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis and increasing lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in adipose tissues. LPL, in turn, hydrolyzes the TGs in chylomicrons and VLDLs to free fatty acids, thus lowering triglyceride levels. Moreover, fibrates increase the synthesis of HDLs.

Fibrates are fairly safe lipid-lowering drugs. However, their coadministration with statins increases the risk of muscle injury. This complication is thought to result from the inhibition of statin glucuronidation, a process that assists in the renal excretion of stains. Serum CPK can be measured periodically in patients undergoing combination therapy to evaluate for muscle injury and rhabdomyolysis.

Notably, fenofibrate is rarely reported to interact with statins to cause muscle injury. As a result, it is preferred over other fibrates (e.g. gemfibrozil) when combination therapy with a statin is required.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serum creatine phosphokinase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: An abdominal ultrasound can be performed to look for gallstones, a complication of fibrate therapy, in symptomatic patients. In contrast, it is not routinely performed in asymptomatic patients.  
❌ Liver function test:
Incorrect: Liver function testing should be performed before initiating statin therapy due to its potential to cause hepatotoxicity. Although fibrates can cause mild elevations in aminotransferase, acute liver injury is rare, and monitoring is not indicated.  
❌ Renal function test:
Incorrect: Gemfibrozil rarely affects serum creatinine levels (unlike fenofibrate) and does not potentiate statin-induced nephrotoxicity.  
❌ Random blood glucose:
Incorrect: Statin and fibrate therapy do not significantly affect blood glucose levels. Niacin, however, can cause hyperglycemia and should be used cautiously in patients with a history of diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man is diagnosed with Gram-positive bacteremia and started on intravenous Antibiotic X. After admission to the hospital, the patient is given a loading dose of the medication. Afterward, he is scheduled to receive additional injections every six hours. Information regarding Antibiotic X’s pharmacokinetics is listed below. The patient’s body weight is 75 kg, and the target plasma concentration for Antibiotic X is 30 mg/L. Which of the following maintenance doses should be administered?  

Pharmacokinetic Parameter
Value
Volume of distribution  
0.4 L/kg  
Dosing interval  
6 hours  
Bioavailability*  
100%  
Elimination rate  
2.6 L/h  
*For intravenous administration
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with Gram-positive bacteremia and started on Antibiotic X, administered via an intermittent dosing regimen. In emergency cases, a loading dose (a large dose given at the beginning of treatment) can be administered to help the medication rapidly achieve target concentrations. Maintenance doses, given at scheduled intervals, can be subsequently administered to help keep the drug level at a steady-state concentration. The maintenance dose can be calculated via the equation above.

The maintenance dose of Antibiotic X can be calculated as follows:

   Maintenance dose = (30 mg/L * 2.6 L * 6 h) / 100% = 468 mg / 1 = 468 mg = ~470 mg

Therefore, 470 mg of Antibiotic X should be administered every 6 hours to help maintain the desired target plasma concentration.
 

Option Analysis

❌ 180 mg every 6 hours:
Incorrect: The maintenance dose can be calculated by multiplying the target plasma concentration, clearance rate, and dosing interval and dividing by the drug’s bioavailability. In the case of Antibiotic X, the patient should take a maintenance dose of 470 mg every six hours to keep the plasma drug concentration at 30 mg/L.  
❌ 250 mg every 6 hours:
Incorrect: A maintenance dose of 470 mg should be given every 6 hours to achieve a plasma drug concentration of 30 mg/L. In contrast, a dose of 250 mg every 6 hours would be insufficient.  
✅ 470 mg every 6 hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 600 mg every 6 hours:
Incorrect: A maintenance dose of 470 mg should be given every 6 hours to achieve a plasma drug concentration of 30 mg/L. In contrast, a dose of 600 mg every 6 hours would cause the actual plasma concentration to be more than the targeted goal.  
❌ 730 mg every 6 hours:
Incorrect: The maintenance dose can be calculated by multiplying the target plasma concentration, clearance rate, and dosing interval and dividing by the drug’s bioavailability. In the case of Antibiotic X, a maintenance dose of 470 mg should be given every six hours to keep the plasma drug concentration at 30 mg/L.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the office for her routine follow-up. She has no active complaints at this visit. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Current medication includes lisinopril. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus in her mother and myocardial infarction in her father. She drinks 2-3 beers on the weekends and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Her recent fasting lipid profile revealed an elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and decreased high-density lipoprotein (HDL). The physician prescribes a lipid-lowering drug that prevents lipolysis by inhibiting hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue. Which of the following is a potential adverse effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient with dyslipidemia is prescribed niacin, a lipid lowering drug, which causes an increase in blood uric acid levels and can induce gout (by inhibiting uric acid excretion and/or metabolism).

Normally, free fatty acids (FFA) are released by the action of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) on adipose tissue. This FFA is taken up by the liver to form triglycerides (TG), which are one of the components of LDL and VLDL. Niacin prevents lipolysis by inhibiting HSL in adipose tissue which leads to a moderate decrease in VLDL and LDL levels. It can also cause a moderate increase in HDL by decreasing its uptake by the liver.

Niacin can sometimes be indicated in the following circumstances:
 
  •  To reduce LDL levels, uncontrolled by a combination of statins and ezetimibe 
  •  To elevate HDL levels 
  •  As an adjunct therapy for severe hypertriglyceridemia 
  •  To reduce the risk of recurrent myocardial infarction 
  •  In combination with bile acid resins to slow the progression of atherosclerotic cardiovascular  disease (does not improve cardiovascular mortality or morbidity) 
Its use, however, is limited by its side effect profile, which include prostaglandin-induced facial flushing and pruritus, reversible increase in liver aminotransferases, postural hypotension, gastrointestinal upset, elevations in serum uric acid levels and increase in glucose levels. When used in combination with statins, it increases the risk of developing myopathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Myopathy:
Incorrect: Myopathy is a potential adverse effect of statin therapy which decreases liver cholesterol production by inhibiting hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase. This patient is most likely prescribed niacin, which can cause myopathy but only when used in combination with a statin.  
✅ Hyperuricemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gallstones:
Incorrect: Gallstone formation is a potential side effect of fibrate therapy which inhibits cholesterol 7ɑ hydroxylase, an enzyme that synthesizes bile acids. This results in supersaturation of cholesterol in gallbladder and the formation of gallstones. It does not inhibit hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue.  
❌ Deficiency of fat soluble vitamins:
Incorrect: Use of bile acid resins can lead to a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins as it binds to bile acids (which help in the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins) in the intestine and prevent their reabsorption.  
❌ Delirium:
Incorrect: Delirium is an uncommon adverse effect of PCSK-9 inhibitors, which is a relatively new class of lipid-lowering drugs that act by inhibiting the degradation of LDL receptors, facilitating the removal of LDL from the bloodstream. No effect on lipolysis is observed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office for the evaluation of episodic facial redness, warmth and pruritus. She reports pruritus and facial flushing for the past 5 days that lasts for approximately 2 hours before bedtime and resolves on its own. The remainder of the system review is unremarkable. She was recently started on a lipid lowering drug for her dyslipidemia. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in her father. She has been working as a gardener near her neighborhood for the past 10 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows a healthy young female with normal skin on inspection. The lungs are clear to auscultation and there are no heart murmurs. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer aspirin 30 minutes before taking her medication
Counsel the patient to avoid sunlight

questions.solution:
This patient’s episodic facial flushing is most likely due to the ingestion of niacin, a lipid lowering drug, which tends to cause prostaglandin-mediated vasodilation at high doses. The role of prostaglandins (released by cutaneous macrophage) is confirmed by the improvement in flushing and pruritus when non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), particularly aspirin, are taken 30 minutes before niacin at bedtime. The flushing and pruritus usually improves after 2-4 weeks of niacin therapy. It is better tolerated when ingested with food. A new drug, laropiprant, a prostaglandin D2 antagonist, is also proven to treat niacin flush.

Other side effects of niacin include reversible increase in liver aminotransferases, postural hypotension, gastrointestinal upset, elevations in serum uric acid levels and increase in glucose levels. When used in combination with statins, it increases the risk of developing myopathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administer antihistamine:
Incorrect: This patient’s facial flushing is most likely secondary to prostaglandin-induced vasodilation, not mast cell degranulation. Hence, it is unlikely to improve with the use of antihistamines.  
❌ Reassure the patient  :
Incorrect: Although patient’s on niacin therapy will become tolerant to this effect with long-term use, active use of aspirin before administering niacin is the most appropriate step at this point.  
❌ Measure 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA)  :
Incorrect: 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is measured in suspected cases of carcinoid syndrome. In addition to flushing, symptoms of diarrhea and bronchospasm and/or a history of valvular heart disease are usually present.  
✅ Administer aspirin 30 minutes before taking her medication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Counsel the patient to avoid sunlight:
Incorrect: Exposure to sunlight is the major trigger for the exacerbation of acne rosacea, which usually presents with erythematous rash of the central face (nose and cheeks). This patient had an acute episode of facial flushing, most likely triggered by a medication.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the office because of muscle pain in his upper and lower extremities. He has been having a hard time raising his arms above his head for the past few days. The patient also reports that he easily gets fatigued and it is difficult for him to climb the stairs to his apartment. Past medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia. He was recently started on a low-fat diet and rosuvastatin to help reduce his blood cholesterol levels. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows weakness and soreness of proximal muscles of upper and lower extremities. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated levels of serum creatine phosphokinase. Rosuvastatin is immediately discontinued and the patient is started on a new lipid lowering drug which interferes with the action of circulating proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9). Which of the following best describes the function of PCSK9?

choices.text: Conversion of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA to mevalonate
Degradation of low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDL-R) on liver cells
Hydrolysis of extracellular triglycerides in lipoprotein
Hydrolysis of intracellular of triglycerides in adipose tissue

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from statin-induced myopathy and is switched to a new and safer drug that inhibits the activity of PCSK9 (e.g., alirocumab, evolocumab).

PCSK9 is a serine protease, predominantly produced in the liver. It binds to the low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDL-R) on the surface of hepatocytes and leads to its degradation, thereby resulting in elevated blood cholesterol levels. PCSK9 inhibitors are antibodies that bind PCSK9 and prevent LDL-R degradation. This leads to an overall increase in LDL-R on hepatocytes which results in a major decrease in serum LDL (by increasing its uptake in hepatocytes) and is indicated in patients with elevated LDL cholesterol. PCSK9 inhibitors are also shown to decrease the incidence of cardiovascular events in susceptible individuals. It is available as a subcutaneous injection and must be administered every 2-4 weeks. It is a comparatively safe lipid-lowering drug with occasional injection site reactions (pruritus, rash) and rare neurocognitive toxicity (delirium, dementia). Muscle toxicity, however, is not observed.  

Option Analysis

❌ Conversion of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA to mevalonate:
Incorrect: Hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase converts HMG CoA to mevalonate, which is a precursor of cholesterol. This enzyme is inhibited by statins and it results in decreased formation of cholesterol, thereby increasing the LDL receptors on hepatocytes and increasing the uptake of serum LDL.  
✅ Degradation of low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDL-R) on liver cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hydrolysis of extracellular triglycerides in lipoprotein:
Incorrect: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) hydrolyzes extracellular triglycerides in lipoproteins to free fatty acids and monoglycerides. LPL activity is up-regulated via the activation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα) by fibrates.  
❌ Hydrolysis of intracellular of triglycerides in adipose tissue:
Incorrect: Hormone-sensitive lipase hydrolyzes intracellular triglycerides in adipose tissue to free fatty acids. It is stimulated by catecholamines, ACTH, and glucagon and inhibited by niacin (vitamin B3) which is sometimes indicated in the management of dyslipidemia.  
❌ Degradation of monoaminergic neurotransmitters:
Incorrect: Monoamine oxidase is responsible for the degradation of monoaminergic neurotransmitters (catecholamine, dopamine and serotonin) in the synaptic cleft. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors prevent the degradation of monoamines and are used in the treatment of major depressive disorder. It does not affect the serum lipid levels.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the office for routine follow-up and has no active complaints at this visit. She was recently diagnosed with hypertriglyceridemia and was started on a low-fat diet along with fenofibrate. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Current medications include fenofibrate and lisinopril. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in her father. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Repeat lipid panel revealed a triglyceride level of 900 mg/dL which was 1100 mg/dL a few weeks ago. A new supplement is added to her diet which decreases triglyceride levels by reducing the production of hepatic very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) cholesterol. Which of the following nutrients is present in these supplements?
questions.solution:
This patient with hypertriglyceridemia is prescribed an omega-3 fatty acid supplementation which reduces serum triglyceride (TG) levels. Eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid are two common omega-3 fatty acids which decrease both fasting and postprandial TGs by reducing the hepatic VLDL production. The exact mechanism is not known but a number of theories had been proposed, which include:
 
  •  Blockade of the enzyme responsible for TG synthesis in the liver (diacylglycerol acyltransferase or    phosphatidic acid phosphohydrolase) 
  •  Increased plasma lipoprotein lipase activity 
  •  Decreased lipogenesis in the liver 
  •  Increase β oxidation of fatty acids 
It is typically indicated in patients with hypertriglyceridemia (TG > 150 mg/dL). It also helps with improving blood pressure and cardiac function. Common adverse effects include gastrointestinal (GI) upset, fish-like taste and a possible increase in low-density lipoprotein (LDL).  

Option Analysis

❌ Niacin:
Incorrect: Niacin (vitamin B3) is used as a lipid lowering agent that acts by inhibiting hormone sensitive lipase in the adipose tissue, thereby preventing the mobilization of triglycerides. Although it reduces hepatic VLDL synthesis, its major role is to increase high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and is not used primarily in hypertriglyceridemia.  
✅ Omega 3 fatty acids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Retinoic acid:
Incorrect: Retinoic acid also known as vitamin A, is an antioxidant and is used primarily in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia and severe acne as all-trans retinoic acid and isotretinoin, respectively. It has no known effect on triglyceride levels.  
❌ Folate:
Incorrect: Folate (vitamin B9) plays an important role in the synthesis of nitrogenous bases in DNA and RNA. Its supplementation is helpful in pregnant women and patients with megaloblastic anemia. No effect on lipid metabolism is observed.  
❌ Ascorbic acid:
Incorrect: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is an antioxidant that facilitates iron absorption in the intestine by reducing it to Fe+2. No effect on lipid metabolism is seen.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right flank pain and hematuria that began suddenly that morning. The pain is intense and lasts for about 30 minutes before it resolves, and then it comes on again. She has no past medical history and is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 156/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 88/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On initial assessment, the patient appears uncomfortable and is vomiting into an emesis basin. On abdominal examination, there is mild distension and no abdominal tenderness, rebound, or guarding. There is right flank tenderness upon palpation. Urinalysis shows hematuria. The patient is started on IV normal saline and laboratory studies are pending. Point-of-care pregnancy screening is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and physical examination findings (e.g. flank tenderness) consistent with nephrolithiasis. Additionally, urinalysis shows hematuria. The best next step in management is to provide pain control with an IV nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, such as ketorolac. Then a non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Nephrolithiasis, also known as renal calculi or renal stones, is a painful condition where crystals form in the kidney, potentially causing urinary tract obstruction.  Renal stones usually form when urine becomes oversaturated with minerals and salts, including calcium, oxalate, and uric acid. Common renal stone types include calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate, uric acid, cystine, and struvite stones. Patients typically  present with acute onset severe flank pain that waxes and wanes. It is typically associated with hematuria, nausea, and vomiting; and urgency and dysuria may be seen.

The acute management of patients with suspected nephrolithiasis includes an ABCDE assessment and stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation. Additionally, IV access should be obtained, and continuous vital sign monitoring, IV fluids, IV analgesia, and antiemetic therapy should be initiated. Basic blood work and urinalysis should be performed followed by appropriate imaging to confirm the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV ketorolac:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV morphine:
Incorrect:  Opioids, like morphine, can be used for pain control in nephrolithiasis. However, they should be reserved for patients who have contraindications to NSAIDs or have insufficient pain control on NSAIDs.  
❌ Administer oral acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is an analgesic and antipyretic. While it can provide pain relief, it is not as effective as IV NSAIDs or opioids for the severe pain often associated with nephrolithiasis. Additionally, vomiting may limit the effectiveness of oral medications in this patient.  
❌ Administer oral ibuprofen:
Incorrect:  Ibuprofen is an NSAID that can be effective in managing pain associated with nephrolithiasis. However, vomiting may limit the effectiveness of oral medications in this patient.  
❌ Administer oral oxycodone:
Incorrect:  Oxycodone is an opioid analgesic that can provide pain relief in cases of nephrolithiasis when NSAIDs are contraindicated or insufficient. However, the patient’s vomiting may limit the effectiveness of oral medications.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from his assisted living facility after an unwitnessed fall two hours ago. He reports feeling dizzy while getting out of bed and falling onto his left side. He did not hit his head or lose consciousness. He continues to feel lightheaded after receiving one liter of intravenous fluids by EMS. He has had fatigue and weakness for the past eight months. He does not drink alcohol or take any medications. Temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 91/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 103/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, he appears thin and pale. He is alert and oriented to time, person, place, and situation. His skin is dry, with an area of ecchymosis overlying his left elbow. Strength is 5/5 in all extremities. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. He has no blood in the stool. Results of initial complete blood count are shown below. What is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
Leukocyte count  
4,400/mm3   
Hemoglobin
6.8 g/dL  
Hematocrit
26.7%  
Mean corpuscular volume  
101 fL  
Platelet count  
135/mm3
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents after a fall due to dizziness in the context of chronic fatigue and weakness. Bloodwork reveals pancytopenia (i.e. macrocytic anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia) consistent with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). In the acute setting, packed red blood transfusion should be considered for significant anemia (hemoglobin levels < 7 to 8 g/dL) as well as for persistent symptoms following fluid resuscitation and for patients with underlying cardiovascular disease.

The most common medical condition that causes non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia is MDS. If laboratory findings show low white blood cells and platelets, then a bone marrow aspirate should be performed for definitive diagnosis. If there is hypocellularity with myelodysplastic morphology, MDS can be diagnosed.

MDS refers to an acquired clonal disorder of the bone marrow that is a common cause of unexplained anemia in adults older than 65 years. Patients with MDS typically present with symptomatic anemia. Some patients may have symptoms of thrombocytopenia, such as bruising or bleeding, or findings from neutropenia, such as recurrent infections. Without treatment, most patients with MDS will eventually require red blood cell (RBC) transfusions. Whenever possible, use of erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs) should be utilized to prevent repeated transfusions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Packed red blood cell transfusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral blood smear:
Incorrect: A peripheral smear will help to differentiate between megaloblastic and non-megaloblastic anemias; however, administration of packed red blood cells takes precedence as this patient remains symptomatic. MDS causes a non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia.  
❌ Liver function tests:
Incorrect: Liver function tests can be performed if chronic alcohol use or liver disease is suspected. This patient does not drink alcohol nor does he have signs and symptoms consistent with liver dysfunction, including jaundice or abdominal pain.  
❌ Iron studies:
Incorrect: Iron studies are done to determine the cause of microcytic anemia. It is not necessary to evaluate macrocytic anemia as seen in this patient.  
❌ Bone marrow aspirate:
Incorrect: Bone marrow aspiration can help determine the cause of decreased hematopoiesis, including aplastic anemia and myelodysplastic syndrome. This is an invasive procedure that can be performed later to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic with a three-month history of fatigue and lower back pain. He fractured his right wrist and two ribs six months ago after falling off a low chair. He also has a decreased appetite. He has not had weight loss, fever, or night sweats. His past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals pallor and tenderness over the lumbar spine. Laboratory findings are shown below. X-ray of the spine demonstrates multiple lytic bone lesions. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

 Laboratory test  Result 
 Hemoglobin  10 g/dL 
 White Blood Cell Count  6,200/mm3 
 Platelet Count  290,000/mm3 
 Mean Corpuscular Volume  89 fL 
 Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  2.2 mg/dL 
 Bicarbonate  24 mEq/L 
 Calcium  12 mg/dL

choices.text: Asymmetrically enlarged and firm prostate on digital rectal examination
Low back pain and stiffness lasting more than 30 minutes that improves with activity

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fatigue, lower back pain, and recent fractures from minor trauma. Evaluation reveals the presence of lytic bone lesions, anemia, elevated creatinine, and hypercalcemia. He most likely has multiple myeloma (MM), which is a malignancy of plasma cells leading to the overproduction of monoclonal immunoglobulins. It usually presents with a constellation of findings that can be remembered with the term CRAB: hyperCalcemia, Renal dysfunction, Anemia, and Bone lesions. The hypercalcemia seen in MM can often lead to constipation.  

Hypercalcemia is a common finding in patients with MM due to increased bone resorption, secondary to secretion of osteoclast-activating factors by malignant plasma cells. Elevated calcium levels can lead to polyuria, polydipsia, neuropsychiatric disturbances, and constipation. Some patients with MM may have blurred vision or headaches from hyperviscosity syndrome, which is due to the increased production of immunoglobulins. Recurrent infections are another hallmark feature of MM since malignant transformation impairs the ability of plasma cells to produce a diverse array of antibodies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Constipation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Asymmetrically enlarged and firm prostate on digital rectal examination:
Incorrect: An asymmetrically enlarged and firm prostate suggests prostate cancer. While prostate cancer can metastasize to the spine and cause lower back pain, it typically results in osteoblastic lesions. The patient's osteolytic lesions are more consistent with multiple myeloma.
❌ Positive straight leg-raise :
Incorrect: A positive straight leg-raise test indicates lumbar radiculopathy, often due to disc herniation. This patient's clinical picture, X-ray, and laboratory findings point towards multiple myeloma. His lytic bone lesions are causing the pain, rather than a discogenic cause. Compression fractures can also occur with MM and can cause severe localized pain.
❌ Cervical lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Cervical lymphadenopathy is typically seen in patients with lymphoma or infection. It isn't a hallmark of multiple myeloma, which affects the bone marrow's plasma cells and doesn't usually involve peripheral lymph nodes.
❌ Low back pain and stiffness lasting more than 30 minutes that improves with activity:
Incorrect: This symptom is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), which is a chronic inflammatory disorder that affects the axial skeleton. Patients with pain from lytic lesions typically describe the pain as a dull or aching pain that worsens with activity. Compression fractures can cause severe localized pain.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of upper abdominal and chest discomfort. The patient says the pain is worse with swallowing, and he has associated nausea. Past medical history includes seasonal allergies, asthma, and atopic dermatitis. He takes cetirizine and uses an albuterol inhaler as needed. He recently completed a two-month course of oral pantoprazole prescribed by his primary care provider for suspected reflux esophagitis with minimal relief of his symptoms. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 125/70 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The oropharynx is clear. Cardiopulmonary examination demonstrates faint wheezing bilaterally on lung auscultation. Abdominal examination is benign. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggesting esophagitis. Given this patient’s associated medical conditions and physical examination, he most likely has eosinophilic esophagitis, which is a specific subtype of esophagitis that occurs in patients with atopic conditions like asthma, allergic rhinitis, and dermatitis.    

Eosinophilic esophagitis is due to chronic inflammation of the esophagus caused by antigen sensitization. There is eosinophilic infiltration of the esophageal mucosa. It should be considered in patients with persistent dysphagia, or patients with presumed gastroesophageal reflux disease that does not respond to medical therapy, especially in patients with atopic conditions.  

Patients with esophagitis typically present with upper abdomen and chest discomfort, nausea, dysphagia, and odynophagia. The specific type of esophagitis can often be determined by history and physical examination. Patients with viral or candidal esophagitis often have a history of immunosuppression. Patients with candidal esophagitis may have oral thrush and a history of recent antibiotic use. Patients with reflux may have halitosis, dental erosions, and heartburn. Patients with pill esophagitis likely will be taking medications known to cause pill esophagitis with little or no water, especially right before bed (e.g., bisphosphonates, NSAIDs, tetracycline). Patients with radiation-induced esophagitis will have a history of head or neck radiation therapy for malignancy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Eosinophilic esophagitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Viral esophagitis :
Incorrect: Viral esophagitis typically occurs in patients with underlying immunosuppression (e.g. HIV, on immunosuppressants like corticosteroids) Patients may present with oral ulcers, odynophagia, and dysphagia. This patient has features of atopy, including dermatitis, asthma, and allergic rhinitis; this makes eosinophilic esophagitis more likely. 
❌ Esophageal candidiasis:
Incorrect: Esophageal candidiasis typically occurs in patients with underlying immunosuppression (e.g. HIV, on immunosuppressants) or in patients who have recently taken antibiotics. Patients will typically have evidence of oral thrush. This patient has features of atopy, including dermatitis, asthma, and allergic rhinitis; this makes eosinophilic esophagitis more likely.  
❌ Pill esophagitis:
Incorrect: Pill esophagitis typically presents in patients taking agents such as bisphosphonates, tetracycline antibiotics, or NSAIDs with little or no water. 
❌ Reflux esophagitis:
Incorrect:  Patients with reflux esophagitis typically have symptoms of chest discomfort and acid reflux; they may complain of a sour taste in the mouth. Symptom relief would be expected with a two-month trial of a proton pump inhibitor (i.e. pantoprazole). This patient has features of atopy, making eosinophilic esophagitis more likely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a six-month history of fatigue, weight gain, and constipation. She also reports bouts of sadness over the same time period. She has no significant past medical history. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 50/min, and blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg. Palpation of the neck reveals a palpable, smooth, rubbery, non-tender neck mass. That patient’s skin is dry, cold, and rough to the touch. Which of the following evaluations should be performed next to help make the diagnosis?

choices.text: Assessment of TSH and free T4
Performance of rapid ACTH stimulation test

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fatigue, weight gain constipation, and feelings of sadness. She has rough and dry skin and an enlarged anterior rubbery neck mass which, taken together, are concerning for hypothyroidism. Laboratory testing with TSH and free T4 should be performed, and if the TSH is elevated and free T4 is low then primary hypothyroidism can be diagnosed.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient parts of the world and is the likely cause of primary hypothyroidism in this patient. It results from production of antithyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) and antithyroglobulin (anti-Tg) antibodies that lead to destruction of thyroid cells and are treated with thyroid hormone replacement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Assessment of TSH and free T4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound of the neck:
Incorrect: For patients with suspected Hashimoto thyroiditis, ultrasound should be reserved for patients with larger goiters, thyroid asymmetry, or thyroid nodularity.  
❌ Assessment for TSH receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: Antibodies to TSH receptors are suggestive of Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Patients with Graves disease usually present with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, hyperhidrosis, warm, moist skin, diarrhea, eye pain, and heat intolerance.  
❌ Evaluation for malnutrition:
Incorrect: Vitamin and mineral deficiencies can manifest as abnormal gastrointestinal and dermatologic findings, such as pellagra due to niacin deficiency or neuropathy due to vitamin B12 deficiency. The constellation of this patient’s findings are not suggestive of a vitamin or mineral deficiency.  
❌ Performance of rapid ACTH stimulation test:
Incorrect: The rapid ACTH stimulation test is used in the diagnosis of adrenocortical insufficiency (ie, Addison disease). Signs and symptoms of Addison’s disease include hyperpigmentation, weakness, fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, and dizziness with orthostasis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. The patient’s mother had surgery at a young age for medullary thyroid cancer, and his maternal grandfather had “high calcium” and an adrenal gland tumor. The patient was told that his family has a familial “tumor syndrome.” The patient is concerned about his risk for similar problems. He currently has no symptoms and is in good health. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there are no palpable masses in the neck. There is no evidence of mucosal neuromas. Biochemical screenings including serum calcium, calcitonin, and plasma fractionated metanephrines are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Genetic testing for a RET mutation
Genetic testing for a MEN1 mutation
MRI of the head and neck

questions.solution:
This patient’s family history of medullary thyroid cancer, hypercalcemia, and an adrenal gland tumor (possible pheochromocytoma) is concerning for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A).
