The physical examination and laboratory screenings for this patient are unremarkable. Given the strong family history, genetic screening for a RET mutation would be appropriate at this time.

MEN2A is a rare genetic disorder that is associated with medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism. This triad differentiates MEN2A from other types of MEN as can be seen in the table below. Patients with MEN2A may present with symptoms of any of the associated conditions, with medullary thyroid cancer being the most common initial presentation (usually early in life). Initial workup is often guided by the presentation (e.g., calcitonin level and neck ultrasound for medullary thyroid cancer), followed by potential screening for additional tumors. Genetic testing to look for specific RET mutations confirms the diagnosis of MEN2. First- and second-degree family members should also be screened, and these individuals should undergo regular monitoring for manifestations of the syndrome.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Genetic testing for a RET mutation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Genetic testing for a MEN1 mutation:
Incorrect: This patient’s family history is more suggestive of MEN2A (given the mother’s history of medullary thyroid cancer), which is associated with the RET proto-oncogene.  
❌ Urinary metanephrines and catecholamine levels:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytoma is associated with MEN2A. However, this patient’s plasma fractionated metanephrines were already found to be within normal limits.  
❌ 24-hour urinary cortisol level:
Incorrect: A 24-hour urinary cortisol level would be appropriate if there were clinical suspicion of Cushing syndrome. However, this diagnosis is not associated with MEN2A which is what this patient is at most risk for based on his family history.  
❌ MRI of the head and neck:
Incorrect: An MRI at this time would be inappropriate due to the lack of clinical and biochemical abnormalities. This would be reasonable if an endocrine tumor were suspected.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a three-month history of joint pain. He has been experiencing pain, stiffness, and swelling in his fingers and toes. The pain has gradually become worse and makes it difficult for him to work. He has not had pain in the elbows, knees, or lower back. He has no significant past medical history, but his father has psoriasis.  Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg.  Thick, scaly, silvery-white skin plaques with punctate bleeding spots are noted on the extensor surface of both elbows.  Examination of the joints reveals swelling and tenderness of multiple joints of the fingers and toes. Transverse depressions, subungual hyperkeratosis, and pitting of the nails are seen. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be associated with this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Psoriatic arthritis (PsA) is a type of autoimmune arthritis that is associated with the inflammatory skin disorder psoriasis. In PsA inflammation causes joint pain, swelling, and stiffness most commonly in the fingers and toes, but other joints can be affected as well (e.g., elbows, knees, sacroiliac joints). Patients with PsA are typically negative for rheumatoid factor (RF) and antinuclear antibodies (ANA), and have elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). They may also be positive for HLA-B27 (in ~10% of cases).    

Involved joints are typically swollen and tender. Dactylitis is a specific sign of psoriatic arthritis that presents as swelling of the entire digit of the fingers or toes termed “sausage digit”. The inflammation can eventually lead to joint destruction that can be seen on imaging. Because of the association of PsA with psoriasis, the characteristic dry, thick, silvery-white scaly plaques of psoriasis may be seen on the extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees, along with pitting of the nails. Radiographic findings of affected joints may show joint space narrowing and juxta-articular new bone formation.     

CASPAR (Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis) were designed to select patients to enroll in research trials and not for diagnostic purposes. However, since no single finding or test can diagnose psoriatic arthritis, these criteria are helpful when evaluating patients with suspected psoriatic arthritis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Elevated C-reactive protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (Anti-CCP) antibodies:
Incorrect:  Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are specific for rheumatoid arthritis. They are not commonly seen in patients with psoriatic arthritis. This patient's clinical presentation of scaly white skin plaques and arthritis is consistent with psoriatic arthritis.
❌ Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA):
Incorrect: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA) are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis. This patient has scaly white skin plaques classic for psoriasis and associated psoriatic arthritis. He does not have renal, pulmonary, or other symptoms that would indicate vasculitis.
❌ Rheumatoid factor (RF):
Incorrect: Although a minority of patients with psoriatic arthritis can have a positive rheumatoid factor (RF), it is more commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and is not a common finding in patients with psoriatic arthritis
❌ Antinuclear antibodies (ANA):
Incorrect: Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are seen in autoimmune and connective tissue diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjogren syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic sclerosis. A minority of patients with psoriatic arthritis will have a positive ANA, however it is associated more commonly with other connective tissue disease and less often with PsA.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the primary care office with joint pain and nail changes. She has a four-month history of pain, stiffness, and swelling in her fingers, and left knee. She works as a data entry freelancer, and her worsening symptoms have significantly impaired her ability to work. She has a 10-year history of psoriasis which is well controlled with topical agents. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg. Physical examination shows a few patches of silvery-white scales on the extensor surfaces of the elbows. Examination of the nails shows transverse depressions and subungual hyperkeratosis. Multiple joints of the fingers and toes are tender and swollen, as is the left knee. Laboratory studies show a C-reactive protein (CRP) of 8 mg/L and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 23 mm/hr. ANA and anti-ccp antibodies are negative. Which of the following will be most helpful for determining the severity of this patient’s arthritis?

choices.text: Age at initial diagnosis of psoriasis
Presence of an elevated rheumatoid factor

questions.solution:
This patient's joint symptoms, skin findings, and elevated inflammatory markers are consistent with psoriatic arthritis (PsA). Once the diagnosis of PsA is made, assessing disease severity as mild, moderate, or severe is essential to determine the most appropriate treatment. Disease severity can be assessed by evaluating a combination of factors including the number of joints affected, the severity of arthritis, presence of enthesitis (inflammation of tendons and ligaments, often achilles tendon) presence of dactylitis, and the degree of elevation of inflammatory markers. Additionally the impact of the disease on function, and the rapidity of disease progression should be considered when determining the disease severity and the treatment strategy.  

Treatment of mild disease typically involves the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for joint pain in combination with topical agents (e.g., corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs, calcineurin inhibitors) for psoriatic skin lesions.    

Disease modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are used to treat moderate disease. Methotrexate (MTX) is the first-line treatment in this setting. However, in the event of inadequate response to MTX after 3 months, the second-line agent (leflunomide) can be used.  Folic acid supplementation should be included whenever methotrexate is used. Topical agents can be added to DMARDs to further help control psoriatic plaques.  

Biologics, such as tumor necrosis factor and interleukin inhibitors, are used to treat severe disease. Screening for latent TB should be done prior to starting biologic agents. While biologics may address both the arthritic and skin manifestations of the disease, topical agents for psoriasis should still be offered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Number of joints affected:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Age at diagnosis of PsA:
Incorrect: The patient’s age at the time of the initial diagnosis of PsA is not used to assess PsA disease severity or to guide management.
❌ Presence of Auspitz sign :
Incorrect: A positive Auspitz sign refers to punctate bleeding spots when psoriatic lesions are scraped off and can be helpful in determining the severity of psoriasis; however, the presence of Auspitz sign is not used to determine disease severity in psoriatic arthritis.
❌ Age at initial diagnosis of psoriasis:
Incorrect: The patient’s age at the time of the initial diagnosis of psoriasis is not used to assess PsA disease severity or to guide management.
❌ Presence of an elevated rheumatoid factor :
Incorrect: Positive rheumatoid factor (RF) can be seen in a minority of patients with PsA, however presence or absence of RF is not used to determine disease severity in psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of severe left knee pain and swelling. He has not had any recent trauma, but recalls multiple similar, though less severe, episodes in his wrists bilaterally that have resolved with NSAIDs. Past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes lisinopril and metformin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg, heart rate is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The left knee is warm and swollen with limited passive and active range of motion due to pain. Left knee x-ray shows chondrocalcinosis. Joint aspiration is performed. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in synovial fluid analysis?

choices.text: Turbid synovial fluid with positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals
Turbid synovial fluid with negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals
Frank pus and gram-positive cocci in clusters
Clear synovial fluid with white blood cell count under 2,000 microL
Bright red synovial fluid with red blood cells

questions.solution:
This older patient who presents with sudden-onset severe left knee pain and swelling with a warm swollen joint with limited range of motion and chondrocalcinosis on x-ray likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), or pseudogout. The key diagnostic feature of CPPD on synovial fluid analysis is the presence of positively birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals under polarized light microscopy.     

CPPD is characterized by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints and soft tissue, leading to episodes of acute inflammatory arthritis. While no specific blood tests can confirm CPPD, inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP are often elevated during acute attacks. Radiographic evaluation may reveal chondrocalcinosis, a characteristic feature indicating calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition in cartilage. The definitive diagnostic modality is synovial fluid analysis from the affected joint, where positively birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals are identified under polarized light microscopy.  

Patients with pseudogout can be asymptomatic with incidental findings of chondrocalcinosis on x-ray, or they may present clinically with acute or chronic joint pain and swelling. Pseudogout typically presents as acute monoarticular or polyarticular joint pain and swelling. However chronic pseudogout can involve the bilateral wrists and small joints of the hands (called “pseudo-rheumatoid arthritis" (pseudo-RA)). Patients with chronic pseudogout can also present with chronic, degenerative arthritis, resembling osteoarthritis.

Option Analysis

✅ Turbid synovial fluid with positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Turbid synovial fluid with negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals :
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals are seen with gout. This patient’s age, history, and the presence of chondrocalcinosis on x-ray make CPPD more likely.
❌ Frank pus and gram-positive cocci in clusters:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD).  Lack of fever and risk factors for septic arthritis, along with a history of recurrent episodes that have resolved with NSAIDs, makes crystal-induced arthritis more likely, and the presence of chondrocalcinosis makes CPPD most likely.
❌ Clear synovial fluid with white blood cell count under 2,000 microL:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Non-inflammatory joint diseases, such as osteoarthritis, typically present with clear synovial fluid and a low white blood cell count in the synovial fluid. This patient's acute presentation, history of similar episodes, physical examination and x-ray findings are more consistent with CPPD which is an inflammatory joint process.
❌ Bright red synovial fluid with red blood cells :
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). The above finding suggests hemarthrosis. Given the lack of reported trauma or bleeding, hemarthrosis is unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of severe right knee pain, swelling, and difficulty moving the affected joint. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and diabetic nephropathy. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 78/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals right knee warmth and swelling with tenderness to palpation and limited range of motion. Laboratory evaluation is significant for creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL and elevated ESR and CRP. X-ray of the right knee is significant for the presence of chondrocalcinosis. Synovial fluid analysis shows a white blood cell count of 10,000 microL and positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with right knee pain, swelling, warmth, tenderness, and limited range of motion, along with radiographic evidence of chondrocalcinosis and positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). CPPD is characterized by deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints, inducing inflammation. For cases where a single large joint is involved, intra-articular glucocorticoids can be used, especially when there is renal impairment and colchicine and NSAIDs may need dose adjustments or are contraindicated.    

Initial management of acute episodes of CPPD often starts with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Colchicine is also often used. Patients with contraindications to NSAIDs, such as those with renal impairment, require alternative therapy. Colchicine may be used in cases of mild to moderate renal impairment, however, renal dosing should be used. For severe acute attacks involving one or two large joints, intra-articular glucocorticoids can provide targeted and potent anti-inflammatory effects. In cases where multiple joints are involved and NSAIDs and colchicine cannot be used or are ineffective, short courses of systemic glucocorticoids may be appropriate. If these initial measures are insufficient, or in cases of recurrent or chronic CPPD, disease-modifying agents such as hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and interleukin-1 inhibitors can be considered.  

Option Analysis

❌ Colchicine:
Incorrect: This patient has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Colchicine can be used to treat CPPD however in this patient with renal impairment and monoarticular arthritis, intra-articular glucocorticoids would be the preferred treatment.
❌ Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs):
Incorrect: This patient has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are commonly used to treat CPPD; however, in patients with renal impairment and monoarticular arthritis, intra-articular glucocorticoids would be the preferred treatment.
✅ Intra-articular glucocorticoids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: This patient has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Methotrexate can be used to treat calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease; however, it is typically reserved for refractory cases. In patients with renal impairment and monoarticular arthritis, initial treatment with intra-articular glucocorticoids would be preferred.
❌ Physical therapy and weight loss:
Incorrect: Physical therapy and weight loss are important adjuncts for managing chronic joint pain and improving joint function, but they are not the primary treatment for acute symptom relief in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). They should be recommended as part of a comprehensive management plan.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic due to 4 weeks of fatigue and malaise. The patient was diagnosed with Crohn disease 1 year ago and was initially treated with long-term glucocorticoids. Two months ago, the patient was weaned off glucocorticoids and switched to azathioprine. Temperature is 37.1 ºC (98.8 ºF), pulse 88/min, respiratory rate 14/min, blood pressure 122/78 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears pale, with scattered bruises over the body. Complete blood count is shown below. Decreased activity of which of the following enzymes could explain this patient's condition?

 Complete blood count (CBC)
 Hemoglobin  8.3 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  25% 
 MCV  85 fl 
 Reticulocyte count  1% 
 Leukocyte count  500/mm3 
 Platelet count  30,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe pancytopenia two months after starting azathioprine for Crohn disease. Severe or recurrent pancytopenia in patients taking azathioprine should raise the suspicion of decreased activity of thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT), an enzyme that is responsible for the degradation of the active metabolites of azathioprine.  

Azathioprine is a prodrug that gets converted to its active metabolite 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) by the action of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). 6-MP then inhibits purine synthesis, suppressing DNA and RNA synthesis and halting cellular division. These effects are most noted in actively dividing cells, including immune cells. In this way, azathioprine inhibits the proliferation of immune cells and suppresses the immune system. Azathioprine is used in autoimmune disorders (e.g., autoimmune hepatitis, inflammatory bowel disease), and can also be used to prevent organ rejection in transplant patients. The major side effects of azathioprine are bone marrow suppression and pancreatitis.  

Due to genetic polymorphism, some people have lower or absent activity of TPMT. Such people are more likely to develop bone marrow suppression due to the accumulation of toxic metabolites of 6-MP and azathioprine. Additionally, patients taking xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g. allopurinol) concurrently with azathioprine or 6-MP are at increased risk of toxicity.  

Option Analysis

✅ Thiopurine methyltransferase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase:
Incorrect: HGPRT is the enzyme responsible for converting azathioprine to 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits purine synthesis. Decreased activity of HGPRT would result in decreased activity of the azathioprine and thus decreased side effects.
❌ Cytochrome p450:
Incorrect: Cytochrome p450 (CYP-450) is a group of hepatic enzymes that are responsible for the metabolism of numerous drugs and toxins. Polymorphism is seen in the cytochrome P450 system, which accounts for different activity levels in the population. Azathioprine is not metabolized by cytochrome p450
❌ Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase :
Incorrect: Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase is the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of 5-fluorouracil. Decreased activity of this enzyme results in increased toxicity in patients taking 5-FU. However, it is not involved in azathioprine metabolism.
❌ Aldehyde dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Aldehyde dehydrogenase is responsible for breaking down acetaldehyde, a toxic intermediate product of ethanol metabolism. Deficiency in this enzyme results in the accumulation of acetaldehyde after alcohol consumption, causing symptoms like facial flushing, headache, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic due to a fever for the last 5 days. The patient also noticed a decrease in urine output. Five years ago the patient developed end-stage renal disease secondary to diabetes mellitus and subsequently underwent kidney transplantation 3 months ago. Current medications include insulin glargine and tacrolimus. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued, and there is tenderness to palpation at the site of the transplant. A biopsy from the transplanted kidney shows dense lymphocytic infiltrate. The patient is started on treatment with mycophenolate mofetil. Which of the following medications has a similar enzyme target to that of mycophenolate mofetil?
questions.solution:
This patient is currently experiencing acute graft rejection, which is characterized by dense lymphocytic infiltration of the graft. It often presents with fever and oliguria. Acute graft rejection can be reversed with the use of potent immunosuppressants; this includes steroids or mycophenolate mofetil.  

Mycophenolate mofetil is an immunosuppressant that can be used to protect against (or reverse) organ transplant rejection. It inhibits purine synthesis by inhibiting inosine-5'-monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), the rate-limiting enzyme in de novo purine synthesis. It preferentially targets this enzyme in B- and T-lymphocytes, the main cells responsible for acute and chronic graft rejection. In addition, it can be used against a wide range of autoimmune disorders such as lupus nephritis, and autoimmune hepatitis.   

One of the advantages of mycophenolate mofetil is that it is less likely to cause nephrotoxicity and neurotoxicity than calcineurin inhibitors. However, it is associated with significant GI symptoms, and less commonly hypertension, hyperglycemia, and even pancytopenia.  

IMPDH is also the target of ribavirin, an antiviral agent used in the treatment of hepatitis C virus and respiratory syncytial virus. By inhibiting IMPDH, ribavirin prevents viral RNA from being synthesized, inhibiting viral replication.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ribavirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pyrimethamine:
Incorrect: Pyrimethamine is an antiparasitic drug that is used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis. It works similarly to methotrexate by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, thereby reducing the generation of tetrahydrofolate.
❌ Trimethoprim:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim is an antibacterial drug that is usually given with sulfamethoxazole. Like pyrimethamine and methotrexate, the target of trimethoprim is dihydrofolate reductase.
❌ Cyclosporine:
Incorrect: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant used to prevent organ transplant rejection. Cyclosporine, like tacrolimus, is a calcineurin inhibitor that prevents transcription of immune cytokines (e.g. interleukin-2), halting the proliferation and differentiation of the immune cells.
❌ Leflunomide:
Incorrect: Leflunomide is an immunosuppressant used to treat autoimmune disorders. It inhibits the synthesis of pyrimidines by inhibiting dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, the rate-limiting enzyme in de novo pyrimidine synthesis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office because of left thigh pain and numbness. The patient’s symptoms started two days after a 12-hour tech rehearsal for a Shakespearen play. She was wearing her costume, which includes a corset, and noticed numbness and burning sensation over the lateral side of her left thigh following the rehearsal. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates loss of light touch and pinprick sensation over the upper lateral thigh. Lower extremity strength is 5/5 bilaterally, and deep tendon reflexes are +2. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. Pain is reproduced with tapping immediately below the anterior superior iliac spine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is a mononeuropathy resulting from the compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN) which travels from the lumbar plexus, through the abdominal cavity, under the inguinal ligament, and into the subcutaneous tissue of the thigh. Commonly identified risk factors include pregnancy, tight-fitted clothes/seat belts, obesity, and diabetes mellitus. Affected patients present with pain, paresthesias (numbness and tingling), and hypoesthesia (diminished sensation) over the upper outer thigh. Muscle strength, however, is normal as the LFCN does not carry motor fibers. Symptoms may be reproduced with tapping over the lateral aspect of the inguinal ligament (Tinel's sign).    

Diagnosis is clinical, and most patients are managed with weight loss and avoidance of exacerbating factors (e.g. avoiding tight-fitted clothing). Anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin, or gabapentin) can help reduce neuropathic pain in patients with refractory symptoms.   

Option Analysis

❌ Compression of the ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal nerve innervates the medial thigh, inguinal region, and lower abdomen. Compression or injury of this nerve can occur during pelvic or hernia surgery. 
✅ Wearing tight fitting clothes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Prolonged strenuous activity is associated with the development of stress fractures. This condition presents as dull, chronic pain of the affected region (e.g. lateral hip pain in femoral head stress fracture). Burning pain and paraesthesia over the lateral thigh is suggestive of cutaneous nerve compression injury.
❌ Femoral neuropathy:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve innervates the anteromedial skin of the thigh (via the medial femoral cutaneous branch) as well as medial lower leg via the saphenous nerve. Femoral neuropathy is associated with diminished or absent knee jerk reflexes. 
❌ Increased intracompartmental pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intracompartmental pressure occurs in patients with acute compartment syndrome, which more commonly develops following a severe injury–such as a car accident or long bone fracture. It typically causes severe pain, paresthesia, and weakness of the affected limb.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation for one week of abdominal pain, nausea and fever. His urine appears dark, and his stools are pale in color. His partner has similar symptoms. He reports that they both traveled to a rural area in India 2 weeks ago. Medical history is significant for HIV infection for which he has not been taking his antiretroviral medications while traveling. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus. Tenderness is noted in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen with hepatomegaly. Laboratory testing confirms acute infection with Hepatitis E virus. The patient is counseled on supportive care and the need for follow-up testing regarding viral clearance. Which of the following laboratory results would be most suggestive of chronic infection?
questions.solution:
This patient’s abdominal pain, nausea, fever, dark urine and clay colored stools are the result of an acute infection with Hepatitis E virus. Most patients will clear the virus spontaneously; however, patients who are immunocompromised, including those who have poorly controlled HIV, are at increased risk for chronic infection.  Chronic hepatitis E infection can be diagnosed when PCR testing continues to be positive for HEV RNA in the serum or stool beyond six months from initial infection.

Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E infections are diagnosed based on laboratory testing.  The presence of anti-HAV IgM indicates acute infection with the Hepatitis A virus. Additional testing with PCR can be done to detect HAV RNA if IgM is negative and infection is still suspected based on the clinical scenario or exposures. Antibody testing in Hepatitis E is not well standardized, therefore both anti-HEV IgM and detection of HEV RNA by PCR are used to definitively diagnose HEV infection. Most patients with Hepatitis E infection will clear the virus within six months; however, patients who are immunocompromised are at risk of harboring the virus long-term and developing chronic infection. Therefore, follow-up testing should be performed to assess the patient’s status at 6 months.  Persistence of HEV RNA in stool or serum beyond six months is diagnostic for chronic hepatitis E infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with acute HEV infection. HEV infection is not considered chronic unless the HEV RNA has been present for 6 months or more.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with acute HEV infection. Hepatitis E infection is not considered chronic unless the HEV RNA has been present for 6 months or more.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with HEV infection that has been fully cleared.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings would be consistent with acute infection, where HEV RNA is present, and it has been less than 6 months from the initial infection and the patient is immunosuppressed.  Patients with immunosuppression may not form antibodies to the virus, and anti-HEV IgM is not necessary to make the diagnosis of acute infection in these cases.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with yellow eyes and skin for one day. She has had abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting and malaise for one week. Her partner had similar gastrointestinal symptoms one month ago but recovered spontaneously and did not have testing for the presence of an infection. Her past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine daily. She drinks approximately two glasses of wine each evening and is sexually active with her biologically male spouse. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg. Examination reveals scleral icterus and jaundice. There is mild tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen with hepatomegaly.  Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value  
Result
AST
802 units/L  
ALT
978 units/L  
Total bilirubin  
8.1 mg/dL  
INR
1.9
Anti-HAV IgM  
positive
Anti-HEV IgM  
negative
HEV RNA by PCR  
negative

choices.text: Counsel on reducing alcohol consumption to less than seven drinks per week

questions.solution:
This patient presents with jaundice, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting and malaise caused by acute infection with Hepatitis A. Treatment is mainly supportive, but patients should be counseled to avoid hepatotoxic medications including acetaminophen. This patient likely acquired the infection from her spouse based on the reported history of similar symptoms. Household and sexual contact with an infected person is a risk factor for acquiring the virus.

Management of acute hepatitis A infection consists of supportive care with adequate nutrition, hydration and symptomatic relief of nausea, vomiting, and pain. Patients should be counseled on lifestyle modifications, including avoiding hepatotoxic medications, herbal supplements and alcohol. Vaccination for hepatitis B should be offered following an acute infection. Post-exposure prophylaxis and prophylaxis of close contacts with an infected person should be offered to individuals who have not been vaccinated against Hepatitis A. Prophylaxis consists of the Hepatitis A vaccine, with or without immune globulin, depending on the individual’s age, immune status, and concurrent medical conditions.

Acute Hepatitis E is managed similarly to Hepatitis A with supportive care and lifestyle modifications; however, post-infection vaccination should include both Hepatitis A and B vaccines.  Patients who are immunocompromised can progress to chronic Hepatitis E infection and may be candidates for treatment with the antiviral drug ribavirin. Reducing immunosuppressive medications should be considered in an effort to allow the patient’s immune system to clear the virus.  

Option Analysis

✅ Counsel on avoiding acetaminophen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Counsel on reducing alcohol consumption to less than seven drinks per week:
Incorrect: Alcohol should be avoided completely during an acute episode of hepatitis.  
❌ Administer ribavirin:
Incorrect: Ribavirin is used in immunocompromised patients with chronic Hepatitis E infection. This patient has Hepatitis A infection with a functional immune system, therefore she would be expected to clear the virus spontaneously.  
❌ Reduce the dose of levothyroxine:
Incorrect: Medication dose reduction is considered in patients taking immunosuppressive therapy who develop chronic Hepatitis E infection or when a medication they are taking is likely to worsen hepatic injury. This patient has hepatitis A, and levothyroxine does not typically require dose adjustments for hepatic impairment.  
❌ Administer Hepatitis C vaccine:
Incorrect: There is currently no vaccine available for Hepatitis C.  After the acute infection, the patient should be offered vaccination against Hepatitis B.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of generalized fatigue and pruritus. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. She has no family history of liver disease. Past medical history is noncontributory and she does not take any medication. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows moist mucous membranes. Neck is supple. Lungs are clear to auscultation. No ascites or organomegaly is noted. Laboratory findings are shown below. Right upper quadrant ultrasound shows a normal appearing liver, gallbladder, and biliary tract. Antimitochondrial antibody titer is 1:80. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Complete Blood Count  

Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL
Leukocyte count  
5500/mm3   
Platelet Count  
200,000/mm3   
Serum Chemistry  

Sodium
142 mEq/L  
Potassium
4.2 mEq/L  
Chloride
95 mEq/L  
Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL  
Alanine aminotransferase  
20 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase  
21 U/L
Serum albumin  
4 g/dL
Serum total bilirubin  
2.1 mg/dL
Total protein  
6 g/dL
Alkaline phosphatase level  
250 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with generalized fatigue and pruritus was found to have elevated alkaline phosphatase and mildly elevated bilirubin, suggesting cholestatic liver disease. Given the normal ultrasound and positive antimitochondrial antibody titer, primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is the most likely diagnosis. This patient should be started on ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA).

PBC is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small and medium intrahepatic bile ducts. Upon diagnosis, the primary treatment for PBC is UDCA. UDCA is a hydrophilic bile acid that works by increasing the hydrophilic index of circulating bile acid, stimulating hepatocellular and biliary secretions, cytoprotection, immunomodulation and anti-inflammatory effects. It is associated with histologic improvement, increased survival rates, and reduced reliance on liver transplantation. It is generally well-tolerated, with some patients having weight gain as a side effect. It leads to biochemical response with normal alkaline phosphatase levels within a year of starting treatment. In the meantime, pruritus can be treated symptomatically with antihistamines or cholestyramine.  

Option Analysis

❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)  :
Incorrect: MRCP would be beneficial for further evaluation if primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) was suspected, which is more common in men and is usually associated with other autoimmune disorders (e.g. Inflammatory bowel disease), and has ultrasound findings of extrahepatic bile duct dilation. None of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, the antimitochondrial antibody titer is consistent with a diagnosis of PBC.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)  :
Incorrect: ERCP should be considered if cholestasis is suspected to be secondary to mechanical obstruction (choledocholithiasis) or strictures (e.g. primary sclerosing cholangitis). Given the normal right upper quadrant ultrasound and elevated antimitochondrial antibodies, primary biliary cholangitis is the most likely diagnosis, which is treated with ursodeoxycholic acid.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide would be appropriate if cholestasis led to cirrhosis of the liver and concomitant ascites. Given that  there are no signs of volume overload on physical examination and a normal liver is seen on the right upper quadrant ultrasound, furosemide is not necessary at this time.  
❌ Referral for liver transplant evaluation:
Incorrect: Referral for liver transplant evaluation would be appropriate for advanced cholestasis leading to cirrhosis of the liver. This patient has no sign of volume overload and normal ultrasound of the liver, and should therefore be treated with ursodeoxycholic acid first.  
✅ Ursodeoxycholic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after developing a headache, confusion, nausea and vomiting while running a marathon. The patient felt like he had to stop running at mile 22 and subsequently had two episodes of non-bilious, non-bloody emesis. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medication. Temperature is 38.0 °C (100.4 °F), blood pressure is 111/70 mm Hg, pulse rate is 105/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. The patient appears confused. Physical examination reveals significant perspiration. Initial laboratory evaluation shows a serum sodium  level of 117 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient presents with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, headache and confusion in the setting of hyponatremia.  These findings are concerning for cerebral edema in the setting of acute hyponatremia. The most appropriate next step in management is administration of an intravenous 100-mL bolus of 3% (hypertonic) saline.

Hyponatremia is a common electrolyte disturbance where the serum sodium concentration is less than 135 milliequivalents per liter. It can be acute (within 24 - 48 hours) or chronic (more than 48 hours). An acute drop in sodium can result in water moving into brain parenchyma, producing cerebral edema and causing symptoms such as headache, seizure, and coma.

Common causes of acute hyponatremia include postoperative states, extreme exercise (e.g. marathon runners), administration of oxytocin, bowel preparations or thiazide diuretics, intake of excessive amounts of water (primary polydipsia) and ecstasy use. Patients with acute symptomatic hyponatremia should be treated with a 100-mL bolus of 3% saline. If symptoms do not improve and the sodium remains low, additional boluses can be given. The goal is to increase the sodium level by at least 1-2 mEq/L/hr until resolution of symptoms, and then to increase the sodium level more slowly after that.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous 100-mL bolus of 3% (hypertonic) saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fluid restriction:
Incorrect: Fluid restriction may allow for slow correction of serum sodium; however, it should not be the sole treatment for patients with acute symptomatic hyponatremia.  
❌ Intravenous 0.9% saline:
Incorrect: For patients with acute hyponatremia, serum ADH is expected to be high, which induces water reabsorption in the kidneys with a significant elevation in urine osmolality. It can exceed the osmolality of normal saline (~280-300 mOsm/L), and has the potential to further lower the patient’s sodium. Use of 0.9% saline should be limited to those patients with evidence of volume depletion and minimal symptoms.  
❌ Immersion in ice water:
Incorrect: Immersion in ice water can be considered for young patients with exertional heat stroke when they remain symptomatic despite evaporative cooling measures. This patient with a body temperature of 100.4 °F is less likely to be suffering from exertional heat stroke.  
❌ Intravenous 0.45% saline:
Incorrect: In patients with acute hyponatremia, serum ADH is expected to be high, which causes water reabsorption in kidneys and significant elevation in urine osmolality. 0.45% saline can exceed the osmolality of normal saline (~140 mOsm/L), it has the potential to further lower the patient’s sodium.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of lower back pain. Review of systems is significant for poor appetite and a 10 lbs (4.5 kg) weight loss over the past 6 months. The patient had a resection of a localized meningioma 2 years ago without complications or recurrence. The patient does not take any medication. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows moist mucous membranes, pallor, and midline tenderness upon palpation at L3 and L4. There is pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the knees. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable without jugular venous distension (JVD). Laboratory results are shown below. A urine dipstick is negative for proteinuria. Radiograph of the spine shows a lytic bone lesion in the L4 vertebral body. Which of the following is the most likely cause of hyponatremia in this patient?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum Chemistry   

Sodium
128 mEq/L
Potassium
3.7 mEq/L  
Chloride
100 mEq/L  
Bicarbonate
25 mEq/L  
Calcium
11 mg/dL  
Blood urea nitrogen  
20 mg/dL  
Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL  
Total protein  
8.5 g/dL  
Albumin
2.5 g/dL  
Serum Osmolality  
285 mOsm/kg  
Complete Blood Count   

Hemoglobin
8.0 g/dL  
Leukocyte count  
10,000/mm3   
Platelets
180,000/mm3   
Urine electrolytes   

Sodium
18 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with low back pain and radiographic evidence of lytic bone lesions. These findings, together with poor appetite, weight loss and anemia, suggest undiagnosed multiple myeloma. Given the elevated protein gap (difference between total protein and albumin > 4 g/dL) and normal serum osmolality (between 280-295 mOsm/kg), pseudohyponatremia from paraproteinemia appears to be the most likely explanation for this patient's low sodium.

Pseudohyponatremia rarely occurs and refers to a lab artifact caused by high serum levels of triglycerides or protein, which can displace free water in plasma, resulting in an inaccurate measurement of sodium levels. When evaluating hyponatremia, a serum osmolality should be obtained. If there is a normal serum osmolality, then pseudohyponatremia is the likely cause and serum triglyceride and protein levels should be measured to confirm the diagnosis.

On the other hand, if plasma osmolality levels rise above 295 mmol/kg, this indicates the presence of other osmotically active solutes, like glucose or mannitol. Hyperosmolarity causes an osmotic shift of water from the intracellular space to extracellular fluid, causing dilutional hyponatremia. If serum osmolality falls below 280 mmol/kg, a diagnosis of true hyponatremia can be made.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pseudohyponatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surreptitious vomiting:
Incorrect: Surreptitious vomiting usually results in hypovolemic hyponatremia, and the serum osmolality is typically < 275 mmol/kg. This patient appears euvolemic on exam with a serum osmolality of 285 mEq/L, which is more consistent with pseudohyponatremia.  
❌ Mineralocorticoid deficiency:
Incorrect: Patients with mineralocorticoid deficiency typically have evidence of hypovolemia and metabolic alkalosis, as well as loss of sodium in urine, causing urine sodium levels to be > 20 mEq/L. This patient appears euvolemic on exam with a serum osmolality of 285 mEq/L and urine sodium level < 20 mEq/L which is more consistent with pseudohyponatremia.  
❌ Cerebral salt wasting:
Incorrect: Cerebral salt wasting occurs with an insult to the central nervous system in the form of trauma, recent surgery, or hemorrhage. The exact cause is unknown, but patients typically are hypovolemic and have a urine sodium of > 20 mEq/L. This patient’s meningioma resection was 2 years ago, the patient appears euvolemic on exam, and the serum osmolality of 285 mEq/L and urine sodium level of < 20 mEq/L; taken together, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with pseudohyponatremia.  
❌ Renal failure:
Incorrect: Renal failure causes true hyponatremia where serum osmolality is < 275 mmol/kg, and patients appear hypervolemic on examination due to volume retention, and have elevated urine sodium levels due to impaired resorption. In addition, BUN/creatinine is typically elevated. This patient appears euvolemic on exam with a serum osmolality of 285 mEq/L and urine sodium level < 20 mEq/L, which is more consistent with pseudohyponatremia.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with a one-week history of pain and swelling in his knees and ankles. Three weeks prior to the onset of his joint symptoms, he had an episode of nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain that resolved on its own. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. On physical examination, there is conjunctivitis bilaterally. The right knee is tender, warm, and swollen. Additionally, there is tenderness of the sacroiliac joints and the left Achilles tendon insertion site. Which of the following best characterizes the pattern of joint involvement that is most often seen with this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Symmetric arthritis of the small joints

questions.solution:
This patient’s joint, Achilles tendon, and eye findings after a recent enteric infection are consistent with reactive arthritis. This disease typically presents with asymmetric oligoarthritis, usually involving the large joints of the lower extremities (e.g. knees, ankles).  

Reactive arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy that presents as joint inflammation typically after an enteric or genitourinary tract infection (e.g. urethritis). Common causative organisms include Chlamydia trachomatis, Salmonella spp., and Shigella spp. Joint pain typically occurs days to weeks after the infection, and joint examination may reveal tenderness, warmth, and effusions. Inflammation of the sacroiliac joints and at the attachment sites of tendon to bone (enthesitis) is common.  

Other manifestations include dactylitis (“sausage digits”), conjunctivitis, or uveitis; painless oral ulcers; cardiac conduction disturbances; and aortitis. A specific skin finding, keratoderma blennorrhagicum (hyperkeratotic nodules on the palms and soles), may also be seen.   

Option Analysis

✅ Asymmetric oligoarthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Symmetric polyarthritis:
Incorrect: Symmetric polyarthritis is more typically seen in rheumatoid arthritis. However, this patient’s history of prior gastrointestinal infection, eye involvement, and Achilles enthesitis is more indicative of reactive arthritis.
❌ Migratory polyarthritis:
Incorrect: Migratory polyarthritis is associated with several diseases, including acute rheumatic fever and gout. This presentation of joint pain, sacroiliac tenderness, Achilles enthesitis, and conjunctivitis following a gastrointestinal infection is more consistent with reactive arthritis. 
❌ Symmetric arthritis of the small joints:
Incorrect: Symmetric involvement of small joints (e.g. hands, feet) would be more indicative of rheumatoid arthritis. This patient’s history and presentation is more consistent with reactive arthritis. 
❌ Monoarthritis:
Incorrect: Monoarthritis is seen in septic arthritis and crystal deposition diseases (e.g. gout, pseudogout). This patient’s history and presentation is more consistent with reactive arthritis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic for new-onset palpitations for the past 3 months. The symptoms occur “out of the blue” for a few seconds at a time. Past medical history is unremarkable. He recalls that his mother had been taking a medication for many years for a chronic condition, but he cannot remember the medication’s name. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, and pulse is 71/min. Cardiac auscultation reveals wide splitting of the second heart sound. An electrocardiogram is significant for tall broad P waves, prolonged PR intervals, and right bundle branch block. A cardiac echocardiogram shows downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets. Exposure to which of the following agents in utero most likely contributed to this patient’s cardiac defect?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with arrhythmias, downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets, and right bundle branch block. These findings are concerning for Ebstein anomaly, which is caused by in utero exposure to lithium.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets and atrialization of the right ventricle. Ebstein anomalies may present at any point in life.

Severe disease presents with cardiomegaly, hydrops, and tachyarrhythmias. Affected patients often die in utero. The moderate disease can present with cyanosis, congestive heart failure secondary to tricuspid valve regurgitation, and marked cardiomegaly. Patients with moderate disease may present with progressive right-sided heart failure in childhood. Finally, the mild disease often presents with arrhythmias, fatigue, progressive cyanosis, and right-sided heart failure during childhood or adulthood.

Most patients will have an abnormal electrocardiogram with tall and broad P-waves (secondary to right atrial enlargement) and a complete or incomplete right bundle branch block. Symptomatic patients may be managed surgically if they are appropriate candidates. If not, they can be medically managed and treated with a standard heart failure regimen of diuretics and digoxin.  

Option Analysis

❌ Methimazole:
Incorrect: Exposure to methimazole has been associated with aplasia cutis. Patients with this condition have a congenital absence of skin, often presenting as a round area without skin on the scalp. Methimazole treats hyperthyroidism through inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. However, the medication has not been associated with the Ebstein anomaly.  
✅ Lithium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ethanol:
Incorrect: Patients with exposure to alcohol in utero may suffer from fetal alcohol syndrome. This condition classically presents with facial features including a smooth philtrum, thin vermillion, and small palpebral fissures. Another primary feature is central nervous system damage. In contrast, in utero alcohol exposure has not been associated with Ebstein anomaly.  
❌ Thalidomide:
Incorrect: Thalidomide was originally developed as a treatment for morning sickness in pregnant women. It is classically associated with phocomelia, which is the absence and/or underdevelopment of the limbs. However, thalidomide has not been associated with Ebstein anomaly.  
❌ Spironolactone:
Incorrect: Spironolactone is an anti-androgen agent that is used to treat hypertension, heart failure, and hormonal acne. There is a theoretical risk of feminization of a male fetus if exposed in utero, though this concern is not well documented in the literature.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department after experiencing a syncopal episode while playing basketball one hour ago. The episode, which lasted about 30 seconds, was witnessed by his grandson, and the patient reports feeling only fatigue following the event. He denies any preceding symptoms. His medical history includes hyperlipidemia, and he is currently on rosuvastatin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mmHg. A late-peaking, grade 4/6 systolic murmur is best heard at the right upper sternal border, with radiation to the carotid arteries. An ECG shows evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with syncope and features suggestive of aortic stenosis (e.g. late-peaking systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border and evidence of LVH on ECG) should undergo inpatient cardiac monitoring and further workup.

Hospitalization should be considered for patients with syncope who have high-risk characteristics. This patient's risk factors, including male gender, age > 60 years, absence of warning signs before losing consciousness, signs suggestive of structural heart disease from the physical examination and ECG, and syncope during physical activity, are linked to an increased 30-day mortality risk. Additional indicators necessitating inpatient assessment include cardiac arrhythmias like sustained or symptomatic ventricular tachycardia, problematic bradycardia or heart block; malfunction of pacemakers or defibrillators; structural heart issues like hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; and significant anemia.

For suspected cardiac-related syncope, the diagnostic approach should be specific to the suspected underlying condition. Electrophysiology consultation is recommended for potential arrhythmias. Cardiac stress testing is useful in cases of syncope during exertion to evaluate for ischemia. For this patient with a late-peaking systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border, echocardiography is necessary to assess for severe aortic stenosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ambulatory ECG monitoring:
Incorrect: Extended outpatient cardiac monitoring with an ambulatory ECG monitor or an implantable loop recorder is appropriate for patients with syncope of probable arrhythmic origin who do not have the high-risk features seen in this patient (e.g., male sex, age >60 years, no syncopal prodrome, concern for structural heart disease based on clinical examination findings, and syncope during exertion). This patient has high risk features, therefore he should undergo further cardiac monitoring and inpatient workup.  
❌ Oral rehydration and observation:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration, observation, and reassurance may be appropriate for syncope due to orthostatic hypotension from dehydration or vasovagal episodes. However, this patient's syncope is likely secondary to aortic stenosis, and he should undergo further cardiac monitoring and inpatient workup.  
✅ Inpatient cardiac monitoring and workup:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tilt-table testing:
Incorrect: Tilt-table testing is primarily used for suspected vasovagal syncope. It can also be helpful when orthostatic hypotension is suspected, but the evaluation is inconclusive. Tilt-table testing is not indicated for this patient who has features of cardiac syncope and aortic stenosis.  
❌ Reassurance and discharge home:
Incorrect: Reassurance and discharge home are appropriate when a benign cause of syncope, such as neurally mediated syncope, is suspected. Neurally mediated syncope occurs most commonly in younger individuals and is associated with a prodrome of symptoms that may include nausea and diaphoresis. This patient's syncope is likely secondary to aortic stenosis, and he should undergo further cardiac monitoring and inpatient workup.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of fever, chills, and generalized malaise. The patient underwent a cystoscopy three weeks ago for hematuria. Past medical history is significant for recurrent cystitis, mitral valve prolapse, and type II diabetes. Current medications include metformin and NPH insulin. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse 99/min, respirations 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> 96% on room air. On physical examination, there are tender erythematous nodules at the fingertips. Cardiac auscultation shows a 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Blood cultures are drawn, and the patient is initiated on an antibiotic that inhibits cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portions of the cell wall precursors. The patient does not respond to this antibiotic therapy. Which antibiotic resistance mechanisms are likely responsible for this treatment failure?

choices.text: Poor interaction with binding proteins at the bacterial cell wall
Amino acid modification at the bacterial cell wall

questions.solution:
This patient has a fever, tender nodules, and a holosystolic murmur with a history of mitral valve prolapse. Given this patient’s history of complicated cystitis, there may be urinary tract colonization with Enterococcus or bacterial seeding (leading to bacteremia) from the recent cystoscopy. These findings are concerning for infective endocarditis.

Vancomycin is a commonly used antibiotic for the empiric treatment of endocarditis. It is bactericidal and inhibits bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. Vancomycin is effective against most gram-positive organisms, including multidrug-resistant organisms such as methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA). It is indicated in the treatment of endocarditis, possible MRSA infection, sepsis of unknown source, and many others. Vancomycin can only be given intravenously for systemic infections, as the oral form does not get absorbed well and is only used to treat C. difficile colitis. Adverse effects include nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, diffuse flushing (red man syndrome), and, very rarely, DRESS syndrome.

Vancomycin is not susceptible to beta-lactamases. Resistance mechanisms to vancomycin have been observed with enterococcal species via amino acid modification of D-Ala-D-Ala to D-Ala- D-Lac, to which vancomycin binds with significantly lower affinity.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Poor interaction with binding proteins at the bacterial cell wall:
Incorrect: Drugs such as methicillin bind to the PBP/transpeptidases that crosslink mucopeptides to form the bacterial cell wall. Alterations mediate methicillin resistance in penicillin-binding proteins that reduce the affinity of beta-lactam agents to these proteins.  Methicillin does not bind directly to the D-Ala-D-Ala amino acid precursors of the cell wall.  
❌ Increased efflux from the cell:
Incorrect: Resistance to tetracyclines is due to increased efflux or reduced uptake into bacterial cells by plasmid-encoded transport pumps. Tetracyclines do not inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis and are not used in treating bacterial endocarditis.  
✅ Amino acid modification at the bacterial cell wall:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mutation in DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones are bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit the prokaryotic enzyme topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase). Mutations mediate resistance to quinolones to bacterial DNA gyrase. These drugs do not inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis.  
❌ Enzymatic degradation of the drug:
Incorrect: Penicillinases (beta-lactamases) are produced by some strains of Staphylococcus aureus and cause penicillin resistance by breaking down the beta-lactam ring of penicillins. Penicillin inhibits bacterial cell synthesis by binding to transpeptidases and not a D-Ala-D-Ala portion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. The patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 3 years ago and was started on a short course of corticosteroids and methotrexate. However, due to severe oral ulcers and diarrhea, the patient asks the physician if she can stop using methotrexate and switch to a medication that inhibits tumor necrosis factor (TNF) that she read about on the internet. The physician agrees on the use of a TNF inhibitor instead of methotrexate. Which of the following should the physician tell the patient about this medication?

choices.text: These medications can increase the risk of lymphomas.
Unlike methotrexate, this new medication does not slow down joint damage.
It is common to prescribe multiple medications from the TNF inhibitor class to achieve the best outcomes.
No testing is required before starting this medication.

questions.solution:
The physician decided to start this patient on a TNF inhibitor after she experienced side effects while taking methotrexate. TNF inhibitors are members of a class of medications called disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) that can be used in rheumatoid arthritis to decrease joint damage. Apart from rheumatoid arthritis, TNF inhibitors can also be used in the treatment of psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disorders, and ankylosing spondylitis. The discovery of TNF inhibitors was a major step in the therapeutic approach to rheumatic disease.

TNF is a major proinflammatory cytokine that is mainly produced by activated macrophages but can also be produced by lymphocytes and natural killer cells. Soluble TNF then binds to its receptors and signals the production of other cytokines (e.g., IL-1, IL-6). TNF plays an important role in many autoimmune disorders and inflammatory disorders, but also is involved in the defense against infections (e.g., tuberculosis) and tumors.

There are 5 TNF inhibitors in use today, four monoclonal antibodies against TNF (e.g., infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab, and golimumab), and one soluble TNF receptor (etanercept).

TNF inhibitors are associated with significant side effects, some of which can be lethal. The most common side effects include:

  • Infections: TNF inhibitors increase the risk of many infections, including viral, bacterial, and fungal infections. These infections can sometimes be lethal. In addition, it has been shown that the use of TNF inhibitors can lead to the reactivation of tuberculosis and hepatitis B and C. Therefore, it is recommended that all patients be tested for active/latent TB, HIV, and hepatitis B, and C before starting the treatment with TNF inhibitors.
  • Hepatotoxicity: Which can be severe and lead to fulminant hepatic failure.
  • Malignancies: TNF inhibitors increase the risk of malignancy, especially lymphomas.
  • Congestive heart failure: although TNF inhibitors do not lead to CHF, patients with preexisting CHF taking TNF inhibitors can develop worsening of cardiac function and increased mortality. Therefore, TNF inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with moderate to severe CHF.
  • Demyelinating disorders: This includes optic neuritis, myelitis, transverse myelitis, and guillain-barre syndrome. Patients with preexisting demyelinating disorders should avoid the use of TNF inhibitors.  

Option Analysis

✅ These medications can increase the risk of lymphomas.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Unlike methotrexate, this new medication does not slow down joint damage.:
Incorrect: TNF inhibitors are considered disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and like methotrexate, they moderate the joint damage in rheumatoid arthritis patients.  
❌ This medication has no contraindications.  :
Incorrect: TNF inhibitors do have a few contraindications, including active infections, moderate to severe heart failure, and hypersensitivity reactions.  
❌ It is common to prescribe multiple medications from the TNF inhibitor class to achieve the best outcomes.  :
Incorrect: While non-biological DMARDs like methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide can be used in conjunction with biological DMARDs to achieve a better outcome, the use of a TNF inhibitor with another biological immunosuppressant is contraindicated.  
❌ No testing is required before starting this medication.  :
Incorrect: The use of TNF inhibitors can lead to the activation of many severe diseases including hepatitis B and C, HIV, and tuberculosis. Therefore, all patients should be tested for active/latent TB, HIV, and hepatitis B and C.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents to the emergency room with hematuria and generalized fatigue for the past month. The patient has not experienced abdominal pain, fever, dysuria, or increased frequency of micturition. However, he has experienced a 3.5 kg (9 lb) weight loss over the last month and loss of appetite. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked 2-3 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He does not consume alcohol or use recreational substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis is shown below. Cystoscopy is performed and biopsy specimens are obtained. Molecular analysis of the cells reveals malignant features and high sensitivity to paclitaxel. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate therapeutic agent?  

Laboratory Value
Result
Color
Clear
Specific gravity  
1.013
Glucose
Negative
Blood
Positive
Leukocyte esterase  
Negative
Nitrites
Negative
Leukocytes
1-2/hpf
Erythrocytes
60/hpf
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent
Casts
None

choices.text: Inhibits topoisomerase I and promotes DNA degradation
Inhibits polymerisation of microtubules and prevents mitotic spindle formation
Inhibits topoisomerase II and promotes DNA degradation
Hyperstabilizes microtubules and prevents mitotic spindle formation
Inhibits ribonucleotide reductase and reduces DNA synthesis

questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with painless hematuria, weight loss, loss of appetite, and a positive smoking history. This clinical vignette strongly suggests a urothelial malignancy unless proven otherwise and necessitates evaluation.

Taxanes (e.g. paclitaxel) are a group of chemotherapeutic agents that act as microtubule inhibitors. They are active during the M phase of the cell cycle. They hyper-stabilize polymerized microtubules that are involved in the mitotic spindle, effectively preventing spindle separation. As a result, anaphase and DNA replication are arrested. Since malignant cells replicate more frequently when compared to normal cells, they are more susceptible to microtubule inhibitors.

Taxanes such as paclitaxel are used for the treatment of a variety of solid tumors including breast, head, and neck, ovarian, lung, prostate, and bladder cancers. Use of taxanes can result in adverse effects including myelosuppression, neuropathy, and hypersensitivity.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibits topoisomerase I and promotes DNA degradation:
Incorrect: Topoisomerase I inhibitors include irinotecan and topotecan. By inhibiting the enzyme topoisomerase I, these medications prevent DNA unwinding and arrest DNA replication.  
❌ Inhibits polymerisation of microtubules and prevents mitotic spindle formation:
Incorrect: Vinca alkaloids, such as vincristine and vinblastine are microtubule inhibitors. Vinca alkaloids bind to ꞵ-tubulin and inhibit microtubule polymerization. In contrast, taxanes work via a different mechanism of action.  
❌ Inhibits topoisomerase II and promotes DNA degradation:
Incorrect: Etoposide and teniposide are topoisomerase II inhibitors. Inhibition of topoisomerase II increases DNA degradation.  
✅ Hyperstabilizes microtubules and prevents mitotic spindle formation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits ribonucleotide reductase and reduces DNA synthesis:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea is an antineoplastic agent that is S-phase specific. The medication inhibits ribonucleotide reductase and thereby arrests the synthesis of pyrimidine bases of DNA. In contrast, paclitaxel works via a different mechanism of action.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The patient took multiple tablets of acetaminophen three hours ago for right foot pain that began several days ago after beginning an intense exercise regimen. The patient has not had any suicidal thoughts, hallucinations, or a history of psychiatric illness. The patient had a runny nose, sinus congestion, and headaches last week. Medications include an oral contraceptive. The patient had one glass of wine last night and normally drinks 2-3 alcoholic drinks per week. The patient does not use tobacco or recreational drugs. Menarche was at age 13, and her last menstrual period was 3 months ago. The patient’s temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 52/min, and blood pressure is 98/68 mmHg. BMI is 15.5 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination reveals soft, unpigmented hair on the face, arms, and legs. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following factors likely predisposed this patient to her current illness?
questions.solution:
This young adult female is presenting with signs of early acetaminophen toxicity (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting). The patient likely has anorexia nervosa given an irregular menstrual cycle, bradycardia, hypotension, reduced BMI, and physical examination findings demonstrating lanugo (e.g., soft, unpigmented hair).

Malnutrition predisposes patients to acetaminophen hepatotoxicity. Hepatocytes mainly metabolize acetaminophen by glucuronidation and sulfation to non-toxic metabolites, which are excreted in urine. A small amount of acetaminophen is metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes (also known as microsomal metabolism) to a highly toxic metabolite, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine, or NAPQI. The hepatic process of glucuronidation relies on hepatic carbohydrate reserves, and in the fasting or malnourished state, glucuronidation of acetaminophen is reduced, which leads to increased microsomal metabolism and subsequent production of NAPQI. Normally, this toxic metabolite is inactivated by an antioxidant called glutathione. In therapeutic doses, acetaminophen does not cause severe side effects. However, depleted glutathione stores, also associated with the fasting and malnourished state, compromise detoxification of NAPQI and predispose to hepatic injury.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 



Option Analysis

❌ Age of patient:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen metabolism is age-dependent, with decreased metabolism and increased risk of toxicity occurring with increasing age. This patient is a young adult, making her age an unlikely cause of acetaminophen toxicity.   
✅ Malnutrition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Recent consumption of alcohol   :
Incorrect: Acute alcohol ingestion is not a significant risk factor for hepatotoxicity; in contrast, it may be protective by competing with acetaminophen for CYP2E1 and, thereby, decreasing the amount of NAPQI produced. Chronic alcohol consumption, in contrast, depletes glutathione stores and synthesis, as well as induces CYP enzymes, resulting in the accumulation of the toxic metabolite NAPQI.   
❌ Recent viral illness   :
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is the first-line therapy for children with fever or pain since aspirin can cause Reye’s syndrome, which is a life-threatening condition that can occur after a viral infection.   
❌ Use of oral contraceptives   :
Incorrect: Medications that induce CYP2E1 enzymes can result in acetaminophen toxicity; since a small amount of acetaminophen is also metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes (also known as microsomal metabolism) to a highly toxic metabolite, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine or NAPQI. CYP inducers can result in elevated NAPQI byproducts. These medications include anticonvulsants, antituberculosis agents, as well as some herbal medications. Oral contraceptive pills are substrates of cytochrome P-450 but are not known to induce these enzymes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for lower back pain. The pain started six months ago and is worse at night. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the lumbar region of the vertebral column. MRI of the lumbar spine shows neoplastic masses. On additional evaluation, the patient is found to have metastatic prostate cancer. The physician decides to start the patient on a medication that blocks testosterone receptors on the tumor cells. Which of the following side effects is this patient at risk for due to this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with metastatic prostate cancer is started on a testosterone receptor blocker, flutamide, as part of the treatment. Hepatotoxicity is a possible side effect of this medication.

Androgens stimulate the growth of the prostate cells and can also induce the growth of prostate cancer; therefore, anti-androgens used in managing prostate cancer inhibit tumor growth. Flutamide is one such anti-androgen that blocks testosterone receptors on the tumor cells, thereby inhibiting the proliferation of the tumor. Due to its anti-androgen effects, flutamide is also sometimes used in managing hirsutism in women and hair loss in men.

The most common side effect of flutamide is hot flashes, usually seen in more than 50% of the population. Also, decreased libido, vomiting, and gynecomastia can be seen. One of the most severe and feared side effects of flutamide is hepatotoxicity. It usually happens secondary to mitochondrial injury of hepatocytes, causing cholestatic hepatitis and, ultimately, hepatic failure. Therefore, patients with severe liver injury must avoid using flutamide.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hepatotoxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Certain medications (e.g., bleomycin, amiodarone) can cause pulmonary fibrosis as a side effect. It is not associated with flutamide.  
❌ Heart failure:
Incorrect: Thiazolidinediones can increase the risk of inducing or worsening heart failure. Flutamide is not directly related to the development of heart failure.  
❌ Hemochromatosis:
Incorrect: Exogenous androgen abuse can lead to hemochromatosis. However, flutamide is a testosterone receptor blocker and does not cause hemochromatosis.  
❌ Nephrotoxicity:
Incorrect: Flutamide is not known to cause nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the physician to discuss his hair loss. The patient first noticed the hair loss two years ago, which has progressed since then. His father and brother also had early hair loss. Physical examination reveals hair loss consistent with male pattern hair loss (i.e. androgenetic alopecia). The physician decided to start the patient on finasteride in addition to a ketoconazole shampoo. Which of the following best describes ketoconazole's role in treating this patient’s hair loss?

choices.text: Decreased testosterone synthesis by inhibiting 17,20 lyase enzyme
Decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone by inhibiting the 5-alpha reductase enzyme
Direct stimulation of the growth of hair follicles
Increased blood flow to the hair follicles
Killing the fungi in the hair scalp

questions.solution:
This patient has androgenetic alopecia and was given finasteride and ketoconazole shampoo to decrease hair loss. Ketoconazole is an antifungal medication that has anti-androgen effects. These effects are due to two main mechanisms:

  • Ketoconazole inhibits the synthesis of testosterone by inhibiting the enzyme 17, 20 lyase, which is needed for the biosynthesis of testosterone
  • Ketoconazole also has competitive inhibition effects on androgen receptors.
Because of these anti-androgen effects, ketoconazole shampoo can be used to treat androgenetic alopecia (i.e. male pattern hair loss). It is often used with finasteride to produce greater effects and decrease hair loss.

Male patients taking ketoconazole to treat chronic fungal infections can experience side effects related to the anti-androgen effects of ketoconazole. These side effects include impotence, decreased libido, gynecomastia, oligospermia, and infertility.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased testosterone synthesis by inhibiting 17,20 lyase enzyme:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone by inhibiting the 5-alpha reductase enzyme:
Incorrect: 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (e.g. finasteride) are effective in treating androgenetic alopecia. However, ketoconazole does not inhibit 5-alpha reductase enzymes.  
❌ Direct stimulation of the growth of hair follicles:
Incorrect: Ketoconazole has no direct effect on the growth of hair follicles.  
❌ Increased blood flow to the hair follicles:
Incorrect: Minoxidil is one of the treatment options for hair loss for various causes. It increases the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) mRNA, increasing the blood flow to the hair follicles, and promoting their growth. Ketoconazole has no such effect.  
❌ Killing the fungi in the hair scalp:
Incorrect: The use of ketoconazole in androgenetic alopecia is due to its anti-androgen effects, not antifungal effects.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of frequent episodes of color changes and pain in her fingers when she is exposed to cold temperatures. She also has had progressive tightening and thickening of the skin on her hands and forearms for the past 6 months. She mentions frequent heartburn and difficulty swallowing. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the skin appears shiny and tight with decreased mobility over the fingers bilaterally and extending proximally to the elbows. There are no other areas of skin thickening or tightening. Full strength is present in the upper and lower extremities. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following additional physical exam findings would most likely be present given this patient’s likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Erythema of the cheeks sparing the nasolabial folds
Excessive hair growth on the face and body
Erythematous, papulosquamous eruption over the dorsal surfaces of the knuckles
Firm white nodules on the fingers

questions.solution:
This 36-year-old woman with skin thickening on her hands and forearms, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastroesophageal symptoms likely has systemic sclerosis. Her symptoms are consistent with CREST syndrome. Calcinosis cutis is the presence of calcifications in the skin and subcutaneous tissue that can present as firm white nodules, particularly on the hands and feet. It is one of the manifestations of CREST syndrome.
