Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic connective tissue disorder characterized by connective tissue thickening due to fibroblast dysfunction and increased collagen and ground substance production. This fibrosis of SSc affects the skin, causing tight and thickened skin, and it can affect internal organs as well. Different disease subsets are associated with different patterns of organ involvement.  

Patients like this one with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis typically present with puffy fingers distal to the metacarpophalangeal joints and develop skin sclerosis distal to the elbows (involving the forearms) and knees, sparing the trunk and proximal extremities. They may also have manifestations of CREST syndrome, which includes Calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasias.  

Raynaud phenomenon is a condition that affects blood flow, usually in the fingers and toes. When patients are exposed to cold temperatures or emotional stress, the blood vessels narrow, leading to reduced blood supply to the fingers, causing them to turn white or blue and to feel cold and numb. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include reflux symptoms and voice hoarseness as well esophageal dysmotility and dysphagia.  

Patients with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis typically present with puffy hands and develop skin thickening that extends to the upper arms, thighs, and trunk. Patients with diffuse disease can also have rapid progression of skin thickening with early development of lung fibrosis; they also have an increased risk of renal crisis and cardiac involvement.  



Option Analysis

❌ Erythema of the cheeks sparing the nasolabial folds:
Incorrect: A malar rash is an erythematous rash over the cheeks and bridge of the nose sparing the nasolabial folds. It is frequently seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It is not seen with systemic sclerosis, which is the likely diagnosis in this case.
❌ Excessive hair growth on the face and body:
Incorrect: Hirsutism is excessive hair growth on the face and body and is most commonly seen in conditions associated with hormonal imbalances (e.g., polycystic ovarian syndrome, Cushing syndrome). It is not seen with systemic sclerosis, which is the likely diagnosis in this case.
❌ Erythematous, papulosquamous eruption over the dorsal surfaces of the knuckles:
Incorrect: Gottron papules are distinct, flat-topped, violaceous to erythematous papules over the dorsal surfaces of the finger joints. This type of rash is seen in patients with dermatomyositis. This patient’s history and physical examination are more suggestive of systemic sclerosis.
✅ Firm white nodules on the fingers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Purple discoloration of the eyelids:
Incorrect: Soft, blue-purple discoloration on the eyelids is suggestive of a heliotrope rash. This rash is characteristic of dermatomyositis, an inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. This patient’s history and physical examination are more suggestive of systemic sclerosis.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe headache and blurry vision. The patient states that her symptoms started an hour ago and have progressively worsened. She was recently diagnosed with systemic sclerosis and is currently taking pantoprazole for gastroesophageal reflux and maintaining core and digital warmth to manage Raynaud phenomenon. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 98/min, blood pressure is 215/120 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination reveals visible skin tightening on the face, forearms, chest, and legs. Retinal hemorrhages are seen on eye exam, and there is no papilledema. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows a bland urine sediment. Results from laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory test  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.2 g/dL 
 Leukocytes  6,200/µL 
 Platelets  61,000/µL 
 Lactate dehydrogenase  2,154 U/L 
 Creatinine  2.91 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL) 
 Peripheral blood smear  Schistocytes
questions.solution:
This woman with a recent diagnosis of systemic sclerosis presents with a sudden severe headache, blurry vision, severe hypertension, and laboratory signs of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and renal impairment; she is experiencing malignant hypertension from a scleroderma renal crisis.  

Scleroderma renal crisis (SRC) is a severe complication of systemic sclerosis (SSc), particularly associated with the diffuse cutaneous form. Risk factors include recent onset of systemic sclerosis (≤4 years), diffuse skin disease, the presence of anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, and recent use of glucocorticoids. In SSc, vasculopathy leads to luminal narrowing and ischemia of the kidneys. In response to renal ischemia, activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) occurs and results in further vasoconstriction and hypertension. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia can occur with schistocytes seen on peripheral blood smears.  

The focus of treatment is to rapidly reduce blood pressure and improve renal function to prevent irreversible kidney damage and other complications. First-line treatment is with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, particularly captopril, which has a quick onset of action. ACE inhibitors have been shown to improve kidney function and survival rates significantly by reducing angiotensin II-mediated vasoconstriction and decreasing glomerular capillary pressure.

Treatments vary for the other manifestations of systemic sclerosis. Raynaud phenomenon is treated with calcium channel blockers and PDE5 inhibitors if patients cannot take calcium channel blockers or show no improvement with them. PPIs are used to treat esophageal reflux symptoms, and endoscopic dilatation may be needed for esophageal strictures. Interstitial lung disease is treated with immunosuppressive therapies, and pulmonary hypertension is treated with phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors like sildenafil; endothelin receptor blockers like bosentan; or prostacyclin pathway agonists like treprostinil.

Option Analysis

❌ High-dose intravenous corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are not used to treat scleroderma renal crisis. In fact, recent use of glucocorticoids is a risk factor for scleroderma renal crisis; therefore, glucocorticoids should be avoided in patients with SSc.
❌ Intravenous esmolol:
Incorrect: β-Blockers are typically not first-line therapy for hypertensive emergencies other than for episodes associated with eclampsia/preeclampsia, acute coronary syndrome, and aortic dissection. Additionally, β-blockers may exacerbate Raynaud phenomenon and should therefore be avoided in patients with systemic sclerosis.
✅ Intravenous captopril:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Urgent hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Dialysis is only used in cases of scleroderma renal crisis with life-threatening complications or refractory fluid overload. ACE inhibitors should be started initially for scleroderma renal crisis, as they can significantly improve renal function and blood pressure without the need for dialysis.
❌ Intravenous cyclophosphamide:
Incorrect: The mainstay of treatment for scleroderma renal crisis is ACE inhibitors. Immunosuppressive agents have not been shown to provide benefit.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, osteopenia and recurrent kidney stones. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 54/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is somnolent but awakens to touch, and the abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation. Skin and mucous membranes are dry. ECG demonstrates sinus bradycardia and a shortened QT interval. Laboratory testing shows a serum calcium level of 14.5 mg/dL. In addition to aggressive IV fluid hydration, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of osteopenia and recurrent kidney stones in conjunction with this acute episode of severe, symptomatic hypercalcemia is consistent with a hyperparathyroid crisis. The initial goal is to reduce serum calcium levels with aggressive IV hydration. Bisphosphonates, such as zoledronic acid, should also be given.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the most common causes of hypercalcemia. In this condition, the parathyroid glands secrete excess parathyroid hormone (PTH). As a result, there is increased bone resorption, decreased renal excretion of calcium, and increased intestinal absorption of calcium. This can result in diminished bone mineral density and signs and symptoms of elevated serum calcium levels (e.g., recurrent nephrolithiasis).

The condition is often mild and asymptomatic. However, severe hypercalcemia can occur. Patients can present with altered mental status, weakness, polyuria and polydipsia, nausea, abdominal pain, constipation, hypertension, and bradycardia. ECG findings of bradycardia, atrioventricular block, and shortened QT interval may be seen. Measuring the serum calcium level will confirm that hypercalcemia is present.

In severe hypercalcemia, initial treatment is aggressive IV fluid hydration to correct the underlying volume depletion. In addition, antiresorptive therapy with bisphosphonates, namely zoledronic acid or pamidronate, can be initiated. Once the patient’s volume status has normalized (or if hypervolemia occurs), loop diuretics may also be used judiciously. Ultimately, parathyroidectomy is the definitive treatment for primary hyperparathyroidism, but the diagnosis must be confirmed with appropriate testing.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV zoledronic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Parathyroidectomy:
Incorrect: Parathyroidectomy is indicated for definitive treatment in patients with symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, but it is not the immediate step for managing acute hypercalcemia due to hyperparathyroidism. Additionally, confirmation of hyperparathyroidism is required before surgery.  
❌ IV furosemide:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics are used in the management of acute hypercalcemia from hyperparathyroidism. However, these are typically initiated as adjunct therapy only after the patient’s volume depletion is corrected.  
❌ Oral calcium carbonate:
Incorrect: This patient has severe hypercalcemia related to hyperparathyroidism. Calcium supplementation could worsen hypercalcemia.  
❌ Oral alendronate:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates are used in the management of severe hypercalcemia due to hyperparathyroidism. However, IV zoledronic acid or pamidronate are the most appropriate options.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of kidney stones presents for evaluation of fatigue, depression and bone pain for several months. The patient’s sister was recently diagnosed with thyroid cancer and their father has a history of pheochromocytoma. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show elevated serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels. Neck ultrasound demonstrates an enlarged left parathyroid gland. Which additional test should be performed next to further evaluate this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Genetic testing for a RET mutation
Genetic testing for a MEN1 mutation

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms and laboratory studies are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism likely from a parathyroid adenoma. Additionally, this patient’s family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN), type 2. Thus, genetic testing for a RET mutation is warranted.

In primary hyperparathyroidism, the parathyroid glands secrete excess parathyroid hormone (PTH). As a result, there is increased bone resorption, decreased renal excretion of calcium, and increased intestinal absorption of calcium, resulting in hypercalcemia. Causes of primary hyperparathyroidism include parathyroid adenomas, which is likely in this patient, multiglandular hyperplasia (formerly parathyroid hyperplasia), and parathyroid carcinoma.

Taking a full history is critical, particularly since parathyroid adenomas are one type of tumor associated with both MEN1 and MEN2A. If the patient has personal or family history suggesting these disorders, genetic testing should be pursued. This can be accomplished with an evaluation for mutations in the MEN1 (for MEN1) or RET (for MEN2A) genes. If positive, screening for additional tumors is warranted.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Genetic testing for a RET mutation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum gastrin level:
Incorrect: This test is used to evaluate for gastrinoma, a component of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). However, this patient’s family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma is more concerning for MEN2A.  
❌ Serum phosphate level:
Incorrect: While hypophosphatemia is a common finding in primary hyperparathyroidism, it is a nonspecific test and would not provide additional diagnostic information in this patient’s case. It can sometimes be used to differentiate between primary and tertiary hyperparathyroidism.  
❌ MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: Pituitary adenoma is a component of MEN1, which would be evident on a brain MRI. However, this patient’s clinical picture is more concerning for MEN2A given the family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma.  
❌ Genetic testing for a MEN1 mutation:
Incorrect: MEN1 mutation testing is used to diagnose MEN1, which commonly presents with tumors of the pituitary, parathyroid, and pancreas. However, this patient’s history is more suggestive of MEN2A given the family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is undergoing a red blood cell transfusion. Thirty minutes into the transfusion, he suddenly develops dyspnea, cough, and chest tightness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), heart rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On physical examination, he appears anxious and tachypneic. There is no rash or urticaria. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral rales without wheezing. There is no lower extremity edema. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and provide respiratory support
Stop the blood transfusion and administer intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone
Stop the blood transfusion and administer intravenous (IV) furosemide
Continue the blood transfusion and administer intramuscular (IM) epinephrine
Continue the blood transfusion and initiate intravenous (IV) broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.solution:
This patient exhibits sudden onset dyspnea, cough, chest tightness, hypotension, and hypoxemia during a blood transfusion and most likely has transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). TRALI is a life-threatening complication of blood transfusions that is characterized by acute respiratory distress and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. It typically occurs during or shortly after a blood transfusion. Management of TRALI involves immediate cessation of the blood transfusion and immediate airway and hemodynamic stabilization.

TRALI is caused by donor antibodies reacting against the recipient's leukocytes, leading to capillary leak and pulmonary edema. The first step in management involves stopping the blood transfusion to prevent further exposure to donor antibodies. Next, patients should receive supportive care with oxygen and mechanical ventilation if needed. This condition can rapidly progress to severe hypoxemia and respiratory failure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stop the blood transfusion and provide respiratory support:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stop the blood transfusion and administer intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). While the transfusion should be stopped, corticosteroids are not generally recommended for treatment of TRALI. The immediate focus should be on providing respiratory support.  
❌ Stop the blood transfusion and administer intravenous (IV) furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). Stopping the transfusion is appropriate, but administering IV furosemide is not appropriate treatment of TRALI. It is indicated for transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which is characterized by volume overload; whereas TRALI involves noncardiogenic pulmonary edema.  
❌ Continue the blood transfusion and administer intramuscular (IM) epinephrine:
Incorrect: Continuing the transfusion is contraindicated in the context of a suspected transfusion reaction. Epinephrine is used for anaphylactic reactions, not for transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), and continuing the transfusion could worsen the patient’s condition.  
❌ Continue the blood transfusion and initiate intravenous (IV) broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). Continuing the blood transfusion in the presence of acute respiratory symptoms suggestive of a transfusion reaction is inappropriate. While the symptoms may mimic sepsis, the temporal relation to the transfusion is more suggestive of TRALI, and antibiotics are not indicated.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic because of joint pain for the last seven months. The pain is in the joints of both hands; it is most severe after waking up and decreases throughout the day. In addition, it is difficult to move her hand or hold any object in the morning, which occurs for the first half an hour after waking. Medical and family histories are unremarkable. On physical examination, both hands have warmth and tenderness in several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The patient is prescribed medication to decrease the joint damage. This medication works by inhibiting tetrahydrofolate synthesis. Which of the following is the most likely medication?
questions.solution:
This patient has most likely developed rheumatoid arthritis and was prescribed methotrexate to prevent further joint damage. Methotrexate is a non-biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) and is used as the first-line treatment of rheumatoid arthritis as it halts the disease progression.

Methotrexate inhibits the proliferation of immune cells and thus inhibits the immune response via multiple mechanisms of action. The main effect of methotrexate is inhibiting the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHTFR). Tetrahydrofolate is the active form of folate needed to make purines and pyrimidine bases and thus make DNA and RNA. By inhibiting DHFTR, methotrexate inhibits the synthesis of DNA and RNA required for cellular division and immune response, inhibiting the proliferation of immune cells. This is also the mechanism by which methotrexate can be used to treat some cancers. It can also inhibit protein synthesis.

Adenosine has anti-inflammatory effects and suppresses T- and B-cell proliferation and response. In addition, methotrexate has another mechanism of action that helps reduce immune response. It inhibits an enzyme called AICAR transformylase, which results in the accumulation of adenosine.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Methotrexate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Leflunomide:
Incorrect:  Leflunomide is an antimetabolite that inhibits the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines. It works by inhibiting the dihydroorotate dehydrogenase enzyme, thereby inhibiting the synthesis of orotic acid from carbamoyl phosphate.  
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids have anti-inflammatory effects and can be used in patients with rheumatoid arthritis to decrease inflammation and pain. They do not inhibit the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate.  
❌ Naproxen:
Incorrect: Naproxen is an NSAID that can be used to treat the pain in rheumatoid arthritis. It works via the inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes and inhibits prostaglandins' synthesis. It has no direct effect on the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate.  
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen acts in the central nervous system by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins and thus reduces fever and pain. It does not affect the peripheral inflamed tissues nor inhibit the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a follow-up of rheumatoid arthritis. The patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis five years ago. The patient’s only medication is methotrexate which she takes regularly. The patient’s last flare of rheumatoid arthritis was one year ago, and the dose of methotrexate was subsequently increased. The patient does not drink alcohol or use nicotine products. At the end of the visit, the patient is again counseled on the potential adverse effects of methotrexate. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which is now stable on treatment with methotrexate.  Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits the dihydrofolate reductase enzyme, preventing the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate. Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for RA as it decreases joint damage and improves joint function. It is also used in other connective tissue disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, psoriasis), some cancers (e.g., primarily leukemia/lymphoma), and ectopic pregnancy. It should be started as soon as possible to suppress the progression of joint damage.

Gastrointestinal manifestations are the most common side effects (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain). Methotrexate can also cause oral ulcers. The most severe side effects are liver toxicity (manifesting as asymptomatic liver enzyme elevations or hepatic steatosis) and pulmonary fibrosis. Finally, because it is a folate antagonist and immunosuppressive, methotrexate can lead to megaloblastic anemia and leukopenia.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevation of liver enzymes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ QT-segment prolongation:
Incorrect:  QT-segment prolongation is associated with several medications, including class I and III antiarrhythmics, ondansetron, and haloperidol. Methotrexate is not associated with QT-segment prolongation  
❌ Microcytic anemia:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is associated with macrocytic anemia due to folate deficiency, not microcytic anemia. Microcytic anemia could be seen in iron deficiency.  
❌ Gingival hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is seen in patients taking cyclosporine, phenytoin, or rarely calcium channel blockers. It is not a side effect of methotrexate use.  
❌ Photosensitivity:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is not associated with photosensitivity. Some medications that can cause photosensitivity include sulfonamides and tetracyclines.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic due to fatigue and decreased energy for several months. The patient states he has no energy to do most routine activities. A review of systems is positive for mouth pain, nausea, and diarrhea. Medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, for which the patient takes methotrexate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and ulcers on the buccal mucosa. Laboratory evaluation shows pancytopenia and normal renal function. The peripheral blood smear shows macrocytic erythrocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. Although it is generally safe and well-tolerated, toxicity can develop, especially in patients taking higher doses. This patient is most likely having methotrexate toxicity given the pancytopenia, macrocytosis, and mucosal ulcers.

Methotrexate toxicity can lead to myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, or pancytopenia) which can be severe and life-threatening. Other severe toxicities include liver damage (steatosis or fibrosis), pulmonary fibrosis, and, in rare cases, kidney failure.

Treating myelosuppression in methotrexate toxicity is extremely important and should be started immediately. Since the bone marrow suppression by methotrexate is due to folate antagonism, it can be reversed using leucovorin. Leucovorin is a reduced form of folate that does not need activation (i.e. reduction) by dihydrofolate reductase, the enzyme inhibited by methotrexate. Therefore, leucovorin bypasses the inhibitory effects of methotrexate and reverses bone marrow suppression. In addition, leucovorin can also change the gastrointestinal toxicity of methotrexate.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Glucagon:
Incorrect: Glucagon is used in beta-blocker toxicity; it would not treat methotrexate toxicity.  
✅ Leucovorin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mesna:
Incorrect: Mesna prevents nephrotoxicity and hemorrhagic cystitis in patients taking cyclophosphamide. It is not used for methotrexate toxicity.  
❌ Protamine sulfate:
Incorrect: Protamine sulfate is the antidote to heparin and would not treat methotrexate toxicity.  
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect:  Sodium bicarbonate can help in renal failure associated with methotrexate toxicity. However, this patient’s kidney function is normal.

questions.text: A study was conducted on a medication to see how it affects joint damage in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. The medication works via inhibition of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase.  Five hundred patients were involved in the study; 250 patients were given a placebo, and 250 were given the medication tested. One year later, it was shown that the patients who took the study medication had significantly less joint damage than patients taking a placebo. Which of the following is a known contraindication for this study medication?
questions.solution:
The medication tested in this study is methotrexate, which is a folate antagonist that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. It is the first-line treatment for rheumatoid arthritis as it moderates joint damage. In addition, methotrexate is often used for other connective tissue disorders (e.g., psoriasis, systemic lupus erythematosus) and some cancers (e.g., leukemia/lymphoma and some solid tumors). Although the medication is generally well-tolerated and effective, it is contraindicated in some patients.

Methotrexate is contraindicated in pregnant women because of its severe teratogenic effects. Due to its folate antagonist properties, methotrexate can cause neural tube defects. In addition, methotrexate use is associated with many congenital disabilities, including cleft lip and palate, diaphragmatic hernia, and hypospadias. Finally, methotrexate can also lead to congenital heart defects (e.g., ventricular septal defects, atrial septal defects). Methotrexate should also be avoided in breastfeeding women as it is excreted in milk. Other contraindications include chronic liver disease (or patients with severe alcohol use disorder), severe chronic kidney disease, and pre-existing pancytopenia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Congestive heart failure:
Incorrect: Congestive heart failure is not a contraindication for methotrexate use.  
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus is not a contraindication for methotrexate use.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not a contraindication for methotrexate use.  
✅ Pregnancy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Smoking:
Incorrect: The medication used in the study is most likely methotrexate. Methotrexate is not contraindicated in patients who smoke or use tobacco.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic due to joint pain for the last eight months. The pain is in multiple joints of both hands and is most severe in the morning. On physical examination, there is warmth and tenderness in both hands' bilateral wrists and the proximal interphalangeal joints. Radiography of the hands and wrists shows decreased joint space and periarticular osteopenia. The patient is prescribed a medication that inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme dihydroorotate dehydrogenase. Which of the following side effects would most likely result from this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient has most likely developed rheumatoid arthritis and is being prescribed leflunomide. Leflunomide is a disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug (DMARD) frequently used in treating rheumatoid arthritis because it can slow down joint damage. It can also be used to treat psoriatic arthritis and some cancers.

The anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects of leflunomide are due to its inhibition of the mitochondrial enzyme dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which mediates the synthesis of the ribonucleotide uridine monophosphate, the rate-limiting step in de novo pyrimidine synthesis. Leflunomide, therefore, prevents the synthesis of pyrimidines, halting cells in the S-phase of the cell cycle. This results in the inhibition of proliferation and progression of activated lymphocytes, blocking an autoimmune reaction.

Leflunomide can cause diarrhea, rash, and hypersensitivity reactions. The most critical side effect of leflunomide is hepatotoxicity, so liver enzymes must be monitored. Finally, leflunomide can lead to pulmonary fibrosis. Thus, it is contraindicated in patients with chronic liver disease or interstitial lung disease.  Finally, leflunomide is teratogenic and should be avoided in pregnancy.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Cardiotoxicity:
Incorrect:  Cardiotoxicity can be seen with multiple medications, including doxorubicin and trastuzumab. It is not a known side-effect of leflunomide.  
✅ Hepatotoxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mouth ulcers:
Incorrect: Mouth ulcers can occur as a side effect of methotrexate, the first-line treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is not a side effect of leflunomide.  
❌ Neurotoxicity:
Incorrect: Neurotoxicity is not a known side effect of leflunomide.  
❌ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone:
Incorrect: SIADH can occur as a side effect of several medications, commonly selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors. However, leflunomide is not associated with SIADH.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic due to joint pain and stiffness in both hands. The pain started eight months ago and has been progressively worsening. The pain is most severe in the morning, and the joint stiffness usually resolves about one hour after waking. Physical examination shows edema and erythema of the bilateral wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints. Radiography of both hands shows decreased joint space and periarticular osteopenia. Which of the following medications can be used to prevent the progression of joint damage?
questions.solution:
This patient has likely developed rheumatoid arthritis (RA), given the symptoms and radiographic findings. Disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) should be started as soon as possible to slow down and moderate joint damage. NSAIDs and steroids can treat pain and stiffness in RA, but they do not slow the progression of joint damage. Sulfasalazine is a DMARD used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is also used for ankylosing spondylitis, inflammatory bowel disease, and polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Sulfasalazine is a prodrug made of 5-aminosalicylate linked to sulfapyridine. The colonic bacteria activate this product in the gut, separating the two products. Mechanisms include inhibiting the expression of NF-KB and cytokines, stimulating adenosine production, and inhibiting B-cell antibody production.

Sulfasalazine lacks teratogenic effects but has many other side effects. These include malaise, nausea, rash (urticarial or maculopapular lesions), and oligospermia. More severe side effects include leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, and elevated liver enzymes.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is an analgesic that relieves pain in rheumatoid arthritis, usually less so than NSAIDs. Acetaminophen does not have anti-inflammatory properties and would not prevent joint damage.  
❌ Dexamethasone:
Incorrect: Steroids can be used in patients with rheumatoid arthritis to decrease pain and relieve the stiffness of the involved joints. However, like NSAIDs, steroids DO NOT slow the progression of joint damage in rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: Ibuprofen is an NSAID (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug) that can help with pain and stiffness in rheumatoid arthritis. NSAIDs do not slow down the joint damage, however.  
❌ Naproxen:
Incorrect:  Naproxen is another NSAID that can help with pain and stiffness in rheumatoid arthritis. NSAIDs do not slow down the joint damage, however.  
✅ Sulfasalazine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, G1P0, at eight weeks gestation, comes to the clinic because of heat intolerance, excessive sweating, and thinning hair. The symptoms began six months ago. Medical history is notable for seasonal allergies. Family history is notable for type I diabetes mellitus and rheumatoid arthritis. She does not use alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drugs. In the office, her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 126/80 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a symmetrically-enlarged, nontender thyroid gland. A fine tremor is observed bilaterally in the patient’s hands when outstretched. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Which drugs are most appropriate for treating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has hyperthyroidism in the setting of a symmetrical, non-tender thyroid, which raises concerns for Graves disease. Thionamides (e.g., methimazole, propylthiouracil) are commonly used treatment options. Thionamides work by preventing thyroid hormone synthesis via inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. In addition, propylthiouracil (PTU) prevents the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 via inhibition of 5’-deiodinase.

It is important to note that methimazole and propylthiouracil (PTU) are used in pregnancy even though they can cross the placenta. However, during the first trimester, when organogenesis is taking place, the fetus is susceptible to drug-induced damage, and thus PTU is preferred. The rationale is that PTU is less likely to cross the placenta due to its extensive plasma protein binding. On the other hand, methimazole is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is associated with aplasia cutis, a condition characterized by the absence of a portion of skin. Then, during the second and third trimesters, once organogenesis is complete, methimazole is preferred due to its lower risk of hepatotoxicity.

Patients taking thionamides require close monitoring of thyroid and liver function and should be educated on symptoms and signs that should prompt medical review.  

Option Analysis

❌ Methimazole:
Incorrect: Methimazole is an oral anti-thyroid drug commonly used to treat hyperthyroidism in the general population. However, methimazole is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is teratogenic and is associated with fetal aplasia cutis, a condition characterized by the absence of a portion of skin.  
❌ Oxytocin:
Incorrect: Oxytocin is released by the posterior pituitary gland and helps to stimulate uterine contractions during labor. It can be given exogenously to assist with labor complications but would not treat hyperthyroidism.  
✅ Propylthiouracil:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radioactive iodine:
Incorrect: Radioactive iodine is a treatment option for hyperthyroidism. However, radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and is secreted in breast milk. Hence, it is contraindicated in pregnant or breastfeeding individuals.  
❌ Synthetic T4  :
Incorrect: Synthetic T4, commonly known as levothyroxine, is used to treat hypothyroidism. However, this patient has heat intolerance, excessive sweating, and hair thinning, which are symptoms of hyperthyroidism. Administering levothyroxine to this patient would exacerbate her condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for three weeks of severe lower back pain that is worse with movement, chills, and intermittent fevers. She has a history of injection drug use. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), heart rate is 112/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 22/min. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lumbar spine at L3 and a 4/6 holosystolic murmur is best heard at the left sternal border. Neurological examination is within normal limits. Laboratory findings are significant for a white blood cell (WBC) count of 15,500/μL, C-reactive protein (CRP) of 130 mg/L, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 120 mm/h. Spine x-rays show L3 vertebral body destruction and collapse of the intervertebral disc space. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of acute lower back pain and tenderness, fevers and chills, history of intravenous drug use, and x-ray findings suggests acute vertebral osteomyelitis. The presence of a 4/6 holosystolic murmur raises concern for infective endocarditis with bacteremia and hematogenous spread to the vertebral column. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients who use IV drugs, and it is known for its aggressive nature and propensity to affect bones and heart valves.

Patients with acute osteomyelitis typically exhibit localized pain at the infection site, often accompanied by tenderness, swelling, and warmth. Systemic symptoms such as fevers and chills frequently occur. In chronic osteomyelitis, symptoms can be more subtle and insidious, such as a continuous dull ache or localized discomfort at the site of infection. Intravenous drug use is a risk factor for vertebral osteomyelitis. Patients can present with severe back pain, fever, chills, weight loss, and neurological signs and symptoms such as incontinence or focal neurologic deficits.  

Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcus aureus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Coxiella burnetii:
Incorrect: Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, can lead to endocarditis, primarily in patients with chronic disease or certain occupational exposures like livestock handling. However, Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of osteomyelitis associated with endocarditis.  
❌ Streptococcus mutans:
Incorrect: While Streptococcus mutans is associated with endocarditis, it is not a common cause of osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of osteomyelitis associated with endocarditis.  
❌ Candida albicans:
Incorrect: Candida albicans can cause chronic osteomyelitis, primarily in immunocompromised patients or in patients with prolonged central venous access. This patient's lack of evident immunosuppression and acute presentation make Candida a less likely pathogen. Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of osteomyelitis associated with endocarditis.  
❌ Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Mycobacterium tuberculosis can cause spinal tuberculosis (Pott’s disease), but it typically presents with a more chronic course. Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of osteomyelitis associated with endocarditis. US guided biopsy should be performed and cultures should test for Mycobacterium tuberculosis to rule it out.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of progressive pain in his left leg above the knee. He has not had recent trauma but reports intermittent fevers and chills over the past week. Past medical history is significant for sickle cell disease. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), heart rate is 102/min, blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The distal left femur is tender to palpation with swelling and erythema. There is no overlying skin wound, and range of motion in the knee is preserved. Results of the laboratory evaluation are shown below. X-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Test
Result
White Blood Cell Count  
16,500/µL  
Hemoglobin
8.6 g/dL  
Hematocrit
26.1%  
Platelet Count  
340,000 /µL  
Sodium
142 mEq/L  
Potassium
4.1 mEq/L  
Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL  
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)  
70 mm/hr  
C-Reactive Protein (CRP)  
55 mg/L

choices.text: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the extremity

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of sickle cell disease presents with signs suggestive of acute osteomyelitis including progressive leg pain, fever, localized tenderness, swelling and erythema, and evidence of inflammation in bloodwork. The initial x-rays are normal, but this is commonly seen in early osteomyelitis. The clinical suspicion of osteomyelitis remains high, and MRI of the extremity should be performed next.

MRI is sensitive and specific for the detection of early osteomyelitis. It can identify findings like bone marrow edema, periosteal reaction, and subcutaneous edema before bony changes are evident on x-rays. It should be performed in patients with suspected acute osteomyelitis and negative x-ray findings or findings on x-ray that are suspicious of osteomyelitis.

Bone scintigraphy, or bone scan, is highly sensitive for osteomyelitis but lacks specificity; it can detect increased bone activity and is useful when MRI is contraindicated, such as in the presence of metal implants, but it cannot differentiate osteomyelitis from other inflammatory bone conditions.

CT scan provides excellent bone detail and is useful for diagnosing chronic osteomyelitis. It can visualize dead bone fragments and surrounding sclerosis and thickening, but it is less sensitive than MRI in the early stages of the disease.

A bone biopsy can be used as the gold standard of diagnosis and to identify the causative organism to tailor antibiotic treatment.
 
MRI shows abnormal heterogeneous marrow signal intensity of the distal tibial metaphysis & diaphysis (black solid arrows) with overlying periosteal & soft tissue edema (white solid arrow). StatDX  

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the extremity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pain management and IV hydration:
Incorrect: Acute vaso-occlusive pain episodes in the long bones secondary to sickle cell disease may be difficult to differentiate from osteomyelitis. Pain management and IV hydration is the mainstay of treatment for acute vaso-occlusive pain episodes. However, in this patient, there is high suspicion of osteomyelitis, and he should have an MRI.  
❌ CT of the extremity:
Incorrect: CT may be used to help diagnose osteomyelitis when MRI is contraindicated. However, in acute osteomyelitis, MRI is preferred. For diagnosing chronic osteomyelitis, CT is generally preferred.  
❌ Bone scintigraphy (bone scan)  :
Incorrect: Bone scan can be performed in the workup of acute osteomyelitis when MRI is contraindicated, such as if metal implants are present. However, it lacks specificity and cannot distinguish between osteomyelitis and other conditions like fractures or tumors. MRI is preferred in most cases in early osteomyelitis for its sensitivity and specificity.  
❌ CT-guided bone biopsy:
Incorrect: Although bone biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis and is used to identify the causative organism and tailor antibiotic treatment in the management of acute osteomyelitis, identifying the most likely diagnosis and extent of disease with MRI is the best next step in the management of this patient.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-week history of progressive painless swelling of his lower jaw. This past week, he started having drainage from the overlying skin which prompted him to get evaluated. He had extensive dental work 10 weeks ago. Past medical history is significant for poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes metformin and insulin. He has no known drug allergies. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), heart rate is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals a swollen indurated area of the mandible at the angle of the lower jaw on the left with yellow granules in the discharge from two distinct sinus tracts open to the skin. Laboratory tests show a white blood cell count of 17,500/µL and C-reactive protein of 45 mg/L. Radiographs of the jaw show left jaw bone destruction with periosteal reaction. Gram stain of the fluid shows filaments as seen below with culture pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 
Taken from the Public Health Image Library (PHIL)

choices.text: Intravenous penicillin G and surgical debridement
Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and outpatient follow-up in 1 week
Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam with surgical debridement
Oral ciprofloxacin and clindamycin with outpatient follow-up in 1 week

questions.solution:
This patient with poorly controlled DM and recent dental work presents with progressive painless swelling and induration of the mandible. X-rays show bone destruction with periosteal reaction suggestive of osteomyelitis of the jaw. The presence of draining sinus tracts with yellow “sulfur granules” and gram-positive filamentous bacteria on gram stains suggests Actinomyces infection. This patient should be treated with intravenous (IV) penicillin G and surgical debridement of the affected area. Beta-lactam antibiotics are particularly effective against Actinomyces, and surgical intervention is necessary to remove necrotic tissue.

Patients suspected of having osteomyelitis should have blood cultures and wound cultures (if possible) taken, followed by empiric intravenous antibiotics. Definitive diagnosis is made with a bone biopsy. The choice of empiric therapy is guided by determining the likely organisms based on patient history, risk factors, and local resistance patterns. Once culture and sensitivity results are available, antibiotics should be tailored to the identified pathogen. In cases of chronic osteomyelitis, or when the infection is complicated by the presence of necrotic bone, soft tissue abscess, or sinus tracts, surgical debridement is typically necessary in addition to a long course of antibiotics.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous penicillin G and surgical debridement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and outpatient follow-up in 1 week:
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis of the jaw caused by Actinomyces. Although amoxicillin-clavulanate can cover Actinomyces, a single beta-lactam agent like penicillin G usually provides sufficient coverage and intravenous therapy with surgical debridement will be necessary in this patient due to the extent of the infection with sinus tract formation.  
❌ Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam with surgical debridement:
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis caused by Actinomycosis species, which is highly susceptible to beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillin G. Broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage is not indicated for this infection.  
❌ Oral ciprofloxacin and clindamycin with outpatient follow-up in 1 week:
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis of the jaw caused by Actinomyces, which is highly susceptible to beta-lactam antibiotics. Clindamycin can be prescribed for patients with a penicillin allergy, but this patient has no known drug allergies. Additionally, surgical debridement will be necessary in this patient given that he has multiple draining sinus tracts.  
❌ Intravenous fluconazole and surgical debridement:
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis caused by Actinomyces. Although Actinomyces has a filamentous appearance similar to fungi, it is a bacterium. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication and not indicated for bacterial infections like actinomycosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of a breast nodule. She first noticed the nodule one week ago while showering. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and two uncomplicated pregnancies delivered vaginally. Vital signs are temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 148/73 mmHg. Physical exam reveals a firm nodule in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Several enlarged axillary lymph nodes are palpated. Further testing reveals the patient has metastatic estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. A medication that prevents the conversion of androgens to estrogen is added to the patient’s treatment regimen. Which side effects should this patient be warned about?
questions.solution:
This patient was started on an aromatase inhibitor (AI) to treat estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. There are two types of aromatase inhibitors. Type I AIs (e.g. exemestane) are steroidal agents that are irreversible competitive inhibitors of aromatase. Type II AIs (e.g., anastrozole, letrozole) are non-steroidal agents. They are reversible competitive inhibitors.

Both type I and II AIs are well-tolerated; however, since estrogen has a protective effect on the cardiovascular system and helps sustain bone density, patients on AIs are deprived of its protective effects. This can increase their risk of developing cardiovascular diseases and osteopenia/osteoporosis, predisposing patients to fractures. Bisphosphonates should be administered together with AIs to prevent such events.

Moreover, around 20-50% of patients develop arthralgias, manifesting as morning stiffness and hand or wrist pain. The exact cause of this side effect is unclear. However, it is hypothesized to be related to estrogen deficiency or immune-mediated inflammation.

Patients can experience menopause-like symptoms secondary to decreased estrogen levels. These include hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and loss of libido.

Letrozole, a type II AI, can also cause hair thinning. Exemestane, a type I AI, can also cause visual disturbances.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Many anti-cancer agents, ranging from methotrexate to busulfan, can cause myelosuppression. However, this patient was initiated on an aromatase inhibitor, which reduces the conversion of androgens to estrogen.  
❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Taxanes, such as paclitaxel, are used to treat breast cancer. Taxanes can cause peripheral neuropathy as a side effect. Taxanes work by blocking microtubule formation.  
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Medications, such as doxorubicin and trastuzumab, can cause dilated cardiomyopathy as a side effect. Neither medication blocks the peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogen.  
✅ Joint pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endometrial hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that can cause endometrial hyperplasia as a side effect. The medication works by acting as an estrogen receptor antagonist in breast tissue rather than blocking estrogen synthesis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of a new-onset rash. She was recently diagnosed with bacterial sinusitis and started on amoxicillin. She also reports mild joint pain for the past three days. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for systemic lupus erythematosus. She is afraid that she might have developed the same condition. She does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash. No costovertebral tenderness or joint effusion is present. Her serum creatinine is 2 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2-5 erythrocytes/hpf, numerous white blood cell casts, eosinophiluria, and negative leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Acute interstitial nephritis due to amoxicillin
Acute glomerulonephritis due to bacterial sinusitis
Bacterial infection of the renal interstitium

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with diffuse maculopapular rash following the consumption of amoxicillin in combination with urinalysis findings of hematuria, white blood cell casts and eosinophiluria is consistent with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN).  

Other adverse effects of penicillin include hypersensitivity reactions, which can present with urticaria, severe pruritus, fever, joint swelling, hemolytic anemia, renal failure, and anaphylaxis. Around five to ten percent of patients will manifest a reaction ranging from mild to severe, or even life-threatening with repeated use.  

Penicillins are structurally similar to each other and other beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g. cephalosporins) and there could be cross-reactivity. Nausea and diarrhea may occur with oral penicillin, especially with ampicillin. Gastrointestinal upsets may be caused by direct irritation or by overgrowth of Gram-positive organisms or yeasts. Ampicillin has been implicated in pseudomembranous colitis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Acute interstitial nephritis due to amoxicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute glomerulonephritis due to bacterial sinusitis:
Incorrect: Glomerulonephritis presents with red blood cell casts in the urine instead of white cell casts. Moreover, fluid retention and hypertension are usually present. It can occur 1-2 weeks after the resolution of streptococcal pharyngitis or skin infection. No association with bacterial sinusitis is observed.
❌ Renal atheroemboli:
Incorrect: Thromboemboli primarily occurs in patients with atrial arrhythmias, a prior myocardial infarction, or can be iatrogenic, usually induced by angiography/cardiovascular surgery. They tend to produce complete arterial occlusion and renal infarction, leading to flank pain, hematuria, and an elevated lactate dehydrogenase with relatively normal transaminases. This is an unlikely cause of hematuria in this patient.
❌ Bacterial infection of the renal interstitium:
Incorrect: Bacterial infection of renal interstitium (pyelonephritis) usually presents with fever, chill, flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness. A diffuse maculopapular rash is usually not seen.
❌ Cutaneous flare of SLE:
Incorrect: Cutaneous manifestations of SLE include a malar and discoid rash, unlike the diffuse maculopapular rash seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department with intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness that began an hour ago. The patient is currently being treated for acute bronchitis with azithromycin. Past medical history is significant for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, Parkinson disease, and major depressive disorder. The patient is receiving antiemetic therapy for severe nausea and vomiting after his first cycle of chemotherapy. EKG is shown below. Which of the following pharmacotherapeutic agents likely caused the above EKG findings?



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with torsades de pointes in the setting of conjunctive use of an antiemetic agent with a macrolide antibiotic. The patient was most likely taking ondansetron, which is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist.    

5-HT3 antagonists (e.g., ondansetron, granisetron, palonosetron) are effective in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Serotonin receptors are sensitive to irritative stimuli (e.g., chemotherapy, infections, distention) that induce serotonin production in the gastrointestinal tract. Activation of 5-HT3 serotonin receptors then relays the impulses to the medullary vomiting center. One of the well-known side effects of 5-HT3 antagonists is QT interval prolongation. Patients can develop torsades de pointes (TdP, French for “twisting of points”) if they take multiple medications that cause QT interval prolongation.    

Moreover, 5-HT3 antagonists can cause side effects including headaches, constipation, and serotonin syndrome (secondary to displacement of serotonin molecules from their receptors).   

Option Analysis

✅ Serotonin receptor antagonist :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: NK-1 receptor antagonists (e.g. aprepitant) are frequently used for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, and usually combined with dexamethasone and a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. They do not cause significant QT prolongation.
❌ Muscarinic receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Antimuscarinic agents (e.g., scopolamine) can also be used for nausea and vomiting related to chemotherapy. However, they are not typically the first-line agent. Moreover, antimuscarinic agents do not cause significant QT prolongation.
❌ Histamine-2 receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: H2-receptor antagonists (e.g., cevimeline, famotidine) are used for gastroesophageal reflux disease and related disorders. They do not cause significant QT prolongation. Some H1-receptor antagonists (e.g. promethazine) can cause QT prolongation.
❌ Cannabinoid receptor agonist :
 Incorrect: Cannabinoid receptor agonists (e.g. dronabinol) can also be used for chemotherapy-induced   nausea and vomiting, as well as anorexia. However, they do not cause significant QT prolongation.

questions.text: A graduate student is conducting research on pancreatic physiology. For one of their experiments, a culture flask containing pancreatic beta cells is prepared. Afterward, glucose is added to the flask. The intracellular ATP/ADP ratio, magnitude of the outflowing potassium current, and magnitude of the inflowing calcium current are measured. Which of the following sets of findings will most likely be observed?
questions.solution:
Insulin is a type of peptide hormone that reduces the amount of glucose in the blood. It is produced in pancreatic beta cells. Insulin’s main function is to facilitate the transport of glucose from the blood into the various insulin-responsive tissues like muscle cells and adipose tissue.  

Insulin is released from beta cells via a four-step process. First, extracellular glucose is transported into beta cells via GLUT2 receptors. Second, inside the cell, glucose undergoes glycolysis to produce ATP. Third, the ATP binds to and closes potassium channels. This causes a decrease in the outflowing potassium current, resulting in cellular depolarization. Fourth, depolarization opens voltage-gated calcium channels, which increases intracellular calcium and causes insulin secretion.  

Once released, insulin binds to its receptors in the target tissue (e.g., adipose, liver, muscle) and causes intracellular storage vesicles, which contain glucose transport proteins called GLUT4, to fuse with the cellular membrane. The GLUT4 proteins then embed themselves into the membrane and allow glucose to enter the cell, ultimately reducing blood glucose levels.  

Option Analysis

❌  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↓  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: In this experiment, glucose is administered to beta cells. The elevated glucose would lead to increased glycolysis and an elevated ATP/ADP ratio. The newly synthesized ATP then closes potassium channels, resulting in a decrease in the magnitude of the outflowing potassium current. 
❌  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↓  ↓ ↑ :
Incorrect: Increased glucose concentrations would result in increased glycolysis, resulting in an elevated ATP/ADP ratio.
❌  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↑  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Increased glucose concentrations would result in increased glycolysis, resulting in an elevated ATP/ADP ratio. However, the ATP then closes potassium channels, which decreases the outflowing potassium current.
✅  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↑  ↓  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↑  ↓ ↓:
Incorrect: An increase in extracellular glucose concentration leads to an increased ATP/ADP ratio and a decrease in the magnitude of the outflowing potassium current. The latter depolarizes the beta cell and causes voltage-gated calcium channels to open, resulting in an increase in the magnitude of the inflowing calcium current.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of weight loss, fatigue, and increased thirst that began around 5 months ago. The patient reports waking up multiple times at night to urinate. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he uses an albuterol inhaler. The patient consumes a balanced diet and exercises four times each week. He works as an accountant and reports being stressed recently due to increased work volume. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 62/min, blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg. Body mass index is 23 kg/m2. The patient’s weight is 3 kg (6.6 lb) less than that recorded at his prior visit.  Laboratory testing reveals a fasting serum glucose of 165 mg/dL. The patient is started on medication to treat his condition. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
This young and otherwise healthy male is presenting with symptoms of hyperglycemia (e.g., weight loss, increased thirst, fatigue). He most likely has type I diabetes mellitus, which is caused by the autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells. As a result, individuals with this condition cannot produce endogenous insulin. Administration of exogenous insulin is needed to treat type I diabetes, as well as late-stage type II diabetes.  

Insulin reduces blood glucose levels via two main mechanisms. First, it upregulates the GLUT4 transporter protein, allowing more glucose to enter and be stored in cells. Second, insulin prevents the breakdown of existing glycogen into glucose (glycogenolysis), thereby preventing new glucose from being released into the blood. In addition to its effect on glucose, insulin also promotes lipogenesis (synthesis of fatty acids and triglycerides) and protein synthesis.  

Insulin is typically administered subcutaneously via syringes or pens because it can be broken down in the GI tract. When injected into the abdominal region, absorption is the quickest, followed by arms, thighs, and buttocks. Some diabetics prefer the insulin pump since insulin dosages are programed into the device and will be delivered subcutaneously throughout the day, thus preventing the need for multiple daily injections.



Option Analysis

✅ Upregulation of GLUT4 protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of hepatic gluconeogenesis:
Incorrect: Biguanides, such as metformin, work by inhibiting hepatic gluconeogenesis. This medication is used to treat patients with type II diabetes mellitus, who develop insulin resistance but are still able to produce endogenous insulin. In contrast, patients with type I diabetes mellitus have an absolute insulin deficiency and should be started on exogenous insulin.
❌ Closure of beta cell potassium-channels :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of sulfonylureas, such as tolbutamide and glyburide. By closing potassium channels, the medication induces beta cell depolarization and subsequent insulin release. However, this medication would not work in a patient with type I diabetes mellitus, whose pancreatic ꞵ cells have been destroyed by an autoimmune reaction. 
❌ Inhibition of SGLT-2 transporters:
Incorrect: Medications such as canagliflozin and dapagliflozin work via this mechanism. By blocking the SGLT-2 transporter, these medications impair glucose reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tube. However, it is not typically used to treat type I diabetes mellitus.
❌ Activation of peroxisome proliferator-activating receptors:
Incorrect: Glitazones work via this mechanism of action. The medication reduces insulin resistance via activation of peroxisome proliferator-activating (PPARγ) receptors. It is used to treat type II diabetes, but not type I.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. The symptoms began around five-hours ago and have progressively worsened. Medical history is notable for type I diabetes mellitus and asthma. The patient takes insulin glargine at night and insulin aspart three times a day before meals. However, she has not recently been adherent with her insulin injections due to stress at work. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 107/68 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient has dry mucosal membranes and appears tired. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing is shown below. The patient is started on an insulin infusion. A few hours later, she begins experiencing muscle cramps and spasms as well as heart palpitations. Which of the following complications most likely occurred?

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Sodium  130 mmol/L 
 Potassium  4.7 mmol/L 
 Chloride  92 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  14 mmol/L 
 Glucose  480 mg/dL 
 Urea Nitrogen, Serum  18 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  1.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has nausea, vomiting, and dizziness in the setting of elevated blood glucose and a history of type I diabetes mellitus. She has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). She was started on insulin, but not potassium supplements. As a result, the patient subsequently developed symptoms of hypokalemia.    

This side effect occurred during an insulin deficit state, the hyperosmolarity caused by excess blood glucose draws potassium, and free water out of cells. As a result, patients may have deceptively elevated serum potassium even though they have a total body potassium deficit. Once insulin is administered, potassium enters the cells, serum potassium concentration drops, and symptoms of hypokalemia develop.  

Moreover, insulin therapy can cause hypoglycemia if an overdose occurs. Some symptoms of hypoglycemia include headache, weakness, hunger, sweating, dizziness, anxiety, and tachycardia. Individuals with renal impairment, the elderly, and children younger than 7 years of age are at increased risk for hypoglycemia. Repeated injections in the same area could cause lipodystrophy, which is the atrophy or hypertrophy of subcutaneous fat near the injection area, causing depression beneath the skin. Lastly, insulin can cause moderate weight gain. 

Option Analysis

❌ Osmotic demyelination syndrome:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome occurs due to rapid osmotic changes. It is usually due to rapid overcorrection of hyponatremia, but can also be due to rapid changes in the concentration of other substances (e.g., glucose). The condition typically manifests with acute muscle paralysis, seizures, and dysphagia/dysarthria. In contrast, this patient does not have these symptoms. 
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia can result if too much insulin is administered. The condition can cause palpitations, anxiety, sweating, and nausea/vomiting. However, it would not typically cause muscle cramps and spasms. 
❌ Wernicke encephalopathy:
Incorrect: Patients with thiamine (B1) deficiency who are started on a dextrose drip can exhibit worsening symptoms. This phenomenon occurs since glucose increases the body’s thiamine demand. Symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy include confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. However, this patient has no history of chronic alcohol use or other risk factors that may predispose her to developing a thiamine deficiency.
✅ Hypokalemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diabetic neuropathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic neuropathy can cause sensory and motor deficits in the extremities. The condition develops gradually over the course of years. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms manifested a few hours after starting the insulin infusion.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine visit. He has no acute complaints and is feeling well. Medical history is notable for type I diabetes mellitus. The patient takes insulin glargine at night and insulin aspart three times a day before meals. He has been adherent to his medications but reports getting pre-prandial fingerstick glucose measurements of 120-145 mg/dL. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 107/73 mmHg. The physical exam is non-contributory. Laboratory testing is ordered, revealing a fasting blood glucose of 130 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c of 8.0%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Add metformin to current treatment regimen
Add lispro to current treatment regimen
Replace aspart with neutral protamine hagedorn insulin

questions.solution:
This patient has elevated preprandial and fasting blood glucose levels, suggesting that his type I diabetes mellitus is poorly controlled. The next step would be to increase the basal (long-acting) insulin dose.  

Insulin is administered via one of two regimens. First, there is the basal-bolus regimen where basal insulin is used to maintain fasting blood glucose levels and bolus insulin is taken before meals to prevent postprandial hyperglycemia. Second, there is the sliding-scale regimen. It is typically reserved for hospital settings where a person’s blood glucose level may fluctuate rapidly due to stressors (e.g., infections, and other illnesses). In this regimen, the patient’s glucose is measured every 4-6 hours and an appropriate dosage of short-acting insulin is given.  

There are five categories of insulin therapies (also termed insulin preparations): rapid-acting, short-acting, intermediate-acting, long-acting, and ultra-long-acting. These preparations are categorized according to their onset of action and duration of effect. Rapid-acting (lispro, aspart, glusine) and short-acting (regular) insulins are used in bolus insulin regimens to counteract postprandial hyperglycemia. Intermediate-acting (NPH), long-acting (detemir, glargine), and ultra-long-acting (degludec) insulins are used for basal insulin regimen to maintain a steady background level of insulin throughout the day. 

Option Analysis

❌ Add metformin to current treatment regimen:
Incorrect: Metformin enhances the effects of insulin, increases peripheral glucose uptake, and reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis. This medication is used to treat patients with type II diabetes mellitus, who develop insulin resistance. In contrast, metformin is generally not helpful in treating type I diabetes mellitus.
❌ Add lispro to current treatment regimen:
Incorrect: Lispro is a rapid-acting insulin. It is administered before meals to counteract the post-meal increase in blood glucose. However, this patient has elevated blood glucose while fasting, which raises concerns for an inadequate basal insulin regimen.
✅ Increase glargine dose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increase aspart dose :
Incorrect: Aspart is a rapid-acting insulin. It is administered before meals to counteract postprandial hyperglycemia. However, this patient has elevated blood glucose while fasting. The most appropriate next step would be to increase the basal insulin dosage.
❌ Replace aspart with neutral protamine hagedorn insulin:
Incorrect: Aspart is a rapid-acting insulin, whereas neutral protamine hagedorn (NPH) insulin is intermediate-acting. The latter becomes active around 1-2 hours after administration and lasts for 16 to 24 hours. However, this modification would leave the patient with no rapid-acting insulin and predispose him to postprandial hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for nausea, abdominal pain, and non-bloody vomiting for the past 24 hours. These symptoms are associated with decreased appetite. The patient is not sexually active. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation without guarding or rebound tenderness. CT of the abdomen shows dilated loops of the small bowel. A nasogastric tube is placed. Further history shows this patient has been taking excessive amounts of laxatives in an effort to lose weight. Which class of laxatives did this patient most likely misuse?
questions.solution:
Bulk-forming laxatives such as methylcellulose, polycarbophil, and psyllium are hydrophilic colloids derived from indigestible fruit and vegetable matter. They are commonly used over the counter to aid in constipation prevention or relief. These laxatives swell in the digestive tract as they absorb water. The distention of the intestinal walls caused by their swelling creates reflexive peristalsis. Bulk-forming laxatives require a significant amount of water in order to function. If taken without sufficient quantities of water, the bulk-forming laxative can become impacted, creating small bowel obstruction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Osmotic laxatives:
Incorrect:  Osmotic laxatives (magnesium salts, sodium sulfate, sorbitol), lactulose, and polyethylene glycol each function to draw water into the bowel lumen to promote large bowel motility. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
❌ Stimulant laxatives:
Incorrect: Stimulant laxatives such as senna and bisacodyl promote large bowel motility by direct inflammation of the bowel mucosa. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
✅ Bulk forming agents:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chloride channel activators:
Incorrect: Chloride channel activators such as lubiprostone cause a hyperosmotic effect, drawing water into the bowel lumen and thus promoting bowel motility. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
❌ Opioid antagonists:
Incorrect:  Opioid antagonists such as alvimopan and methylnaltrexone are used for opioid-induced constipation (OIC). They block gastrointestinal mu-opioid receptors, which allows propagation of downstream acetylcholine signaling in cases of OIC.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the hospital for routine colonoscopy screening. The patient’s first screening colonoscopy 10 years ago was normal without any polyps. The patient has chronic constipation and routinely takes senna to help promote bowel movements. Prior to the colonoscopy, vital signs are unremarkable.  Physical exam does not show any abdominal distention or tenderness to palpation. During colonoscopy, dark pigmented spots are visualized in multiple locations throughout the colon. Which of the following most likely caused these findings on this patient’s colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
The dark spots throughout this patient’s colon are referred to as “melanosis coli.” Melanosis coli is caused by stimulant laxatives such as senna and bisacodyl. As the metabolic breakdown products of these laxatives pass through the colon, they become active and cause cell death and apoptosis in the lining of the colon, causing lipofuscin deposition (not melanin as the name might imply) and eventually dark pigmentation of the colon. Melanosis coli is not associated with an increased risk of colon cancer and resolves with the discontinuation of laxatives.

Stimulant laxatives act by causing direct inflammation of the colon, which in turn causes the colon to reflexively undergo peristalsis. Stimulant laxatives are meant to be used as short-term therapies for constipation, and should not usually be used on a chronic basis. Dietary alterations, patient education, and regular exercise are key first steps for the treatment of constipation, followed by bulking agents such as psyllium, if indicated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Metastatic adenocarcinoma to the colon:
Incorrect: Metastatic adenocarcinoma to the colon would likely present with multiple masses visible on imaging and/or on colonoscopy. The findings on this patient’s colonoscopy of dark pigmented spots are not suggestive of any underlying masses. Patients with metastatic colorectal cancer may describe weight loss, fatigue, pencil-thin stools, hematochezia, or others.  
❌ Previous polypectomy:
Incorrect:  When found on colonoscopy, polyps are typically resected and harvested using an endoscopic snare for pathologic analysis in order to assess risk for possible malignancy. Minor bleeding may occur during cold or hot snaring. The finding in this patient’s colonoscopy of dark pigmented mucosa would not likely be from previous polyp resection sites from 10 years ago. More importantly, the patient’s previous colonoscopy is reported as normal.  
❌ Mucosal artifact from repeated colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A well-executed colonoscopy has virtually no chance of chronically irritating the bowel mucosa. Submucosal dissection and perforation are the most common adverse events associated with colonoscopy and carry approximately a 7% and 1% risk, respectively. These would not cause dark pigmented spots in the colon.  
✅ Medication effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis often has profound and easily recognizable findings on colonoscopy including edema, erythema, backwash ileitis, erosions, ulcerations, and loss of the typical vascular pattern. The dark mucosal pigmentation described in this patient’s colonoscopy is not indicative of ulcerative colitis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The patient had undergone a lung transplant 8 months ago and has had several episodes of cytomegalovirus infections since then. Two days ago, the patient was diagnosed with CMV retinitis and was started on an antiviral agent that does not require intracellular activation and is known to bind in-vitro with virally encoded enzymes, such as DNA polymerase and RNA polymerase. Laboratory results are shown below. ECG shows nonspecific ST changes and inverted T waves. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of this patient’s current presentation?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Calcium  6.5 mg/dL 
 Magnesium  0.9 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient’s generalized tonic-clonic seizure is likely secondary to severe hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. He is also found to have hypokalemia with ECG changes (nonspecific ST changes and inverted T waves). These electrolyte abnormalities likely resulted from the initiation of forcarnet.  

Foscarnet is an inorganic pyrophosphate analog that inhibits herpesvirus DNA polymerase, RNA polymerase, and HIV reverse transcriptase directly without requiring activation by phosphorylation. Foscarnet blocks the pyrophosphate binding site of these enzymes and inhibits cleavage of pyrophosphate from deoxynucleotide triphosphates, leading to chain termination. It is indicated for the treatment of acyclovir-resistant HSV infections. It is also used as an alternative to ganciclovir for the prophylaxis and treatment of CMV infections in immunocompromised individuals.
