Major adverse effects include nephrotoxicity and electrolyte abnormalities (hypo- or hypercalcemia, hypo- or hyperphosphatemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia) that can lead to seizures. The principal mode of viral resistance to the drug involves mutation of the DNA polymerase.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cidofovir:
Incorrect: Although cidofovir is effective against CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients, it is usually associated with nephrotoxicity, causing elevated creatinine levels. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen.
✅ Foscarnet:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is associated with the development of crystal nephropathy and requires activation by viral kinase.
❌ Didanosine:
Incorrect: Didanosine is an antiretroviral medication that is associated with an increased risk of pancreatitis. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen and it is not effective against CMV retinitis.
❌ Valganciclovir:
Incorrect: Valganciclovir is a prodrug of ganciclovir. It is typically associated with the development of bone marrow suppression. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man comes to the physician with a chief complaint of fatigue. The patient states that he has been feeling tired for several months. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and profound diffuse tender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory testing is shown below. Flow cytometry shows a significant cluster of cells with CD5, CD19, dim CD20, and CD23 positivity. Fludarabine and rituximab are prescribed. Several months later, the patient presents with a recurrence of symptoms along with cachexia and night sweats. The patient is subsequently started on alemtuzumab. Which of the following best describes the molecular target for this drug?

 Test  Value 
 Hemoglobin  6.0 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count   3.7 X 109/L 
 WBC Differential   93% lymphocytes 
 Coomb’s test  Positive
questions.solution:
This older patient initially presented with symptoms of fatigue. His laboratory tests reveal anemia, with a profound lymphocytic leukocytosis and a positive Coombs test indicative of leukemia. Furthermore, flow cytometry showed positivity for CD5, CD19, dim CD20 (why this patient was also treated with rituximab), and CD23, differentiating this as chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL often occurs in elderly patients over the age of 60 and has an overall median survival rate of 10 years following diagnosis. The patient’s treatment with rituximab (a monoclonal CD20 antibody) and fludarabine (a purine analog) are often first-line treatments for CLL. Despite being on fludarabine and rituximab (a treatment known as FR), this patient’s CLL did not go into remission and required further therapy. Rather than restarting another cycle of FR, a better treatment strategy would include starting a therapy with a different mechanism of action.    

CD52 is a glycoprotein widely expressed on all immune cells' surfaces.  Activation of CD52 was shown to offer costimulatory signals for T cell activation. Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against CD52. Alemtuzumab binds to lymphocytes, causing complement-mediated cell lysis, apoptosis, and antibody-dependent cellular toxicity of lymphocytes in circulation, making it ideal for chronic lymphocytic leukemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ VEGF:
Incorrect: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a key physiologic mediator of blood vessel development in the body (1). Aberrant expression of VEGF is a hallmark feature of several different solid tumor types, namely renal cell carcinoma. To date, there are 11 anti-angiogenic drugs directed against VEGF. It is not relevant in the treatment of leukemias. 
❌ EGFR:
Incorrect: Physiologically, the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a primary regulator of epithelial growth and maturation in tissues. Some cancers such as glioblastomas, breast and lung cancer aberrantly express EGFR, making it a driver of tumorigenesis. 
❌ HER2:
Incorrect: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is a member of the EGFR growth factor receptor family, involved in regulating the growth and maturation of epidermal tissues. Recently HER2 has become an important biomarker and therapy for approximately 30% of breast cancer patients. Patients who exhibit amplification of the ERBB2 gene, which is what codes HER2, receive trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to and inhibits the extracellular segment of the HER2/neu receptor.
❌ CD20:
Incorrect: CD20 is a specific B cell marker. Anti-CD20 therapies, namely rituximab,  are one of the hallmarks of chemotherapy for patients with CLL. Since this patient received rituximab and still did not achieve remission, another therapy is more appropriate (See main explanation). 
✅ CD52:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to an oncologist’s office for consultation following a biopsy of a recently diagnosed cancer. The patient was diagnosed with clear cell renal cell carcinoma of the left kidney. Which of the following would be an ideal therapy to inhibit the microvascular growth and angiogenesis which often accompanies clear cell renal cell carcinomas?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recently diagnosed clear cell renal cell carcinoma. Treatment for kidney tumors is multifaceted and includes possible radical nephrectomy, partial nephrectomy, or targeted therapy with various immunotherapies. This question is asking for a specific therapy that will block neovascularization and angiogenesis seen with cancer. In the pathophysiology of cancer, it is well known that cancer cells overexpress vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), which as the name suggests, promotes neovascularization in the tumor microenvironment. VEGF expression is associated with several different cancer types. Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets VEGF-A, preventing this process of neovascularization from taking place. Bevacizumab is also useful in preventing wet age-related macular degeneration from taking place, which is typically characterized by choroidal neovascularization. Side effects of bevacizumab include hemorrhage, blood clots, and impaired wound healing.  

A helpful mnemonic to remember the anti-angiogenic effects of bevacizumab is that it inhibits the growth of blood vessels. 

Option Analysis

❌ Transtuzumab :
Incorrect: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to HER2 receptors in breast and gastric cancers. 
❌ Imatinib:
Incorrect: Imatinib is a bcr-abl tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. 
❌ Hydroxyurea:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase used in the treatment of melanoma and treatment-resistant CML. 
❌ Tamoxifen:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. It has no effect on preventing micro vascularization and angiogenesis. 
✅ Bevacizumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the physician with a newly diagnosed unresectable lung cancer. The patient’s therapeutic options are discussed during an oncology tumor board meeting. After coming to a consensus, the pharmacological therapy of choice is discussed with the patient. It is explained to the patient that the therapy targets an extracellular ligand for the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). This patient is most likely going to be started on which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
For this patient with an unresectable lung cancer, a possible therapeutic option would be the use of a monoclonal antibody (also called biologics) which targets the extracellular domain of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). Monoclonal antibodies end with the naming convention “mab,” and always target extracellular proteins. Small molecule inhibitors, on the other hand, end with the naming convention “ib” and can target extracellular proteins as well as intracellular targets as well. Key differences in the mechanisms of action between monoclonal antibodies and small molecules are listed below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Imatinib :
Incorrect: Imatinib is a small molecule inhibitor that targets the bcr-abl tyrosine kinase inhibitor. 
❌ Methotrexate :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist which binds to the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).
❌ Hydroxyurea:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase used in the treatment of melanoma and treatment-resistant chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).
✅ Cetuximab:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bevacizumab:
Incorrect: While bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody, it targets the VEGF-A receptor, preventing angiogenesis in the tumor microenvironment.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for progressive lethargy and confusion. The patient’s roommate states that he has been increasingly confused over the past 24 hours and appears more lethargic than usual. The patient has a past medical history of cirrhosis due to untreated hepatitis C. Temperature is 38.5℃ (101.3℉), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 98/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is oriented to self and place, but not to month or year. Abdominal examination shows moderate ascites with diffuse tenderness to palpation. Diagnostic paracentesis shows a neutrophil count of 325 cells/μL (0.35 × 109/L). The patient is started on a 5-day course of ceftriaxone, and he improves dramatically over the next few days. Which of the following should be initiated prior to discharge?
questions.solution:
The patient has cirrhosis and presents with signs and symptoms consistent with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), including fever, confusion, and abdominal pain in the context of ascites. Paracentesis shows ascitic fluid PMN count ≥250 cells/μL indicating SBP. The management of SBP includes empiric antibiotic therapy with tailored antibiotic therapy once culture results are available, cirrhosis management, and prophylactic antibiotics to prevent SBP recurrence. Empiric antibiotic therapy with a third-generation cephalosporin (e.g. ceftriaxone) is recommended. Treatment should continue for five days and then the patient should be reassessed. Antibiotic prophylaxis with daily oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be prescribed for patients who have had SBP to prevent recurrences.  

Antibiotic prophylaxis for SBP should be given to patients with cirrhosis who have risk factors for SBP. Risks include ascitic fluid protein concentration <1 g/dL, episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding, and one or more episodes of SBP. Prophylaxis has been shown to decrease the risk of bacterial infection and mortality. Daily oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is effective for secondary prophylaxis of SBP. This regimen targets the common organisms responsible for SBP (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella) and has been shown to significantly reduce the recurrence rate. Fluoroquinolones can also be used.    

Patients being treated for SBP should have their cirrhosis managed starting with managing the underlying causes, which may include alcoholic liver disease or chronic viral infections, like hepatitis B or C. Patients should be counseled about lifestyle changes, like avoiding alcohol and hepatotoxic medications, such as acetaminophen. If applicable, vaccines against Hepatitis A and B should be given and patients should be screened for esophageal varices.  

Option Analysis

❌ Protein-restricted diet:
Incorrect: Patients with cirrhosis tend to be malnourished, and dietary protein restriction is not recommended because a negative nitrogen balance can increase mortality. Protein restriction for patients with cirrhosis should only be prescribed for patients who have had transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting.
❌ Daily oral propranolol :
Incorrect: Nonselective beta blockers like propranolol are used in patients with cirrhosis and portal hypertension to reduce the risk of esophageal varices. In patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), beta-blocker use is associated with worse outcomes, and it should be permanently discontinued once SBP has developed.
✅ Daily oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Daily oral neomycin :
Incorrect: Neomycin is a non-absorbable antibiotic that can be used to treat hepatic encephalopathy in patients unresponsive to lactulose and unable to tolerate rifaximin. It is not used to treat spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
❌  Daily oral amoxicillin-clavulanate :
Incorrect: Amoxicillin-clavulanate is inappropriate for prophylaxis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis because it does not provide optimal coverage against the typical causative pathogens (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella).

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of six months of easy bruising, thinning skin, polyuria, hypertension, and central obesity with violaceous striae. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She has been smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), blood pressure is 152/91 mmHg and pulse is 90/min. Supraclavicular and dorsocervical fat pads are noted to be enlarged. Neurologic examination shows proximal muscle weakness bilaterally. The abdomen is obese with dark terminal hairs and violaceous striae. 24-hour urinary free cortisol and late-night salivary cortisol levels are significantly elevated. Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the abdomen shows a 9-mm left adrenal mass. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows a 7-mm pituitary mass. The patient undergoes inferior petrosal sinus sampling which does not demonstrate a central-to-peripheral adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) pituitary gradient. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple signs and symptoms of hypercortisolism has late-night salivary and 24-hour urinary free cortisol measurements that confirm the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome. The elevated serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) indicates ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome. The patient is found to have a pituitary microadenoma (<10 mm), but inferior petrosal sinus sampling does not indicate that the pituitary gland is the source of ACTH. Therefore, CT imaging of the chest should be done to look for small cell lung cancer, which is the most likely ectopic source of ACTH in this patient with a significant smoking history.

Once Cushing syndrome is confirmed, plasma ACTH levels should be measured. If ACTH is low, then this indicates ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome and abdominal imaging should be performed to look for an adrenal mass. If ACTH is high then the patient has ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, and a brain MRI should be performed to look for a pituitary source of ACTH. If a pituitary macroadenoma(≥10 mm) is found, this is likely the source and the condition is referred to as Cushing disease. If a microadenoma (<10 mm) is found, then inferior petrosal sinus sampling should be performed. The ACTH levels in the blood from the petrosal sinus (central) are compared to the levels in the peripheral vein. A significant central-to-peripheral ACTH pituitary gradient (often a ratio greater than 2 or 3 at baseline, and greater than 3 after CRH stimulation) indicates a central source of ACTH (i.e. the pituitary gland). If there is no significant gradient, it suggests that ACTH production is coming from somewhere other than the pituitary, indicating an ectopic source. The next step given the low central-to-peripheral ACTH pituitary gradient is to perform chest imaging to look for a lung malignancy. Ectopic ACTH production from small cell lung cancer is typically treated with tumor resection.

Management of Cushing syndrome depends on the underlying cause of the condition. Management of Cushing disease from a pituitary adenoma should include surgical consultation to determine if tumor resection with transsphenoidal adenomectomy is appropriate. This is usually followed by hormone replacement therapy with growth hormone and glucocorticoids. Alternatively, if surgery is not appropriate, radiotherapy can be considered. Other treatment options include medical therapy with adrenal steroidogenesis inhibitors, like ketoconazole and metyrapone, or somatostatin receptor ligands, like pasireotide.

Bilateral adrenalectomy can be used to definitively treat adrenal hyperplasia, and unilateral adrenalectomy can definitively treat adrenal adenomas. The adrenal enzyme inhibitors (metyrapone or ketoconazole) can be given to reduce cortisol secretion in order to improve patients’ physical condition before surgery.
 

Option Analysis

✅ CT imaging of the chest:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transsphenoidal adenomectomy:
Incorrect: This is a treatment option for patients with Cushing disease (glucocorticoid excess due to a pituitary mass). Though this patient has a microadenoma, the negative findings from petrosal sinus sampling indicate an ectopic source of ACTH and not a pituitary source.  
❌ Pituitary radiotherapy:
Incorrect: This is a treatment option for patients with Cushing disease (glucocorticoid excess due to a pituitary mass). Although this patient has a microadenoma, the petrosal sinus sampling indicates that an ectopic source of ACTH is the cause, not a pituitary source.  
❌ Adrenal mass resection:
Incorrect: This is a treatment option for patients with Cushing syndrome due to a hormonally active adrenal mass (which would cause low serum ACTH). This patient has ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, so the adrenal finding on imaging is likely an incidentaloma and not related to this patient’s presentation.  
❌ Ketoconazole and metyrapone:
Incorrect: These medications are adrenal steroidogenesis inhibitors and can be used as medical therapy to treat Cushing syndrome due to adrenal or pituitary overproduction. This patient likely has an ectopic ACTH source, and imaging should be done first to determine the etiology.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with left ear pain and fullness for the past two days. He noted some clear, odorless discharge from the left ear this morning. The patient was recently on vacation, during which he went kayaking and swimming. Past medical history is unremarkable. Current medications include baby aspirin and multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is pain with the traction of the left pinna. The external auditory canal has erythema and swelling with mild serous discharge. The tympanic membrane is intact. Otitis externa is suspected, and an antibiotic ear drop solution is prescribed. What is the preferred antibiotic treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has otitis externa, which is most often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. As a result, he was started on an antibiotic ear drop. Ciprofloxacin, a second-generation fluoroquinolone, is the drug of choice since it has antimicrobial activity against P. aeruginosa. In contrast, the other answer choices are third-generation fluoroquinolones that lack coverage against P. aeruginosa.  

The quinolone antibiotics are separated into four generations based on their antimicrobial activity spectrum. Earlier quinolone generations are mostly limited to treating Gram-negative infections. Newer generations can treat infections caused by certain Gram-positive bacteria. Fluoroquinolones are the antibiotic of choice for treating otitis externa since they are not ototoxic.  



Option Analysis

❌ Levofloxacin:
Incorrect: Levofloxacin is a third-generation fluoroquinolone often used to treat community-acquired pneumonia. It has antimicrobial activity against Enterobacteriaceae, atypical pathogens, and Streptococci but not against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is the most common cause of otitis externa. 
❌ Sparfloxacin:
Incorrect: Sparfloxacin is a third-generation fluoroquinolone with antimicrobial activity against Enterobacteriaceae, atypical pathogens, and Streptococci but not against Pseudomonas aeruginosa (a most common cause of otitis externa). Moreover, sparfloxacin is not renally excreted and therefore should not be used to treat urinary tract infections. 
✅ Ciprofloxacin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gatifloxacin :
Incorrect: Gatifloxacin is a third-generation fluoroquinolone with antimicrobial activity against Enterobacteriaceae, atypical pathogens, and Streptococci but not against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is the most common cause of otitis externa. It has superior coverage of Streptococci when compared to other fluoroquinolones. Concurrent use of gatifloxacin with digoxin can cause increased serum digoxin levels. 
❌ Moxifloxacin:
Incorrect: Moxifloxacin is a third-generation fluoroquinolone with antimicrobial activity against Enterobacteriaceae, atypical pathogens, and Streptococci but not against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is the most common cause of otitis externa. It has superior coverage of Streptococci when compared to other fluoroquinolones. As a newer fluoroquinolone, moxifloxacin has been noted to have less significant interaction with calcium-containing products.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of generalized malaise and palpitations for the past two months. He does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or nausea. Past medical history includes hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. An echocardiogram performed last year demonstrated mild atrial dilatation and ventricular hypertrophy. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.96 F), pulse is 123/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. ECG shows an irregular rhythm with narrow complex tachycardia and no organized P waves. Pharmacological therapy with intravenous metoprolol is initiated. Which of the following effects will metoprolol administration have on the type of cardiac cell represented in the tracing below?

choices.text: Decrease the slope of phase 0 depolarization

questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic generalized malaise and palpitations suggestive of atrial fibrillation.   Metoprolol (class II antiarrhythmic) is administered to this patient for rate control. The tracing in the question stem demonstrates the action potential of cardiac pacemaker cells in cardiac slow-response tissues such as the sinoatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes. In pacemaker cells, class II antiarrhythmics prevent epinephrine and norepinephrine from binding to beta receptors, which indirectly decreases the number of open L-type calcium channels. Ultimately, this decreases the amount of calcium that enters the cell at the end of phase four, leading to a slower pacemaker potential. This can be observed as a decrease in the slope during phase four and a decreased heart rate.  

β-blockers also indirectly prevent the opening of L-type calcium channels at the end of phase 2 in non-pacemaker cells (e.g. cardiac myocytes). This effect decreases the amount of intracellular calcium available to the muscle fibers, weakening the force generated during systole. Beta-blockers ultimately reduce myocardial oxygen demand by reducing heart rate and contractility via these pharmacologic effects.





Option Analysis

❌ Decrease the slope of phase 0 depolarization:
Incorrect: Class I antiarrhythmic medications block sodium entry into the cell during depolarization. This effect decreases the slope of phase 0. The tracing in the question stem corresponds to the pacemaker action potential.
❌ Lowered threshold potential:
Incorrect: Threshold potential refers to the voltage required to initiate an action potential. β1 adrenergic agonism via medications or stress, as well as mechanical stretch, decreases this threshold in both fast- and slow-response cells. Na+ channel blockers (e.g. lidocaine) increase the depolarization threshold in fast-response cells, and Ca2+ channel blockers (e.g. verapamil) raise this threshold in pacemaker cells in both the SA node and AV node.
❌ Decreased excitation and contraction coupling:
Incorrect: Decreased slope of phase 4 depolarization
✅ Decreased slope of phase 4 depolarization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced refractory period:
Incorrect: Use of the β-blockers results in cardiac membrane stabilization. Conduction through the SA and AV nodes slows, and the refractory period increases via the indirect blockade of Ca2+ entry into pacemaker cells.

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted where patients with a recent myocardial infarction treated with percutaneous coronary intervention are randomized to placebo or study medication. The survival percentage of both the groups is followed for a year with the following data demonstrated in the chart below. The differences between each curve were statistically significant. Which is the most likely study medication used in this trial?
questions.solution:
Medications that have been shown to improve long-term survival in patients after myocardial infarction (MI) include beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers, and statins.  

Beta-blockers (e.g. metoprolol) are used following myocardial infarction to reduce myocardial oxygen demand by reducing AV nodal conductivity, slowing the heart rate, and reducing afterload. They have been shown to reduce short-term morbidity, improve long-term survival, and prevent reinfarction and cardiac arrests by 16%.  

Other indications for beta blockers include the treatment of supraventricular tachycardias (SVT)-- especially ventricular rate control for atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.



Option Analysis

❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is associated with an increased risk of all-cause mortality in patients with coronary artery disease without systolic heart failure or renal impairment.
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Digoxin has been suggested to increase mortality risk in survivors of acute myocardial infarction in a dose-dependent relationship.
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine has been associated with a higher risk of death in patients presenting with NSTEMI. No mortality benefit has been observed.
✅ Metoprolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amlodipine:
Incorrect: Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that does not reduce post-myocardial infarction mortality.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of painful skin lesions. The patient has erythematous erosions over the face, limbs, trunk, and oral cavity. Before developing this rash, he developed fever, chills, and sore throat three days ago. He was diagnosed with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure disorder six months ago and is currently taking lamotrigine. The patient is ill-appearing. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 117/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 94%. Skin examination reveals blistering lesions and erosions in the oral cavity, face, upper limb, and trunk. A lateral pressure to the skin results in the shedding of the epidermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). SJS is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by cytotoxic T-cells (CD8+ T-cells). The condition is characterized by necrosis of the epithelium of the skin and mucosal membranes, resulting in blistering lesions and erosions, fever, and systemic illness. Involved areas typically include the skin of the face, trunk, and limbs and mucous membranes.  

Many common medications can trigger SJS. Anticonvulsants associated with SJS include lamotrigine, carbamazepine, phenytoin, and ethosuximide. 


Option Analysis

✅ Stevens-Johnson syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Erythema multiforme :
Incorrect: This patient’s skin lesions, involvement of mucosal membranes, fever, and history of lamotrigine use suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome. 
❌ Staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome :
Incorrect: Staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome is associated with blistering lesions, skin tenderness, and fever; however, mucosal membranes are spared. This condition is more commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.
❌ Pemphigus Vulgaris :
Incorrect: Pemphigus Vulgaris can present with blisters, mucosal lesions, and fever, but it is primarily seen in older patients. Also, the association with using lamotrigine makes Stevens-Johnson syndrome the more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Bullous pemphigoid:
Incorrect: Bullous pemphigoid is a blistering disorder characterized by tense bullae that are usually itchy and may turn painful with time. Mucosal lesions can sometimes be seen, but fever is rare.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man admitted to the inpatient wards presents with hematuria. He has not had dysuria, straining, polyuria, abdominal pain, or fever. His medical history includes chronic lymphocytic leukemia, for which he underwent a bone marrow transplant two weeks ago, type II diabetes mellitus, and chronic back pain. Before his transplant, he was treated with an antineoplastic drug that induces DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following could have prevented this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Aggressive hydration to prevent ureteric calculus formation
Treatment with penicillin to prevent glomerulonephritis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hematuria following initiation of a chemotherapeutic regimen suggestive of hemorrhagic cystitis secondary to cyclophosphamide use.  

Hemorrhagic cystitis, following the use of nitrogen mustards like cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide, is an inflammatory process induced by a toxic metabolite called acrolein. The liver metabolizes Cyclophosphamide, and acrolein is formed as a metabolic product. This substance is then filtered by the kidneys and concentrated in the bladder, promoting proinflammatory cytokines, generating reactive oxygen species, and producing nitric oxide. These compounds damage the urothelium, resulting in hemorrhage and edema. Forced saline diuresis, aggressive hydration, and pretreatment with MESNA, a neuroprotective agent, are indicated in all patients receiving cyclophosphamide. Mesna acts as a  thiol compound with a sulfhydryl donor that binds to acrolein, creating an inert thioether excreted in the urine.  



Option Analysis

✅ Pretreatment with a sulfhydryl donor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cessation of analgesics :
Incorrect: Analgesic nephropathy can present with hematuria in patients with a history of chronic pain and overuse of NSAIDs. Additional symptoms include flank pain and investigations that reveal azotemia. 
❌ Aggressive hydration to prevent ureteric calculus formation:
Incorrect: Nephrolithiasis typically involves ureteric colic (radiating pain to the groin), nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. Isolated hematuria is unlikely to stem from a diagnosis of ureteric colic. 
❌ Treatment with penicillin to prevent glomerulonephritis :
Incorrect: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis follows a streptococcal pharyngeal/skin infection and is prevented by the administration of penicillin. The most common clinical findings include hematuria, hypertension, and a urinalysis demonstrating dysmorphic red blood cells and red blood cell casts. 
❌ Screening renal ultrasound :
Incorrect: ADPKD or renal anatomic defects can present with hematuria, hypertension, flank pain, and a dilated pelvicalyceal system on ultrasound. Screening renal ultrasound is indicated in patients >18 years of age with a positive family history of ADPKD. Without a positive family history, a renal screening ultrasound is not indicated.

questions.text:
A 22 year old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent palpitations for one month. He has noticed the palpitations intermittently, particularly during intense activity. His past medical history includes generalized anxiety disorder, for which he takes fluoxetine daily. He drinks 4-5 beers daily. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Heart sounds are irregular. ECG is shown below. He is initiated on warfarin with a dose adjusted to an INR between 2-2.5, and electrical cardioversion is planned following appropriate anticoagulation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacological agent to administer for rate control?
 
Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent atrial fibrillation as evidenced by a rapid rate, irregularly irregular rhythm, and absent P waves on ECG. Management of atrial fibrillation targets both symptom management and prevention of thromboembolism. The initial management of atrial fibrillation involves a rate or rhythm control strategy.

Agents prolonging the AV node's ERP can achieve adequate rate control of calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem, which slows the phase 4 and phase 0 depolarization in pacemaker tissues by blocking the L-type calcium channels. As a result, AV conduction is markedly slowed, and re-entry through the AV node terminates, thus aborting the associated arrhythmia. Calcium channel blockers like verapamil and diltiazem can be administered to achieve rate control in hemodynamically stable patients while considering cardioversion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Quinidine:
Incorrect: Quinidine is a type of an antiarrhythmic that slows phase 0 depolarization in ventricular myocyte action potentials. Quinidine effectively reduces the incidence of recurrent atrial fibrillation but is no longer recommended for rhythm control. It is not the first-line treatment of choice for rate control in atrial fibrillation.  
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that can reduce AV nodal effective refractory period via vagomimetic action. Digoxin is typically reserved for patients with atrial fibrillation following treatment failure with the administration of a beta blocker or calcium channel blocker.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic utilized for rhythm control in patients with atrial fibrillation. Amiodarone is associated with the greatest likelihood of maintaining sinus rhythm and is effective in preventing recurrent atrial fibrillation.  
❌ Ibutilide:
Incorrect: Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic effective for pharmacological cardioversion of atrial fibrillation. It is not used as a rate control strategy for atrial fibrillation.  
✅ Verapamil:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness since last night. He has not had any syncopal episodes, chest pain, nausea, or vomiting. His past medical history includes cluster headaches and GERD. His current medications include triptans PRN and ranitidine PRN. He drinks 4-5 beers and 4 cups of coffee daily. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. His paternal uncle died at age 35 due to a cardiac condition. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 175/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Heart sounds are regular. He appears alert and oriented. Lead II telemetry is shown below. He is administered a medication that blocks calcium influx and promotes potassium expulsion from pacemaker cells resulting in hyperpolarization and prolongation of the AV node refractory period. Which of the following is the most likely therapeutic agent administered to this patient?
 
Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as evidenced by both symptoms and ECG findings that include rapid, narrow, complex, regular tachycardia without discernable p-waves.

In hemodynamically stable patients, non-pharmacological treatment options include vagal maneuvers. If the arrhythmia persists, IV adenosine is effective in terminating the arrhythmia.

Adenosine is an antiarrhythmic medication that binds to the adenosine receptors (A1) on pacemaker cells and promotes the efflux of potassium resulting in hyperpolarization. Additionally, adenosine inhibits L-type calcium channels. Together, these effects prolong the ERP through the AV node to depress the reentrant circuit. In most cases, adenosine is effective in terminating PSVT.

Adenosine is also used for noninvasive stress testing to evaluate chronic stable angina. Since it prolongs the effective refractory period of the AV node, it carries a risk of AV nodal block. Other adverse effects include chest pain, dyspnea, flushing, bronchoconstriction, and hypotension.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is an AV nodal blocking agent that can be used for the treatment of PSVT following the failure of non-pharmacological methods and adenosine. Verapamil does block L-type calcium channels and slows conduction through the AV node. However, it does not induce hyperpolarization of pacemaker tissue.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a beta blocker that inhibits adrenergically mediated ectopic activity and slows conduction through the AV node.  Propranolol is not indicated in the treatment of PSVT.  
✅ Adenosine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic that blocks delayed rectifier potassium channels,  inhibits myocardial calcium channels, exerts beta-adrenergic blocking properties, and blocks inactivated sodium channels.  
❌ Ivabradine:
Incorrect: Ivarbadine is indicated in the treatment of chronic heart failure and chronic stable angina. It selectively inhibits the funny sodium channel and prolongs phase 4 of SA node depolarization.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with palpitations and lightheadedness. She returned from a trip to Mexico one week ago. Two days ago, she was seen in the emergency department for evaluation of loose stools and abdominal discomfort and was discharged. Her medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 202/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 105/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96% Mucous membranes appear dry. Physical examination reveals hyperactive bowel sounds in all quadrants. She appears drowsy but responds to verbal commands. Laboratory investigations and ECG reveal the findings below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   130 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.7 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.4 mg/dL 
 BUN/Cr  25  
 Mg  2.0  
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  12  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40 % 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  9,000/mm3 

 By Jer5150 - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0 Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Most cases of hypokalemia arise from gastrointestinal or renal losses. This patient presents with symptomatic hypokalemia (N:3.5-4.0 mEq/L) from a recent gastrointestinal infection and diuretic use. Hypokalemia can manifest with characteristic changes on an ECG, although these are not always apparent.
 
 By James Heilman, MD - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,  Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
Hypokalemic changes include ST segment depression, PR interval prolongation, U waves in the lateral leads, and a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave. The appropriate treatment for such findings would be IV potassium and cessation of medications contributing to potassium losses. Patients with hypokalemia often have associated hypomagnesemia. Magnesium replacement may be warranted in most cases when potassium is refractory to replacement.

In this patient, ECG findings indicate acquired long QT syndrome due to hypokalemia induced by gastrointestinal losses and a diuretic (hydrochlorothiazide) intake.
 

Acquired long QT syndrome can result from medications (like antipsychotics, antiemetics, antiarrhythmics, antimicrobials ), electrolyte abnormalities, and bradyarrhythmias. Torsade de pointe is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that results in cyclic twisting/alteration of the QRS axis and morphology that occurs secondary to acquired or congenital torsade de pointe.
 

The treatment of choice for torsade de pointe is IV magnesium. Although the mechanism is not clearly understood, it has been postulated that magnesium acts on the myocardium by slowing the SA node impulse formation rate, prolonging conduction time. Magnesium is essential for the movement of calcium, sodium, and potassium cardiac cells and stabilizes excitable membranes.
 

Option Analysis

✅ IV Magnesium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transvenous pacing:
Incorrect: Temporary transvenous overdrive pacing is reserved for patients with torsade de pointe who do not respond to IV magnesium.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Bradycardia can exacerbate torsade de pointe and is not the treatment of choice for long QT-related torsade de pointe in hemodynamically unstable patients.  
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a Class Ib antiarrhythmic that is a useful treatment for patients with ventricular arrhythmia, particularly ischemic tissue. Although Class Ib medications can be used to manage torsade de pointe, they are not first-line agents for this condition.  
❌ 3% normal saline:
Incorrect: 3% normal saline is indicated for patients with severe, symptomatic hyponatremia. This patient's altered mental status is more likely related to her underlying cardiac arrhythmia.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with nonischemic cardiomyopathy and hypertension comes to the clinic for follow-up following recent hospital admission for acute decompensated heart failure. She becomes short of breath after walking a block but has not had syncope, cough, or hemoptysis. Her current medications include metoprolol, lisinopril, furosemide, spironolactone, and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> of 90%. An echocardiogram reveals an ejection fraction of 30%, mild mitral regurgitation, and pulmonary hypertension. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Ivabradine is added to her treatment regimen. Which of the following phases of the pacemaker action potential is targeted by this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptomatic heart failure (NYHA Class II-III) with reduced ejection fraction and is currently on optimal medical therapy with a diuretic, an ACE inhibitor, aldosterone antagonist, and a beta blocker. Ivabradine is a selective sinus node inhibitor that inhibits the funny sodium current that occurs through the HCN channels in the heart's pacemaker cells. As a result, this medication inhibits phase 4 of the cardiac pacemaker action potential.

Ivabradine is also indicated in the treatment of chronic stable angina in patients with chronic heart failure and a heart rate of >70 bpm. It is not beneficial in those with stable coronary artery disease without heart failure. Adverse effects of ivabradine include symptomatic bradycardia and visual disturbances (presence of phosphenes).
 



Option Analysis

❌ Phase 0:
Incorrect: Phase 0 depolarization depends on a calcium current via L-type calcium channels. These channels are inhibited by class IV antiarrhythmics like verapamil and diltiazem. Ivabradine does not inhibit L-type calcium channels.  
❌ Phase 2:
Incorrect: Phase 1 and 2 of the cardiac action potential are not present in pacemaker cells. Instead, phase 0 proceeds directly to phase 3. Ivabradine acts on cardiac pacemaker cells at phase 0 of their action potential.  
❌ Phase 3:
Incorrect: Phase 3 of the pacemaker action potential is governed by the decay of calcium channel current and repolarization driven by rectifying potassium channels. Ivabradine does not affect phase 3 of the pacemaker action potential.  
✅ Phase 4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phase 4 and Phase 0:
Incorrect: Calcium channel blockers affect phase 4 and phase 0, slowing pacemaker potential and delaying depolarization of pacemaker tissue. While ivabradine does act on Phase 4 of the pacemaker potential, it does not affect phase 0 of the pacemaker action potential.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent boils and skin infections. The patient has had 3 skin infections in the past 5 months that were treated with antibiotics. Anterior nare culture is performed, which yields gram-positive cocci in clusters. These bacteria are able to grow in a medium containing oxacillin. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic for the treatment of this patient’s infection?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent boils and skin infections due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Methicillin-resistant strains are able to grow in the presence of oxacillin due to a mutation in the gene that encodes for penicillin-binding proteins. Among the cephalosporins, only ceftaroline is effective against MRSA.

Ceftaroline is a fifth generation cephalosporin that differs from the other cephalosporins due to its activity against MRSA, which is resistant to all other β-lactams. Ceftaroline’s Gram-negative activity is similar to that of the third-generation cephalosporins but does not include coverage of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Ceftaroline may be used in community-acquired pneumonia and skin infections.

In contrast, the fourth-generation cephalosporin cefepime is a broad-coverage agent with potent activity against both Gram-negative bacilli (including P. aeruginosa) and Gram-positive cocci. The fourth-generation cephalosporins have clinical uses similar to that of the third-generation drugs, but are more resistant to beta-lactamases. However, they do not provide coverage against MRSA. Fourth-generation cephalosporins can be used in bacteremia, febrile neutropenia, as well as intra-abdominal and urinary tract infections.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin effective against Gram-positive cocci, Proteus mirabilis, Eschereria coli, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. It can be used for surgical prophylaxis and for the treatment of urinary tract infections as well as minor skin and soft tissue infections. However, cephalexin does not provide coverage against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  
❌ Cefoxitin:
Incorrect: Cefoxitin is a second-generation cephalosporin that has extended Gram-negative coverage. It can treat infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Serratia marcescens, and Enterobacter aerogenes. However, cefoxitin does not provide coverage against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin with improved activity against Gram-negative bacteria but reduced activity against Gram-positive bacteria. Ceftriaxone is most commonly used to treat infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Pneumococci, Meningococci, and Neisseria species. However, it does not provide coverage against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  
❌ Cefepime:
Incorrect: Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin with potent Gram-positive and Gram-negative coverage. It is also effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and crosses the blood-brain barrier. However, cefepime is ineffective against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, which is the cause of this patient’s cutaneous symptoms.  
✅ Ceftaroline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic to evaluate elevated deposits around the eyes. The deposits developed for a year and are now affecting her physical appearance. Past medical history is significant for a syphilitic chancre, which was adequately treated with an antibiotic. Family history is significant for the death of the patient's mother from a massive myocardial infarction at the age of 42. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals the findings below. A fasting lipid profile is performed, and the results are shown below. In addition to dietary modification, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?
 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Laboratory Value
Results
Total cholesterol
375 mg/dL
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)
240 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
35 mg/dL
Triglycerides
100 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has xanthelasma around the eyes, a family history of premature coronary artery disease, and laboratory evidence of hypercholesterolemia. She is most likely suffering from familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the LDL receptor (LDL-R) gene. The mutation leads to increased levels of LDL-cholesterol and total cholesterol levels in the blood. Such individuals are at increased risk of premature cardiovascular disease, often beginning between 30 and 40 years of age.

FH is typically treated with statins, lipid-lowering drugs that competitively inhibit HMG-CoA reductase and lead to decreased hepatic cholesterol synthesis and increased LDL recycling. The overall effect is a significant reduction in LDL levels, a modest reduction in TG levels, and a moderate increase in HDL levels. Moreover, statins help decrease the risk of cardiovascular mortality in susceptible patients by decreasing serum cholesterol levels.

Indications for starting statin therapy are as follows:
  
  • LDL ≥ 190 mg/dL 
  • Clinically significant atherosclerotic disease (e.g., acute coronary syndrome, myocardial infarction, stroke, and transient ischemic attack) 
  • Diabetes mellitus in patients aged 40-75 years 
  • Estimated 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk ≥ 7.5% 

Option Analysis

✅ Atorvastatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cholestyramine:
Incorrect: Cholestyramine is a bile acid resin that helps decrease LDL cholesterol by binding bile acids in the intestine and preventing their reabsorption at the intestinal brush border. However, it does not appear to mitigate the risk of cardiovascular complications associated with hypercholesterolemia.  
❌ Ezetimibe:
Incorrect: Ezetimibe is a drug that lowers circulating cholesterol levels by decreasing cholesterol absorption in the small intestine. While it can help reduce this patient’s total cholesterol level, it does not mitigate the risk of cardiovascular complications associated with hypercholesterolemia.  
❌ Gemfibrozil:
Incorrect: A fibrate, such as gemfibrozil, would not be the appropriate first-line medication for this patient. Fibrates work by acting as ligands to the PPAR-α receptor and primarily lower VLDL without affecting LDL levels.  
❌ Omega-3-fatty acids:
Incorrect: Omega-3 fatty acid is not an appropriate first-line medication for this patient's condition. This drug is primarily used for lowering triglyceride levels, which are normal in this patient.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the office for a routine follow-up. He has been feeling healthy and has no concerns. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in his father. The patient smokes a pack of cigarettes daily but does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 125/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows a well-appearing male with no abnormal findings. Laboratory testing is obtained, and the results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?  

Laboratory Value
Results
Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)
190 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
35 mg/dL
Triglyceride (TG)
100 mg/dL
Hemoglobin A1c
6.4%
Serum creatinine
1.2 mg/dL

choices.text: Schedule patient for a follow-up visit in 12-months

questions.solution:
Statins are an important part of the management plan in patients with significantly elevated LDL cholesterol levels and those at increased risk of cardiovascular mortality (e.g., diabetes and age >40 years).

Statins act by competitively inhibiting the hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase, which normally converts HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a cholesterol precursor. Of note, the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate is the rate-limiting step of cholesterol metabolism. As a result, statins decrease hepatic cholesterol synthesis and increase low-density lipoproteins (LDL) recycling via the upregulation of LDL receptors on hepatocytes.

A baseline workup is necessary before starting statin therapy to help monitor the treatment response and identify potential side effects. These include:
 
  • Serum creatine kinase (CPK) to determine baseline levels 
  • Lipid profile to monitor treatment response 
  • Liver function test (LFT) for potential hepatotoxicity.  
  • Thyroid function test (TFT) as myopathy can be aggravated in patients with hypothyroidism who are taking statins 
  • Renal function tests are not routinely indicated but should be obtained in patients with chronic kidney disease. 
If patients develop aminotransferase levels exceeding three times the upper limit of normal, then immediate discontinuation or dose reduction of the medication is indicated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Initiate atorvastatin therapy:
Incorrect: This patient’s LDL levels are elevated and can benefit from statin therapy. However, baseline labs should be obtained before starting statin therapy.  
✅ Perform liver function testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Replace metformin with glimepiride:
Incorrect: This patient’s HbA1c is within the target goal (<7%). As a result, there is no need to replace metformin with glimepiride.  
❌ Schedule patient for a follow-up visit in 12-months:
Incorrect: Although this patient is currently asymptomatic, his lipid profile shows significantly elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. The patient should be started on statin therapy after baseline labs have been obtained.  
❌ Prescribe vitamin E supplements:
Incorrect: This patient’s LDL levels are significantly elevated, and vitamin E supplements have no proven benefit in managing lipid disorders.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for a routine visit. She is asymptomatic. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension which is controlled by losartan. She has been smoking 2-3 cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 66/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Lipid panel

Total cholesterol  
236 mg/dL (6.24 mmol/L)
HDL cholesterol
92 mg/dL (2.56 mmol/L)
LDL cholesterol
122 mg/dL (3.00 mmol/L)
Triglycerides
124 mg/dL (1.45 mmol/L)

choices.text: Calculate the 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk

questions.solution:
While a general estimate of the relative risk for ASCVD in patients can be approximated by counting the number of traditional risk factors present, a more precise estimation of the absolute risk for a first ASCVD event is necessary when making treatment recommendations in patients aged 40-75 years who have no prior ASCVD and are asymptomatic. For this patient with a history of hypertension and smoking, the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) should be calculated, and based on the level of risk, prevention strategies and decisions regarding the lipid panel results can be made.

For all asymptomatic patients without a history of ASVD who are being screened for cardiovascular disease, the initial step in management involves determining the presence of one or more of the traditional risk factors (hypertension, cigarette smoking, diabetes mellitus [DM], premature family history of ASCVD, chronic kidney disease, obesity) for ASCVD. If a risk factor is present, then the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) should be calculated to classify patients into various risk categories: low risk (< 5%), borderline risk (5%‒ 7.4%), and intermediate risk (7.5%‒19.9%) and high risk (>20%). Based on this classification, optimal risk factor modification and primary prevention strategies, including statin therapy can be determined. All patients ≥ 20 years of age should have a baseline lipid profile and treatment decisions for prevention of ASCVD should be based on the results of the lipid panel, patient age, and the patient’s calculated 10-year risk for ASCVD.  

Option Analysis

❌ Initiate high-intensity statin:
Incorrect: According to the ACC/AHA guidelines, high-intensity statin therapy is indicated for primary prevention of ASCVD in patients with an LDL cholesterol level ≥ 190 mg/dL and for patients with diabetes and multiple atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk factors. This patient’s ASCVD score should be calculated before determining the necessary intervention, but this patient would likely not require high-intensity statin therapy.  
❌ Repeat lipid panel while fasting:
Incorrect: Fasting and nonfasting total cholesterol and HDL cholesterol levels have fairly similar prognostic value and association with cardiovascular outcomes. LDL levels vary slightly with and without fasting. Fasting is not generally required. It may be required with elevated triglyceride levels.  
❌ Initiate low-dose aspirin:
Incorrect: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force advises individualized decision-making regarding low-dose aspirin therapy for adults aged 40 to 59 years with a 10-year ASCVD risk of ≥ 10% and no elevated risk of bleeding, provided they have a life expectancy of ≥ 10 years and are willing to commit to daily aspirin for a decade. Conversely, the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines suggest limited use of aspirin in routine primary ASCVD prevention, citing a lack of overall benefit. This patient’s ASCVD score should be calculated first before deciding on treatment.  
✅ Calculate the 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain an electrocardiogram (ECG):
Incorrect: The USPSTF does not recommend screening for coronary artery disease with resting ECG in asymptomatic patients at low risk, defined by the USPSTF as a 10-year cardiovascular event risk of <10%. This patient’s ASCVD score should be calculated first.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine visit. He is asymptomatic. He has a past medical history of hypertension that is controlled by losartan. He has smoked 2-3 cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 75/min, blood pressure is 134/90 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 13/min. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Lipid panel is shown below. The calculated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 3.1%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Lipid panel

Total cholesterol
220 mg/dL (6.24 mmol/L)
HDL cholesterol
82 mg/dL (2.56 mmol/L)
LDL-C cholesterol
140 mg/dL (3.00 mmol/L)
Triglycerides
124 mg/dL (1.45 mmol/L)

choices.text: Coronary artery calcium score with CT scan

questions.solution:
Screening for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in adults without a prior history of ASCVD who are asymptomatic is important for preventative strategies, including statin therapy for elevated LDL cholesterol, as well as early identification of patients at high risk for heart attack, stroke, and related conditions. Risk stratification enables healthcare providers to tailor preventive interventions effectively. In patients like this one with an elevated LDL-C that is less than 190 mg/dL and a 10-year risk for ASCVD < 5%, diet and exercise counseling without statin therapy is recommended.

Patients with elevated LDL-C and a low 10-year cardiovascular event risk (< 5%) are advised to adopt lifestyle modifications. This includes a nutritious diet that emphasizes the consumption of vegetables, fruits, nuts, whole grains, and lean proteins, including fish; and limits trans fats, processed meats, refined carbohydrates, and sugary drinks. Patients who are overweight should be advised about calorie reduction and strategies for sustained weight loss. All adults should be counseled to get at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity physical activity each week to maintain good health.

Patients with borderline (5%‒7.4%) or intermediate 10-year cardiovascular risk (7.5‒19.9%) should be counseled regarding lifestyle changes, and they also may benefit from statin therapy, particularly if they have specific conditions like diabetes or a family history of premature ASCVD. Patients with a high 10-year cardiovascular risk (≥ 20% 10-year risk) generally require more aggressive management. This can include high-intensity statin therapy, stricter control of blood pressure and glucose levels, and possibly other medications to manage lipid levels.  

Option Analysis

❌ Moderate-intensity statin:
Incorrect: This patient's LDL cholesterol level is below the recommended absolute level for starting a statin (190 mg/dL [4.9 mmol/L]), and his calculated ASCVD risk falls below that for which guidelines recommend considering statin therapy (≥ 7.5%). Additionally, he does not have a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which would be an indication for moderate-intensity statin therapy. Therefore, lifestyle modifications should be recommended.  
❌ High-intensity statin:
Incorrect: Patients at high risk based on the ASCVD calculator should be counseled on lifestyle modifications (e.g., healthy diet, increased physical activity), and started on high-intensity statin therapy regardless of the presence of risk-enhancing factors. This patient’s ASCVD risk score is < 5%. Therefore, statin therapy is unnecessary, and the patient should be counseled on lifestyle modifications.  
✅ Diet and exercise counseling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Low-dose aspirin therapy:
Incorrect: The USPSTF advises individualized decision-making for low-dose aspirin therapy initiation as primary prevention of ASCVD in adults aged 40 to 59 years with a 10-year ASCVD risk of ≥ 10% who do not have an increased risk for bleeding. The AHA and ACC suggest that low-dose aspirin might be considered for ASCVD primary prevention in adults who are at higher ASCVD risk but not at increased bleeding risk. Low-dose aspirin is not indicated in this patient.  
❌ Coronary artery calcium score with CT scan:
Incorrect: The coronary artery calcium (CAC) score uses CT scanning on patients who are in the borderline to intermediate risk category of ASCVD (those with a 10-year risk between 5% and 20%), to more accurately determine the need for statin therapy or other interventions. This patient’s low ASCVD risk does not put him in a category where a CAC score would alter management.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for his yearly examination. Since being seen last year, the patient has become progressively more fatigued and experiences shortness of breath with exertion. He was hospitalized four times in the past year for three episodes of pneumonia and one episode of left leg cellulitis. The patient has noticed easy bruising and frequent bleeding when brushing his teeth and shaving. Two weeks ago, he developed a small wound on his right forearm, and it took over one week to start healing. The patient has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and takes metoprolol and warfarin. Vital signs show mild tachycardia. On physical examination, there is conjunctival pallor. There are diffuse scattered petechiae and small ecchymoses on skin examination and a 2 cm healing wound on the right forearm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue and shortness of breath with exertion in addition to easy bruising and bleeding. Additionally, he has had several bacterial infections and poor wound healing. This presentation raises concern for pancytopenia. Patients aged 60 years and older presenting with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia should be evaluated for myelodysplastic syndrome. This patient should have a complete blood count (CBC) to assess the hematologic cell lines and to guide further workup.

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) refers to a group of hematologic malignancies characterized by impaired hematopoiesis. All three cell lines (white blood cells, red blood cells, platelets) can have abnormal morphology, abnormal function, or abnormal numbers (cytopenia). Patients with suspected MDS should have a thorough history to evaluate for prior environmental exposures (e.g. benzene), chemotherapy, or prior radiation therapy.

History of recurrent bacterial infections can indicate leukopenia (especially neutropenia). Easy or persistent bleeding while shaving or brushing teeth suggests thrombocytopenia. New fatigue and exertional shortness of breath without another obvious cause (e.g. congestive heart failure) may indicate anemia. Physical examination may demonstrate signs of cytopenias, including conjunctival pallor, tachycardia, petechiae, and ecchymoses.

Whenever MDS is suspected, other causes of cytopenias should first be investigated. If clinical suspicion remains for MDS, then a peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy (aspiration) should be performed. If MDS is confirmed, further cytogenetic and molecular testing should be performed to determine treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Myelodysplastic syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia:
Incorrect: HIT can occur in patients taking heparin or heparin-like medications and can lead to both bleeding and clotting. This patient’s warfarin would not cause HIT, and it would not explain the frequent infections or signs and symptoms of anemia that are present on bloodwork.  
❌ Beta-thalassemia minor:
Incorrect: Patients with beta-thalassemia minor have a heterozygous mutation that causes underproduction of hemoglobin beta-chains. Patients with Beta-thalassemia minor are typically asymptomatic. This patient’s presentation suggests significant pancytopenia, which beta-thalassemia minor would not explain.  
❌ Lead poisoning:
Incorrect: Lead poisoning is more common in children and in patients living in old houses with old, chipped paint. It typically causes microcytic anemia and other symptoms, such as nerve palsy (e.g. foot drop) or gingival lines. This patient’s symptoms suggest pancytopenia rather than pure anemia.  
❌ Bernard-Soulier syndrome:
Incorrect: This syndrome describes a defect in the ability of platelets to adhere to von Willebrand factor. This can impair platelet aggregation and present as bleeding, but it would not explain this patient’s signs and symptoms of anemia (i.e. fatigue and shortness of breath with exertion) and leukopenia (i.e. frequent infections and poor wound healing).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the hematology/oncology clinic as a referral for abnormal blood counts. Over the past year, the patient has become more fatigued and short of breath with exertion and has noticed easy bruising. She was hospitalized twice for bacterial pneumonia in the past year. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. She works in a rubber production factory. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, she is pale with conjunctival pallor and scattered petechiae on the arms and legs. Serum complete blood count shows white blood cells 3200/mm<sup>3</sup>, hemoglobin 7.9 g/dL, platelets 45,000/mm<sup>3</sup> and 5% blasts on peripheral smear. Bone marrow biopsy is performed and shows over 10% dysplastic cells in all three cell lines and 12% blasts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the hematology/oncology clinic with fatigue, shortness of breath with exertion, recurrent infections, and easy bruising. Complete blood count shows pancytopenia. This patient also works in a rubber factory, which could expose her to benzene, increasing her risk of developing MDS. This patient’s exposure and pancytopenia make myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) likely. The abnormal morphology of all cell lines with > 10% dysplastic cells and blast percentage of 12% on bone marrow biopsy indicates MDS with increased blasts.

MDS refers to a group of hematologic malignancies characterized by impaired hematopoiesis. All three cell lines (white blood cells, red blood cells, platelets) can be affected and may have abnormal morphology, abnormal function, or abnormal numbers (cytopenias). Common risk factors include environmental exposure (e.g. benzene), prior chemotherapy, and prior radiation therapy. Patients generally present with signs of a cytopenia, which can be confirmed with a complete blood count. The diagnosis should be confirmed with peripheral smear and bone marrow biopsy.

Peripheral smear and bone marrow biopsy should be examined for dysplasia in one or more cell lines and for blasts. If there are dysplastic cells and > 20% blasts on bone marrow biopsy, acute leukemia is diagnosed. If there is dysplasia in one or more lineages with dysplastic cells > 10% and < 20% blasts in the bone marrow, then MDS can be diagnosed. The bone marrow biopsy specimen should be sent for cytogenetic and molecular testing for MDS-defining genetic abnormalities, such as 5q deletion, SF3B1 mutation, and biallelic TP53 inactivation. If no defining genetic abnormalities are present, then the MDS is classified based on cellularity and the percentage of blasts. Hypoplastic MDS is defined by marked hypocellularity. MDS with low blasts is diagnosed when there are < 5% blasts on bone marrow and < 2% blasts on peripheral blood smear. MDS with increased blasts is diagnosed when there are 5‒19% blasts on bone marrow and > 2% blasts on peripheral blood smear.  

Option Analysis

✅ Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with increased blasts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML):
Incorrect: APML is a specific subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which is usually treated with all-trans retinoic acid and arsenic trioxide or chemotherapy. This diagnosis requires > 20% blasts on bone marrow examination.  
❌ Acute myeloid leukemia (AML):
Incorrect: The diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia requires > 20% blasts on bone marrow examination.  
❌ Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with low blasts:
Incorrect: MDS with low blasts is diagnosed when there is dysplasia in one or more cell lineages with > 10% dysplastic cells, < 5% blasts on bone marrow examination, and < 2% blasts on peripheral blood smear. This patient has 12% blasts on bone marrow examination and 5% blasts on peripheral smear and, therefore, does not meet criteria for this diagnosis.  
❌ Hypoplastic myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS):
Incorrect: Hypoplastic MDS is characterized by a bone marrow examination showing marked hypocellularity. However, this patient’s bone marrow examination reveals 12% blasts, ruling out this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic to establish care. Over the past few months, she has had pain in the left knee that is worse when walking up and down stairs. She also has occasional pain in the right hip from prolonged walking and has pain and stiffness in both hands with a few bony growths noted. Both hands are stiff in the mornings, lasting 5 minutes. The pain in all joints is worse at the end of the day after hours of gardening. Past medical history is significant for dyslipidemia and hypertension, well-controlled with atorvastatin and losartan, respectively. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, the distal interphalangeal joints of two fingers have bony hypertrophy with limited range of motion but no erythema or swelling. The left knee has minimal effusion without erythema or warmth. There is medial joint line tenderness,  limited range of motion, and crepitus with movement. There is a reduction in passive range of motion of the right hip. Serum complete blood count is within normal limits. Serum uric acid level is 8.4 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 79-year-old woman presents with pain in both hands, the left knee, and the right hip. The pain is associated with less than 5 minutes of morning stiffness and worsens with use during the day. The left knee has evidence of a noninflammatory effusion with crepitus, joint line tenderness, and limited range of motion. The interphalangeal joints of the hands have evidence of bony hypertrophy. This patient’s age, history, and clinical exam are consistent with osteoarthritis.

Joint pain is a very common reason for patients to seek medical care, and it can be caused by a wide variety of local or systemic pathologies. To narrow down the differential diagnosis, it is helpful to classify the type of joint involvement. Joint pain can be traumatic or nontraumatic; and acute, subacute, or chronic. It can involve one joint (monoarticular), a few joints (oligoarticular), or multiple joints (polyarticular). It can affect mostly the skeleton (axial) or the extremities (peripheral). And finally, joint pain and swelling may be inflammatory (e.g. septic arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis) or non-inflammatory (e.g. osteoarthritis). The history and physical examination will provide clues to the diagnosis. Imaging, arthrocentesis (cell count, differential, gram stain, culture), and blood work may be needed to make the diagnosis.

Patients with osteoarthritis typically have joint pain that is worse with activity, as well as morning stiffness lasting less than 30 minutes. They typically experience limitations in functioning. Physical exam may show bony enlargement in the hands at the interphalangeal joints and the base of the thumb. The knees may exhibit bony enlargement, joint line tenderness, limited range of motion, and instability. Effusions may be present, but arthrocentesis will reveal synovial fluid that is non-inflammatory or only mildly inflammatory. Osteoarthritis typically affects the knees, hips, interphalangeal joints of the hands, the first CMC joints, first MTP joints, and facet joints of the lower cervical and lower lumbar spine. Diagnosis is made clinically, and radiographs can be used to help make the diagnosis. Characteristic findings on the x-ray include characteristic features of OA like marginal osteophytes, localized joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, and cysts.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Osteoarthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gout:
Incorrect: Patients with gout typically present with acute flares involving one or occasionally a few joints that are painful, swollen, warm, and erythematous. This patient has a mildly elevated uric acid level, but this alone is not diagnostic of gout. This patient’s presentation is more characteristic of osteoarthritis.  
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: In rheumatoid arthritis (RA), patients typically have symmetric arthritis of the small joints of the hands and feet that is associated with over 30 minutes of morning stiffness, with the pain and stiffness improving with activity. Physical examination will reveal multiple small joints of the hands and feet with signs of inflammation, such as swelling, warmth, and erythema. This patient's presentation is more characteristic of osteoarthritis.  
❌ Ankylosing spondylitis:
Incorrect: Patients with ankylosing spondyloarthritis typically present with chronic back pain before the age of 45. Patients are often young men with a family history of inflammatory back arthritis.  
❌ Psoriatic arthritis:
Incorrect: Psoriatic arthritis typically presents in patients with skin psoriasis. Patients can have inflammatory arthritis of the peripheral joints, axial joints, or both. Patients may also have dactylitis (ie sausage digits), and nail changes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for generalized weakness and a new rash. Over the past month, the patient has become fatigued much more easily when walking, gardening, and brushing her hair. The patient has also developed pink-purple discoloration over both eyelids and in a V-shape over the anterior neck and chest. She has no fever, chills, dysphagia, chest pain, shortness of breath, or orthopnea. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Vital signs are unremarkable. A physical examination is performed, showing 3/5 muscle strength in the proximal upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated creatine kinase of 2800 U/L and the presence of anti-Mi-2 antibodies. Which of the following physical examination findings, if present, would be a specific indication of the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pink-Violaceous papules on the dorsal aspects of the fingers
Thin tight skin on the fingers
Hyperkeratosis and fissuring of the palms and lateral fingers

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness, a heliotrope rash (pink-violaceous rash on the eyelids), and a V-sign (pink-violaceous rash on the anterior neck and chest) most likely has dermatomyositis. Pink-violaceous papules on the dorsal aspects of the bony prominences of the fingers, referred to as Gottron papules, are pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.

Inflammatory myopathies are a group of conditions that result in progressive muscle weakness. These include dermatomyositis, antisynthetase syndrome, immune-mediated necrotizing myositis, inclusion body myositis, and polymyositis. A thorough history and physical examination can help pinpoint a particular diagnosis, and autoantibodies and muscle biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

History may reveal signs of progressive proximal muscle weakness, such as in the shoulders and pelvic girdle muscles in dermatomyositis and polymyositis. For example, patients may describe difficulty combing their hair or standing up from a chair. Patients with inclusion body myositis may have both proximal and distal muscle weakness that is asymmetric. Patients with inflammatory myopathies may have associated rashes or findings such as shortness of breath (from pulmonary fibrosis) or difficulty swallowing. The presence of a rash can be used to distinguish dermatomyositis from polymyositis. Patients may have a family history of rheumatologic diseases. Physical examination should be used to assess muscle strength and to determine if weakness is symmetric or asymmetric and predominantly proximal or distal. A careful skin examination is necessary to look for associated rash. Patients with dermatomyositis may have a heliotrope rash, V-sign, rash on the posterior shoulders (shawl sign), and Gottron papules.
