Fig 1. Gottron papules (reference: Ricceri F, Prignano F. Gottron papules: a pathognomonic sign of dermatomyositis. CMAJ. 2013 Feb 5;185(2):148. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.111791. Epub 2012 Jul 23. PMID: 22825999; PMCID: PMC3563888.)  

Option Analysis

✅ Pink-Violaceous papules on the dorsal aspects of the fingers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fine inspiratory crackles:
Incorrect: Fine inspiratory crackles can be seen in autoimmune diseases that are associated with pulmonary fibrosis, such as scleroderma and antisynthetase syndrome. Pulmonary fibrosis can be seen in dermatomyositis, but it is not an indicator of dermatomyositis since it can be seen with many rheumatic conditions.  
❌ Thin tight skin on the fingers:
Incorrect: Sclerodactyly (or thin tight skin) can occur in immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy but is not generally seen in other inflammatory myopathies. It is also a prominent feature of scleroderma and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome). Gottron papules are pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.  
❌ Swollen tender joints:
Incorrect: Arthritis can be seen in antisynthetase syndrome as well as many other rheumatologic diseases. It rarely may be seen in dermatomyositis, and it does not specifically indicate dermatomyositis when it is present as it can be seen with many rheumatologic conditions.  
❌ Hyperkeratosis and fissuring of the palms and lateral fingers:
Incorrect: This finding, referred to as “Mechanic’s hands,” can be seen in both dermatomyositis and antisynthetase syndrome. It does not specifically indicate dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a two-month history of worsening shortness of breath. Additionally over the past two months, she has experienced intermittent low-grade fevers, diffuse muscle weakness and pain, and swelling of the joints of her hands. She has no dysphagia or changes in the color of her fingers with exposure to cold. She has a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension for which she takes metformin and carvedilol, respectively. Temperature is 37.8ºC (100.0ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 131/85 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 94% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral basilar inspiratory crackles. Examination of the hands shows bilateral hyperkeratosis, fissures, and scaling on the radial aspect of the fingers along with swelling of the bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints. There are no ulcerations on the fingertips. Muscle exam shows 3/5 strength in the shoulders and hips bilaterally with 5/5 strength of the distal muscles. There are no other rashes and no skin thickening on the rest of the hands, forearms, or trunk. Muscle biopsy shows perimysial inflammation with muscle fiber degeneration. Which of the following autoantibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents acutely with low-grade fever, shortness of breath, muscle weakness, arthritis with bilateral inspiratory crackles, low O2 saturation, and mechanic’s hands on physical examination. This constellation of findings is highly suggestive of antisynthetase syndrome. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are typically present in patients with antisynthetase syndrome.

Inflammatory myopathies are a group of conditions that result in progressive muscle weakness; these include dermatomyositis, antisynthetase syndrome, immune-mediated necrotizing myositis, inclusion body myositis, and polymyositis. A thorough history and physical examination can help pinpoint a particular diagnosis; for example, proximal muscle weakness is typically seen in patients with dermatomyositis and polymyositis, while distal asymmetric muscle weakness is more often seen in patients with inclusion body myositis.

Increased creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) can be seen with myopathy, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are typically normal or mildly elevated. A combination of autoantibody testing and muscle biopsy findings can be used to determine the specific diagnosis. Skin biopsy can be used to differentiate dermatomyositis from polymyositis. Chest radiography and pulmonary function tests (PFTs) with diffusing capacity of carbon monoxide should be performed for all patients with suspected or confirmed dermatomyositis (DM) or polymyositis (PM), regardless of pulmonary symptoms. High resolution computed tomography (CT) scan should be performed for all patients with cough or dyspnea, findings consistent with interstitial lung disease on physical exam, or antisynthetase antibodies.

The table below lists the associated antibodies and muscle biopsy findings for each type of inflammatory myopathy.
 
 

Figure 1. Mechanic’s Hands

Option Analysis

✅ Anti-Jo-1:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anti-Mi-2:
Incorrect: Anti-Mi-2 antibodies are associated with dermatomyositis. While mechanic’s hands can also be seen in dermatomyositis, the lack of other rashes and the presence of fever, findings consistent with interstitial lung disease, and arthritis in this patient are more suggestive of antisynthetase syndrome.  
❌ Anti-SRP:
Incorrect: Anti-SRP is associated with immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy. This patient’s muscle biopsy does not show findings of necrotic and regenerating muscle fibers that would indicate immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy.  
❌ Anti-Scl-70:
Incorrect: Anti-Scl-70 is associated with scleroderma (systemic sclerosis). This patient’s mechanic’s hands and myopathy (inflammatory findings on muscle biopsy) are not suggestive of scleroderma. This patient has no evidence of skin thickening or dysphagia that would suggest an overlap syndrome with scleroderma.  
❌ Anti-histone:
Incorrect: Anti-histone is associated with drug-induced lupus. While lupus can present with many different symptoms that overlap with inflammatory myopathies, this patient does not take medications that would cause drug-induced lupus (e.g. hydralazine, procainamide).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of severe thirst and production of large volumes of urine over the past month. She has bipolar disorder and has been on lithium therapy for several years. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination her mucus membranes appear dry; the exam is otherwise unremarkable. A point-of-care glucose check is 88 mg/dL. The physician suspects the patient’s condition is likely caused by lithium and orders an initial set of laboratory studies to evaluate. Which of the following sets of laboratory results would best support their suspicion?

choices.text: Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  150 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  150 mOsm/kg
Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  150 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  700 mOsm/kg
Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  126 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  270 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  100 mOsm/kg
Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  128 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  320 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  800 mOsm/kg
Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  125 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  265 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  500 mOsm/kg

questions.solution:
Polydipsia and polyuria together in the setting of lithium therapy is concerning for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Initial laboratory findings to support this diagnosis would include elevated serum sodium and osmolality combined with low urine osmolality.   

Laboratory findings for DI typically include elevated serum sodium and osmolality alongside low urine osmolality (usually < 300 mOsm/kg), reflecting the inability to concentrate urine. Water deprivation testing can differentiate DI from other water balance disorders (e.g. primary polydipsia), particularly in cases where initial laboratory results are relatively normal. In primary polydipsia, restricting free water intake will stimulate ADH release to maximally concentrate the urine (thus, raising urine osmolality). This process is impaired in DI, so if the urine osmolality remains low the next step is to perform a desmopressin challenge to determine if DI is central or nephrogenic. In central DI, desmopressin (a synthetic form of ADH) compensates for the lack of endogenous ADH and raises urine osmolality. Conversely, in nephrogenic DI there is little to no change in the urine osmolality as the kidneys cannot respond to ADH or its analogs.  

Option Analysis

✅  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  150 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  150 mOsm/kg :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  150 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  700 mOsm/kg :
Incorrect: High urine osmolality in the presence of elevated serum sodium and osmolality suggests an effective concentration of urine, which could be seen in patients with dehydration who still retain the ability to concentrate urine adequately. However, lithium is associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus which is characterized by an inability to concentrate urine.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  126 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  270 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  100 mOsm/kg :
Incorrect: The presence of low serum sodium and osmolality alongside low urine osmolality could indicate primary polydipsia. However, the patient in this vignette is more likely to have nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to lithium use.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  128 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  320 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  800 mOsm/kg :
Incorrect: This pattern could suggest an osmotic diuresis process (such as hyperglycemia). However, the patient in this vignette is more likely to have nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to lithium use.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  125 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  265 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  500 mOsm/kg :
Incorrect: Markedly low serum sodium and osmolality with a relatively normal urine osmolality might suggest a syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) where water retention leads to dilutional hyponatremia. The kidneys are concentrating urine relative to the serum, which contrasts with the expected findings in lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to weakness for the past few months. He has intermittent, mild achiness throughout his abdomen that tends to come and go. Past medical history is significant for delayed growth throughout childhood and recurrent kidney stones. The patient has also had two urinary tract infections in the past two years. On review of systems, he has no acute weight changes, polyuria, vomiting, or diarrhea. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs. He does not take any medication or supplements. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient seems underdeveloped in stature and muscle mass. Muscle strength is grossly 4/5 in all four extremities. Fingerstick blood glucose is 160 mg/dL. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in his bloodwork results?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of childhood growth restriction, recurrent kidney stones, and prior urinary tract infections presents for evaluation of weakness. Together, this constellation of symptoms is suspicious for renal tubular acidosis (likely type 1), which would cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.

There are several causes of a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA), which is defined as an anion gap of 4-12. NAGMA frequently occurs with hyperchloremia in the setting of bicarbonate loss rather than extra acid production. Renal and gastrointestinal causes are the most common, but other causes exist, such as iatrogenic causes. Hyperalimentation from parenteral nutrition and excessive 0.9% saline infusions (“normal” saline is not physiologically “normal”) are common causes in the inpatient setting. Profuse diarrhea can lead to NAGMA via bicarbonate loss. Hypoaldosteronism and the use of spironolactone have also been implicated. Finally, renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is a commonly overlooked cause of NAGMA. Younger patients are more likely to have type 1 or type 2, whereas older patients or those with chronic medical issues may have type 4 renal tubular acidosis. The urinary anion gap can help confirm this diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: This patient’s weakness, abdominal symptoms, poor growth, and recurrent kidney stones together suggests that renal tubular acidosis (likely type 1) is the cause, which leads to a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. 
❌ Metabolic alkalosis:
Incorrect: Metabolic alkalosis is often associated with excessive bicarbonate intake (e.g., milk-alkali syndrome), profound vomiting or diarrhea, diuretic use, or a hyperactive renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. This patient’s history and symptoms are more suggestive of renal tubular acidosis, which causes a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. 
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia can be seen in type 4 renal tubular acidosis due to hypoaldosteronism. This patient’s weakness, growth restriction, and recurrent kidney stones are suggestive of type 1 renal tubular acidosis which (like type 2) causes hypokalemia along with a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. 
❌ Elevated serum ketones:
Incorrect: This would be present in diabetic ketoacidosis or starvation ketosis. This patient’s clinical picture, including mild hyperglycemia, is more supportive of renal tubular acidosis (likely type 1), which would not lead to ketoacidosis or an elevated anion gap.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for several days of generalized malaise and muscle cramping. She has no significant past medical history and does not currently take any medication. Temperature is 36.2 ºC (97.2 ºF), pulse is 48/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 88/59 mm Hg. BMI is 17 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is fatigued and has evidence of muscle wasting, but she is in no acute distress. There are skin abrasions on the dorsum of the right hand, and the tongue is dry appearing. An image of her teeth is shown below. Serum potassium level is 3.0 mEq/L and bicarbonate is 31 mEq/L. Intravenous access is established, and the nutrition team is consulted due to the patient’s low BMI. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sarcopenia (muscle wasting), malaise, low BMI, and low blood pressure. She is found to have significant dental erosions, abrasions on the back of the right hand, a low potassium level, and metabolic alkalosis. This suggests that an eating disorder associated with chronic vomiting (likely bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa) causes metabolic alkalosis in this patient. A serum phosphorus level should be checked now as this patient is at high-risk for refeeding syndrome once nutrition rehabilitation is implemented. Refeeding syndrome is defined as the complications resulting from fluid and electrolyte shifts during aggressive nutritional rehabilitation of malnourished patients. Hypophosphatemia is a common complication and serum phosphorus levels should be regularly monitored and phosphorus given as needed.   

Metabolic alkalosis refers to an increased serum bicarbonate concentration. The most common causes of metabolic alkalosis are excess gastrointestinal and renal loss of acid (hydrogen ions). Patients with acid-base disturbance require a basic metabolic panel to adequately characterize the electrolyte status and should have an arterial blood gas performed to assess the pH and respiratory status (via pCO2).   

Patients should undergo an ABCDE assessment to ensure stability and look for life-threatening emergencies. Any concomitant electrolyte abnormalities should be corrected, and IV fluid resuscitation is important in patients with volume depletion. Patients with metabolic alkalosis often have volume depletion and sometimes renal dysfunction, both of which need to be corrected. Once the patient is stabilized, the diagnostic workup can be guided by history, physical exams, and basic laboratory testing.   

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain serum phosphorus level:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Start acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that promotes urinary bicarbonate excretion and can lower serum bicarbonate. While this can be useful in certain cases of chronic respiratory acidosis, this would not improve this patient’s metabolic alkalosis, which is caused by chronic vomiting. 
❌ Start furosemide:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics tend to cause hypovolemia, which will lead to increasing serum bicarbonate (i.e., “contraction alkalosis”); although, if the hypovolemia causes severe kidney injury, a metabolic acidosis could be seen. This patient is already volume depleted and has metabolic alkalosis caused by chronic vomiting for which furosemide would be inappropriate. 
❌ Obtain serum aldosterone level:
Incorrect: A serum aldosterone level is part of the workup for Cushing syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism. This patient’s low BMI, low blood pressure, dental erosions, and low potassium levels are much more suggestive of chronic vomiting. 
❌ Start midodrine:
Incorrect: Midodrine is sometimes used to treat chronic hypotension in patients on hemodialysis or acute conditions, such as hepatorenal syndrome. This patient is not symptomatic from low blood pressure and this medication does not address the underlying cause of her hypotension and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man was admitted to the intensive care unit three days ago for severe respiratory failure requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. He was found to have an exacerbation of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction and is currently undergoing diuresis. The patient has severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and uses 4 liters of supplemental oxygen chronically. His respiratory status has significantly improved, and the plan is to extubate him today. He was also found to have a partial small bowel obstruction upon admission and a nasogastric tube was placed for decompression. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 66/min, respiratory rate is 14/min and in synchrony with the ventilator, blood pressure is 110/74 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 99% on minimal ventilator settings. Current medications include acetazolamide, bumetanide, lisinopril, and metoprolol. Results from bloodwork done that morning can be seen below. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s metabolic alkalosis? 

 Laboratory Study     Result    
 Serum bicarbonate     38 mEq/L (baseline 32 mEq/L)    
 Serum blood urea nitrogen (BUN)     34 mg/dL    
 Serum creatinine     1.9 mg/dL    
 Urine chloride     18 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) was admitted for respiratory failure due to an exacerbation of heart failure and was placed on mechanical ventilation. He was also incidentally found to have a partial bowel obstruction and underwent nasogastric tube suctioning. The subsequent metabolic alkalosis with low urine chloride indicates that nasogastric suctioning is the probable cause of the metabolic alkalosis.    

For patients with metabolic alkalosis, the history and physical exam can help narrow down the differential diagnosis. Urine chloride can often help differentiate between common etiologies, particularly if the cause is not obvious, or multiple contributing factors are present, as seen in this case. A normal/high urine chloride (> 20 mEq/L), also called chloride-resistant metabolic alkalosis, indicates disorders of the kidneys or the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Causes may include diuretic use, hyperaldosteronism, Bartter syndrome, and Gitelman syndrome.   

A low urine chloride (≤ 20 mEq/L), as seen in this case, also called chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis, indicates gastrointestinal loss (prolonged vomiting or nasogastric tube suctioning, or laxative abuse), or cystic fibrosis. Adult patients presenting with metabolic alkalosis from cystic fibrosis will already carry the diagnosis. They may have a history of recurrent respiratory infections and fatty stools and will usually have wheezing on pulmonary auscultation and digital clubbing. Patients with eating disorders may have volume depletion and hypokalemia from excessive vomiting or laxative abuse.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nasogastric tube suctioning:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bumetanide:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics are an appropriate treatment for many patients with hypervolemia from an exacerbation of heart failure. However, overdiuresis can lead to metabolic alkalosis. Given that this patient’s urine chloride is low, overdiuresis is not the cause of metabolic alkalosis. 
❌ Acetazolamide:
Incorrect: This patient is likely being treated with Acetazolamide for chronic respiratory acidosis from COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease). Acetazolamide promotes urinary bicarbonate excretion and leads to the lowering of serum bicarbonate levels and metabolic acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis. 
❌ Renal insufficiency:
Incorrect: Renal insufficiency from acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease would lead to metabolic acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis. 
❌  Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril could cause acute kidney injury or, rarely, type 4 renal tubular acidosis; however, both would lead to metabolic acidosis and not metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents to the hematology clinic with complaints of progressive fatigue, early satiety, and discomfort in the left upper abdomen. She has been experiencing night sweats and unexplained weight loss over the last few months. Her past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus which are all well controlled with medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is marked splenomegaly on abdominal examination. Laboratory results are shown below. An attempt to perform a bone marrow biopsy results in the inability to aspirate bone marrow fluid despite several attempts. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on this patient’s peripheral blood smear? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     9.1 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     27 %    
 Leukocyte count     3,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     105,000 /mm3    
 JAK2 mutation     Positive
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms, splenomegaly, laboratory results (anemia, thrombocytopenia), and dry tap on bone marrow biopsy are suggestive of primary myelofibrosis. Primary myelofibrosis is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by bone marrow fibrosis and subsequent extramedullary hematopoiesis (notably in the spleen, causing splenomegaly). Myelofibrosis is associated with teardrop-shaped red blood cells or dacrocytes on the peripheral smear.       

Primary myelofibrosis is characterized by fibrosis of the bone marrow due to abnormal megakaryocytes releasing growth factors, leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and anemia. The levels of white blood cells and platelets can vary. Cell counts may initially be elevated, but typically decrease with disease progression. Extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs, resulting in the production of blood cells in the liver and spleen, and the presence of dacrocytes (teardrop-shaped red blood cells) on a peripheral smear indicative of erythrocyte deformation. Genetic mutations such as JAK2, CALR, and MPL are common, and the difficulty in aspirating bone marrow, leading to a "dry" tap, further supports the diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis.        

Patients with primary myelofibrosis and essential thrombocythemia can test positive for JAK2, CALR, or MPL. Patients with polycythemia vera will test positive for JAK2 mutation and negative for CALR and MPL. Patients with chronic myeloid leukemia have a Philadelphia Chromosome (PC) positive myeloproliferative neoplasm and will test positive for the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome).  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypersegmented neutrophils:
Incorrect: Hypersegmented neutrophils are typically associated with megaloblastic anemias, such as vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, not myelofibrosis which is the cause of anemia in this case. 
✅ Dacrocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Spherocytes:
Incorrect: Spherocytes are commonly seen in patients with hereditary spherocytosis or hemolytic anemias. Spherocytes are not typically seen in myelofibrosis.  
❌ Schistocytes:
Incorrect: Schistocytes are fragmented red blood cells often seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias, such as thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) or hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS), not typically in patients with myelofibrosis.
❌ Basophilic stippling:
Incorrect: Basophilic stippling is typically seen in conditions associated with impaired hemoglobin synthesis, such as lead poisoning or thalassemia. They are not characteristic of primary myelofibrosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath, cough, and fever over the past four days. Her condition has worsened in the last few hours. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 39.3°C (101.1°F), heart rate is 118/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 87/57 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on 4L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula. The patient is unable to speak in full sentences and is using accessory muscles to breathe. Physical examination reveals bilateral crackles. There is no jugular venous distension or lower extremity edema. A chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral opacities. Blood cultures are drawn and intravenous (IV) broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Which of the following initial ventilator settings is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with features indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), including hypoxemia, bilateral chest X-ray opacities, with no signs of volume overload. ARDS is characterized by rapid onset of severe inflammatory lung injury leading to increased pulmonary vascular permeability and alveolar damage. Patients typically present with rapid onset severe respiratory distress, often following a precipitating event such as sepsis, trauma, pneumonia, or pancreatitis. In ARDS management, the aim of mechanical ventilation is to optimize oxygenation and minimize ventilator-induced lung injury. The ideal initial ventilator settings include a low tidal volume (4-8 mL/kg), high initial FiO2 (100%), PEEP of 5 cm H2O, and respiratory rate of 12 breaths/min.         

Initial ventilation settings should start with a tidal volume of 6 mL/kg of predicted body weight, within the 4-8 mL/kg range recommended for ARDS. This strategy is employed to reduce the risk of alveolar overdistension and subsequent barotrauma. The FiO2 is initially set to 100% to counter severe hypoxemia quickly, and then it is carefully reduced based on arterial blood gas results, to prevent oxygen toxicity. Setting the Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) at 5 cm H2O helps maintain alveolar patency at the end of expiration, enhancing oxygenation without causing overdistension or barotrauma. Monitoring and maintaining the plateau pressure below 30 cm H2O is also critical to avoid overdistension of the alveoli. Additionally, a respiratory rate of 12 breaths/min is chosen to facilitate permissive hypercapnia, a tactic that allows higher CO2 levels as a trade-off for lower ventilatory pressures and volumes, thereby reducing the risk of lung injury.   

Option Analysis

✅  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     6     100     5     12    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     12   100    1020:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). A tidal volume of 12 mL/kg is significantly higher than the recommended range of 4-8 mL/kg for ARDS, risking ventilator-induced lung injury. Additionally, a high respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min can lead to alveolar overdistension and does not align with the concept of permissive hypercapnia, which is often employed in ARDS management. 
❌  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     8   60 5    20:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). An FiO2 at 60% may be insufficient for severe hypoxemia, and the initial strategy in ARDS typically starts with 100% FiO2, which is then titrated down based on arterial blood gas results. Additionally, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min may not permit permissive hypercapnia, potentially leading to overventilation. 
❌  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     44015 12    :
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). An FiO2 of 40% is likely inadequate for initial management of severe hypoxemia in ARDS, where starting with 100% and titrating down is preferred. The high PEEP of 15 cm H2O, while potentially beneficial for alveolar recruitment, can also increase the risk of barotrauma, especially in the absence of careful monitoring and adjustment. 
❌  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     6     60   10 12    :
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). An FiO2 of 60% is likely inadequate for initial management of severe hypoxemia in ARDS, where starting with 100% and titrating down is preferred.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of fevers and joint pain over the past several days. Two days ago, she developed pain in the joints that first involved the left wrist that resolved, then pain in the left elbow that resolved, and then pain in the right knee. Following this, she developed pain and swelling along her left posterior ankle and the top of her right wrist. She is sexually active with two male partners and does not use barrier protection. The patient recently went hiking in New Hampshire two weeks ago. She takes a combined oral contraceptive. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 94/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg. There is significant swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation along the dorsal aspect of the right wrist and the achilles tendon of the left ankle. There is no swelling, warmth, or tenderness of the joints. Skin examination reveals tender vesiculopustular lesions on the arms and legs. Which of the following studies is most likely to reveal the underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Serum nucleic acid amplification testing for N. gonorrhoeae

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of fevers, migratory arthralgias, asymmetric tenosynovitis, and tender vesiculopustular rash combined with a history of unprotected sexual activity strongly suggests disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI).

Fevers in adults can be caused by infections, venous thromboembolism, underlying malignancy, autoimmune conditions, and medications. The evaluation and diagnostic workup should be guided by history and physical examination, which may indicate the most likely diagnosis.

DGI is a complication of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, characterized by dermatologic manifestations, tenosynovitis, and polyarthralgias or monoarthritis. Serum nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for N. gonorrhoeae should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. NAAT is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing gonorrhea and can be used on urine samples, cervical swabs, urethral swabs, and rectal and pharyngeal swabs.       

Option Analysis

❌ Serum uric acid concentration:
Incorrect: This test is used to diagnose gout, which typically presents with monoarthritis (especially of the big toe) and not with migratory arthralgias, tenosynovitis, and skin lesions as seen in this patient. The patient's age and presentation suggests disseminated gonococcal infection and not gout. 
❌ Serum antinuclear antibodies:
Incorrect: ANA testing is used to evaluate for autoimmune diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus, which may present with joint pain and fevers. This patient has a triad of tenosynovitis, migratory arthralgias, and vesiculopustular skin rash consistent with disseminated gonococcal infection. She also has had unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. 
❌ Serum rheumatoid factor:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid factor (RF) is used to help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis, a chronic autoimmune condition that leads to symmetric polyarthritis typically of the hands and feet. It does not typically present with acute onset fever, vesiculopustular skin lesions, migratory arthralgias, and asymmetric tenosynovitis. 
❌ Serology for Borrelia burgdorferi:
Incorrect: This test is used to diagnose Lyme disease. Patients with Lyme disease may have a history of tick exposure and the characteristic erythema migrans rash. While the patient has a history of hiking in an endemic area, her clinical presentation and sexual history is more suggestive of a disseminated gonococcal infection.  
✅ Serum nucleic acid amplification testing for N. gonorrhoeae:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
